description:
I love this place! They exceeded my expectations as well as those of my friends. We arrived as a party of four on a Saturday night around 6 PM, and we were seated immediately. We got the crispy vegetable spring rolls, regular XLB, seafood gyoza, Beijing noodles, and trio of buns, all which were delicious, plus my favorites: 

- Shrimp toast: This is essentially the long Chinese donut (the one you normally eat with jook) with shrimp baked into it. The donut was crispy and the shrimp reminded me of that which you'd find in the fried shrimp ball at dim sum spots. It's drizzled with a sauce that is reminiscent of sriracha mayo. 

- Lamb dumplings: I can't decide if these dumplings or the tom yum XLB were my favorite of the night. If you love lamb, you will love these. Each fat dumpling is stuffed with ground, flavorful lamb. It comes with a sauce that is similar to soy sauce (unless it actually is). So delicious! 

- Tom yum XLB: The real winner of the XLBs is the tom yum XLB. They're a deep red/maroon color, and wow, the flavor of tom yum is definitely there. It was such a trip for me but in the best way. It was my boyfriend's and friend's favorite dish of the night. Made us wonder all the different soups you can transform into XLB!

All in all, I was super satisfied with my dinner here. Everything was delicious. It's a super trendy environment full of millennials, haha. I would definitely come back and probably order everything that I had this time. Can't wait to go back :)
author: Daisy T.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars. 

I came here right at opening and has the following:

XLB: filling wasn't as flavorful as DTF, meat was more on the chunky side. Wasn't completely filled with soup. I'd definitely say I've had better. Had to request Ginger as it didn't come standard. It was minced/grated vs cut into thin matchsticks. 

Seafood potstickers: great presentation but the skins were thin and soggy; when picking up with chopsticks the skins broke. Flavor was good and the fusion dipping sauces were spot on. 

Shrimp and pork shu mai: solid; nothing amazingly mind blowing about them. I still think Koi Palace does a better version. 

Char sui bao: delicious! Probably the best item we ordered. 

Green tea milk buns: matcha flavor wasn't very strong in the buns, the creamy milk center was delicious. 

Decent overall but for the prices I'd rather be at Koi Palace.
author: Vicky L.

description:
Finally some legit dim sum in SF. I know, crazy right? You would think the stuff would be growing in the streets here, but I'm sorry to say it's been spotty at best for decent to good dim sum.

I've been high and low and everywhere in between this town and I wrestle with the fact the stuff I can get in Colorado tastes better, get more of it and at a better price than anything I've tried in the Bay Area and going out to Richmond as well.

Moving on, this place caters more to the hip tech business crowd. No big families or aunties yelling for the next cart to come along. It's a nice modern space, slightly sterile but still comfortable. You order off a menu and dishes are brought to you quickly I might add.

Everything was great, just the pot stickers fell a little flat but it's a personal taste choice more than anything.
author: Ikaika F.

description:
Fun, high energy dumpling  spot in 
San Francisco.  Very busy, with good service and good dumplings.  They have a giant jumbo tv screen with music videos playing, but very low sound so you can enjoy your company.
The restaurant is clean, the restrooms are clean and stocked.
The menu is easy to order from, little pricey with the quantity and size of dumplings.  
Shrimp  toast  Outstanding $9.00
BBQ pork Bao Ok $6.50
Pork Gyoza Outrages $8.00
Pork XLB Very Good $8.50
Shrimp and Pork Sui Mai Fantastic $6.00
Beijing noodle Mmmm $9.50 
Trip of Buns $6.00, had to order a green tea bun to go as well.
Fun place with good food, will come back and would recommend to friends and families.
author: David E.

description:
Yum yum yummmmm! Always in the mood for dumplings and this place did not disappoint. Went here for breakfast/ brunch on Saturday. Make sure you get there before noon otherwise there will be a wait. The staff is extremely friendly and they are very attentive. They have communal tables and outdoor seating.

My favorites were the green beans, pork and shrimp sui mai, and shrimp toast! The shrimp toast was really interesting- Chinese donut with shrimp on top. Crispy and savory! The gyoza were surprisingly delicious as well- they make them the traditional way so they are connected.

They serve tea in individual servings so everyone can choose a different tea. They have a good assortment. 

The XLB are flavorful but I don't prefer the aluminum trays that it comes in. Make sure you carefully transfer the XLB to your spoon before eating.

The dumplings have good flavor but the skin was a little too thick to my liking. The plating was perfection- love the colors of the and micro greens that top the dish.

Ended with the egg yolk bun that was good but not oozing egg yolk like my favorite place! Overall, a great restaurant and I'll be coming back!
author: Natalie V.

description: Great food and a fun experience trying unique dumplings. My favorites were the chicken gyoza, pork soup dumplings and pork bao. There were three people total in our party and this was the perfect amount to share dishes. We got 7 dishes and we were very full afterwards... could've gone with one less probably. It's worth the wait!! Enjoy!
author: Sara S.

description:
My new favourite dim sum place! Everything here is great! 
If you don't want a long line - arrive before 12pm. After 12pm, you might wait up 30-45mins, but pretty decent wait for this place! 
My favourites are definitely the seafood gyozas, xiao long bao and beijing noodles. 
Service is super fast, so you never wait too long for your food! But sometimes I wish everything wouldn't come out so fast so I feel like we just gobble everything up! This is definitely a fast paced restaurant and it'll be great for brunch. 
Parking is street parking but you should be able to find parking in this area!
author: Kelly L.

description:
We found his place through yelp and wow!  Tom Yum Soup dumplings wrapped in beet skin were he surprise of the meal. Pork XLB soup dumplings served in a foil container so the soup does not leak out - brilliant.
There are tables for 2, 4 and 8 people. Looks like they have a great delivery take out business. Moms secret-recipe Lamb dumplings with Chinese 5spice, cabbage and garlic were excellent. 

We got there as soon as they opened at 11:00 and by 11:45 it was packed. 

Parking is hard to find but worth the hunt. 

We will be back!!
author: Wendy C.

description:
I'm not an expert on dumplings, but I do know what tastes good and what doesn't.

I came with my girlfriends on a Thursday night for dinner, around 7:30 and there was spattering of groups waiting outside to be seated. While it seemed like we would be waiting forever, the wait staff does a good job of getting diners in and out in a timely fashion.  Our wait time was about 20 minutes.

Here's what we ordered:

SHRIMP TOAST - so good we ordered 2 servings! It was so flavorful and the toast/donut part was light! It didn't make you feel overly full.

GAN BAN NOODLES- noodles were soft/ chewy and deifnitely fresh! The peanuts gave it a nice crunchy texture.

LOBSTER SUI MAI- Really good! Must order!

PORK XLB- What I had been waiting to try. There's nothing like it that I've tasted! Soup inside a dumpling?!  I had to get directions from my friend on how to eat it, but the red wine/sauce that it came with was good! I didn't like that it was a tad bit hard to take out of the tin, but if you did it carefully and slowly, you would have success and eat it properly! I think I could have eaten all 6 pieces myself!

CHICKEN BAO- I loved that it was pan seared. However, I think this was my least favorite dish. It was too doughy for me. 

SHRIMP HAR GOW: Nothing special about this dish either. I could get it from my local dim sum place. There wasn't much taste from the filling inside.

Overall if I were to come back, I'd just order the shrimp toast and the XLB.

Service was super fast! I felt like our waiter was dashing from table to table. And whenever we'd need something or wanted to order more food,  he was gone from our table before the last word came out of our mouths. LOL!
Guess I know why they can get people in and out of there!

Cool spot to see them actually making the dumplings, if you wanna watch them.
author: Mimie L.

description:
I was so excited about coming to a restaurant that specializes in dumplings for dinner, and it did not disappoint. We got here around 7pm on a Thursday and it was already pretty crowded.

I love how the menu is pretty much all dumplings and buns. We got the shrimp toast ($9), pork XLB ($8.50), shrimp har gow ($6.50), bbq pork buns ($6.50), and trio of dessert buns ($6). They were all really good! I especially liked the XLB which were juicy and delicately made, and the bbq pork buns, which were fatty and meaty. The dessert buns were good too, not too sweet, but a bit too heavy on the carbs for an already heavily-carb loaded meal.
author: Amy C.

description:
Dang this place is B O M B. Clean place with good service and bao's that melt in your mouth and disappear in seconds! 

Got the pork bao, bbq pork bao, garlicky green, trio, and siu mai (And also a trio to go but shhh).
the green beans were very garlicky out the ouside with a nice crunch! Super yummy and it was presented nicely too! Siu mai, though not my go to for dimsum foods had a nice skin, juicy on the inside, and big pieces of shrimp. The baos came out steaming hot (got the steamed version as opposed to the pan fried) and the dough was soft, a bit sweet, and wrapped the filling so nicely. Between the bbq and regular pork, I'd say the tangyness of the bbq beats the light hint of ginger-y bao. Both nice and juicy though!! 


There was the trio of bao with egg custard filling, the beet and taro filling, and green tea with condensed milk filling. Out of the 3 (though again, all were good) the consistency of the taro was the best. It was a bit thicker in filling and had some texture so it. It also had the faint but noticeable taste of taro, very yummy!! 

Will def be back to try the noodles and shrimp toast.
author: Linde H.

description:
The best time to eat dumplings is all the time!

A modern and fun space that serves up delicious dumplings, baos and other dishes with flair. Beautifully presented and equally delicious!

Decently sized restaurant with a fun vibe and entertaining where you can watch the kitchen staff prepare dumplings from a window- just like Din Tai Fung. Good music, neon lights, and Kpop MV play on the projector giving the place a karaoke/lounge nightlife feel.

Pork Xiao Long Bao - different from the traditionally made XLB that's served on top of napa cabbage in a steam basket, these are individually placed in aluminum cups. A bit small, but still soupy with a good morsel of minced pork mixture on the inside. Delicious with ginger, black vinegar and soy dipping sauce. An order comes with 6 dumplings.
 
Siu Mai (Shrimp & Pork) - Ground pork with shrimp encased in a wonton, fatty pork was nice and tender. Big chunks of shrimp, sweet and not fishy and the exterior of the wrapper was soft and thin. Often found Siu Mai to be rubbery and chewy at most places, but it's just right here!

Garlicky Green Beans - Sauteed green beans in garlic and garnished with edible flowers. Perfectly cooked beans with just enough bite, yummy garlic, and sesame flavor. Good veggie dish to share.

Har Gow - shrimp encased in a rice flour wrapper and steamed, nice chunks of shrimp but found the wrapper on this dumpling too tasteless and left more to be desired.

Chicken Bao (Seared) - Steamed bao filled with chicken, green onion, mushroom and ginger mixture and seared. Love the contrast of the soft, fluffy bao to the slightly crisp and roasted flavor from the searing. The chicken mixture is juicy, tender and delicious! You get 3 baos per order.

Trio of Buns - a happy ending to any meal here, a trio of sweet steamed buns. Green Tea with Milk filling, Beet and Taro filling and Egg Yolk Bun. The buns are light, fluffy and come out steaming hot. Fillings are lightly sweetened and the perfect texture, a bit gelled and custard-like. Didn't know which one I liked more, but I can't stray from a good classic ... so the Egg Yolk did me in. It wasn't the best sweet steamed buns I've had but they were good!

Service is always on point here. Food always comes out quickly and piping hot. Never had an issue waiting too long when dining here. Price is similarly on par with that of DTF. Close to the Caltrain station and easy for Lyft/Uber drop offs. Definitely a new favorite spot of mine for dumplings and baos!
author: Janet N.

description:
hmm more like 3/12... 
We got the pork xlb, tom yum xlb, the shrimp & pork siu mai, pork gyoza & the King dum. 
-The tom yum xlb and the gyoza were probably my favorite. The beet skin color is beautiful and it was flavorful w/ the addition and chili oil. The gyoza was perfectly crispy
-the King dum is beautiful and great for pics but it's difficult to eat and drinking the hot soup w a straw was just kinda weird especially since we were sharing it amongst 5. 
-Everything else was super mediocre and overpriced.
author: Khanh D.

description:
Dumpling Time was where we ended up on a Wednesday night in the Design District of the city. Now this area is usually pretty dead, especially on a week night. Well that's not quite true at Dumpling Time where there was a line of hungry patrons waiting for a seat at this place. It was about a 45 minute wait to get seated. They should invest in a digital wait list since it's such a popular spot.

Knowing this place is famous for their pork xlb, I had to give it a try. They come in a steam tray of 6 per order and do go down really quick. I mean real quick so you probably want an entire tray to yourself. We sat with a good view of the kitchen so we were able to watch the masters at work the entire time. It definitely is a skilled art that you would appreciate. The xlb is definitely delicious and I would recommend that you also order the 4 piece siu mai with it. Other clear winners were the lamb and the egg yolk bun (get that for dessert). Be sure to use the chili sauce at the table for an elevated experience. I feel like I'm having dim sum yet not quite in a dim sum environment. Know what I mean? 

For a local spot, it's way easier to get here than Din Tai Fung which is outside of my acceptable driving radius for good food. As much as I would love to make the drive down there, it's just not happening. Dumpling Time will satisfy this void and I'll be happy it's here in the city. For those that don't want to wait for a table, you can order to go. It's probably better so you can enjoy the delicious dumplings in the comfort of your own home.

Note the closing time of 9:30pm which is incredibly early. People already started clearing out at 9pm so be sure to put in your last order by then.
author: Tim G.

description:
Located pretty much over by San Francisco's Design center area at the foot of Potrero hill and where all the freeways converge, Dumpling Time offers to Xao Long Bao (XLB): i.e. those dumplings that explode with hot soup.  The wait is resonable on a Saturday at around 2pm just prior to closing.  The service is a bit hit or miss but they do get the orders right.

Also on the negative side is the tea.  It sucks here.  Why offer expensive chinese food if your tea sucks?  Makes no sense at all.  The tea looks like it's high quality as it is presented in a container where you see the leaves and it meshes with the hot water.  But that's a mirage.  I saw some kid working on the side who was simply opening up tea bags and dispersing leaves into the tea container.  That explains the bad quality.

Now to the dumplings.  Note how in the first couple of paragraphs, I was a bit negative of this place.  True, but now the positive.  Every dumpling we ordered was pretty decent.  I will add one last negative: there are two very expensive items that are too hard to pass up:  Wagyu Beef Gyoza (about $15 or so) and Lobster Shu Mai (about $17 or so).  DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY.  They both do not taste any better than the cheaper items for sale.  The Wagyu Beef Gyoza tastes pretty much like a $2 pot sticker you can order in SF Chinatown so don't pay unnecessary foodie tuition like I did.  Ground Wagyu beef tastes no different than any other ground beef.

The Lobster Shu Mai on the other hand tastes no different than shrimp shui mai so don't bother wasting your money.  You'll save $30-$40.

All that being said, I will say, the quality of the dumplings here are very good.  So good, I'd come by again if I were in the neighborhood.  The service is off most likely because of how crowded the place is..the young'ens who work here lack the attention span to be perfect.  I will say, that if the service is improved, this is easily a 5 star place (well, assuming the tea situation is improved).

The XLB's are 4.5 star quality.  Pretty darn good but not as good as Din Tai Fung in San Jose (SIngapore, Costa Mesa, Hong Kong, etc.)
author: Tony U.

description:
Solid spot for dumplings. They make them fresh and in house, similar to Din Tai fung. They're super quick here and the prices aren't too bad. 
The XLB dumplings were yummy and delicious. The soup wasn't all soaked up in the wrap and had a decent amount in each dumpling. 
I also liked the noodle dish we had, omg. I could eat two bowls of that myself.  

Parking was a bit difficult. We parked on the side and walked a bit down to the restaurant. This place isn't on the super busy part of town so no worries about traffic getting out of SF.
author: Linda C.

description:
We have been to Dumpling Time twice and it already became one of my favorite spots in the city. 

Seafood gyoza has blown my mind both times. Highly recommended. Shanghai dumplings (with vinegar sauce) are also amazing. Both are perfect. 

Beijing noodles and pork buns are also recommended. 

The venue is casual and unpretentious. Pretty comfortable and allows you just enjoy your food and company. This place can get very busy on weekends, nevertheless, worth the wait.
author: Doruk B.

description:
This restaurant seems random in location but was very packed. When we arrived we had eight parties in front of us with an hour wait time, but we got seated within 15 minutes. So don't let the wait time scare you they seem to get parties out fast and are efficient. 
Some of the tables are communal style which was fine, but it sometimes felt hard to talk because you could hear the group next to you talking. They have a big screen with music videos playing which was cool but added to the noise level.
The service was nice but for bringing out the food the kitchen was slow and inconsistent. The food came out one at a time so slow. Since I am vegetarian, this felt restricting because I would have to wait for particular dishes or my friends would eat less to wait for the meat dishes. The king dumpling also came out so late we had finished all our other plates and were full by that point.

We ordered:
- garlicky green beans
- char-siu bao
- gan ban noodles
- vegetarian dumplings
- king dum

Overall, food was really good and worth the visit. Only 4 stars because of how slow each dish was individually brought out, otherwise I would've said 5/5.
author: Kaitlyn S.

description:
I came here early on a weekday and the wait wasn't too bad for two people. It's Cal-Asian so it's a combination of different Asian flavors. 

We ordered Seafood Gyoza (spinach skin, crab, scallop, shrimp, cilantro): I  overlooked the cilantro bit on the menu so it was hard for me to enjoy this. However from what I could taste, it seemed like a solid dish.

Beijing Noodles (pork, green onion, ginger and soybean paste): I like mixing noodles together to get every single noodle coated with the yummy soybean paste. Noodles were al dente and delicious.

Pork XLB (pork belly and xiaoxing wine): To me it was a little challenging to take them from the aluminum [pans without breaking the skin, but the XLB was really flavorful and moist. 

Pan fried Char siu bao: This was my favorite - BBQ pork inside a pan fried bao is always a good thing. 

Every dish came out piping hot and the texture of the hand cut noodles was on point. Maybe next time we will have more room for the giant XLB!
author: Nette T.

description:
Dumpling craving satisfied!!!

Gahhhh even w a group of 5 people total we were so full.  The portion is decent and food is great!  Highly recommend the tom yum soup dumpling!!!  Waitress was so awesome and she definitely gave us great service!  Even passing by and we saw a dish that looks delicious she heard us say OMG what is that?  Her listening skills were tuned into us and she came back with name of the dish.  She even shared her favorites without us having to ask.  That was super helpful!  Highly recommend this place!
author: Thuy N.

description:
Surprised to find that on a Monday evening this place has a huge waitlist! We decided to do takeout and got several items:

Garlicky Green Beans: a great side, this is so yummy!
Lobster Siu Mai: so good!
Gan Ban Noodles: wasn't the most impressive and gets a bit heavy when you have a lot of it but delicious nonetheless
Vegetable Dumpling: one of the best I've had


I would definitely come here again (hopefully to sit down). If you're looking for delicious Chinese food this place is a great spot!
author: Ayumi W.

description:
Even though there wait list system is horrible and the guy who manages the door is not the fastest or makes the best decisions when it comes to getting a table for a group that's more than 2 people, this place has to get 5 stars. Their food is amazing, service is quick once you get a table and if you only order one thing (which I wouldn't understand why anyone would do that) order the pork belly dumplings - steamed. 
Definitely plan 30-60mins wait on a weekend night
author: Martin W.

description:
Dumpling Time is a modern-day dimsum place, minus the carts. The plates here are elevated versions of your favorite dimsum dishes, with beautiful presentation. Come early, or expect a wait! They allow you to put your name on the list about a half hour before opening. Also, Google still says that they open at 11:00 on Sundays but they're actually open at 10am!

We ordered a little bit of everything which was all delicious, but I really enjoyed the shrimp toast, tom yum goong XLB, siu mai, and vegetable dumpling. The flavors were all on point, and the presentation was amazing! I'd definitely recommend coming here if you love dimsum but are looking for a more modern and upscale environment with unique spins on dimsum.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Arrived ~6:30pm on a Sunday. You know you're in the right place when you see a crowd of people waiting outside a building. I waited for ~30 min for a table and considering the line ahead of me I thought it moved pretty fast!

Overall, I had a great meal and experience. I thought this was a nice and modern take on dim sum. Prices weren't extremely high but they weren't as inexpensive as other dim sum places (average price ~6-8 per dish).

I ordered the garlicky green beans ($8) which I would recommend. Not too oily which I liked. The shrimp toast ($6) was BOMB!! Fried bread with shrimp and spicy mayo... can't beat that! I also got the cilantro and cilantro har how ($8) and really enjoyed the dipping sauce they provided. We also ordered the Maine crab siu mai ($12) and I thought it was good but not worth the extra $6. I didn't really taste the truffle oil or the crab. The King Dum ($9) is more for show than for taste. I've had their other soup dumplings and highly recommend getting those. Finally, I ordered the BBQ pork buns, fried ($6.50) and these were my FAVE!!

Great food and good service. Would come back again if I was willing to wait.
author: Angelina H.

description:
A good spot for dumplings! Went on a Friday night and there was quite a bit of a wait - we waited for over an hour or so which wasn't a big deal since we weren't super hungry and walked around in the meantime. We got seated at the communal table which wasn't bad at all and enough space for what we ordered. The space is quite large and pretty cute but can get a bit loud.

We ordered the regular xia long bao, the bbq baos, and the xian dumplings. Our favorite was the bbq baos as they were sweet and the dough was great. The xia long bao was alright, but it seemed like he better option was to get the Tom yum xia long bao - which we'll be back for. The xian dumplings were also really good.

The tea selection looked great and next time I'll  make sure to order some. The service was rather quick in that once we ordered we didn't have to wait too long for our food.

Will be for sure be back!
author: Valeria S.

description:
Industrial neighborhood and then lies a contemporary dumpling restaurant for some dumpling time!

It can be packed and line up during peak hours! 

XLBs are fresh and dough well made to have it still soupy inside.  They have Tom Yum Thai flavor dough.  It's a nice twist to the delicious flavor!

Fresh garlic string beans and presentably delightful! 

Their crisp gyozas are a must to order!  Black bean noodles are slurpalicous! 

Homely and yummy entrees to comfort the hungry tummy!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Love this place, I've been about 3 times. If you can go right at 5 and you'll have no wait. The wait hasn't been too bad when I have shown up and there's a crowd. Only waited maybe 20 minutes on a Friday night so that was good. It has plenty of seating but can feel a bit packed. Be prepared to sit at communal tables.

My favorites:

Fried tofu
Tom yum xlb - unique and very flavorful
Peanut butter pork baos - pan fried

It is pricier and can cost up to $30 a person. Bring a few friends so you can try more items. Sooo good.
author: Samantha D.

description:
I'm usually skeptical of asian-fusion restaurants and prefer very authentic Chinese food, but I was very pleased with my visit to Dumpling Time! We came pretty late at around 8pm on a weeknight, and there was still quite a long line. We didn't have to wait too long, which was a plus. 

We ordered the lamb dumping, tom yum soup dumplings, seafood gyoza, and the custard bun (trio). Keep note that the soup dumplings are more of the cantonese-style, dim su xiao long bao (not the super soupy, Shanghainese style ones). Of the three savory items, my favorite was definitely the tom yum soup dumplings. The dumplings skins were interestingly colored with red beet, and the savory, sweet-and-sour flavor of tom yum soup made the dumplings a unique taste. The seafood gyozas were delicious as well, with a nice crispy crust, and the lamb dumplings were good too (if you're a fan of lamb, since some people find it to be gamey). My favorite item of the night was the trio steamed custard buns. These were SO good! The buns were fluffy, and they came with green tea, taro, and custard fillings.

All of the dumplings and buns were also colored, which was very appealing to the eye. This place gets busy, so be prepared to wait in lines! However, I would definiltey recommend a visit for a more modern take on dumplings.
author: Sandra S.

description:
CATCHING UP AND DIM.SUM

I've anticipated that moment I'd come here and stuff my face and made sure I did just that the next time I came home. I am home. Lets eat....

We arrived 15 minutes before opening and there were a few people before my party. This place is so cute! Perfect for SoMa. It IS dog friendly but furry friends must sit in the outdoor patio area (i know it's cold, don't worry there's heater lamps and they can zip up the walls). Ambiance + Service + Food were amazing!!! 

HOT TEAS.
BI LAO CHUN GREEN TEA ($3.5) - Gentle, mild sweet, fruity aroma. Presentation of my tea was absolutely beautiful served in a clear glass individual pot with full bodied fresh herbs at the bottom. The first sip was very light and definitely gentle - probably the most gentle tea I have ever had. Impressive. HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

FOODS. 
You've been warned: they don't serve rice!

GARLICY GREEN BEANS ($8) -  Perfectly sauteed garlic green beans garnished with edible baby flowers. The presentation was beautiful and inviting. The green beans weren't soggy or too crispy and the garlic flavor wasn't overpowering yet present. HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

SEAFOOD GYOZA (5pc/$10) - Spinach skin, crab, scallop, shrimp, with spiced chili butter. I do love seafood but not too much seafood where it's overkill. We ordered this because the server had recommended it and I was hesitant it was going to be to seafoody but it wasn't. The spinach skin helped break the seafood taste. I tasted shrimp and scallops the most of the three seafoods. I would prefer the skin to be a little bit more cooked and crisped but afraid doing so would look the bright green color of the wrapper. RECOMMEND.

PORK XLB (6pc/$8.50) - Pork belly, savory soup, shao-sing wine. If you know me, I am a XLB snob. Their XLB was executed perfectly!!! OMG!!! Perfect thickness of the skin (not too thick and not too thin), very soft, and fragile. The meat filling was rich in flavor and there was plenty of broth. I had a foodgasm pricking a hole and sipping it's juice and then putting it wholesomely in my mouth. Yah, get that mind out the gutter.  I wish they had steamed the dumplings not in mini cupcake wrappers and found a different method, they tend to tear easily when trying to separate them. This was my favorite item at the restaurant. HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

HAR GOW SHRIMP (4pc/$6.50) - shrimp, cream cheese, juicy pork. I thought this was going to be the typical Har Gow dumpling because it looked typical. But the cream cheese adds a little more creaminess to the filling. We were planning to order the Shrimp and Cilantro but this comes with a unique green cilantro dipping sauce. The cilantro flavor isn't strong in the dipping sauce but it adds that nice veggie/herb taste with the shrimp. HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

BEIJING NOODLES ($9.50) - Pork, green onion, ginger, soybean paste. I've had this before and there wasn't anything too special with their take on the noodles. I did notice pork sauce was rich and hearty that we didn't need too much of this. RECOMMEND.

HAPPY ENDINGS.
GREEN TEA & MILK BUN 3 pcs/$6.50 - Such a sweet treat at the end of a delicious meal. Three steamed milk buns (green, white, red) filled with flavored custard. I think my favorite one was the white one, it had a milky vanilla filling. HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

Yup, I do love this place and if I ever move back I will be a regular.

JABA APPROVED. Until the next bite....
author: Jane A.

description:
It's Yum-pling Time!! Really really glad we dropped in to eat here while in SF. Wait time was pretty much as expected, came in a little after 7pm. Waited about 30-40 minutes, but trust it was definitely worth the wait! Yelpers were right about this place, service was on point and fast. Servers were friendly and so helpful. Peak times here are definitely between 6-8pm. After 830 the crowds seem to die down. Now as for the menu most of the dumpling options are $10 and under! 

In LA, we usually go to Din Thai Fung for dim sum munchies. I guess in SF it's Dumpling Time! Now for the food we ordered a few things. 

-Shrimp & Pork Siu Mai 4pc: $6
-Shrimp & Cilantro Har Gow 4pc: $6.50 
-Pork XLB 6pc: $8.50 
-Tom Yum Goong 6pc: $9.50
-King Dum (big a$$ Dim Sum): $9
-Trio of Buns (dessert): $6 

All of em were great! All worth a try! All worthy for posts on the gram! My personal faves were the Tom Yum because the beet skin tasted good. The King Dum was amazing and huge, you use a boba straw to slurp up the soup in the dumpling! It was so good we ordered some to go. The trio buns we got to go and yes their bomb as well! Thank you Dumpling Time for living up to the hype! ( b^_^)b
author: Kevin M.

description:
I would say Five stars for the presentation but three stars for the flavor. 

We ordered king-dum, xiaolongbao, shrimp siu mai, and lamb dumplings. All the dishes were beautiful with the colorful floral decoration on top. We were very happy about the shrimp cilantro siu mai. However, the xiaolongbao and king-dum were a bit disappointing in terms of the flavor of the soup inside and the meat stuffing. There needs to be a bit more umani to add more pop to the flavor. Currently, the flavor is not as good as its presentation.
author: Lu L.

description:
Dumpling time is a pretty bustlin' spot on Division and King and seems to be popular with the Tech crowd from surrounding offices. Our table got the Xiao Long Bao, the King Dum, and the Pork Gyoza, and the food did not disappoint. What did disappoint however was the rude service at the door, and table service also felt a little bit off. Also - expect to pay SOMA prices. 

Parking is usually easy to find, definitely a plus!
author: Sebastian F.

description:
+ Fast service
+/- Dumplings - a bit salty, but tasty
+/- Pork baos - standard
- Beijing Noodles - did not taste authentic and was very salty
author: Margaret R.

description:
Feel the rhythm, feel the rhyme, get on up, it's DUMPLING TIME! Xiao Long Bao is one of my most favorite of foods and it's one item I can't get in Charleston, SC. Whenever I land in SFO I can hear the dumplings calling my name. I arrived at lunchtime so my first stop after dropping my bag at the hotel was finding an amazing meal.

There was a short wait but it was totally worth it. Plus, they make up for any time you wait with insanely quick service. The efficiency of ordering is great and they turn tables fast if you're looking for a speedy lunch. But the real excitement here is the food. As we perused the menu, we overheard a family next to us place theirs and inspired us on a couple items. 

We were mostly interested in the XLB so we ordered a couple different types. Obviously the OG and then a variant made with beets in the dough. Both were excellent but nothing beats a classic... so we doubled down and ordered another. It's kinda nice that they come in these little foil ramekins so you don't lose your soup in prep.

Make sure to indulge in more than just the soup dumplings though. We snagged an order of BBQ Pork Bao which had a perfectly fluffy outer layer and great ratio of filling inside. The flavor was excellent but another big winner was the lobster shumai with truffle oil. If I was back again tomorrow I would order all these items again... and maybe add a couple more too!
author: Scotty C.

description:
I really really loved this place. One of the best dumpling places I have ever tried and honestly better than din tai fung in my opinion. 

Food: I got the xiao long bao, king dum, pork gyoza, matcha dessert bun, and BBQ pork bun. This place has some of the best buns outer skins ever because it was cooked just right without being too soft or hard. I really loved the king dum and it was fun to drink the soup with a straw and the presentation was super pretty. The xiao long bao tasted homemade and super fresh and overall I loved everything! 

Service: great great service!! Everyone here is so nice and happy and it really makes you feel welcomed 

Ambience: on the smaller side and there is always a line but the wait isn't too long. They play kpop videos on a big screen inside and it feels kinda cramped but not deal breaking small. 

Price: personally, this is place isn't as expensive as I expected to be and well worth the money. 5-6 dishes is about $50
author: Dorothy L.

description:
Alright, so I was about 5 seconds away from burning this place to the ground. Reason being, that we had our dog with us for my boyfriend's birthday, and we ended up waiting 1.5+ hours on a Thursday night for outdoor seating, due to the host messing up the waitlist and skipping us several times by accident. Angry blackout rage was happening.

BUT THEN - he finally called our table, promptly apologized for forgetting our name on the extremely long waiting list, and gave us complimentary tea and salad of our choice. The service was extremely prompt and we got our food hella fast. Once we were seated, we were in and out within 35 minutes. The food itself was delicious and well priced.

1. Shrimp toasts - I'm not sure what I was expecting, but based off of the mixed reviews, I knew I needed to try it. This reminded me of a chewy doughnut roll, with an embedded layer of shrimp fishcake flavor, with a drizzle of a seasoned mayo. Bad description, but it was unique, tasty, although a bit heavy to share between two people (get a group).

2. Cucumber salad - this was complimentary due to the host mistake, but was refreshing. Nothing too special, but for free? I'll take the veggie hydration flavors.

3. Xiao Long Bao - As others have said, this is tasty. Hot, juicy, and plump - just the way I like my men and dumplings. Jk. Not as good as Din Tai Fung, but what is?

4. Green beans - Loved this. Crisp and well flavored, and you can feel less guilty about the shrimp toasts since this is a green vegetable. That's how diets work right?

5. Chrysanthemum tea - floral, refreshing, and light. Non-caffeinated if you're having a late night meal.

6. Pork buns - tasty! I'm usually not a fan of buns since they end up being doughy, but this was crisp on the bottom, had good meat to bun ratio, and had a flavorful porky saucy interior. There are 3 that come in one order so make sure to double it, if you have 4+ folks.

Overall, great addition to the area and looking forward to coming back!
author: Stacy K.

description:
Solid basic dim sum and dumplings! If you're feeling basic dim sum like sui mai and ha gow and also want pork buns and xlb, dumpling time has you covered! 

I surprisingly loved their ha gow which is the shrimp with cilantro dumpling. I rarely order this even at actual dim sum places but it was pretty good here and the green mustard sauce they paired it with was SOO GOOD. Tasted like a mix of cilantro, avocado, mustard and some spice I couldn't quite pin down. 

My least favorite part was the trio of buns. They were ok but nothing special. I'd much prefer the lava buns from koi palace over these. 

I'll be back. Price was was ok, as expected for sf restaurants- 6 dishes for $47. Parking is residential and not too bad.
author: Shelly W.

description:
If you have a 2nd or 3rd generation Asian American g-ma who has a thing for neon lighting and K-pop music videos..I wouldn't be too surprised if she is moonlighting as the chef at Dumpling Time. 

Even though I'm more of a traditionalist when it comes to my XLB and Sui Mai (shout out to my puo puo!), I still walked away enjoying the ambiance, the speedy service, and the overall quality of the ingredients.

I'll start with the Shrimp Toast. I thought it was a very clever way to work in the Chinese Donut. Not overly greasy and was a great way to start off the meal. The Sui Mai came out next, and the pork and shrimp all tasted very fresh and was steamed perfectly. No one likes saggy Sui Mai! We ended the meal with XLB, which checked all the boxes when it came to texture ( skin wasn't too thick and held little pockets of soup), but fell short when it came to flavor. The pork was still very tender but lacked that gingery kick that usually rounds out the taste of traditional XLB. 

I recommend Dumpling Time if you're looking for a fun, hip take on traditional dumplings, dimsum, or noodles; but feel free to pass if you're in the mood for some traditional homestyle cooking.
author: Josh H.

description:
If you've ever wished a place in Cali was in your hometown, this would be one of those places; but don't take my word for it...take Michael Bauer's. He's the San Francisco Chronicle Food Critic that named Dumpling Time 1 of 100 places to eat in this magnificent city. 

As you walk in, you'll see 2-3 people hand making their delicious dumplings, and you can't help but try and find out what's the fresh to go dumpling they're putting together, but don't worry, everything is so fresh, they're just waiting on you to order them so they can place the bamboo steamer onto their huge commercial steamer. And to manage what's on the steamer is a task I certainly wouldn't want. 

This eater seats around 80, say 60 inside and around 20 outside and from the time they open, there's a line throughout the day; talk about a home run...and the hilarious thing is that the owners who came up with this concept did it for sheer entertainment. They're definitely not new to the restaurant game as two of their highly successful concepts are just around the block: Omakase (3 Michelin Stars: 2016, 2017, 2018) and Okane, a casual Sushi/Japanese Tapas place is a really popular place. 

5/5 Siu Mai $6.00 came in nice and hot, freshly steamed and the meat was perfectly seasoned and tender. You could tell the dish was made from fresh pork, not frozen and the shrimp had a nice fresh consistency too. 

5/5 King Dum $9.00 was a Xioa Long Boa but in a 3X size, and it was served with a bubble tea straw. The soup was piping hot so you'd best leave it alone for around 5 minutes before trying to sip the delicious soup from it or you'd burn the top of your mouth. 

5/5 Pork Gyoza $8.00 were excellent; love the presentation of this dish as it comes with the skin stuck all together; really fresh tasting and I love the crunchy bottom of the gyoza too. 

5/5 Pork Boa Seared $6.00 were steamed, then seared to finish off the top and bottom; the inside was filled with seasoned pork with a hint of ginger and it was absolutely amazing. One of my favorites for the night.

5/5 Egg Yolk Bun $6.00 were part of the sweet selections or the "Happy Endings" menu; these were done perfectly with a sweet egg yolk type filling that resembles almost a egg custard tart but smoother and richer and thicker consistency. 

If you sit inside, you'll see K Pop videos of your favorite group but the music isn't really loud at all; servers are all very friendly and totally with the program...I'm just wishing I had eaten here more than once to try the many other things on the menu that look so so good. 

For those of you who live in the Bay Area, consider yourselves very lucky!
author: Ivan H.

description:
Came here for dumplings and the only thing I liked was the shrimp toast. We waited close to 1.5 hours, which sets the bar for dumplings fairly high. 

Unfortunately, we weren't very impressed with most of the items we had including XLB, king dum, noodles, happy ending trio. I did like the shrimp toast and I thought it was cool that the dumplings came with different color skin but the taste wasn't special.
author: Sophia L.

description:
It really doesn't get more Chinese than dumplings for Sunday brunch.  My friend and I decided to come here and line up before they opened (10 am) since this is still very much a trendy restaurant and it doesn't take reservations. 

We were immediately seated (everyone who was in line when they opened was seated) and the server recommended that we order 2-3 items per person.  I didn't eat breakfast that morning and was a bit ravenous so we decided to order seven items to share between the two of us - shrimp and pork siumai, shrimp hagaw, pork xiaolongbao, lamb dumpling, BBQ pork seared bun, wagyu gyoza and crispy tofu.  

The relatively standard items (siumai, hagaw, xiaolongbao, Pork bun) were OK.  The wagyu gyoza was probably not the best preparation for wagyu - it doesn't really highlight the wagyu and isn't worth the buy-up. The crispy tofu was surprisingly good - I think they used silken tofu and the texture here is amazing.  Like the wagyu, the lamb dumpling was probably not the best use of this ingredient.  Seven items were definitely more than enough to get us full. 

Overall, this was a good meal. Service was meh but the food came out quickly. The ambiance was OK and the price is relatively affordable (including tax and tip, the above meal came out to be around $40 per person).  This felt a little like din tai fung.  Not sure that it deserves the top 100 rating but it's a fun place nonetheless.
author: Andrew S.

description:
The minute I arrive in San Francisco I have just one thing on my mind: SOUP DUMPLINGS! 

Scotty C and I headed here for an early lunch. It was busy, but we didn't have to wait long at all. They take your name at the front door and then call you up when your table is ready. It was a little breezy so we asked to be inside. We were seated at a communal table. 

Our order: Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings), Tom Yum Goong (soup dumplings wrapped in a beet skin), Maine lobster Siu Mai (chives, butter, white truffle oil), and Char Siu Bao (roasted pork belly with a touch of peanut butter). It was all delicious and I would order it all again. The beet version of the soup dumplings was interesting and good. But, nothing compares to the standard good ole XLBs. So damn yummy. Afterwards, we ended up getting one more order of them. Honestly, if we didn't have a big dinner later that night we probably would've stayed there all day housing soup dumplings.

I would definitely hit this place up again. Make sure to take a peek in the front window when you walk inside. You'll see all the action as they are cranking out dumplings by hand. So cool to watch!
author: Nikki W.

description: Arrived before a Friday noon and the wait is less than 5 minutes. I ordered pork XLB, pork dumplings and garlicky green beans. Food came fast, the flavor is okay, could go a little easier on MSGs. The pretty garnish on top of pork dumplings is simply for the look. They either don't have any flavor or their flavor don't compliment what's beneath.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Easily, one of my favorite places to get dumplings! 

I was skeptical of this place at first because I find that places with a hipster feel tend to fall short. To my surprise, I enjoyed everything that we got here. 

Some recommendations--

TOM YUM GOONG 
This is an absolute must. If you're only looking to order one XLB dish, skip the regular pork XLB and get this one! 

SEAFOOD GYOZA
Mmmm, loved the tangy and spicy aioli served on the side. Gyoza was nice and lightly crisp on the outside and the filling was packed with seafood. I preferred this over the wagyu gyoza! 

Get the king dum (giant XLB), only if it's your first time here, for a picture. Otherwise, it's really not great. Dumpling wrapper was too thick. Tofu sesame squares were really good. Loved the thin and crispy batter on the outside but I probably wouldn't order it again. 

Highly recommended!
author: Annie L.

description: I was excited to try this place because every time I drive by there is always a line. Slightly disappointed. It wasn't bad but wasn't great. I've had much better. We ordered XLB, pork and seafood gyoza, siu mai, har gow, the shrimp toast and trio dessert. The seafood gyoza was the best. Shrimp toast was different, but good. The others were meh. Not really worth the price.
author: Theresa N.

description: Im gonna try out this place sounds delicious . Tomorrow im coming here with my family and were gonna eat the king dumpling,red dumpling, other dumpling and i know it will be good cause the kind lady made my day.
author: Chen C.

description:
Why is this place so popular?! I came before opening time on a Sunday and there was already a good-sized line forming. I suppose there aren't too many Asian options in the Mission Bay/Design District area. The interior is clean and modern with a huge screen showing K-Pop- not your typical Chinese restaurant haha. 

I did enjoy the tom yum XLBs- very unique and savory. Get these! The original pork XLBs were whatever- kinda had a weird taste to them and did not measure up to the XLBs I've had from authentic Chinese restaurants. Same goes for the shu mai- I would rather get them from a legit dim sum restaurant for a fraction of the price. Garlicky green beans were good enough. 

Come here if you're in Mission Bay and craving Asian food, but otherwise the good stuff is in Chinatown or Richmond!
author: Chloe Z.

description:
Cleanliness: 5
Food: 4
Quality: 3
Service: 3 

Expect to wait at least 20-25 minutes here for a party of 2 or 30 minutes for a party of 4 if you're eating here around 7pm! Wait time wasn't all that bad, but once we were seated, service was rather slow and sometimes non-existent. 

I came here as a party of four and for the table, we ordered a plethora of soup dumplings, regular dumplings, and baos. The baos were definitely my favorite, they were amazingly fluffy with a slightly sweet and airy bread and a crispy bottom. The red color of the lamb dumpling threw me off at first but don't let looks freak you out! They were delicious. Everyone's favorite seemed to be the wagyu beef dumplings though. 

Overall, a nice eating establishment with good food; it's just heavily overpriced for the amount you are given. I think Chinatown serves up dumplings that are just as good for a third of the price
author: Xuan L.

description:
This may be my new favortie dumpling place in SF. Exceptional menu and setting. Parking is not hard to find and we beat the line by arrivjng 10 minutes before it opened on a Saturday.

Quick and pleasant service.

Price is fair.

We ordered the following:

Shrimp and Chives Har Gow
Shrimp Toast (my fave! Dont skip this)
Wagyu Gyoza
Tom Yum Goong
Shrimp and Pork Siu Mai
Green Tea & Milk Bun (Carl loved this!)

Everything's unparalleled!

Definitely will coming back. 

*they have outdoor seating which is a plus!
author: Madel R.

description: The food here is pretty decent. At first, I thought the Tom Yum XLB would be too gimmicky, but it actually tasted good. Not sure if the wrapper really did anything for it, but the soup was fragrant and sour. Everything else was just OK. Everything on the menu is a bit pricy. I kind of expected for the price, everything else would be top-tier here, but the health standards are a little iffy. If you get a window seat, you'll notice a lot of flies on the window which is quite unappetizing. Bathroom floors are also extremely sticky.
author: Steven Z.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. TAKE MY MONEY.

Dumplings and veggies rock - I go here way too much.  It's walking distance and the food is delish.

My go to order is:
Green Beans
Shrimp and Cilantro Har Gaw
Pork and Shrimp Sui Mai
Pork Shanghai Dumplings
Seafood Potstickers
Egg Custard Dessert Buns

The Xian Dumplings and Noodles aren't really my jam but it's more because of personal preference.

I am constantly battling to be Duchess here so that says something!
author: J. T.

description:
It's Dumpling Time!  A nice concept of an Asian fusion on various types of dumplings.  

This joint does get really busy but the wait is not long.  It helps with the several community tables they have inside.  What also helps is the quick and fast service.  Once you place you order, you will get a check that list your order almost immediately.  Don't fret - you do not have to pay.  Just leave the check on the table.  The waiters will mark off what each item as they bring them out.  You pay after you eat.  :)

The shrimp toast was served using a Chinese donut.  If eaten immediately, the was great.  The combo of the airy donut and savory baked shrimp was delightful.  However, if eaten when the donut cooled, then it was very heavy and you can taste the oil in the donut.  The garlicky green beans were so yummy that we finished the entire bowl.  We also had the lamb dumpling.  The flavor was a bit bland for my likely; however, there was no gamey taste in the lamb.  The waygu beef gyoga was great.  Beef is not really common in dumpling so it was nice change. 
 We also had the main lobster sui mui which was decent.  To be honest, I really could not tell it was lobster.  From the dumplings, I really like the tum yum goong.  The filling was uniquely tasteful with the coconut milk.  Lastly, we had the king dum.  Understanding that the taste may not be there (which it wasn't), we ordered just to take a pic to share on Yelp.  

Overall, I highly recommend the green beans, tum yum goong and waygu beef gyoya.
author: Felisha L.

description:
(*Channels inner Sir Mix-a-Lot) I like big BUNS and I can not lie. You other cooks can't deny. That when a server walks in with some creamy hot filling...all that food, yah boy better be willing! 

For all y'all who are about to quit on this review faster than Lebron James during the NBA Finals (GO DUBS!), hold up a sec. I just need to brag about how GOOD Dumpling Time was. After having wanted to visit this little dim sum eatery for months, I finally had a chance to eat here with my girlfriend. Though the prices were on the higher-end, the quality of the service and food were truly on point! 

Unlike most dim sum joints I've been to (both big and small), Dumpling time was unique in that it offered a bunch of creative fusion items.  Though this place had your usual Hargow and Siu Mai options for example, Dumpling Time also served dishes like their King Dum (gigantic soup dumpling) - many of which I never dreamed of seeing. Plus, they even had a couple noodles dishes for those who'd want to have something other than dim sum. And staying authentic, Dumpling Time of course had many types of hot tea. 

In terms of cost, this is where Dumpling Time diverged from most "average" dim sum restaurants. Pretty much all of their dishes were priced on the high end. Expect to pay about $2-$3 more for things you can otherwise find somewhere else. Like, the Siu Mai was $6! I'd say this place was - at least cost wise - a mini version of Din Tai Fung.

My girlfriend and I ended up splurging and got the Beijing Noodles, Shrimp Toast, the Pork Xiao Long Bao (XLB), Siu Mai, and the Bun Trio. Here's what we thought of the experience:

-- PRETTY AMAZING FOOD FOR THE COST --
Though I'm more of a cheap a$$ who feels like low-cost dim sum is the way to go, I definitely thought that much of the food we ordered was worth it!

1. Beijing Noodles (7/10): Let me start with the one that I didn't think was worth the price/hype. Although I enjoyed the soft texture of the hand cut noodles and how it contrasted with the crisp scallions, I felt like it was pretty subpar. Portion size was very small and the meat/sauce lacked flavor. 

2. Shrimp Toast (9/10): SO GOOD! This was pretty much your usual Chinese donut with spicy aioli sauce and shrimp filling. Crunchy, savory, and delectable experience. Could've been much cheaper ($9!!) but would get again. 

3. Siu Mai (9/10): One of the best I've had. Although small, each piece came out smoking, juicy, and SO FLAVORFUL! This was definitely my girlfriend's favorite.

4. Xiao Long Bao (10/10): Truly on par with the ones at Din Tai Fung, Dumpling Time's XLB was AMAZING! Delicious soup, hot and juicy pork, and great vinegar dip - all ingredients of a perfect XLB.

5. Bun Trio (10/10): Not one, not two, but THREE orgasmically good buns. The standard Egg Yolk Bun was so savory and satisfying, the Beet and Taro Bun was surprisingly good, and omg the Green Tea and Milk Bun was the best thing I had at Dumpling Time.

-- HIGH QUALITY ATMOSPHERE --
Though the restaurant space was tiny, it had an amazing San Francisco vibe to it. The patio seating was so relaxing, there was a nice breeze going, and the background music added a nice punch. I just loved how the the place was in a random street too!

-- FAST, ACCOMMODATING SERVICE -- 
Loved the workers here! They were friendly, allowed us to move to a different table, AND brought out our food SO FAST! We pretty much came and left within 40 minutes.

-- CONVENIENT LOCATION --
Probably one of the best perks about Dumpling Time besides everything above was the spot itself. It literally only took us around like 15 minutes to walk here from the 4th and King Caltrain Station and so it really wasn't a detour to come here. Plus, the restaurant was very close to the freeway. 

To me, Dumpling Time is one of those places where you should eat at if you want something beyond the normal dim sum experience. As a fusion eatery, it truly blends together all the flair of the city with the scrumptiousness of traditional dim sum. Although this place is pricey, I still think it is worth a try. I give it a "Nice-su, you can take your parents here and they'll be happy" rating. If anything, come and then tell your friends you got a small taste of Din Tai Fung in the city!

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
Pros: Pretty authentic tasting dumplings.  Looks the part and tastes the part.  Favorites included the steamed lamb dumplings and the gyozas. String beans were solid as well.
Cons: too much fancy frou frou on the dumplings.  Just b/c we're in SF doesn't mean it needs microgreens and thinly sliced radishes.  Also some of the XLB skins were inconsistent and stuck to the foil.
author: Derrick C.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night and surprisingly there was no wait at all (this is my second time here and the first time I waited about 30 mins). Today we ordered shanghai noodles, pork potsticker&XLB, and some string beans.  

The shanghai noodles were good and came out super fast....not impressed by it but it's definitely worth at least one try.  The XLB here Is pretty bomb, definitely satisfies my soup dumpling craving !  Pan fried potstickers went really well with the dipping sauce, wish it was a little more crispy though. String beans, you can't go wrong with string beans.  Yum~^_^
author: Irene M.

description:
Rather than rambling off 80% of the menu, a more time efficient way to order for my table of 5 would've been to say, "We want everything on the menu *except* these three items!" 

As our order was taken quickly & the dishes came out even quicker, we didn't have to wait long to gorge ourselves on dumplings, buns, noodles, & the odd veggie here & there to round out the meal. 

I'd take bites of the Cucumber & Fresno Chili Salad throughout our meal; the refreshing acidity balanced the otherwise rich meal. Still-crisp Garlicky Green Beans were on par with others restaurants & not overly sauced. 

I liked the Cilantro & Shrimp Har Gow a little less than the Shrimp version; the twist is there is cream cheese & pork in these steamed dumplings. Shrimp Toast, a Chinese donut with minced shrimp & spicy aioli, was addictive. Steamed Chicken Bao were amongst the best tasting I've had. Crispy Sesame Tofu Squares were soft on the inside & had a five spice type seasoning. Pork XLBs were soupy enough, but I'm intrigued by the King-Dum, an XLB so large, the menu claims "you'll need a straw!" 

The items I ordered for the table but didn't try -- Seafood Gyoza w/ shrimp, scallops, & crab, BBQ Pork Bao, Main Lobster Siu Mai, & Beijing Noodles -- were all hits. 

Dessert, called "Happy Endings" (truer words were never spoken), were so sweet & delicious, I wanted an order of three all to myself! Both the Egg Yolk Bun & Green Tea & Milk Bun had ample fillings. 

Our family dim sum breakfast came out to about $145. Not cheap compared to Chinatown & Clement Street eateries, but honestly, it's less than what we usually spend at Koi Palace or Yank Sing. I can't wait til it's Dumpling Time again!
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Oh wow. What a great place. 

Don't let the wait intimidate you. A girlfriend and I came around 7 a couple saturdays ago and waited 20 minutes. They move fast! 

Friendly staff and great beer list to start. We started with spring rolls while we decided on the rest. Came out quickly and were delicious. 

We ordered the King Dum and oh my lawwwdd. Worth the 20 minute wait is all I have to say. 

Will definitely return.
author: Olivia B.

description: I recently discovered this place and it is absolutely amazing. The dumplings are the best I have ever had! They have really cool things like a giant dumpling with a straw for you to drink the soup inside. We tried an egg yolk sweet bun that felt like eating a cloud. Also great vibe and decoration. This is a must if you visit SF
author: Maria O.

description:
Really loved this spot. We showed up around 6 on a Thursday and ended up at one of the big tables without a wait. We got:

- seafood gyoza - this was probably our favorite
- Beijing noodles - good but reminded me of your standard ground beef spaghetti 
- pork xlb - really good and unique
- shrimp and pork siu mai - pretty standard 
- pork dumplings - also pretty standard 

Loved the fast service and the atmosphere inside. They have a projector playing kpop music videos!

Pretty good price point too, it was around $30 per person for a decent amount of food.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
I really wanted to try this place because their dumplings looked unique and tasty, so I tried the green seafood gyoza and the red tom yum soup dumplings. I enjoyed both of them because their respectively colored skins were packed with flavor. 

The seafood gyoza were filled with an array of seafood, but I mostly noticed the nice plump shrimp meat. And these dumplings come with chili butter for dipping, which is creamy and delicious.

The beet-stained tom yum soup dumplings were tasty, too. The beet coloring doesn't really affect the flavor and the skins aren't the thinnest, but the soup is good. They didn't really taste that much different than other soup dumplings I've had, but I still enjoyed them.

Overall, I really like the creative dumplings they serve here, and I would come back to try more.
author: Dillon L.

description:
Dumpling time is my go to dumpling place for dumpling cravings mainly coz it's close by to where I live!

It gets really busy and almost always had a wait, but the place is fairly big so you end up getting a table within ~30 minutes!

I've had their chicken and vegetarian dumplings and baos and really like that they are fresh and light. I would, however, have liked a bit more flavor in my dumplings; it's a tad bit subtle for my tastes. Their vegetarian dumplings are actually really good.

I've also had a bunch if their appetizers and they are all good. I've heard great things about their XLB's although I have personally not had them!

The Gan Ban noodles.. I didn't like.. they were too filling, but didn't have too much flavor.

Service is typical of dumpling places: quick and no-nonsense.

So maybe stick to appetizers, baos and dumplings and if you are NOT hungry get two plates per person.
author: Divya S.

description:
Okay I feel a little guilty that I like this place so much: on one hand I can get dumplings at other restaurants for much cheaper but on the other hand this place just does it well with some interesting flavors. 

My favorite dumplings are the seafood gyoza- the sauce that comes with it is really good and just works well with the shrimp in the dumpling. 

Most of the dumplings are pork-heavy but there are a handful of options for vegetarian/pescatarians though I do wish there were more.

Overall, good food at reasonable prices for sf (20-30 bucks / person including tax/tip and I usually leave feeling stuffed). There is sometimes a wait but usually not on weekday nights and they move the tables fast so the wait isn't too bad even on weekends.
author: Hyan P.

description:
what time is it? dumpling time duh!

ordered:
*seafood gyoza- soooo good i had to order another one. highly recommend it!
*xlb- ehhh nothing special. not even that juicy. i wouldn't recommend it.
*maine lobster siu mai $12- you would think that you'll be able to taste the lobster or the truffle on this thing but i couldn't so therefore i would not recommend it. 
*beijing noodles $9.50 super small in portion and also again nothing special
*shrimp toast $9- this thing is bomb dot com! this is a must order! very innovative in terms of creating a new spin on such an old school chinese donut. 
*pork bao-nothing crazy
*bbq pork bao-nothing memorable
*pork dumpling-nothing wowwser

overall, i have to say dumpling time was A okay. some dishes were better than others. my friends and i felt like the staff were rushing us to eat and leave. food came out super fast. they do get pretty busy. no reservations accepted. prices are a bit on the expensive side. i would come back for the shrimp toast and the seafood gyoza. if you are in the area, i would definitely say try them out. 

tips:
*restroom available
*cash and credit card accepted
*street parking
*indoor/outdoor seating available
*charges $1.50 pp if you eat outside dessert
author: Lisa D.

description:
Came here on a weekend and there was about a 20+ minute wait.

Service was decent. I think it's cool that you can watch the cooks assemble the dumplings near the entrance.

What was ordered:

Shrimp Toast: Yummmm! I really enjoyed their take on the Chinese donut. Prepared with shrimp and topped with a really good sauce (spicy aioli), I can definitely eat plates of these.

Beijing Noodles: Solid noodles. Good sauce, pork, and noodles. A-Ok 

King-dum: Friend who had it said it taste the same as the normal pork XLB - nothing mind blowing but still good.

Pork XLB: Isn't phenomenal and doesn't stand out to any other XLB i've had in my life - but still good. My friend commented that the soup wasn't super flavorful.

Tom Yum Goong: The star of our lunch. Super delicious, flavorful, and had me craving for more. If you pay DT a visit, I highly recommend ordering this. 

Happy Ending (Three Sum) - Egg Yolk, Beet & Taro, Green Tea & Milk Bun: If you've ever had a steamed bun (i.e. pork bun) the bun is basically the same - you get a lot of doughy bun and a small sliver of flavor/paste in the middle. The flavor is not present in the bun part but rather inside the bun. 

Overall: 7/10 It's a solid place to try if you're in the area. However, I've had better, cheaper xlbs in The Bay, LA, & NYC.
author: Ida H.

description:
Arrived early Sunday around 1045a, long line as we suspected but
went by fast. Service was about average, and food was Mediocre.

Items we ordered:

Beijing noodles-bland 
Cucumber, fresno chili salad-refreshing
Shrimp toast-flavor amazing, but kind of oily
Xiao Long Bao & Tom yum Goong-the pork was better, but cooked to perfection.
Har Gow-Simple nothing fancy
Pork belly bun-The bao was a little too much, inside was A-Ok
Pot stickers-Meh

In all aspect I felt it was over-rated, but that's just my opinion.
author: Kathy V.

description: Great dumplings! The "King Dum" with friends hand for scale. Great outside seating on the patio - heated and dog friendly!
author: A R.

description:
I couldn't believe it myself...I had the King Dum and dare I say that it may have been the best XLB I've ever had??!?

I guess technically it is a DLB (D for big ;) or "da" in Chinese). The King Dum was just so good in every way possible. I didn't expect to like it - actually just wanted it for the picture. But wow, it has not been hyped up enough! Now I really wish I had ordered the soup dumplings to compare.

Be prepared for a line, but it moved relatively quickly for me on a Sunday so don't be discouraged. Get in there and let the lights dim sum.
author: Claire W.

description:
Best steam bun ever!!! Soft fluffy clouds of joy.
All in house fresh made.  The beet wrapper pork belly coconut milk soup dumpling is pure ecstasy. Prices are amazing all across the menu. This is my current favorite restaurant in the city. I get excited just thinking of dumpling time
author: Keezer K.

description:
OK... How did I just find out about this place. I've worked in the area for the last 3.5 years and just now found out about this place. AND... It's AMAZING. 

Piece of advice: Get there early if you're going for dinner. The lines can get long but the servers and hosts do a great job keeping the flow going. FYI, theres indoor and outdoor seating and you can see the cooks in the kitchen making dumplings, super cool. :)

What you MUST try: 
- Tom Yum XLB
- Pork XLB
- King-Dum
- Shrimp Toast
- Beijing Noodles (SO TASTY!)

Other items that were just as delicious:
- Steamed Pork Buns
- Pork Gyoza
- Pork and Chicken Bao
- Sauteed and Gingered Snap Peas
- Garlicky Green Beans

Dessert:
Order the Trio of Buns so you can try all three buns. My favorite surprisingly was the green one. :) So tasty, I want another one right now.

Beverages:
If you're a tea drinker try the Bi Lao Chun Green Tea - It's light with a fruity aroma.
author: Katherine B.

description:
Food is tasty, but pricey considering the small portions. Not recommended for big groups unless you order two or three dishes of the same thing. The baos and xiaolongbaos only come with 4 or 6 pieces and the two noodle dishes are meant as a side instead of an entree. I feel like this would be a good spot for pairs or smaller parties, if you want to walk away really full and satisfied without making your wallet cry. 

Small portions aside, the food was good and service was prompt. The xiaolongbaos were juicy and flavorful. I enjoyed both the original kind and the one with beet skin. Fried tofu was good but the fried donut with shrimp was just okay. The noodles were average. There's a semi outdoor area that's heated and dog friendly.
author: Ying Z.

description: Was it the best I've ever had ? No. Everything is very standard. My bf loved the lobster siu mai. I really like the seafood gyoza. And how the pan seared it with the slurry is the most awesome thing I've seen. Great idea. The xlb was juicy and melt in your mouth but the tins remind me of the buffets you go to. Nice plating clean and nice restaurant with Kpop playing on the screen. It's probably just three stars for food. The Beijing noodles were disappointing. And I wish the chili oil was spicy. They have peanuts in it so beware allegens. Service was nice.
author: Jennifer V.

description:
Very solid dumplings. You can literally see the chefs expertly wrapping the dumplings through the window. The novel part about this restaurant is that you can get a helllla big xiao long bao, aka king dum. It is not the tastiest item on their menu, but it is exciting to take photos with a large dumpling and drink it with a tapioca straw.

My favorite things besides the dumplings are the Beijing noodles and the green beans. Their garlicky green beans are surprisingly really good!
author: Andrea T.

description:
Come on... Get outta here. This place is so dang good, I just came on a whim with the SO and just had the best comfort food known to (Asian) mankind. 

We had the shrimp toast which is like a mouthful of the best toasted crunchy bread known to man with some incredible shrimp paste on top that'll shock your taste buds. The green beans which are light and flavorful then the lobster shiu Mai which shows you who is boss. The incredibly well decorated vegetable dumplings were almost too pretty to eat and should've been in this new season of Chef's Table on Netflix. And to top it off the tofu squares (basically fried tofu) were scaldingly delicious and the crack they sprinkle on top was insane in the membrane. 

The dessert green tea buns are bursting with white gooey goodness, so good you'll forgive my description of it. 

Absolutely a pleasure to dine here and service is fast and furious- easy parking too. 

Thanks for having us, Dumpling Time!
author: David T.

description:
This is a 3.5 star rounded up to 4. Why? It's because I think this place is overhyped. The wait, the noise, and especially the price is what turned me off. 

Cons:
40 minute wait on a random weeknight.
It was so loud I could barely hear my bf across from me.
This place is so expensive for such humble foods. Maybe because I'm Chinese and this is food from my people. Come on, it's just ha gow, siu mai, and XLB. We had to take things off so we wouldn't rack up a huge bill.

Pros:
-The actual food was good. I do love how they seem to try to put a twist on the usual. But those were the extra expensive twists. 
-The service was very attentive for my visit until we decided to order the dessert. Not sure why all the food came out so fast within like 10 min and then when we ordered dessert. It was like 20 min with no one to check up or explain. It made me reconsider the dessert and we just got it to go.

We ordered:
-Siu Mai. Pretty delicious
-String beans. can't go wrong with this garlic breath
- XLB. They kept breaking which is a no no, but the meat was tender!
-Trio Bao. OMG. I want more!!!!!!! So simple but so yum.
-Pork noodle. Disappointing. Bland noodles.

Also, when they say share a table, they really mean share a table. Like a small table square table for four with two couples.! One of which was on a first date. Slightly awkward that my elbow was basically touching his elbow. Do we talk to them too? Do we sit facing each other or side by side? Wait why aren't they eating their food. Wait, I can't focus on my boyfriend because I'm so intensely listening to their first date conversations. Haha. Smart play though Dumpling Time or else people would need to wait even longer. Next time get more tables of 2 and split when needed. 


Hipster dumpling that tastes good but too pricey for such humble foods. It's like going to a hipster place at Dogpatch where they serve like $35 hamburger.  $55 hamburger with wagyu or something. I digress. Oops. At least the food is good and you won't be disappointed. Just more broke.
author: Josie W.

description: Easy, trendy, dim sum fix. It kinda has a corporate feel to it for some reason but I'll say for good dimsum there was no wait first thing Saturday morning, and it was really good. The XLB had so much soup inside I could've scalded my eye with the way it popped but I have to admit the dumpling shell isn't as thin as dintaifung for my LA friends. The hargao is plump with shrimp and comes with a cilantro dip that I thought was delicious and went well together. I like that they implemented a different twist. They make the dumplings fresh and I know because you can watch them make it behind the glass. My friend says she's never had to wait longer than 20 minutes which I think is the biggest incentive to visit for me when it comes to dimsum in sf.
author: Jane K.

description:
Very fancy dumpling place in a very gentrified, renewed area. There can be a super long wait, depending on what time etc. you get there. This is definitely not your traditional dim sum place where you go tackle the waiter or yell for more dumplings. 
The amount of stuff we had on the menu was pretty staggering- ranging from XLBs to veggie dumplings to beijing noodles. Everything was very good and tasty, though the xlbs were a little difficult to eat, and some would say it's a trick to use the little tins instead of having the dumplings on their own. Would definitely go back.
author: Samir K.

description: SO. GOOD! I found out about Dumpling Time from a post on insta right before I was heading up to SF for the weekend and am so glad I did! We went right around 1 on a Saturday and the wait was surprisingly not long at all, about 20 minutes or so for a party of 8! But I would recommend going a little later in the afternoon to avoid the rush. Service was great even with a full house and the food came out pretty quickly but in waves so the table never felt TOO jam packed. I feel like we ordered one of almost everything on the menu haha. The soup in the XLB was delicious and there was a decent amount of it. I must say that I love the aesthetic of the king dum but it wasn't very practical to eat. The flavor was still great but it's so big that I found it strange to sip soup with a straw and scoop up a bite of the dumpling. What really wowed me was the tom yum XLB! Amazing, I've always wanted to try soup dumplings made with a different type of soup. Another must order was the shrimp toast- a fried Chinese donut (it's a savory one) with shrimp and a bit of spicy mayo on top. The only items that I felt were a little lacking in flavor were the garlic green beans and the bbq pork bao which was sad because I love those dishes! Will definitely be back when I'm in town again though.
author: Adrienne V.

description:
I adore dumplings. Meat in an edible wrapper? Yes please! When Dumpling Time popped up as an office lunch option, I decided to give them a try. Our delivery order arrived via Caviar on Friday, April 13th around 12:30pm.

*Cucumber and Fresno Chili Salad ($5)
*Pork Bao: 3 pieces, Pork, green onion, and cabbage ($6)
*Pork XLB: 6 pieces, Pork belly, savory soup, and shao-sing wine ($8.50)
*Shrimp and Pork Siu Mai: 4 pieces ($6)
*Beijing Noodles: Pork, green onion, ginger, and soybean paste ($9.50)

I got the xiao long bao. They were nice and flavorful. Though I did wish they were soupier. I love a good brothy dumpling. The cucumber salad was really good. Crunchy and refreshing. The shu mai were tasty, but a little mushy. Maybe they steamed too much in the take out container during transit? The pork baos were okay. Kinda reminded me of the big chicken baos my brother loved as a kid. I didn't try the noodles, but my coworker seemed to like them.

I kind of wished they offer the giant xlb for delivery as it looks rather fun to eat. Maybe I'll stop by the actual restaurant one day to try it out.
author: Elena N.

description: Good food. Recommended by some co-workers, we tried this place for lunch on a whim.. but was a little unimpressed. The was good and tasty... just like any other good dim-sum place. If you're from the immediate area i.e. live or work, it's a good place to go, but I doubt I'll be that eager to make a special trip.
author: Orlando J.

description:
Freshly made everything, and you know it when you taste it!!
Shrimp har gow: favorite savory dish! You know it's good when 1 is already missing before the photo.
The trio for dessert: Green tea and milk being my personal fav!
author: Nora K.

description:
Unique place with a really rustic feel. They use a projector to play kpop videos in the main dining room. They have an open kitchen, so you can see them preparing the dumplings, pretty cool! 

We came on a Saturday night around 7pm, and there was a huge mass of people waiting outside. We took it as a good sign that they were busy. Put our names down, about 10 tables before us, and probably less than a 30 minute wait before we were seated. 

Between two people, we orders 4 items: the lamb dumplings, the king dumpling, the beijing noodles, and the bbq pork buns. My favorite item was the king dumpling; the soup within it had great flavor. Everything else was pretty average, nothing really blowing my mind. I would say, overall, it is a bit overpriced for the portions you get.
author: Stanley P.

description:
Took a while to get here; third time's the charm!  Can see why this place is quite popular- decent vibe and food!  Not the most amazing, best dumplings I've ever had in my life, but it's pretty good.  Came 11:30am on a Sunday and got seats 10 min after signing in.

Venue / Service: clean and bright on the inside, though it does feel cramped.  We sat nearby the kitchen and the servers were moving so quickly past each other that some glassware fell and broke. The kitchen is open so you get to see them making the dumplings which is cool to watch!  

Food: it's pretty much all about the dumplings, so be prepared to carb-load a bit!  Would probably limit the number of baos if you don't wanna get full too quickly.
-- CHICKEN BAO seared (Chicken, green onion, mushroom, ginger)(3pcs/$6) - decent amount of filling inside vs. wrapper, and it was quite tasty!  Love the green onion and ginger to brighten up the otherwise heavy filling.
