-- PORK XLB (pork belly, savory soup, shao-sing wine)(6pcs/$8.50) - hard to go wrong with XLBs but these were quite good.  The wrapper is super thin, so be careful of breaking them when you are trying to take them out of the container.  Soup was nice and light yet savory, and the pork had a nice texture.  

-- KING-DUM (1pc/$9) - pretty much is the equivalent of 6 of the smaller XLBs.  The wrapper is quite thick, unlike the regular XLBs and you have to poke a hole in it with your straw so that the filling / soup inside will cool (which took quite a while).  There's a LOT of filling so keep this in mind if you are ordering other dishes.  Overall, I think I preferred the smaller XLBs in terms of easiness to eat, but it's a fun dish to try.  

-- Three-sum dessert buns (green tea / milk, beet / taro, and egg yolk)(3pcs/$6) - our favorite was the egg yolk flavor-wise, though the beet taro combo was an interesting one.  The green-tea / milk one was slightly on the sweeter side for us, but appreciated how these had a decent amount of filling vs. the wrapper.  

All in all, this isn't the absolute best dumplings I've had, but they are higher on my list.  Would recommend for first timers with XLBs and those who want a photo op with a huge dumpling.  Otherwise, hope you have the patience of a saint given the lines this place usually has (I'd probably only wait 30 min for this)!
author: Audrey H.

description:
Dumpling Time is a real godsend in the food desert that is SOMA. The wait on a Saturday morning was not short, but once I was seated the service was efficient and friendly. Of the dishes I tried, the Tom Yum Soup dumplings were my fav. They came, still steaming, in a bright beet red color. I thought perhaps their taste wouldn't live up to their instagrammy good looks, but boy was I delighted when the flavors of the tom yum soup burst forth, hitting every spot. 

Dumpling Time is a clear winner, and I'll be back.
author: Isabella S.

description:
So good! But so far away from where I usually am in SF. :(

All the dumplings and shu mai I had here were incredible. Every time I come back, I will for sure order the shrimp and cilantro har gow, the soup dumplings, and the shrimp and pork shu mai. While the wagyu beef gyoza was good, I feel like I would have enjoyed the chicken gyoza for half the price just as much.

Dumpling Time, why do you have to be so far away? Can you expand and open a location in the Sunset? Given how busy y'all always are, I'm pretty sure y'all will do fine!
author: Charles L.

description:
Do you like dumplings? Chinese dumplings? Xialongbao? Pan-fried buns? Har gow? Japanese gyoza? Do you appreciate the wonderful texture of handpulled noodles? If you answered yes to these questions, then make your way over to Dumpling Time NOW! 

We have only gone on weekends (lunch and late dinner) and had to wait between 20 and 35 mins.. pretty typical of SF and worth the wait. This is a casual restaurant with some communal seating and some tables. Service is quick and the servers seem knowledgeable about the food. 

Let's get to the food. Here's the deets on everything we have tried here:

-Tom yum XLB: delicious take on a classic Chinese dumpling. The filling and soup have hints of lemongrass and coconut. SOOOO GOOD. Highly recommended! Don't worry about the beet skin if you're not a beet fan- it doesn't taste like beets!! The skin is not as delicate as the ones at my favorite place for XLB, but you can't have everything in life, can you? 

-chicken gyoza: the texture for gyozas here is incredible!!! There is a crispy layer on the bottom and a kinda spicy seasoning on top. The chicken and mushroom filling is amazing too. Get these!

-pork bao: perfectly pan-fried and delicious filling. Recommended, unless you already have other bready items. This+the shrimp toast+two other dumpling dishes can be a lot for two people (oops did we order all that for two people?)

-shrimp toast: this item is very popular on yelp, and rightfully so. I would say it's an absolute must if you're in a group of 3-4 so everyone can have a piece instead of multiple pieces- tends to fill you up a lot, and remember, you have many other types of delicious dumplings to try! 

Xi'an dumplings: we got the pork ones and boyfriend LOVED them. Apparently these remind him of dumplings he had in NY. If you like boiled dumplings, these are pretty legit. The thick wrapper is just not my top favorite dumpling.

Beijing noodles: much like the rest of the menu, they only have two options- pork and veggie. The pork noodles comes with minced pork over handpulled noodles and it's quite good. Pro tip (from our server): use the little bowls they give you for the noodles. It's a lot easier to eat the tiny bits of pork out of a bowl that you can pick up and put really close to your face :)
author: Debika M.

description:
I really wanted to like this place because of the pretty pictures I've seen on instagram and partly because of the hype. But tbh, it's slightly overpriced and the portions are small. Food is good but nothing special.

I was committed and I braved through the rain so I can try the food here. 
Upon arrival, I was super excited to try the food, hoping it'll be what I imagined for it to be...but reality can be disappointing or just a tad bit.

This place wasn't bad but just overly hyped for what it truly is. 

The foods that I tried were:
-Jumbo XLB: fun concept and great for IG story but in reality, once you pop in the straw then the juice leaks out from the bottom. You either have to suck fast or it'll leak. A tip is just it cool down a bit then go at it. If you attack it too fast then you'll end up with a burn mouth and tongue.
-Pork XLBS: they were good but nothing special.
-Shrimp Dumplings: One of my favorite items. 
-Bun trio(sweet): I loved the custard one. Second to that the matcha/green tea one. My least favorite was the beet and taro one - a weird combo and I personally don't care bout it.

There are so many dumpling places so this place doesn't really stand out. I don't feel like I will be back here anytime soon or even at all. It was a decent experience and I'll leave it at that.
author: Ngoc P.

description:
This was our first stop in our very long, meticulously-planned SAN FRANCISCO TRIP!! My friend and I curated an itinerary of notable SF places for a day adventure, and Dumpling Time was the perfect way to kick it off ^_^

We got here a bit early (10:40am). Plenty of metered parking around the area. We parked a few blocks away, but the walk over is pretty cool-- I'm not familiar with SF districts, but Dumpling Time is situated in something of an interior design hub, with countless hip furniture stores to peruse while we waited for them to open.

Service here is great! Our server was very kind and attentive, always checking up on us. A breezy Saturday calls for sitting outside, which was lovely with the heaters underneath the overhang.

We ordered three dishes to split. Call me crazy, but with so few veggie options in sight, I decided to give myself a break... It was weird trying meat again, but I found myself enjoying the dishes a lot! I swear I won't make any more exceptions LOL.

TOM YUM GOONG: SOOOO delicious and savory! I loved the juicy filling and the beet skin! The pictures made it look like some of the dumpling skins were inconsistent, ranging from fire truck red to, well... chicken cutlet pink... but we got lucky and ours were this perfect, vibrant shade of red! They were gorgeous and very tasty, my favorite dish of them all. 

MAINE LOBSTER SIU MAI: These took 10 minutes longer than everything else, so just a heads up if you planned on doing that ~perfect  bird's eye shot~ for the IG feed-- your other dishes might get a lil cold. Otherwise super yummy! The lobster was blissfully flavorful, surprisingly filling for such small bites. I loved the floral garnish.

KING DUM: This is the gimmick everyone comes for-- and tbh, this was my least favorite lol. It wasn't horrible but I think a bit overhyped. The boba straws are cute but impractical. The dumpling skin is too thick to pierce, so you'll be ripping it apart while the juice drains below the steamer basket slots-- you end up not drinking much of the soup at all )-: Also, we noticed that it seemed almost a little deflated when we got the order. When it's finally cut open there's very little filling, only small chunks in each corner of the dumpling. Still delicious but not worth it imo.

There's chili oil and soy sauce for dipping, but the dishes are so flavorful that you really don't need it! Overall a great modern twist on dim sum. I would love to take my Taiwanese parents here to see what they think ^_^
author: Emmeline W.

description:
This is my first time in SF and coming from Toronto where there's an abundance of great Chinese food, I had high hopes coming to SF to experience the same. However, our friends already helped us set expectations that Chinese food in SF isn't the best but that this place was not that bad.

Came on a Wed night and there was already a bit of a wait as we did not have reso. We ordered a bunch of things off the menu and though nothing stood out in terms of "OMG this is so good!", the dishes are very unique. Hipster dim sum if you would. Highlights include the giant Xia long bao (XLB) you drink from a bubble tea straw and beet colored XLB with Tom yum filling which we enjoyed. Overall it was a great experience but for the price point (~$180 for 6 ppl) and quality of dim sum, I would not be eager to come back.
author: Justina L.

description:
If a tourist asked me where they could find the best chicken bao in San Francisco, I would tell them it is the one near a bunch of warehouses in an isolated area. I happened to stumble on this place because I got lost and a lot of restaurants happened to be closed for the Memorial Day weekend. Interestingly enough, there were tons of people waiting to eat even though the surrounding area was empty. 

I decided to order 3 pieces of Chicken Bao with seared buns ($6) and 5 Chicken Gyoza pieces ($7.50). I was under the assumption that I was going to be hungry after eating both of these dishes. However, I was wrong. I felt super full and very satisfied. 

The chicken bao was warm and super crunchy on the outside. The skin was thick and soft on the inside. It was not salty at all and left me wanting some more. I loved the mushrooms and how they crunched with every bite. The chicken gyoza was oily and the inside was similar to the chicken bao. 

The chicken gyoza was really spicy somehow and I ended up drinking from the whole water pitcher!

I plan to come back. Hopefully not from getting lost!
author: Kristina M.

description:
This one was tough... Dumpling time is a case of "Does it live up to the hype?" I'm sure if you're scrolling on your explore page your eyes caught it, opened up yelp, bookmarked it and finally got around to trying it. Awesome we're on the same page now.

When you arrive you put your name on a list and they call you when it's your turn. I got there around 830pm and with a good amount of people, surprisedly this wait was quick(around 15 minutes)

As for the Food
* Maine Lobster/Sui Mai $12 - It was good, not great. I don't think I would order it again though
* Shrimp Toast $8 - Best thing here! Def memorable and unique. I've never had anything like this before.
* Har Gow $6.5 - Most disappointing item of the night, quality was okay but the shops in outter Richmond/inner sunset taste far more superior and for half the price. 
* Beijing Noodles $9.5 - Quality noodles and you obviously taste how fresh it is. The downside is that lacks flavor, it was missing a little something to really elevate it. 
* Hot Tea Options - They bring your tea in a steeper, that's definitely a win

I didn't try any of the Baos because my friends who went prior recommended that I don't, and that's what are people usually raving about. 

The service here was A1, food comes out in a flash and the servers are quick to respond. 

As for parking it's relatively easy in my option, lots of street parking in the area.

Overall if you're coming here for dim sum, maybe pass? Looks are deceiving and overpriced if that's what you're looking for. I would say it's more 3.5 though, it's just a little pricey.

But Dumpling Time doesn't live up to the hype for me
author: Arron E.

description:
Arrived there around 2 pm, but still had to wait in line for about 30 minutes before getting seated.
You will pretty like this place if you go there with the mindset that you will have to wait a while before your first bite.

1) Celery, Yuba, Peanut Salad (3.5/5): Nice fresh and simple appetizer. I would probably always order one of those since they serve them almost immediately, and after a long wait in line, you can't wait to put something in your mouth!

2) Shrimp Toast (2.5/5): Don't recommend. It quickly fills your stomach without leaving that happiness that food should give you.

3) Pork Xiao Long Bao (4.5/5): For me, the Star of this place! We always order 2 of those and easily finish them. Just be careful, don't get burned ;)

4) Bejing Noodles (3.5/5): They taste pretty nice, but I felt like they were not quite salty. Add some soy sauce and enjoy them better!

5) Three-Sum (3.5/4): I really wish they have lava egg yolk bunn instead of custard ones, but hey, you cannot have everything. Anyway, they taste nice, it is basically the only dessert, so it became a kind of must order for someone like me that want to finish a meal with something sweet.

Overall Rating (4/5): 
Not sure why, but it always leaves me a nice feeling to eat here. The food is nice, the price reasonable and the ambiance very relaxing. If you are looking for a nice dim sum place in SF that will not rip you off, you can never go wrong with Dumpling Time!
author: Manuel T.

description:
This is our favorite neighborhood dim sum spot.  It's definitely not your traditional HK dim sum place, but in a great way.  It's Asian fusion dim sum, done right with restraint.  Come early right when they open or come late.  Anytime in between is at least 1.5 hour wait.

Our favorites are the shrimp toast, shrimp & cilantro har gow, seafood gyoza, char-siu bao (seared) and the Gan Ban noodles.  The shrimp toast is a remake of a traditional classic which was shrimp paste with white bread, battered and fried.  This version on the Chinese fried donut elevates it and adds a very crunchy element that pairs well with the shrimp paste.  The shrimp & cilantro har gow comes with the best cilantro dipping sauce.  It accentuates the taste of the cilantro in the dumpling without being having a too "green" taste.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
FINALLY!  We were able to try this place! We came here pretty late for a Sunday evening and there was still a lot of people waiting outside! Parking is scarce on the streets and near many warehouses. It was kinda creepy getting back to our car. 

The restaurant was clean, modern, pretty decent size and good for large groups. There is inside and outdoor patio seating. Their two clean bathrooms are all gender types so that was good. I would have never thought this restaurant would be in this location though.

We ordered:
*They ran out of cucumber salad when we got there about 7:30p.
** Make sure to mix the two sauces on the table and dip the Dim sum. I liked that better than what they give out for the gyoza and lamb dumplings.
- Bunny Nara Sparkling Sake $18 - @7% I would think it was  little strong. It had a weird taste with sweet but still good enough
- Garlicky green beans - was good
- Steamed pork bao - the bread was super fluffy and pork was tasty. This was the best I have had!
- fried pork gyoza - very soft shell and tasty pork. This tasted freshly done.
- Steamed lamb dumplings - was tasty but shell was kinda thick and lamb was gamey. Won't order that again.
- Shrimp & pork siu mai - very good; soft wrapper and pork was flavorful 
- King Dum - their pork soup dumplings in king size! WOW! I actually thought this would be bigger from the news article and Yelp pictures but it's a decent size. Drinking the soup before opening the wrapper was an experience just to try it!  Soup was very good. The inside pork was delicious and fresh! The wrapper was a little thick but once you open it up, it blended well.

I would give this place a good solid 4 star?  Loved watching the chefs making the dumplings. You can tell what was made fresh vs frozen or a little old. Prices are decent, food and good service. Make sure to get the king-dum soup dumpling. Great for selfies!!  Haha [65/100]
author: Edna G.

description:
Come early with at least 3-4 people and be prepared to wait a little during peak times.

Service - Really efficient.

Wait Time - Came with a party of 3 on a Sunday around 10:45am and there was no wait. The place was filled  by 11:30am and by noon there was a significant wait. Came with a party of 2 around 7pm on a Friday night and waited about 20-25 minutes. 

Food - LOVED the seafood gyoza and green tea and milk buns. Would probably pass on the XLB, especially since everything else is so good. The XLB was okay but nothing special. Came in little cupcake tins with red vinegar (as opposed to the brown vinegar with ginger). 

Drinks - Limited selection of beer, wine and sake. 

Cost - A little pricey if just two people (with drinks came out to $100+) but not too bad if you have a ton of people to share stuff with (with no drinks, came out to $20-$25 per person).

Waiting area is all outside and they also have an outdoor enclosed patio with space heaters.
author: Sarina Y.

description:
When in SF definitely need to stop by Chinatown and surrounding areas to try out asian food. 

We found this place on yelp and I can say their dumplings are very fresh not frozen which is a plus! 

We tried the Tom Yum Goong. It did have a hint of Tom yum but not much but I'm not complaining since the inside was very fresh. Only part I didn't enjoy was trying to get the dumpling out of the aluminum foil tray. 

The King Dum dumpling is one big dumpling. Be careful with all dumplings since the filling is very hot with juices especially the King Dum.I was surprised it tasted very good for being so big since I tried one in NYC and that one was over hyped. 

Beijing noodles was a fail though. Fresh noodles with no flavor. Too bland for my taste. 

Decor was nice 

Staff very attentive. 

We came at lunch time and was seated very quickly. 

Definitely will come back.
author: Thomas N.

description:
This place has authentic Chinese classics done well, and their innovations are a lovely twist on the traditional foods too! The servers all spoke English, however there were bilingual ones that spoke mandarin/canto too which makes it more inclusive! 

Personal favs:
- beet & shrimp xiaolongbao, which was a delicious twist on a classic also the colour was super cool!
- tea & milk buns, which were amazing
- lamb dumplings, you'll only really like them if you like lamb
- gyoza, had a delightful crunch on the bottom and a nice&different spice than traditional gyoza

Good:
- the big xiaolongbao was definitely cool esp with the straws and everything, but it wasn't nearly as good as the small one. It lacked more in flavour in comparison, but it was still really good.
- regular baozi were fine, not really anything new but a classic done well!

Tip: line is really long and there's no reservations so be prepared to wait! Also there's a sign in sheet which some people missed and they had to wait extra, so be aware!

Overall: it was a strong taste of traditional & innovative food that was definitely worth the crazy long wait!
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
You know you're old when you no longer understand the slang the youngins are using. Like when people said "bougie" I had no idea if it was a compliment or an insult, "S'CUEEE ME, WHAT YOU SAY ABOUT MY MAMA..?!" Finally learned the meaning of it and Dumpling Time put the bougie in dim sum. 

.::Dim Sum Lights Up In Hurr::.
Shrimp toast ($8): chinese donuts meshed with minced shrimp and spicy aoli. An interesting dish I havent really had at other places but to break it down it's cha leung (chinese donuts) with creamy shrimp paste. A bit oily if you're not used to it.

Char-siu bao ($6.50): 3pcs. char-siu roasted pork belly with PEANUT BUTTER? Sounds weird, but somehow it worked out like a math equation you've been trying to solve for a long time. The peanut butter added an interesting twist to a plain bun. 

Tom Yum Goong ($9.50): 6 pcs. XLB (xiao long bao) wrapped in beet skin. The inside consists of pork belly, shrimp, and coconut milk. Probably one of my favorite dish. Super unique taste.

King Dum ($9): super size XLB (Xiao Long Bao), puts the XL in XLB. The skin was a little too thick for me but makes sense to hold the soup inside. Comes with a straw to suck up the soup. 

Maine Lobster Siu Mai ($12): 4pcs. Chives, butter, white truffle oil. while tender I didn't taste any white truffle oil. 

Beijing Noodles ($9.50): hand cut noodles, recipe from the owner who is from Xi'An. Made with pork, green onion, ginger, and soybean paste. Pretty tasty but wish it had more flavors to it. 

.:: Service/Parking/Atmosphere::.
For a party of 3 we waited around 15-20 minutes on a Sunday night. There was a nice outdoor waiting area with heaters. The waiter was very attentive and thorough with the menu explanation being it was our first time. 
Parking was easy on a Sunday night, I found parking at the lot right in front of Dumpling Time. 
Atmosphere was super hipster. There was a projection on the wall of Kpop videos. The tables were all wood. Cute plant decors all over. Wall design was unique and clean cut.
author: Chena N.

description:
On the knowledge that the GF was craving for Xiao Long Bao (or soup dumplings), I looked up a place and decided that this was walking distance from where we were. We decided to take a little longer route as it took 30 minutes, but hey, it was nice to be able to walk somewhere and get some soup dumplings.

Dumpling Time had a unique location as it took a second to figure out where it was. I thought it was pretty hidden and well I'm happy that I found it and tried the place out. I mean, a restaurant that solely cooks xiao long bao... how could it go wrong? We could've gone other places, but Yelp steered me right, and it was more convenient. 

I ordered the black bean pork, xiao long bao, and some bigger char siu bao. It was all great, there wasn't really anything bad that I could really say about this place. The service was great, and I got what I searched out for. I would definitely recommend this place. This place is definitely hits the right spots for that specific cravings for soup dumplings.
author: Bruce K.

description: After hearing the hype of Dumpling Time, my husband and I finally conjured up the courage to wait for lunch on a Saturday. The notorious wait wasn't too bad, maybe 20-ish minutes. After having perused the menu while waiting, we went with the chicken bao, XLB, and pork gyoza. Of the three dishes, the XLB was the best, followed by the pork gyoza. I would definitely second the recommendation of coming here with a group of people. With just the two of us, it felt like we ate enough but didn't get to try much. I would definitely come back here and try some of the other dumpling options!
author: Lisa I.

description:
Excellent service and excellent dumplings! I finally got a chance to try SF's latest and greatest dumpling scene, where traditional and unique spins are added to classical Chinese dumplings, noodles, dim sum, and appetizers. All the dishes are served fresh with great presentation.

Some of the more traditional items include the pork xiao long bao (6pcs for $8.50), garlicky green beans ($8), and pork baos (3 pcs for $6). These were all very delicious and great orders. 

Some of the more unique, yet also delicious, items include the Tom Yum Goong xiao long bao (6pcs for $9.50) (I love the red color of these dumplings and you do taste the tom yum flavor), the Maine lobster siu mai (4 pcs for $12) (this comes with chives, butter, and white truffle oil, it's really tender and scrumptious!), and the shrimp toast ($8) (Chinese donut with shrimp and spicy aioli). 

Don't skip dessert - I tried both the Egg Yolk Bun and the Green Tea & Milk Bun (3 pcs for $6) and they were both so soft and exemplary. My favorite of the two was definitely the egg yolk bun so if you are only getting one, go for the egg yolk. They also offer a Beet & Taro Bun, which I did not try. 

In addition to all the food, I really loved their tea. They offer a selection a high-quality tea, each served in an individual pot ($2.95). I tried the Chrysanthemum Buds, which was VERY flavorful and floral. I also ordered the Tie Guan Yin Oolong Tea, which had a softer flavor, but still very good. 

The staff was very friendly and provided excellent service for our table. Our waitress, (I think her name was Anna), was extremely helpful and courteous. All of the staff did an excellent job to make our dining experience enjoyable.

With such good food, great staff, and clean, modern décor, Dumpling Time is sure to be a destination dumpling spot in San Francisco. They have plenty of indoor and outdoor seating, but I would recommend going early as there could be a good wait for a table.
author: Jean S.

description:
Quick and attentive service but the food itself was alright.

Every single Xiao Long Bao that I had fell apart by the time I lifted it out of its container (which to me seems like they recognize that the dumplings cannot hold up without having a teeny vehicle). It was definitely a struggle to eat. The vinegar that it came with was also alright -- nothing special. I've had great soup dumplings before that do not fall apart at Din Tai Fung and I although I can tell Dumpling Time is trying, it just falls short.

My friend and I had the beef noodles which were also okay. The meat was definitely delicious but there was not much sauce in the dish so the noodles were plain and lacked in flavor. The shu mai was also okay. Not too sure where all the craze is coming from.

Prices were also pretty high given the quantity of food. Ambiance is nice though, casual and aesthetically pleasing. Overall, a decent experience.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Awesome little dumpling joint in the SOMA/ "design district" area. They have a bunch of different options and everything was basically chinese with a little twist of hipster/modern cooking. 

I loved the food and just had to take one star off for the high prices and sometimes slow service.

Definitely somewhere I'd take a nice date or my family/friends when they were visiting, but not somewhere that I'll head over on a regular.

I think the logo and all the neon signs in there are super fun and awesome!
author: Andrew T.

description:
It was our first time here! Got in around 8:30pm didn't wait long for a Saturday night. Our server, Marcelle has a great personality and was very attentive! We ordered the Shrimp donut that was highly recommended in previous reviews. It was AMAZING! We also ordered the King Dum and it was delicious too! For dessert we decided to try the trio of boa buns! They were all yummy but our fave was the egg yolk bao! 
We will definitely be back! Great service and delicious eats!
author: Janelle C.

description:
MMMM! Did someone say dumplings?

Whenever the beau and I spend the weekend in the city, we always crave Asian food, especially after a night of drinking. And honestly, I don't dare to do brunches on Sunday because I am too impatient to wait 1+ hour for eggs and toast. So I was skimming through Yelp and totally saw that I had Dumpling Time booked marked so we decided to go here. We were worried about the wait time but somehow we lucked out and got seated right away.

Here is what we ordered and it's rating:

Pork Gyoza: 2/5 - Nothing special
Char-Siu Bao (Seared): 3/5 - Loved that the bottom was seared but the char-siu itself was very bland.
Garlicky Green Beans: 4/5 Tasty - garlicky and full of flavor
Pork XLB: 4/5 - Juicy and porky
Tom Yum XLB: 5/5 - MY FAVORITE! You can totally taste the lemon grass! MMM!
King Dum: 3/5 - Pretty but this one lacks a lot of flavor and was not as juicy as the little XLB.
Pork and Shrimp Siu Mai: 3/5 - Just your average siu mai, no complaints here.

Honestly, this place is more of a 3.5 star for me but service was tentative and friendly so I round it up the 4 stars. I was a little skeptical about the pork and tom yum XLB because they were placed in those little tins since they are normally overcook. But not these, their XLB was super juicy and the wrapping was actually thin! So high-five to them for getting that technique down! As for rest of the dishes, they were average. I think next time, I would just order 3 of the tom yum XLB + a plate of the green beans for myself and call it a day!
author: Judy V.

description:
I came here wanting to get the king xiao long bao but they ran out :( But people have said the skin was thick so I guess it's okay that I didn't get to try it. Everything was just as good as it looked! I really liked the shrimp toast and seared bbq pork bun. The dessert milk bun was also good and not overwhelmingly sweet, which I liked.

There is a small parking lot and street parking. We went on a weekend so the long wait was expected, but so worth it! It's a bit more pricey than your usual dim sum restaurants.
author: Kim N.

description:
Pricey dumpling restaurant with outdoor and indoor seating. Tight quarters. Long wait, and crowded but I enjoyed everything I ordered. It tasted fresh and was full of flavor. (Besides the beet & taro bun, it had very faint flavor)

Recommend the shrimp toast, char sui bao and seafood gyoza.

Didn't notice until the end that they had hot oil!

The waitress was nice, but after we ordered she was gone. A bunch of other servers comes and delivers your food to your table. We missed an order, but told her at the end and she was very nice about it and took it off the bill.

They serve sake and beer and has very little selection of non-alcoholic drinks.

Parking on side of restaurant on the streets. Sketchy looking at night, dim lights.
author: Teena N.

description: From a vegetarian perspective there are dishes here and there are vegetarian dumplings but they are strictly ok. This place is fine if you are in the area and want to go for lunch but I wouldn't recommend coming here out of your way.
author: Ruchi M.

description: The food is overrated and overpriced at best. XLB is okay but cannot compare to NYC, the ribs are way too fatty and sweet for my taste. And I suspect there's a lot of MSG in it as I was very thirsty after the meal. HarGow may be the only saving grace for this place. Also, the front of the house is so slow at getting people seated. Inefficiency at its best.
author: Grace C.

description:
Great authentic food. Limited menu, but I like that - it means they do a few things and they do them right! Definitely the place to come for the bao and the noodles.

THE WAIT: None at 6pm on a Tuesday! We sat in the "outside" area where dogs are allowed. It's actually covered and is pretty much like sitting inside - even though it was a chilly SF night, the heat lamps were so intense I got hot and took off my jacket!

THE SERVICE: Great, friendly, timely.

THE COST: $42.75 before tips for two. Great quality & affordable!

MUST-HAVES: Seared pork bao, Beijing noodles. If you love XLB, get the Tom Yum Goong. 

QUICK BITES
* Cucumber, Fresno Chili Salad ($5) - 4 stars
Though simple, they have the right combo of flavors and a perfect crunch to the cucumbers!

VEGGIES
* Garlicky Green Beans ($8) - 4.5 stars
Tons of garlic flavor which I love, and excellent crisp! I was also craving this and it totally hit me in the right spot.

BAO
* Seared Pork Bao (3 pc $6) - 4.5 stars
Perfect sear, great flavor in the filling!

XIAO LONG BAO
* Tom Yum Goong (wrapped in beet skin, 6 pc $9.50) - 4 stars
No complaints, as good as any XLB I've had! The tin cup makes it extra easy logistically to eat with the soup. 

NOODLES
* Beijing Noodles ($9.50) - 4.5 stars
Perfect amount of sauce & meat, nice & soft/fresh noodles!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Such a wonderful dining experience here! Staff was super friendly & helpful. The dumplings were delicious!!! Cute and fun atmosphere. I highly recommend. I wanted to go back a second time in the week I was in SF. 

Dear dumpling house, 
pls open in orange county. kthxbye. 
i love you.
author: Rona M.

description: I was skeptical that a restaurant this clean and cute would have good xiaolongbao (XLB). I was happy that my fears were put to rest and my tummy satisfied! I tried the classic XLB, bbq pork buns, lamb dumplings and dessert buns that came in three different flavors - egg custard, green tea, and taro. The egg custard filling was more popular with my group. They did a great job nailing both the traditional and more unique dumplings / bao. I only wish I tried the XLB in the beet wrappers! Too cute!
author: Alice L.

description:
Very good dumplings - not world's bet but price to quality ratio is up there. Stick with the classics in general and you won't be disappointed. 

Recommend: beet skinned XLB (does not taste like beet, for the record) and actually the spring rolls were rockin, too. 

Bbq pork bun had their nice peanut butter undertone and was puffy (we had steamed).

Skip the lamb xi'an dumpling- not as luscious as I had foreseen in my head.  

No dessert for us this time and just water as we had a long day of jammin around the city, but the total was $30 and we (2) were comfortably full without being pants-stretching full. 

Recommend if you're in this part of town.
author: Nicole C.

description:
I was worried that this place would be gimmicky but I was wrong - everything we ordered was delicious, and actually quite affordable! People always go on and on about Din Tai Fung, but honestly I think this place is leagues better. 

We ordered almost everything on the menu but the stand outs for me were the gyozas and the tom yum xiao long bao. All of the dumplings were juicy, and delicious. 
The vegetarian xian dumplings were surprisingly good (and beautifully plated). 
All of us got tea as well, and I loved that they came in individual pots. 

If you're coming with a party bigger than 2, be warned. The wait is LONG if you don't come early!
author: Alexandra L.

description:
Very fun, hip, modern and entertaining dumpling restaurant! It's located in the Mission Bay on 9th and Brannan St. around there which is a great location! Tons of parking options and even walking distances! 

I thought the restaurant was amazing. The space inside is modern and cool and super clean bathrooms, which is always a plus!! One of the walls is painted with cool linear drawings and together they have a harmonious feel and not at all distracting. Second wall plays a projector of Korean music videos which is very fun and interactive idea! 

The food! Oh, the food! Amazing dumplings! They provide many options from chicken to pork to seafood and veggies! I tried few different veggies and seafood and hands down the best dumplings in San Francisco by far! The flavors and combinations of colors and presentation design are so simple but go so well together! Hey have great choices of amazing tea and alcohol to pare with your dumplings order! Very fast paste restaurant and service unbelievably friendly and accommodating. If you have egg allergies or other allergies do ask your server. Not all dumplings have eggs in them.
author: Galya T.

description:
What time is it? 

Dumpling time!!! 

:)

Yes, such yumminess! Omg.. so I came here on a Saturday night with my bestie for dinner. We arrived when they were just opened up shortly. I think we got seated within 10-15 mins. We chose a table outside because the hostess said the indoor seating was communal. Outside was fine since they do have heat lamps in the tented seating area. We got the King Dum, regular XLB, Tom Yung Goong XLB, and Beiing Noodles. Everything was delicious, and we loved it. Service was attentive and friendly. 

I would definitely return again. :)
author: Amy C.

description:
Great place for xiao long baos (soup dumplings)! And an added plus, they have an outdoor patio with heaters!! 

We had the following dishes:
- xiao long bao pork - this was my favorite dish here. Warm, soupy filled dumpling. Very flavorful!
- beijing noodles - hand cut noodles with minced pork. Very simple in flavor, not too much sauce which is great but a bit dry. 
- snap peas - tossed with ginger. If you like ginger, this dish is a solid veggie option. 
- shrimp toast - this is equivalent to what is known as a chinese donut with a bit of shrimp embedded inside. A bit dry in my opinion, I wish it was more moist. Also some other restaurants make this dish with rice paper and soy sauce around the donut - I think if this restaurant attempted that dish, they would do it well!
author: Claire W.

description:
Solid option for Chinese food in this area.  A few recommendations: 
- Tom Yum Goong XLB 
- Beijing noodles 
- Sweet dessert buns. All the flavors are fantastic but my favorite is the egg yolk bun while my husband prefers the green tea and milk version.
author: Charlene C.

description: Wow!! My friends had been trying to get me to stop by here every time I go to San Francisco, and I just kept saying no. I was happy with my dumplings in China town. I can't believe I have been missing out for so long. Service os fast, dumplings are all unbelievably delicious!! I cannot wait to go back again!
author: Erica C.

description:
Got here right at opening and was seated immediately, so that's how you avoid the wait I guess! Normally I try to avoid rating restaurants unless I've been multiple times so take my excellent review understanding it's a one time affair. 

We were starving after a Giants game and decided to walk here with a couple of friends. The food was hot, fresh, and unique. It's the perfect format of dining in my opinion - everyone gets to try a little bit of everything and the food just keeps coming and coming! (Well, you have to order it of course). 

Little touches with the decor and serving style make it a trendy but affordable option. I liked getting my own tea kettle of my choice of tea that I didn't have to share as well. 

Overall, had a nice experience and would be back if I found myself in this area again!
author: Rachel A.

description:
Recently went here on a crowded Saturday in a group of four. Overall, I think it's a great option for dim sum. The menu is quite varied and the kitchen-to-table time is quite quick. The noise level is quite high in the main dinning area; the alternate seating area of the enclosed patio is better. 
I think the owners borrowed (copy) a lot of the design concept and menu from the high end, and, global, Taiwanese-based Din Tai Fung.  But, service was fine and we never felt rushed. 

For ordering, I think ordering a few dishes to start is a good move. Then, follow a pace with additional orders over time. That way, food stays hot and the table doesn't get crowded with dishes and baskets. 
I suggest coming during non-peak times. The waiting area is outside in the front parking lot.
author: Leo W.

description:
Had this bookmarked forever and finally got a chance to visit! 

Good food. A little overhyped. Pricey for the portion size. Chill atmosphere. 

Came here during a Friday afternoon after the lunch rush and right before their mid-day close.  We were seated right away. They have a mixture of indoor and outdoor seating but we chose the inside. I like that they have community tables.  This isn't a common thing in the states but pretty common overseas. 

We ordered the pork gyoza, mamas secret recipe dumplings, XLB, sauteed garlic green beans, and shui mai. It might seem like a lot of food, but between 2 ppl we finished everything and weren't stuffed. 

The pork gyoza was good. It had a nice crispy bottom that was covered in a spicy powder (the same kind used for ramen). Not sure I would order it again. 

The mamas secret dumplings come in veggie or pork. We chose the pork. These were good. The filling was juicy and flavorful. Only thing we didn't understand was the stuff they threw on top. They had pea shoots, grape tomatoes, and sliced radishes as a garnishing. All of it was raw and didn't have any taste.  It was pretty but didn't add anything to it. 

XLB, it's their signature dish. It was average. The skin could have been thinner. I did like that all of them were really juicy. 

Garlic green beans was flavorful and fresh. It didn't come out overcooked or wilted. Only complaint is the price. The serving size of this dish is on the small side and the price tag was $8. 

This was my favorite dish! The shui mai was DELICIOUS. It was made just like my favorite place in Hong Kong. Same flavor and consistency. While I rave about this, again only complaint is the price. Is 4 tiny pieces worth $6? A specialty dim sum place charges way less even in the city. 

Overall would come back if in the area, but prob not to often bc of prices and parking. Also just for reference, lunch for 2 ppl including tip came to about $50. Pretty pricey.
author: Junella T.

description:
I took my Chinese boyfriend's parents and his uncle here for lunch and boy was I hoping it would live up to the hype. I wanted them to try food that was somewhat similar taste to what they're familiar with but with a modern fusion twist. Dumpling Time fulfilled this! 

VIBE: trendy Asian fusion, definitely not a typical Chinese dim sum joint 

SERVICE: the hostess seemed kinda snooty and she did not like it when me and my man stood near the front watching the workers make dumplings. Isn't that what the large display windows are for though? 
Also, they automatically charged me 18% tip for our party of "6" even though there was only 5 of us.... i didn't want to make a fuss over the bill though after my card was already swiped for this amount. 

FOOD: I think I ordered over half the menu!

Garlicky green beans- must have veggie for the table 

Crispy sesame tofu squares- the texture of these were so soft and lovely. Exceeded my expectations 

Seafood gyoza- expensive (5/$10!) BUT SO WORTH IT. So flavorful in every bite! Definitely one of my favorites here 

Shrimp toast- wish we ordered two of these, it was that good

Beijing noodles- typical minced pork noodle dish, didn't taste too special to me

Gan Ban noodles- supposedly less popular than the Beijing noodles here but THIS NOODLE DISH WAS BOMB!! I really wonder what the sauce is made of in this dish

Har Gow- a little too sticky texture . Not that exciting 

Pork XLB- probably one of the better XLBs I've tried 

Tom Yum Goong- THIS BLEW THE PORK XLB out of the water. I REALLY liked the flavor of these with the tom yum soup inside . Bursting with flavor 

King Dum- honestly this was ordered for the picture taking. It's quite large and the flavor isn't as good as it cools down

Three-sum- Green tea/milk bun, beet&taro bun, and egg yolk bun. Super cute buns to end your meal with. But my favorite was green tea. 

Overall this meal was quite pricy ($180 after tip for the 5 of us) but my future in-laws seemed content . Aside from the few jabs that they could make dumplings at home better, I knew they did deep down enjoy this meal :)
author: Yvi L.

description:
We were debating driving to San Jose for DTF or to try this place out. I'm so glad we did because I actually preferred this place over DTF. The flavors were really unique. Some dumplings were paired with unique sauces such as a butter or cilantro sauce which made it even tastier. I think we pretty much ordered every dumpling on the menu. 

My favorites were the Tom Yum Goong XLB and the Lobster Sui Mai.

Desserts were a little disappointing only because I thought it was going to ooze out but it was more like a paste than a gooey custard.
author: Janie L.

description: This place is quite the experience! The dumplings are bomb the K-pop is on and the line will always be long. Enjoy dumpling time for a deliciously interesting eating experience!
author: Lani A.

description: The best dumplings I have ever had. Wait can be long but worth it. Once you order the food comes out very quickly. Very reasonably priced. We've gone in a group of 3 a couple times and it came out to about $20 a person with sake and tons of food. Super delicious. I highly recommend it.
author: Lulu K.

description: Went here today for lunch with coworker and its was really good. A little crowded during lunch. I'm pescatarian they had enough options for me
author: Rio J.

description:
Best dimsum I've ever tasted!! So fresh and delicious. The shrimp toast is a must!! 
It gets packed so allow extra time for seating.
author: M H.

description:
We stumbled upon this place right before 5PM, and its a good thing we did because there is a line. Do not fret, they have a lot of space and the service is really quick. Okay, now the food. 

We had the seaweed salad, buns (steamed and crispy), steamed short ribs, dumplings, and noodles. 

The buns were the highlight, especially the pork belly peanut butter bun. The PB is not overwhelming but goes great with the pork. The noodles were also well done, garlic and sausage. 

If I had to pass on a dish it would be the steamed short ribs. They were good, but my preferences is a crispy rib and these are a wetter texture (which is traditional). 

Overall this place knocks it out of the park. The food comes quick and reminds me a little of Din Tai Fung. We will definitely be back and I will try that beet sweet dumpling!
author: Willard J.

description:
I think we got the Tom Yum Goong, Crab & Seafood Gyoza, Pan Fried Pork Bao, and the Trio of dessert dumplings.

Overall the price was fair, there was a good amount of seating too. Pretty quick service and it's a popular spot. 

Pretty good overall, only complaint about the Gyoza was the outside wasn't crispy at all (could just be the way they make it though, but I just prefer it that way).
author: Kenny N.

description:
The best XLB I've had in SF! And amazing wagyu gyoza. We also got the shrimp dumplings (good), lamb dumplings (meh) and a generous portion of garlic string beans (delicious!)

We went around 7:45pm on a Wednesday and there was about a 15-min wait.
author: Jia H.

description:
Four score and four Saturdays ago I was forced to go to Dumpling Time. I didn't want to go. Why? Because I live across the street and I see crowds and crowds of people there constantly. Read: you are going to have to wait. If you have read any of my other reviews, then you know I flipping hate waiting. I hate waiting without cocktails even more. 

I walked over at 8:30 and reluctantly put myself on the waitlist, which was pretty long considering DT closes at 9:30. I walked back across the street to have a drink at Saap Ver (excellent Thai restaurant). I ordered a glass of wine and waited for my buddy to meet me. I finished my wine when my buddy showed and we walked back across the street to see where we were on the waitlist. It hadn't moved much since I left.  Read: You can sit at Saap Ver for about 30 minutes for drinks while you wait. 

I surveyed the scene while we waited. There were hammer pants, faux hawks and man buns abound. Oh my. 

Finally we were sat. I was medium hangry. We started with some beers. I had the Modern Times Fruitlands. My buddy had the Harajuku Girl. Fruitlands is a solid choice, but the Harajuku was an awesome beer, no doubt (see what I did there). 

We ordered the shrimp toast to start. I wasn't excited when my friend ordered it but I was pleasantly surprised by how delicious it was. The shrimp was baked into the bread, and the bread was buttery and crisp - delicious. 

I'm too bored of my own review to continue. You pretty much get the point, right? You have to wait too long here. Good food, good hooch, long wait. Good but not if you hate waiting.
author: Sunny S.

description:
My friend and I just finished outdoor Yoga with Live Be Yoga Tour at Fort Mason and we were looking for something hot and savory to eat. She suggested this place to try. We are now head over heel in love. We put our names down and were seated fast within 15 minutes.

I didn't have much expectations coming here considering trying Din Tai Fung before (which in my opinion is overrated). The food here completely won us over. We started with the shrimp toast which was a must try! It's like a crunchy Chinese donut with shrimp paste on top. Just that simple but it tasted so delicious. And come the beet dumplings. One bite into the tiny pretty rose shaped dumpling, all the goody flavorful and savory soup came it and filled your taste buds with satisfaction. A slight hint of lemongrass made everything well put together and kind of refreshing. 

We also had the gyoza and happy endings with green tea baos. All thumbs up!
author: Khang V.

description:
Dumpling Time is unique, AFFORDABLE, and trendy AFFF. 

We ordered:
- Beijing noodles: BOMB. This is a very simple dry dish. Literally noodles, pork, some green onion, ginger, and soybean paste. I was expecting soup noodles but was pleasantly surprised at how much I liked this dish. 
- Tom Yum Goong XLB: SO unique! The filling had the characteristic creamy coconut milky flavor of Tom Yum soup with pork belly and shrimp. Also loved the vibrant beet skin wrapper. 
- Seared Chicken Bao: Chose the chicken one because everything else we got had pork. Personally, I prefer seared baos over steamed because of the nice sweet smoky crunchy exterior. Contrasted to the moist juicy chicken filling, this was probably my favorite thing. (Totally regretted not trying the Pork Baos!)

An interesting twist to typical dim sum... without trying too hard. Would love to come back and try some other things!
author: Caroline K.

description:
I had seen this place on Yelp and bookmarked this as a MUST TRY. We went on the Tuesday after Christmas since I was off of work and I had hoped it wouldn't be too busy because of the date. We went with my finances family and aimed to get there at 11:45am since I know how busy it can get, per the reviews. Boy did we get there are the right time. After us, many more groups came and the queue just kept getting longer.

The service was quick and dumplings delicious. We got..well what did we NOT get. We tried a lot of stuff and everything was delicous. My favorites were (in order from most favorite to still a favorite):

-SHRIMP & CILANTRO  4pcs/$6.50
Shrimp, cilantro, juicy pork
-CHAR-SIU BAO  3pcs/$6.50
Char-siu roasted pork belly, touch of peanut butter
-SEAFOOD GYOZA  5pcs/$10
Spinach skin, crab, scallop, shrimp, with spiced chili butter

We had many more but too much to name. I will say we tried the green tea and milk dessert dumpling which was interesting. Glad I tried it but I wouldn't order it again.
author: Katlyn H.

description:
I think I might have hyped this place too much in my head before coming here. I was SO excited to try the King Dum huge XLB but overall I was a little disappointed. Thankfully my other friend got there earlier, so I ended up not having to wait to long to get seated~ 

I know that dim sum tends to be a little pricier in the city, but for the overall portion size, I feel like their prices are a bit on the high end. They make their dumplings fresh every day, so that's a plus at least! 

We ordered the Tom yum goong xlb, king dum, pork dumpling, garlicky green beans, har gow and xu mai. Shared between 3 people, this definitely didn't feel like enough food, but all the items were pretty tasty! I really liked the pork dumplings and Tom yum goong, and the pesto-like sauce that came with the har gow. So unique! Flavors were all great, but I felt like the dumpling erred on the small side -- if I'm paying ~$6 for 4 pieces of har gow, I expect them to be bigger than what they turned out to be. Overall, it felt more catered to the non-asian community, in that it was pricier and ordered a la carte vs directly from the cart. 

The King Dum was most disappointing since it was very difficult to share and the wrapping was a bit too thick on top, but too thin towards the bottom, making the overall experience underwhelming. At $9, it's more for the novelty than the flavor. 

All in all, flavors are great here but I feel like you can get better dim sum for lower prices, especially if you head into SF Chinatown!
author: Tina T.

description:
After seeing a picture of the giant Xiao Long Bao on Facebook, we just had to go there. Look, I get it, I'm a basic person and yes I realize that avocado toast was not on the menu.

We went there on a Friday night and it was packed! Fortunately, the turnover at the tables is pretty fast and the wait wasn't too long. We ordered, the King Dum (giant XLB), shrimp toast, and Beijing noodles. I'm not a huge fan of dumplings and sadly Dumpling Time didn't change that. In fact, it was more of a disappointment than I am to my parents (sorry I didn't get into Harvard mom). The giant xiao long bao was actually pretty small. Maybe it was cold inside? The shrimp toast was good but the portion was so small I think I might have accidentally ordered it off of the kids menu. The Beijing noodles were kind of flavorless and the portion was also pretty bad. If you're sober or able to walk elsewhere, I'd skip this spot.
author: Mike K.

description: Thank you to my fellow Yelpers!!! I had a great time and the food was great. I waited for maybe 5 minutes (and this was a late lunch). The service was wonderful. She was very helpful and she let me know what is what. Is it expensive? Yes...Ofcourse. Is it good? Yes. I'm a fan. It looks like a hole in the wall type of place...but for a good reason. I also got to see them make the dumplings as well...pretty cool.
author: Olive R.

description:
My friend and I got finally got a taste of Dumpling Time.  Overrated.  Disappointed.

The menu has a variety of small bites to be shared.  There's dumplings, noodles, baos, and various dim sum items.  Vegetarians, there's also a few things for you.  

The winner of the night was the shrimp toast ($8) which was chopped shrimp on a Chinese donut.  The spicy aioli added a nice touch of savoriness to it.  The pork gyoza ($8) was delicious with its slight crunch.  The pork sui mai ($6, 4 pieces) were the normal ones you would get from dim sum.  The Beijing noodles ($9.50) was my least favorite dish of the night.  I found the noodles were too soggy and the ground pork lacked flavor.

We came for the dumplings.  We were disappointed with the dumplings.  We ordered pork xiao long bao ($8.50, 6 pieces) which is made with pork belly and placed in little tins.  Though the contents were tasty, my xlb stuck to the tin and as carefully as I peeled back, my xlb tore and out came the soup.  We also ordered the famous kingdum ($9 each) which is a giant xlb served with a boba straw to suck out the soup.  Because of the size, the kingdum will take about 20 minutes to come out.  Not sure why we needed a straw because the soup was scarce.  Beware, it takes a bit to cool down.  

Those with peanut allergies: beware of their homemade hot sauce on the table.  There isn't a warning so I put a few scoops on my noodles before I came across something that looked like a peanut.  I asked a server and she confirmed that the sauce is made with peanuts. 

We were seated in the back corner on the way to the restroom.  It was away from most foot traffic but the service wasn't there when you needed it.

WHAT TO KNOW:
*Entire party must be present to be seated
*Indoor and outdoor covered areas
*Credit cards are accepted
*Street parking
author: Nicole S.

description: We went here yesterday for dumplings and it was so good I'm already craving them again and want to go back!!! I left my phone at home so I don't have photos, but my favorite items were the soup dumplings, main lobster siu man, and the shrimp and cilantro har gow. The sake was excellent too. Very chill atmosphere for a casual date night. I will definitely be returning here.
author: Jackie G.

description:
Love this place! I have been here twice in the last week. 

The BBQ pork buns are delish. 
The green beans are a wish (come true)
The pickled veggies are to die for
The seafood dumplings are to vie for (share, please!)

Seriously : the servers are quick and friendly. The tea is good too. It's all the fun of dim sum with a hip SF vibe.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
Absolutely worth the wait. I came here for the novelty King Dum, a giant XLB the size of a baby's face that you slurp with a boba straw, but I actually enjoyed the other items on the menu more. 

Garlicky Green Beans // Very tasty, and a good crunch. 

Beef noodles // Small portions and the flavor doesn't penetrate the noodles as much as I had expected. 

Fried Tofu // A good ratio of breadcrumbs and soft, gooey tofu. Plus, it comes with this sweet and spicy sauce. 

Chicken Bao // Would definitely recommend for the flavor and texture - it had a nice crunch to it. 

Shrimp and Cilantro Har Gow // The fusion between the two is way better, especially with their very green cilantro sauce. 

Trio Buns // Probably my favorite part of lunch! The egg custard was soft, and the red beet and taro bun surprised me with how subtly the two flavors worked so well together. GET IT! 

A bit expensive, which is why I came with my parents!
author: Arielle I.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! 

Everything on the menu is worth it (but skip the noodles, bland). Come with a group so you can try everything.

My favorites:

Shrimp toast
BBQ pork buns
Pork XLB
Shrimp har gow
Green beans
Seafood gyoza


Do not miss the seafood gyoza and the shrimp toast.
author: Julia O.

description: Seriously the best dumpling place I've ever been to!   The wait outside is long and cold but the food is SO AMAZING and 100% worth it. Honestly the cold kinda primes you because the dumplings are so warm and comforting and delicious in comparison. Also the food came out in .2 seconds after we ordered, which apparently how it works here and how they flip tables so quickly. Awesome, recommend, go here
author: Farida Y.

description:
ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS! Calling all dumpling lovers .. you will be amazed by this place.

My boyfriend tried them out for a work meal and couldn't stop talking about it for weeks, so I had to give it a shot myself. I went for lunch time on a Saturday and we did not have to wait at all. There was 3 of us and we sat at the communal table. We ordered pretty much everything that sounded good and little by little it started arriving. Everything that came out of the kitchen was absolutely delicious. I don't like shrimp and I was drooling over the shrimp toast they have!

Worth every penny.
author: Inci A.

description: I was thoroughly happy with Dumpling Time. Our party of 3 probably ordered about 10 dishes which consisted of dumplings, noodles, gyoza, and boa buns. I would say that about 95% of the food that we tried was all delicious. I really enjoyed the beijing noodles, even though I felt the noodles needed a little more salt. The XLB's were super flavorul. I really enjoyed the seafood gyoza as well as the pork gyoza. We ended the meal with the sweet boa buns which were really freakin good. My favorite was the green tea boa. Would highly recommend checking this place out if your looking for some delicious dumplings.
author: Steven K.

description:
Whoo whoo! My 100th review goes to Dumpling Time and I'm glad it's a good one.

Came here on a weekday during lunch hours and there were plenty of tables available. However, parking is the worst! So many interior design stores in the neighborhood and parking was so full. 
Very cute store with some outdoor seating.

I mainly came to try the King Dum but I'm glad everything tasted so good!
 
Maine Lobster Siu Mai: Pretty yummy and I could definitely taste the truffle. But I think I will be good with ordering the regular one next time!
Pork XLB: Pretty juicy and comparable to good XLB places!
Pork Gyoza: I think it was just perfect! The skin was crispy and came out very hot.
King Dum: Comes with a boba straw for you to slurp the soup out! Had to split this into pieces to eat but I was surprised that it tasted the same as the Pork XLB's. Not bad but I wouldn't order it again. Mainly ordered for the picture hehe
author: Kristie L.

description:
Keeping it simple ...
Freshly well made items cooked well.
One of their attraction is the super oversized dumpling for one.
author: S.K. Y.

description:
The restaurant was situated in the design district so it made sense that the interior was extremely hip. I loved the pink neon wall decor that depicted cartoon dumplings and the illustrated wall that portrayed cities around the world. (Shanghai, etc.) There was the option for outside seating as well. 

[ King Dum ] This was the first time I had a soup dumpling. I had a lot of trouble getting the soup up the straw so I ended up eating it with a spoon. The soup flavor was a amazing! 

[ Shrimp Toast ] This dish was pretty much shrimp wrapped inside a Chinese donut. It was very crunchy and savory.
author: Annie Z.

description:
It's dumpling time, it's dumpling time (I'm trying to riff off the old Dragon Tales theme song, but I don't think it's working...).

We shared the seaweed, seafood dumplings, and shrimp toasts. Fancy names, fancy looks, and fancy prices, but just regular Chinese food tastes to me.

The seaweed was in Chinese style, with a slight vinegar taste and oily sheen to it. Good to share as an app. 3.25/5.

The seafood dumplings were basically har gao (shrimp dumplings) you'd get at a dim sum spot, except with a spinach skin that wasn't in the chewy style you normally get at dim sum spots. I think these would've been tastier in person, fresh off the wok, but even then. 3.25/5.

The shrimp toasts were just you tiao (fried Chinese donut) with shrimp cake atop the dough. The dough was appropriately layered but could have been a bit more crunchy and golden brown. 3.25/5.

My guess is that this place would be better in person given the fried nature of the items we ordered. I'd be down to try it again.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Portions are a bit on the smaller side. I say order more than you think you'll need. I left with an appreciation for the Pork XLB and Beijing Noodles.

The Tom Yum XLB are great though a bit too out there for me. It truly tastes like Tom Yum soup and nails presentation. I just prefer the actual traditional Tom Yum. Similarly, the oversized King-dum XLB was fun for photos and less fun to drink soup through a straw. Don't let it sit too long! The bottom soaks up too much of the liquid and the ratio is off.

There's more than just Chinese foods available. Items like edamame, gyoza and spring rolls are also featured in the fusion menu. The dim sum is pretty good when you disregard the high price for what you get in the Richmond/Sunset or Chinatown.

For inexpensive, quick and casual I venture to Shanghai Dumpling King. For a well established and refined experience I dine at Din Tai Fung. For some place hip and fun, i'll continue to come to Dumpling Time.
author: Samantha L.

description: Really didn't mind the chefs taking a big steamy dump-ling right on my table for me to scoop up and num-num as fast as humanly possible. Heard a lot of great things about this place and finally made it out--so good. The steamed dumplings with cilantro sauce were kinda meh but overall? Fire.
author: Patrick A.

description:
I loved this place. Went here for lunch on a weekday and service was also very quick and easy. We were in and out in 45 minutes. We got the following items, in order of preference: 

1. Tom yum goong - pork belly, shrimp, coconut milk soup dumpling in a beet skin. This was fantastic. I loved the flavor of the coconut milk. Really made it unique 
2. Char siu bao - awesome bao with pork belly and peanut butter, which added a little bit of sweetness 
3. Shrimp and Pork siu mai - really good 
4. Beijing noodles - good but don't think these are a must have 
5. Green beans - these were pretty good if you want to have some veggies to mix up the menu. They were cooked nice and crispy so I liked these more than steamed green beans 
6. Shrimp har how - nothing unique but still good
author: Aakanksha M.

description:
Hooray!! Hipster Dumpling Heaven! Dumpling Time is currently the talk of the town and, after eating here twice in one week, I'm starting to understand what all the damn hype is all about.

FOOD: Must try items include the Shrimp & Cilantro Har Gow, Tom Yum Goong (Xiao Long Bao with a Thai twist,) and the Green Tea & Milk Bun! While I'm super big on traditional XLB, I really enjoyed the Asian-fusion twist on these as they made for interesting combos of flavors. 

VIBES: As I alluded to earlier, this place is practically engineered to attract Design District workers looking to snap a pic with the giant XLB for The Gram... #guilty. That said, the atmosphere is very hip: there's K-Pop always projected onto the wall, there are bright neon signs peppered throughout the room, and the staff are all equally energetic and casually engaging. 

If you're l i t e r a l l l l l l y looking to eat, l i i i i i k e, some tasty Asian fusion food in a fun and 'grammable setting, then Dumpling Time is your place to be!
author: Stephen D.

description:
100 recommend if you eat in person. It's fantastic and my favorite dimsum in SF so far (dragon Beaux, yank sing,  great eastern, ton kiang) 

100 do NOT recommend for delivery. 

Trust the reviews, seafood gyoza was bomb, wagyu gyoza was good but not anything special. The donut was surprisingly really good. XLB both regular and tom yum was delicious.

Highly recommend green tea milk buns and egg custard buns. 

I will say there was a 40 minute wait when we got there 10 minutes after it opened. What?! But it went by quickly and was really probably just 30 mins. Worth noting we were a party of 8. 

I will def go a million times over again
author: Genica R.

description:
I love dumplings. Dumplings are life. I AM A DUMPLING!!!!

We were cutting it SUPER close to their closing time, but they seated us quickly. And we quickly ordered 5 orders of dumplings. Here's the breakdown:

Seafood Gyoza: this was good and I love seafood. I also liked the thin crunchy fried part.

Tom Yum Goong XLB: good, but didn't taste like Tom Yum to us. Maybe too herb-y?

Pork Xi'An Dumpling: lovely presentation, but just your standard dumplings.

King-Dum: I don't know if I'd order it again. It's a fun idea, but maybe the execution needs work. There was very little meat for what it was. Good thing they brought it on a plate because it was super easy to poke through and the soup gathered below the bamboo steamer.

Green Tea & Milk Bun (dessert): this is a MUST-HAVE! The milky paste on the inside wasn't too too sweet and it was soft, warm, and delicious.

Overall, nothing super special. But I'd definitely try and snag an order of the Green Tea & Milk Buns again if I was in the area.
author: Athena C.

description:
BEST DUMPLING PLACE IN SOMA!!  This was one of the first dim sum places I tried when I first moved to SF and it did not disappoint. The wait time can be incredibly long depending on the time of day on a weekend, but they are extremely efficient both in seating and service, so no matter how long we waited, it never took us long to get food once we were seated. A variety of things on the menu are really good- my the xiao long bao is always a favorite of mine, as are the beef & noodles, so yummy! The prices are extremely reasonable compared to other dim sum places in SF, and a lunch/dinner for two will not empty your wallet, even if you feel the portions are small and you will need to order more. 

I've already been 5 times since the first, and I know it's coming up in my near future...next weekend anyone?
author: Marites S.

description: Been here twice, first time, food was delicious, hot soup dumplings and great service. Second visit, our XLB and Tom yum came out below room temp-basically cold. The wrappers where doughy, uncooked and I don't about the meat if it was fully raw but def not hot. Told the waiters, they brought out new hot steamy ones because the first one has no steam what's so ever and not translucent. You can see from the picture that the dough looks way too plump and risen to be cooked hot soup dumplings. Hopefully they will be more conscientious when serving fully cooked, hot food and not prioritize speedy service. Serving poorly cooked dishes is unacceptable.
author: Kimmie H.

description:
TLDR: XLB was LIT. This was the winning factor.

Trendy dumpling place that is surprisingly delicious.
I've had a lot of different types of dumplings in my life. XLB, regular dumplings, wontons, bao zi, you name it. I lived in Beijing for 7 years, home of dumpling makers. Which pretty much makes me a dumpling connoisseur :-) 

* Pork XLB ($8.50 for 6) - This was what made me respect the place. I cannot emphasize enough how many places I've been to that put XLB on their menu, that end up in disappointment. This is because the skin is too thick, there is NO soup, the soup LEAKS (bad craftsmanship), the skin sticks to the plating (bad execution). NOT HERE! It is very difficult to make XLB, clearly, given my multiple attempts to find places that make them well. The meat inside was tender and soft, as it should be. Not as a ball of meat that has been separated from the skin - because there was fat and it was not overcooked! A++

* Shrimp toast ($8) - I love Chinese donut or "you tiao" and I've never considered it as a toast. This is what I mean by trendy / hip haha. I've only had it with congee or soymilk. It was indeed very delicious with shrimp on top. Very crispy!

* Pork dumplings ($9 for 8) - Standard. Good.

* King Dum ($9 for a big ol' thang) - This is the what people come here for, and the pics. Of course garnished with flower petals.... who would've thunk to use a boba straw for dumpling? -snaps pics- I've actually had a large XLB with a straw before in Shanghai so it was cool to see it being offered at a restaurant in the States. Personally, not for me because the skin was too thick. But the meat inside was nice and juicy.

* Chicken / pork gyoza ($7.5 / $8 for 5) - Standard. Liked that the chicken gyoza had mushrooms in it. But 5 pieces for $8?! 

* Gan ban noodles ($9.50) - I LOVE cold noodles. This was delish! 

* Three sum (dessert) ($6) - Sums out, buns out. This threesum included 1) green tea & milk, 2) beet & taro, and 3) egg yolk. All were freaking delicious. Highly recommend if you are sharing. 

OVERALL, I would come back. There are places in Chinatown that have these prices & the quality of food / vibes are not to this standard. Reminds me of DTF in that sense, though I would pick DTF over this any day hehe.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Went here with a group at someone else's suggestion. The food turned out to be mostly great. 

We tried one or two of every style of dumplings they offer. The Pork and Seafood varieties of Gyoza dumplings were excellent, as were the open faced Maine Lobster Siu Mai. The pork soup dumplings were messy, but also surprisingly good. 

The only thing I didn't really like were the Bao seared buns. They were just too doughy for my taste. 

The menu isn't cheap, but not outrageous for SF. Also, lines can be long and slow at lunch. Get there a little before noon to avoid having to wait.
author: JC C.

description:
I enjoyed the food here, but I was disappointed that I was still VERY hungry after paying a steep price.

Some items I really enjoyed were:  garlicky green beans,  shrimp & pork siu mai, and shrimp toast. The xiao long bao and king-dum leaked when they arrived, so I didn't enjoy them as much...

Overall, a decent place for dumplings, but for the price I paid, I expected way more food. Would I come back? Probably not.
author: Vu P.

description:
It's in a quiet plaza with some furniture stores. As a fun fact, we had parked on the furniture side. I had been wondering if it was fine to park with all the tow-away signs, but we decided it was fine because the signs did not specify which stores. After eating, we saw people removing those signs with new ones specifying the addresses (basically the office side) for which parking was allowed.

I liked it. Cute and hipster. Videos playing on the wall. Bright and cheery vibe. The food was good - similar to other dimsum places. I think the King XLB is a bit of an Instagram fad - it's not as practical to eat and enjoyable as the normal bite-sized ones. The soup is scalding hot and difficult to drink through a plastic straw. I also don't like the idea of drinking boiling hot soup through plastic. It's not easy to share and the whole thing kind of breaks apart so you end up with dumpling skin and broken up meatballs with leftover soup seeping between the bamboo container to the little plate underneath.

The gyoza was satisfyingly crunchy and the stuffing was good, but it felt like it lacked that extra oomph. The Beijing noodles (Basically zhajiangmian) were great but portion was shockingly small especially considering the ingredients are not expensive. It was like an appetizer size, definitely not a full portion. 

I enjoyed the food and atmosphere. It's tailored to a wider audience and have helpful descriptions on the food items are on the menu. I liked that the dumplings were made fresh, unlike a lot of places that just fry frozen dumplings...as expected of a dumpling house. Prices were on the higher end, but that's expected for the location. Recommend getting the normal XLB for food enjoyment; King XLB for the pictures if you must.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Pros:
- All the dishes were either mediocre or above
- Good for family style (small portion sizes tho, so one dumpling per person lol)
- Shrimp toast - the only dish I would recommend

Cons:
- Long wait all the time.. we got there less than an hour before they closed and still long lines
- Super small portion sizes (SUPER SMALL)
- Expensive

Would not return. Trying to find authentic chinese dumplings at a better price - plz msg me with suggestions.
author: Elvi T.

description:
Dumplings, dumplings, dumplings!

My friend and I were VERY skeptical at first. 

A dumpling spot in SOMA in the DESIGN district....let me just jump ahead and say we were wrong!

My friend and I ordered basically everything we left STUFFED. We went from one good dish to the next. So creative, bravo!

Went again last night with two visitors and this is the first time I took my guests to a relatively "newish" spot. Met one of the partners, Guy. He was very friendly and told me about the new spots opening soon, Niku steakhouse and the butcher shop! Can't wait for these to open. ON IT!
author: Tina T.

description:
great parking and great food. nice patio seating with a nice menu selection. 

recommend:

Wagyu beef gyoza
shrimp + pork mai
shanghai noodles
author: Milynda P.

description: The line was long for good reason.  Amazing. Our table tried 10 items each thing was amazing in its own right.  Tom Yum... to die for.
author: Jeni A.

description:
Super tasty! 
Ordered the shrimp toast, buns, noodles and several types of dumplings and EVERYTHING was amazing!
The service was great as well. The waiter checked on us periodically and did so mindfully as not to interrupt our conversations. In addition, we were not rushed although there were several people waiting which was GREAT! I hate being rushed out especially when I may want to order more. 
The food came out quickly, everything was hot, fresh and made to order.

One tip: It can be a bit of a wait but well worth it!
author: Marcia B.

description:
The wait is worth it because I am truly in euphoria when I visit this place. 

The sauteed & gingered snap peas are a healthy enough serving of greens to make me feel less guilty about ordering stacks of dumplings. Super crunchy and satisfying. 

The Tom Yum Goong dumplings are so delicious. So flavorful with the perfect amount of soup-meat-dough ratio. Pork XLBs and Shrimp and Pork Siu Mais are also among my faves. Also, the shrimp toast is a must! Perfectly fried Chinese donut with minced shrimp on top. Last but not least are the egg yolk buns which are wayyy superior to the other two buns. All in all, I can always count on this place to deliver.
author: Briget P.

description: Am I the only person who thinks this place is just okay? Not worth the wait and totally over priced for what it is. I'm glad we went to see what the hype was about, but probably won't make our way back.
author: Taylor P.

description:
My love for dumplings is for eternity... at least until I get sick of them.  One of the reasons why I wanted to come here was that they had the supersize soup dumpling that you can eat with a straw. It may be a gimmick...but definitely a good one! We order a good amount of food that the waitress had to clear out some plates to make room for others. The portions are not that large, so you can order plenty of dishes,  but will just cost a bit more at the end. The ginger snap peas and cucumber salad were both seasoned very well and had good flavors. The chicken goyzas had a good crisp taste and the xi'an pork dumplings came with a special dipping sauce. The char su baos were fluffy and the xlb did not disappoint.  The tom yum goong xlb were flavorful (according to my friends). The trio of buns is a perfect way to end the meal as each one came with a different filling... and all were tasty!

Everything here was delicious!
author: Charlie T.

description:
OH MY LORD!!! Honestly the best dumplings I ever tasted and cheap! I love the vibe in there, blasting top 40 music and just the environment. They do have an indoor and outdoor seating and the food is to die for!! I would recommend getting there at 6pm if you don't want to wait for a while, after that it gets pretty packed. Everything I ordered was on point. 

What we ordered: 
- Garlic green beans
- Shrimp toast . Chinese donut w minced shrimp 
- Garlic seaweed salad
- Shrimp dumpling 
- Gan ban noodles. Loaded w veggies 
- Seafood gyoza 
- Crispy chicken bao 
- Pork soup dumplings 

Dessert:
- green tea & milk buns
- beet & taro buns
author: Jenn L.

description:
Amazing dumplings and dim sum, beautiful presentation too! The colors were beautiful and the flavors in each piece were distinct despite some of the ingredients being duplicated. 
The staff were all very friendly and worked together to get our food out fast and hot. When we walked in we noticed the huge window that featured the dumpling and noodle chefs hard at work. It was cool to see their skills in action! Definitely recommend getting to this spot!
author: Lauren E.

description:
Definitely in love with Dumpling Time and wish I worked closer so I could come all the time.

Living in the avenues, it takes a special restaurant to get me to leave the land of dim sum for...dim sum. Luckily, Dumpling Time is worth the trip out. 

We lucked out, on a Saturday night at 7pm, that the way was only 15 minutes before we got seated. Definitely would not come in a group bigger than four here! Ample parking nearby. 

Half our food came out immediately after we ordered. The item we waited on the longest were the dessert buns. Servers were super sweet and patient with us (we kept adding on items).

What we tried:
Shrimp toast - MY FAVORITE ITEM. MUST ORDER
Chicken Gyoza - taste good in the sauce on the table instead of the one it comes with
Chicken Bao - good, but not my favorite item, I'd skip the bao if you had to decide
