Pork Bao - friends loved these (can't personally comment)
Pork Dumplings (king dum / tom yum goong) - friends loved the tom yum better
Green beans - good
Gan Ban Noodles - surprisingly good! nice filler
Sui Mai - friends enjoyed
Xi'an Vegetarian Dumpling - I actually would choose to order these again over the gyoza if I had to pick

All 3 dessert buns- my favorites were the egg yolk and the green tea.

Definitely would come back!
author: Arezou A.

description:
Drove past here and saw a huge crowd so wanted to come here ever since! Came on a Tuesday night and there was a 15 minute wait but was seated with two other couples at a six top. We ordered like ten dishes and because we were at the communal table we realized we ordered like 3x as much as everyone else did - whoops. We were beyond stuffed and have so much leftover. 

I was already kind of drunk so don't remember what our favorites were. We got the bunny sake which while it has a cute name I would not recommend ever because it was overly sweet and they served it in these awkward square "cups" that made it hard to drink without spilling on yourself. I would also skip the shrimp toast, Ive had much better elsewhere. Super trendy and young ambiance, especially for a Chinese restaurant.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Hey, I really like this place!  My friend had just moved into this neighborhood and we love trying out new restaurants. We came here close to noon on a Friday, and was seated immediately.  The exterior of the restaurant is unassuming, and the interior is clean and bright. It has an open kitchen design. We couldn't narrow down on what to order, as so many items looked great on the menu.  Our waiter gave us some recommendations and helped us out. We ended up ordering Shrimp & Cilantro Har Gow, Beijing Noodles, King, Dum, and Tom yum Goong XLB. 

Shrimp & Cilantro Har Gow- our waiter recommended this dish and it didn't disappoint. Har gow was stuffed with fresh shrimp and the skin was thin. 5 Stars 

Beijing Noodles- this dish smelled and tasted great. It was a little bit on the greasy side. 4 Stars 

Tom Yum Goong XLB- we wanted try something unique instead of the traditional xlb. This dish was definitely unique. The beet skin gave a vibrant color and the xlb was juicy! Though it didn't really taste like Tom Yum to me, it was very yummy nevertheless. 5 Stars 

King Dum- We ordered this dish for fun, coz sucking meaty XLB juice out of a boba straw seemed like a fun idea. Lol! Well, as it turned out it wasn't all that easy. And it tasted just okay. 3 Stars 

I wish we had more stomach space to try other items. Our next table neighbors ordered the shrimp toast and the gan ban noodles. They looked and smelled delicious. I also want to try the green tea and milk bun next time.
author: Valerie C.

description:
Dumpling time is a dream come true, with all the dumplings, baos, and gyozas you could ever desire. I came with a friend on Saturday around noon and was pleasantly surprised by how much seating space they had. The two of us were seated in no time. 

As for the food, we ordered 4 dishes to split between the two of us. (Normally I could probably eat more, but I had a post-workout shake earlier that morning so I wasn't super hungry.)

PAN SEARED CHAR SU BAO: I couldn't decide which bao to get so the waiter recommended this one and it was the perfect choice! Super yummy and the peanut flavor added a nice kick.

SHRIMP TOAST: This was essentially a modern twist to your traditional 油条 (you tiao) but with shrimp on top! It was surprisingly addicting and I enjoyed it far more than I thought I would.

BEETS XIAO LONG BAO: You sure can't miss this dish, which comes out in a firetruck red color. The skin is made with beets, which explains the bright color and interesting taste. My friend thought it was a little funky, but I liked it.

SHU MAI: I've never been a big fan of shu mai, but this tasted just fine. No better and no worse than I've had from other restaurants.

I can totally see myself coming back often because the food is delicious and there are still so many items on the menu that I want to try!
author: Alice S.

description:
Food was really good! Parking and seating was nice! But the service was a little off. 

Seared bao and summer rolls were amazing! I loved how the crunchy outside of the baos make the inside fluff a treat. I have never had it that way before. I recommend the basic bao pork and cabbage. It was so good we ordered some To go! But it didn't make it that far...it was just too amazing. Also the summer fresh rolls are really packed with red peppers, carrots, lettuce, you name it! The largest summer roll I've ever had!  

We also ordered the shrimp gyoza and it came out green, which was pretty interesting. It was really good. 

The dessert bao was warm and gooey. I loved the green tea boa. I would've loved to have it with green tea ice cream !! 

The ambience was okay, not too loud or crowded. I sat in the middle isle seats and constantly had waiters bumping into my seat. They also forgot about our dessert order because when they remembered it came it out in 2 minutes. 

I really like this place cause it's cheap and good. I would come here again.
author: Natalie R.

description:
Came here on Christmas night from out of town after reading that this is one of the few restaurants that would be open on Christmas day. Couldn't be happier with our food experience. As long as you plan ahead and get there early, you'll enjoy your experience as well.  Don't come here late and hangry because you might be waiting a while.

We got here just a few minutes before they opened, and already walked up to a large crowd of people waiting.  Is it a Hunger Games scene? Is  this a lottery system? How does one get selected to go in? Simple: immediately add your name to the paper waitlist at the front.

This place is small, so only so many people get to go in at the same time.  It must have been a Christmas miracle because we were one of the last people to make the cut, and they do not play around!

This place makes legit dumplings and even better soup dumplings.  I've never been happy with any soup dumplings that I've tried over the years. A lot of places claim they serve it, but they tend to be dry on the inside with no soup spilling out, so you might as well just call them regular dumplings. This place though, perfection both in flavor and execution.

Some of our favorites were the green beans (out of this world), lobster siu mai, tom yum soup dumpling, pork gyoza. Everything was outstanding. Food came out fast but service was somewhat slow, so I recommend placing your order all at once or you might be waiting a while.
author: Chanita S.

description:
So good! Will definitely be coming back. 

Food: 
We tried the following dishes, starting with my favorite dish:
(1) Beijing noodles - Just all around yummy and the noodles had the chewy texture of fresh noodles.
(2) Egg yolk bun - Just sweet enough and so fluffy. I don't enjoy desserts which are too sweet, so this hit the spot.
(3) Garlicy green beans - Crispy and not overcooked.
(4) Pork gyoza - Fried just the right amount so they were slightly browned and crispy on the outside.
(5) Xiao long bao in pork and tom yum goong - I liked the pork better, but they were both well made. 

Service: There was a bit of a wait to sit down for dinner (around 10 - 20 minutes), and you put your name on a paper list to make a reservation, but the service once seated is fast.

Atmosphere: It's a sit down place, but the atmosphere is pretty casual. They have outdoor and indoor seating areas.
author: Michelle B.

description:
You know that one song? Yeah that one that was on The Proud Family and like a million other shows?

ITS PEANUT BUTTER JELLY TIME
PEANUT BUTTER JELLY TIME

WHERE HE AT
WHERE HE AT
THERE HE GO 
THERE HE GO

Except we're not on The Proud Family. We're in San Francisco. SoOoOoOo:

ITS DUMPLING DUMPLING DUMPLING TIME
DUMPLING DUMPLING DUMPLING TIME
WHERE HE AT WHERE HE AT (that's me waiting for my food)
THERE HE GO THERE HE GO (that's me thinking my food's coming but it's actually for someone else LOL SAD LIFE)

I came to Dumpling Time with some friends on a Sunday morning. We arrived at 10:30, half an hour before opening, found parking right outside, and we were first in line. In just 5 short minutes though, the place quickly became filled with people. We sat outside and ordered the garlicky green beans, shrimp toast, King XLB soup dumpling, tom yum goong (pork belly, shrimp, coconut milk, wrapped in beet skin), Xi'an pork dumpling, and for dessert we had the trio of buns (green tea/milk bun, beet/taro bun, & egg yolk bun).

The green beans were sooooooo good. One of my friends said she wasn't going to have any because she hates vegetables but then she ended up eating it the whole time too insert eye roll emoji here.* The other thing I would recommend are the beet skin dumplings. Not sure who what when where why, but there things are delicious. The ever so hyped King dumpling I cannot give too much comment on because we were so adamant about waiting for all of our food to come out (for a photo ofc), that by the time we finally ate the dumpling, all the soup had sunk down to the bottom, so that was our fault. None of the less, it was tender and juicy so next time, I would be down to try it again and this time NO PHOTOS, GOING TO GO STRAIGHT INTO EATING.
author: Maleah M.

description:
I am obsessed with this place and the dumplings. When you walk in on the left people are making the dumplings fresh!

I love the seafood gyoza, shrimp and cilantro haw gow, and the pork soup dumplings. I just had the dessert buns and the egg yolk one is impressively yummy!
author: Tina L.

description:
Dumpling Time will always hold a special place in my heart. My boyfriend took me out on a date night, but the original location had already closed its kitchen. Lame! It wasn't even that late. Fortunately, Dumpling Time was still open. It's even open until 9:30pm everyday! And for lunch. I know I'll be coming here many more times because of how close I live.

The only downside (and upside?) is how popular it is. We put our name down and waited outside in the cold. There was a patio area that looked nice, but it was still too chilly for my liking. It took 15-20 minutes of waiting for us to be seated at a bench in the middle of the restaurant. We had taken a look at the menu already and decided.

Everything was tasty! During this meal (edit: and also a future time I visited) I tried the following items:

* Garlicky Green Beans - So good but so salty! Definitely a good starter to get you warmed up for dumplings.
* Chicken Gyoza - Perfectly crisped and seasoned. Flavorful even without soy sauce.
* Pork Bao - Medium sized with a good amount of filling. I really want to try the char-siu ones that have a little peanut butter in them.
* Beijing Noodles - Also salty (I think because of the soybean paste) but great to share with multiple people... Unless you like it so much that you don't want to share.
* Shrimp & Cilantro Har Gow - I would say it's better (less greasy) than most dim sum places I've been to. Impressive!

There are so many other options for food and beverage. I can't just come here once or twice. I know I'll have to wait even if it's for lunch or dinner, but it's totally worthwhile. The vibe is young and fun, the service and serve times are quick, and most importantly, the food is tasty!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I have came here twice. Once last year - wait was about an hour long for a table for 2, and again recently - wait was only about 15 minutes for a table of 3 but it was communal. 

I have tried the shrimp toast, "king dum" - large xlb with a straw, Tom Yum Goong xlb, pork xlb, garlic string beans, lobster shu mai, beijing noodles, and their xi'an pork dumplings. The prices are pretty steep compared to regular dimsum/xlb places, but most of the items here are pretty good and good to try. The shrimp toast is pretty unique and has great flavor to it, even though it looks kind of simple (chinese donut and shrimp). The "king dum" large xlb is great for pictures and the experience, but not very worth it. The tom Yum Goong xlb is pretty good and unique, haven't seen this anywhere else. The regular pork xlb is pretty tasty with a good amount of soup. The garlic string beans are pretty good and goes well with the xlb, but nothing very unique about it. I've never tried or seen lobster shu mai before so we gave this a try - pretty expensive and I don't think I will order this again. It doesn't taste too different/special, not worth the price in my opinion. The beijing noodles is pretty good and has great flavor to it. The xi'an pork dumplings I would pass on next time because it tasted different that regular pork dumplings and I didn't really like the filling. It also looks like a salad dish mixed with sprouts and radish which was kind of weird to me.

The service is pretty good, though you may need to flag them down when you need something. Parking is fairly easy as well. Great place to try!
author: Bailey L.

description:
We came her for Mother's Day lunch and the wait was about 30 minutes, not bad. There are seats and benches in the patio area which was nice for customers to sit while waiting for their table. They do not take reservation, it's a first come first serve basis. As soon they seated us, we ordered immediately and the food came out very quick! Our server Wendy (I think that was her name) was excellent! 

We ordered the following dishes: 

Garlicky green beans - tasty! seasoned very well. 

Shrimp toast (Chinese donut, minced shrimp, spicy aioli) - really good but oily. 

Seared bbq pork bao (char siu roasted pork belly) - we opt for the pan seared and it decent, wished it was more seared for that crunch texture. 

Seafood Gyoza (spinach skin, crab, scallop, shrimp, chili butter sauce) - this was one of our favorites! Very tasty! 

King Dum - so big that you need a straw! This was nice for pictures but the skin was too thick and the meat was not firm. 

Trio of buns (green tea & milk bun, beet & taro bun, egg yolk bun) - these were okay, the green tea stood out the most. 

Xian pork dumpling - nothing special and very bland. 

Har Gow - these were good but we had better. 

Overall, the dishes we ordered were hit or miss. Wait wasn't long and food came out quick! We will be back to try the other dishes.
author: Linda P.

description:
WOW! What a great concept. Trendy place with yummy food to share.  The Beijing noodles were delicious. Green beans were cooked perfectly. 
Dumplings dumplings dumplings. 
Nice decor.  Multiple tv screens to make one big tv playing Asian videos. Awesome!
I enjoyed Dumpling Time and will definitely come back!
author: Kat G.

description: Best dumplings in SF! Yep- I said it! Worth the wait- which there is ALWAYS a wait. Get the pork and shrimp dumplings with the chili dipping sauce. Beware you will have to listen and watch hours of K-Pop while you eat but it's slightly entertaining.
author: Mary B.

description:
My husband is a regular lunch patron here and took me yesterday to experience "the best dumplings if sf, and maybe the Bay Area with only din tai Fung as a close contender." I wasn't prepared to agree, but I do. 

There is an obvious lunchtime rush from the growing startup community close by, that seemed to quiet around 130. Trendy indoor and outdoor covered seating as well as some communal tables too. Service was awesome, efficient yet friendly, with some of our orders arriving immediately (like less than 5 minutes wait! For the siu mai and har gow specifically) and piping hot. 

For one hungry guy and one very preggo me, we finished: 
1 beer (him)
4 crispy spring rolls with sweet sour chili dipping sauce
Salt and pepper fried tofu with same dipping sauce
4 shrimp and pork siu mai
4 shrimp har gow 
8 xi'an vegetable dumplings
1 green tea milk bun (with 2 to take home)

Total $60+\-

The food was amazingly fresh and definitelymade to order. Not super greasy like traditional dim sum and with a fusion twist of seasonal spring veggies. The tofu were so light and perfectly fried. I'm vegetarian so hence the large proportion of non meat items... the vegetable dumplings are the only vegetarian dumpling offered (contain egg) but there are ample appetizers as well. Those xi'an dumplings were definitely the highlight. Served covered with edible micro greens and flowers, radish, and halved tiny tomatoes, they were beautiful and enough for me.
author: Debora L.

description:
The experience we faced when waiting in line was not acceptable. We had a few kids with us and the hostess decided without asking us we would be more comfortable outside so she had us wait. After we confronted her to question why a group of 10 which came 40 mins after us is going inside before us. Waiting over 1hr 15mins with starving kids didn't help that it was warm out. The hostess knew she had made a pretty big error in judgement and tried to resolve it but the resolution was us waiting a bit longer. 

The place had exceptional service once we were seated. The food was very delicious as usual. I wouldn't want to wait like this again. Hopefully they do some internal training to have the door person ask customer their preferences rather than make assumptions. 

I give it 5 stars for the food and service inside but the bad experience waiting is a 0 Star.
author: Phoutty K.

description: I love their tom yum soup dumplings! I could eat 15+ of them! The giant soup dumpling is so cute and fun but you need to eat it fast while it's hot.
author: Debra N.

description:
Came here a second time. Food is still excellent. The ones I like best are: seafood gyoza and XLB soup buns. The mom's secret recipe pork dumplings are also really good. The wait also wasn't so long on a weeknight. 

The bad: The service is way too slow. Takes an eternity to bring the food. Another eternity to get your check and pay. There is virtually no service other than someone bringing your food in a rush. You'd have to be quick and flag someone down. Took us 2 hours to get through dinner because the service was so slow. 

The K-pop on the big projector screen, loud bass pumping (you can't hear any real music), especially if you're sitting near the screen, the neon lights inside, the crowding, the loud noise inside, all incredibly obnoxious. Ambiance here is terrible and unpleasant. 

No complaint about the food though. Pretty excellent.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
love love love!!  in town for Conference
.. cane here because iLOVE dumplings.... these did not disappoint!! everything was delish!!  snap peas, dumplings
author: Cas S.

description:
Was a bit skeptical coming here for lunch since I've never been to a good, upscale dim sum place, especially in Portrero Hill.

Wait/Ambiance: Came here on a Thursday at noon with a friend and there was no wait! It's a pretty big restaurant with both indoor and semi-outdoor seating. The decor is modern, with neon lights and black walls, but also very aesthetically pleasing and good lighting

Food: Definitely not super authentic dim sum, but still good. We got the King Dum, which is a giant XLB that comes with two straws to poke into it, garnished with flowers on top. It was really yummy - maybe the best XLB I've had in SF. The Beijing noodle was also yummy (I added the hot sauce oil for an extra kick) with ground meat and freshly pulled noodles. I don't really recommend the Siu Mai, which was a bit bland (also had to add hot sauce which I never do for siu mai). Finally, the char siu bao was also good - we ordered the seared, not steamed, version which was tasty and even had a bit of peanut butter inside for uniqueness. 

Service: Quick service, really attentive servers but don't expect your typical dim sum waiters here. I'm used to ordering in Chinese and being left alone but it's quite the opposite here
author: Victoria L.

description:
Cute hipster haven for residents of soma who crave Chinese food. But I wouldn't go out of my way to get XLBs here. Lines get ridiculous starting at 6:30 so get there early! Hostess is also pretty curt and rude so I was wary from the start but servers inside are friendly. Price point is higher than I'd like for the quality of food, but what can you expect in SF. 

Definitely a hip and young vibe, with kpop music videos projected on a blank white wall and neon signs washing guests with a magenta haze. It kinda feels like I'm at a warehouse party. Food is also fun to IG with flower petals and vibrant colors. Beet colored dumpling skins ftw! 

The giant xlb was kind of a gimmick to me and after having it ordered once, I'll stick to the little ones because they're just easier to eat! 

The steamed buns for dessert were good and I recommend those if nothing else.
author: Lisa K.

description:
This day literally could not have started on a better note - 1) we found amazing street parking steps from the restaurant after reading endless reviews about how street parking is hard to find 2) showed up on a Saturday around noon to a huge crowd waiting outside, but we waited about a total of 5 minutes since the only party of 2 ahead of us bounced so we got to take their spot! 3) they have chrysanthemum tea - YUM

This menu is HUGE and i'd definitely suggest going with a large group of people so you can try everything, but since the bf and i eat enough for about 6 people, we figured we could handle it. We ordered about $100 worth for the two of us after tip/tax:

- Shrimp Toast (6 piece) - crispy chinese donut with shrimp, topped with what seems like sriracha mayo and some cilantro

- Shrimp & Cilantro Har Gow (4 piece) - ugh the cilantro in this is next level

- Beijing Noodles - good, but i think next time i would stick with just the dumplings since this is more just a filler

- Char-Siu Bao (crispy) (3 piece) - pan seared bao is a game changer, definitely get these crispy! i will be back to try the other two options

- Pork XLB (6 piece) - SO. MUCH. SOUP. how is that even possible. the bf and i watched the lady making them at the front of the restaurant after our meal trying to learn her strategy

- Tom Yum Goong XLB (6 piece) - so different from the typical xlb, and such a pretty red wrapper! i think they said it was made of beet. i'm kind of a spice wimp and i did expect this to be a little spicy, but it's very mild so no need to steer clear of this one!

- Maine Lobster Siu Mai (4 piece) - yummmm, this has a hint of truffle but the flavor wasn't overwhelming at all

- Trio of Buns (Green Tea/Milk, Beet/Taro, and Egg Yolk) - GET THIS. i'm not a huge fan of beets or taro, but it was aight. the green tea milk and egg yolk though are incredible. Knowing that i could pass on the beet one i would just get an order of the green tea and an order of the egg yolk next time, but the trio is a great option for the first timer
author: Sam L.

description:
My boyfriend and I came to Dumpling Time for a Monday night dinner before we went to the Giants' game at AT&T Park. It was about 1/4 crowded when we got there at 5:30 pm, however when we finished eating at 6:45 pm, the restaurant was full! Definitely come early if you don't want to wait for a table. 

We ordered the following:
- Shrimp toast: Basically shrimp paste on a Chinese donut. Loved the spicy aioli on top! 
- Tom yun goong XLB: These XLBs came in beet infused dumpling wrappers. They were thinly wrapped with juicy insides! It had a different taste because of the coconut milk, but we liked it. I want to try the regular pork XLB next!
- Shrimp and pork siu mai: We thought these were less oily than your average dim sum place! They were pretty good, but didn't stand out. 
- Har gow: These were ultra rich from the cream cheese and we enjoyed them. 
- Three-sum: The dessert baos came in a trio: beet & taro, green tea & milk, and the classic egg yolk. Egg yolk was my favorite and beet & taro was my least favorite. I think the first word in the baos describes the bao bread and the second word describes the inside. I thought I would like the GT bao but the inside was purely milk flavored. Would def order the egg yolk bun again!

Service was extremely friendly and all the food came out really quick and steaming hot. Our total was about $45, but we also got hot green tea. 4 dishes was a good portion size for us. I would definitely come back!
author: Tara A.

description: Might be worth moving to California for ;) The shrimp toast is insanely good!!! It's fun how they bring things out at different times-also helps you not look like such a pig  Everything we had was great!
author: Lacey S.

description:
Like most Asian Fusion, Dumpling Time doesn't make the cut. Nice try dudes, nice try. The best dumpling was probably the Tom Yum Goong as it was the only one with flavor. Skip the baos, they are a huge dry disappointment. The best dish of the night was the shrimp toast - and I am fcking allergic to shrimp. 

Where are y'all getting your weed from, and what strains are you smoking because Dumpling Time is OVERRATED.
author: Susy C.

description:
My favorite dumpling restaurants in San Francisco.
Their "little dragon" dumplings are yummy, and almost as good as Ding Tai Fang in Taipei.
author: Tom L.

description: Great place to try out different kinds of dumplings. Service is very fast and ready for the busy lunch crowd from the surrounding businesses. Very nice people working there. A definite place to go back for lunch or dinner in the near future. Not cheap, but good food.
author: Kim F.

description: Short review: Dumpling Time is an awful value when it comes to dim sum but it's very non-Chinese speaker friendly, tries to infuse some unique spins on some dim sum favorites, and has both indoor and outdoor seating.  Constantly has Asian music videos in the background - pretty fun for people who have never seen them before.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Xian dumplings: not sure why they're called Xian dumplings since they tasted like regular pork and cabbage dumplings. It came with what can be described as a mini flower salad on top. 

Beijing noodles: the Chinese description said that this is jajangmyeon/zhajiang noodles but this definitely isn't, it's better described as minced pork and green onion over dry noodles. 

All in all, both dishes were good, just not in line with what I was expecting. 

Xiaolongbao: juicy as they should be. The soup inside was light and clean, and the pork was not too oily. A solid choice.
author: Norman S.

description:
I've had my fair share of XLB/soup dumplings and the regular sized ones (6/$8) at Dumpling Time are the best I've ever had. They are nearly perfect. I was a bit skeptical when I first saw them steamed individually in metal tins inside of steamer basket.  However, after one bite, I completely understood why and we ordered a second steamer of XLB.

XLB
- There is quite a bit of soup stuffed into each one, more juicy than many other XLBs at other restaurants. The soup itself is super flavorful.
- Most of the dumpling skin is a perfect thinness although the top part is a bit thicker where it bunches up. Note: the top does get a bit dry if you let it cool too long. 
- The filling has a smooth mouthfeel and there is a good amount inside of each dumpling.
- Overall great ratio of soup and filling to dumpling skin.

Other dishes
- We also chose to get the pickled lotus root and carrot salad, green beans, and the pan fried chicken baos. The pickling on the lotus root was very subtle but it was a nice crunchy side to have with the dumplings and bao. 
- The XLB were soo good that it really out shined the other dishes.  I really like the bao to filling ratio in the chicken bao, but the filling didn't have as much flavor as the XLB and since the XLB were so juicy, the bao filling seemed dry. The green beans were also underwhelming in flavor. Good thing theres soy sauce and chili oil on the table!

Seating
- My friend and I agreed to communal seating inside for a slightly shorter wait on a Sunday night. They also have outdoor seating with a much quieter setting than the indoor tables.

I'd definitely return to try their other dumpling offerings!
author: Yvonne K.

description:
Came here for lunch during one of our trips to San Francisco. I have been wanting to try something new and came across Dumpling Time during one of my yelp searches. Come early! We arrived at Dumping Time around 1030am and there was already two groups ahead of us. When you arrive, you can see that the workers at Dumpling Time are busy getting the restaurant ready for opening. You can see the chefs working nonstop making the dim sum items. They already have the list out for you to write your names on, which is great. 

Dumpling Time started seating people promptly at 1100am. Even though we came early, we noticed that everyone that got there as they opened were seated. So I guess you can get there at 1100am and it should be okay. They didn't seem super busy on a Saturday morning. They have indoor seating and outdoor seating. You will be able to to choose as long as there is both options available for you. They will also ask you if your whole party is present. 

We got a few things to try! We got their shrimp toast, char-sui bao, chicken bao, xiao long bao, tom yum goong, pork xian dumpling, and their trio of buns. 

Their shrimp toast was really delicious! It's pretty much a Chinese donut with shrimp paste on top. I thought they did this dish really well. I couldn't really taste the shrimp but the Chinese donut part is very savory. It had just the right amount of crunch and the aroma of it was so yummy. 

Their char-sui bao and chicken baos have the option of them steaming it or pan searing it. We got both with a pan sear and it gave it a nice crispy textured to the sides. The dough that they used for their bao was very good -- very soft. It was probably my favorite part of the baos. As for the inside, they're pretty normal to me. They should just have a dish of just plain pan seared baos .. I would totally order that! 

Their xiao long bao and tom yum goong were pretty similar in taste. The only difference was that the tom yum goong had a little bit of spice to them. But other than that, they're about the same. I probably wouldn't have been able to tell the difference if their wrappings weren't different. Both were pretty good. All of them were really juicy and none of our dumplings popped prior to reaching us! 

Their pork xian dumplings weren't that great. To me, they were quite bland even with the sauce that they provided. I had to use chili oil to give it some flavor haha! 

Their trio of buns were our dessert! It consisted of green tea and milk bun, egg yolk bun, and beet and taro bun. The egg yolk bun had an egg custard like filling inside and was the sweetest of the three. The green tea and milk bun had a very delicious aroma and was not too sweet at all. The beet and taro bun was yummy as well -- also not as sweet. I think my favorite was the green tea one. The egg yolk bun was too sweet. And the beet and taro bun was so so. 

The price seems average but it does seem pricier than regular, traditional dim sum. I was super stuffed after lunch. We ended up spending $80 for all of that food. I'm not sure if I'd want to go back since there are so many other choices in San Francisco for dim sum....but if I was in the area, I would definitely go for a trio of green tea buns!
author: Doriee D.

description:
My review is based off of coming in July 2017, near the time when they first opened.

This is a nice place to visit if you're a fan of dumplings with a twidge of bougie plating.

Either my friend overhyped Dumpling Time or I didn't feel like it was worth it because you can literally get the same flavor and quality at other dimsum restaurants. I don't think the amount of food that you're getting is worth the higher price you're paying either.

I was definitely expecting some spectacular tasting XLBs that would've blown my taste buds away based on everyone else's reviews, but I feel like I've had the same taste at other dumpling or dim sum places. I guess what was unique about the experience was that the plating was super nice and extra (ahem, the secret recipe). Unfortunately I don't think I'll come here again unless a friend is DYING to try this place ... and even then I'd still probably recommend going somewhere else.

|Beet XLB| -- Beautiful reddish color to the dumpling skin. My boyfriend did point out that the skin was thicker than other places like DTF, so it didn't wow him. This tasted like any other XLB, so I don't think it was worth the price or wait.

|Mother's Secret Recipe| -- I thought the dumplings were small and that the majority of the dish was a bed of nicely cut onions, leaves, and peppers that only added color to the dish. 

|Seafood Gyoza| -- I was expecting more cause it was labeled "seafood" gyoza, but it should've just been labeled "Shrimp Gyoza" because that's all I tasted. The shrimp flavor is similar to getting hao gao at dimsum restaurants. The green skin is different, but doesn't enhance the flavor or anything. I did appreciate the sauces accompanying the dish.

TIP: If you're here early, definitely take a peek inside the place and ask if you can put your name down before the rush of people come. Thanks to the chef who had at let me write my name down even before 5PM when they opened for dinner :)

My meal was honestly fine until the very end. I had just started attempting to calculate how much tip I wanted to leave until employees were all up in my face trying to clean up the table. I understand you're trying to be efficient and prepare for the next pair of people to sit, but I literally just received my check. It didn't help that the waiter also grabbed the plate with dumplings I was planning on taking home. I didn't even get a chance to ask for a box because they were LITERALLY rushing to just take everything off the table. Luckily I was still able to salvage it before he ran off to dump the plate.

Although the King XLB sounds compelling and is Snapchat/IG worthy, the price did not seem worth it to me. 

TLDR: Expect to pay at least $20 per person if you're hungry because each dish is around $9. The dumplings are on the pricey for what you're getting since you can get the same flavor at other XLB restaurants or dimsum places. If you're into more bougie plating and presented dumplings, then I guess this place could be for you. Cute modern looking restaurant with parking spots. Come early to put your name down.
author: Jackie H.

description:
On a Sunday for lunch, there were 6-7 groups ahead of us (party of 3) but it was only a 15-20 min wait. The service is very quick and I noticed that people are generally in and out of the restaurant quickly as well.

Pork XiaoLongBao (3.5 stars) // juicy and flavorful!

Tom Yum XiaoLongBao (3.5 stars) // more juicy than the regular XLB, much sweeter broth, You can't taste the Tom Yum flavor until you bite into the meat of the dumpling.

Seared Pork Bao (3.5 stars) // The bun is slightly sweet, which makes it better than the tasteless bun of the Chicken Bao. The meat and cabbage in the bao are lightly salted, I think it would taste much better with more salt/soy sauce in the marinade. 

Seafood Gyoza (4 stars) // Wonderful crisp shrimp enveloped by spinach wrap as the gyoza skin, perfectly paired with the mayo dipping sauce. 

Three-Sum (3.5 stars) // I tried the green tea bun and it was good! Milk filling was not too sweet and the bun left a slightly sweet and bitter matcha flavor. The beet bun has a taro filling and plan steam bun has a custard filling.

Beijing Noodles (2.5 stars) //  Very underwhelming, small-portioned and overpriced ($9.5). This dish was very oily, and lacking in flavor and ingredients from other zhajiangmian that I've had before.

Food is pretty tasty here and generally reasonably priced.
author: Amy T.

description:
Planning on coming back :) this place is a little out of reach (not close to bart) - recommend driving or ubering over. 

We ordered the shrimp toast, char siu bao, pork XLB, and Beijing noodles. 

My favorite is probably the shrimp toast (5/5) - it's an interesting modern twist on a traditional Taiwanese breakfast staple (you tiao/Chinese donut) combined with a traditional dim sum ingredient - shrimp. 

Also liked the char siu Bao and pork XLB. My least favorite was the Beijing noodles - very underwhelming. The noodles were too oily, and there was too much green onions and not much other ingredients/topping to add variety.

Service was really good. Our food was out hot and fresh within 15 minutes of placing the order! 

Portions were a bit on the smaller size, but decently priced compared to other dim sum places in sf. It was enough food for the four of us though! 

Didn't get to try the happy endings (dessert Bao's) - coming back for that next time.
author: Valerie T.

description:
I had a week long dumpling craving that was finally satisfied. Liked the food but the service was horrible. I'd say it's one of the better dumpling places in SF that won't kill your wallet. Still not going to match up to places in LA (cheap and amazing), but it satisfied my cravings. 

Service and setting: the restaurant itself is ok. It's not nice for a date spot or anything, but large and patio seating. What killed me was the service. They made us wait in freezing cold when 3/4 people were there, we said we would order, and they weren't even busy (plenty of tables). Super slow, not very polite... when we wanted a dessert menu (all food clearly finished) I waved my arms and they all ignored / weren't bothering to check. There's also no where to put any bags / coats so they constantly knocked over my bag tucked in the seat 2/5. 

Food: really saved the experience for me so it was worth the poor service. I wouldn't spend money on noodles based off what I had. We had a minced beef dry noodles (one of my fav dishes) but I wasn't impressed, just salty and not much else. Veggie (I think) dumplings with tons of excessive garnish. Probably to draw the sf hipsters... lol. Those were good though. Also awesome and definitely would order again include seafood gyoza, xlb, har gow, shumai. The skin was not as chewy and delicate as I'd like but fillings were awesome and overall super satisfied. Milk bun was also a nice sweet finish but wouldn't say it's a must have. TLDR save your money for dumplings 4/5

I will definitely be back when the next craving hits and hopefully the service won't suck next time.
author: Anna N.

description:
I popped my giant soup dumpling cherry here! 

The XL xiao long bao takes 15 mins to cook so it's best to order that immediately and then decide on what else you want to add to the order. The regular sized xiao long baos come in 6 pieces and mini aluminum trays like the ones used for egg tarts.  

For 6 girls, we ordered 5 XL soup dumpings, 2 regular pork soup dumplings, 1 tom yum goong, seafood gyoza, gan ban noodles, shrimp & cilantro har gow, shrimp toast, and cucumber chili salad. It was the perfect amount of food that we completely finished minus some remenants of the XL soup dumplings that the girls didn't finish.  

I must admit that the XL soup dumping is a little overrated.  The soup was good but the texture of the meat/veggie was much different than the regular soup dumplings.  I definitely prefer the regular ones over the XL.  As for the pork vs tom yum goong, I can't really decide since I only had 1 piece of the tom yum goong.  

My next favorite item was the seafood gyoza.  There are real pieces of quality seafood in it and were not minced so finely that you can't tell what you're eating. The cucumber salad was meh because it wasn't marinated long enough. 

We didn't have room for dessert but I would have liked to try the trio buns.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Normally, I am a "china town" style dumpling & dim sum place kind of person. You know, the food is only good when it is served out of a crappy looking restaurant with staff that can barely say "Hi" & "Hello" and following with a full lengthy cantonese chat that I have know idea what is going on. It's authentic I guess. 
Recently, I am a bit more open to "Urban" kind of Asian food. I think SF and the food quality has changed me a little. 
I believe you can still have some yummy, delicious and authentic food at some up & trendy places. 

I'm glad that dumpling time SF has what it takes to win my 5 stars on Yelp 

The wait:15-20 mins for a party of 2. Reasonably short & it's next to BoConcept so I can just walk next door and kill my time and my credit card 

The restaurant: There's outdoor seatings & indoor. Such a cute place with good taste in furniture choice & murals. I loved their neon signs. I genuinely love places that know how to use neon signs. Owners have good taste, You'll get good food.

The food: I'm Asian & a snob with my dumplings so I am not a big fan of the GIGANTIC xiao long bao (big soupy dumpling that you have to use the straw to it -$8) I like my petite cute little dumplings that I can hold with my chopsticks & Instagram it. 

I am really impressed with the Shrimp Toast - O.M.G. I have a huge obsession with chinese donut bread & seafood so you know this dish is hitting me hard to my Spot! Ohhhh yeah..

We ordered Beijing Noodle (this is not a soupy kind, this is the dry nooodle) with ground pork & special mix dressing. This is delicious as well. 

We went on a serious food coma & we didnt damage our pocket. We paid around $20/person including tips so I think it's reasonable fir a brunch date in the city. 

By the way - this place is Instagramable AF. Way to show off your brunch & make people envy your life. Muahaha.
author: Thao P.

description:
FOOD:
I ordered the Xiang hai dumpling, xiao long bao, the 7 piece and the XXL Xiao Long Bao. Honestly the big one was only worth it for the first time; after that, I don't think it's worth it. It was pretty good but I prefer the smaller ones only because it was easier to take a bite out of. Overall, the soup and the meat and the skin was delicious. Would definitely go back again. 

SERVICE:
The service was really great. They have a really long line, so I suggest going early. I came during opening and we had to wait at least 45 min. The building is nice and very spacious. 

ATMOSPHERE:
There are outside tables and inside tables. Both places are open and very spacious. It was overall a fun place. They also have a giant tv that's fun to watch.
author: Matt C.

description:
This is the place you bring your non-Asian friends when they're like "this is authentic, right?" or on the complete opposite side, your traditional Asian parents for some special occasion like graduation or whatever.

Was around the area for dinner time, and boo and I wanted something share-able and Asian. Most Asians who are AB-whatever don't usually eat dim sum in the PM. We tend to get our dim sum in the morning, so when I saw this place was open for dinner I thought...we need to try it! We were in the mood for dumplings, and with a name like Dumpling Time, we knew we'd be set. My friend had yelped this spot before and highly recommended the Shrimp toast and now I'm telling you--order it. You won't regret it even though it sounds funky. It's basically you tiao (AKA chinese donut) and delicious shrimp and cheese I believe. Just try it. We also ordered the veggie dumplings, siu mai, and boo got the famous XLB and pan-seared fluffy pork bao too. After you order, the server puts your items on a receipt paper list and keep it at your table--exactly like what daytime dim sum spots do. At the end of dinner, we both walked out completely full and filled with delicious flavors. 

There is a restroom in the back part of the restaurant--very clean and easily accessible. Parking is easy to find and pretty safe being in the Design district. We only waited about 15-25 minutes for dinner on a Sunday before getting seated which was pretty great for prime dinner time. I'd suggest instead of pen and paper waitlist, have the cell phone text/call service. It gets cold waiting outside in the evening, so getting us connected and texting us when our table is ready is a fab idea. The ambiance is dimly lit and cool--feels like I'm in Hong Kong with yuppies. They play Asian music videos on the projector screen wall, and have outdoor seating too (I think heated). Very family and group-friendly!

I'd say if you're coming here for dim sum, it's definitely not as diverse in variety, but the quality is awesome. It's tastier and a bit larger in portion/bite sizes compared to spots like the infamous Din Tai Fung (I don't like the DTF's in the Bay Area), so I'd definitely come back again. In terms of dumplings, yes the skin is delicious and I've had better inside stuffings for veg...but they plate their food with a more "hip" aspect with microgreens and little accents that make this a younger, fresher, SF-vibe dim sum spot.
author: Jodi H.

description:
Came here again and we had a great meal - changing my rating to a 4/5. I think it's because we ordered better items! Still a little pricey to get full, but the dumplings are hot and delicious.

Recommended items:
Tom yum xlb (and regular xlb)
Veggie xian dumplings
Seafood gyoza
Shrimp toast
Crispy tofu squares

Meh items:
Giant xlb
Shumai 
Pork buns
Beijing noodles
author: Michelle R.

description:
We tried out this place after passing by many times and it always has a crowd waiting outside. Take out orders might be faster than dining in.

The food were excellent! Seared baos are phenomenal! The searing adds a smoky dimension to the buns, mmm so yum! Gyozas were delicious, crispy on the outside and gingerly on the inside. Siu mai tasted very fresh and succulent. Noodles were pretty good, lots of oil but it wasn't greasy. Shrimp toast was something new to both of us, and we are not new to dim sums. It's essentially shrimp paste on youtiao (Chinese donut), the sauce ties in the combination, pretty good.

You can see the staff making dumplings on the left side just inside the front entrance too. Will be coming back for quality dim sum!
author: YY M.

description:
Highly overrated. This would not be one of my top places for XLB or dumplings! Overpriced, bad service (like horrid), and although the food might be photographable, I would say it's mediocre at best. 

I came here with a group of five for dinner. After an hour wait, we were seated. The place is loud with music videos and things playing from a projection on a wall. The video kept malfunctioning and replaying so it was very distracting and no one bothered to fix it. We ordered an assortment of gyoza, dumplings, xiao long baos, and trio dessert buns. The xi'an dumplings were presented beautifully in a very modern, classy, and highly instagrammable way. I recall them tasting great as well - but that's the extent of how much the dishes stuck out to me. The xiao long baos were underwhelming in flavor and the gyoza and the rest of the dumplings were really nothing special in my book to warrant the $6-7 price tag for five pieces or $9 for the tom yum goong xlb. It's kind of ridiculous.

The service was horrendous. Maybe they were still trying to get it together - but the wait staff were primarily concentrating on just taking the orders and checking them off the list when they arrived, then scurrying off as quickly as humanly possible. There was no feeling of customer service besides that, it actually felt almost rude. Trying to flag someone down for water was an impossibility. The staff walked around so fast and even with our hands raised, trying to make eye contact - it probably took us at least 20 minutes to finally get someone to give us a refill on our empty bottles. We literally had a game going on trying to make eye contact with someone, anyone, walking around. It was almost like the staff were trained not to address any issues outside of taking orders and delivering them.  

My favorite thing about this restaurant was the trio of milk buns which were honestly, quite delicious. However, if your name clearly indicates a specialty in dumplings and the best thing was the milk buns - there may be something amiss! Thanks but no thanks, I don't think I'll be recommending the place to others.
author: Deanna S.

description:
Dumpling Time was great! It was nice to see a menu full of items to choose from. They have a variety of dumplings as well as cooked vegetables, interesting sides and noodles.

We shared the following:

-Garlicky Green Beans
-Chicken Bao (Seared)
-Gan Ban Noodles
-Chicken Gyoza
-Pork Xiao Long Bao (Soup dumpling)

Everything ranged from good to excellent. My favorite dish was probably the Chicken Bao. The chicken tasted great with savory seasonings and balanced with the slight sweetness from the bun and topped-off with nice flavor from the sear. The XLB (soup dumplings) were also very good...savory and rich in flavor.

This is a popular spot so try arriving a bit early. The service was good and friendly.
author: Ken G.

description: Dumpling time is one of those Americanized dim sum places similar to yang sink. I am less of a fan than my boyfriend is (who loves Americanized Asian food.) When I went, they were out of the massive soup dumplings so that was a bummer. We had the edamame, pork gyoza, lobster shumai, regular soup dumplings, shrimp haw gao, shrimp toast, and three sum. All of the food was good but nothing blew me away as being so much better than normal dim sum as to justify the noticeably higher price (I guess it's cleaner?) I think the most memorable dish for me was the three sum (which was one of each dessert bun.) There was a green tea bun that was delicious. I was less impressed with the shrimp toast and the lobster shumai... probably would not orders those again. All in all, the food was fine but not necessarily worth the price. That being said, my bf LOVES this place so... YMMV.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
In my wildest dreams,  every day would be DUMPLING TIME! But in this case, I guess 2 hours is enough to get your dumpling fix on! The Omakase Group (the geniuses behind Michelin star sushi bar Omakase) offers beautiful dishes and a wonderful ambiance with this new restaurant. I recently went here for brunch and here are some highlights: 

Starters:
Cucumber and Fresno Chili Salad ($5) - very refreshing and subtle chili and sesame flavor! 

Chicken Fillings (All of these dishes practically have the same filling - only difference is the dough):
Chicken Gyoza (5 pc/$7) - Slightly pan fried with delicious dough and great texture from the shiitake mushrooms. 
Chicken Bao (3 pc/$5.5) - Same taste as Gyoza but lots of filling! 

Shrimp Dishes: 
Shrimp Toast (6 pc/$9) - basically a Chinese donut with shrimp and a nice paste with it. 
Shrimp Har Gow & Shrimp and Chive Har Gow (4 pc/$6) - we made the mistake in ordering both. I suggest just getting the chive one! 

Pork Lovers: 
XLB (6 pc/$8) - probably one of the best I've had and would even say it's better than Din Tai Fung. 
King Dum (1 pc/$8) - Only good for pictures to be honest. Basically a Ginormous XLB, I didn't even know what to do with it after I drank the soup. 
Xi'an Dumpling (8 pc/$9) - beautiful presentation and the dumplings go well with all the greens. 

In addition to the dim sum, they make their own Beijing noodles, but they are not as good as everything else. I highly suggest getting a beer with your meal and coming before 12 pm if you're coming on a weekend! 

Just to note: The prices of some of the reviews have changed by 2 dollars so this is the most recent as of 8/19/17
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
Mixed feelings about Dumpling Time. It's very trendy at the moment, so our group of 4 waited about an hour for a table; with all the foot traffic, I had really high expectations! 

There are a few things on the menu that rock and are 100% worth getting: the seafood gyoza and the tom yum goong XLB (basically tom yum soup in a xiao long bao - genius). We ordered an extra round of the seafood gyoza because it was so good! The "King-Dum" that has been sensationalized on social media is worth getting at least once, but honestly the ratio of meat to soup to skin was off, and our poor king-dum fell apart within the first bite. 

The other options are pretty standard dumpling restaurant items at about 2-3x the price point for on par or even slightly below par quality. I'd probably skip those items in favor of somewhere in Chinatown, but Dumpling Time is definitely worth at least one visit!
author: Denise L.

description: Excellent spot for dumpling lovers. I think this place is more fusion than authentic as the prices are a little higher, but the food here is delicious! The XLB were smaller than I've had at other places but definitely filled my craving. Also tried some pork baos and edamame. The best part was the dessert though - the dessert baos were so soft and yummy.
author: Cheng X.

description: A long wait but the line went by fast. Food was served very quick. I will come back again - it's tasty, but not necessarily the top of the line dumplings I've had.
author: Gloria T.

description:
3.5/5 Rounding up for nice service

Coming from the (extremely) Asian part of Socal and being raised by a mother who basically only eats dumplings and vegetables I tend to be picky about my dumplings. That being said, I came in with the expectation of an Asian Fusion take on dumplings and prices that aren't exactly traditional (aka cheap). I got exactly what I expected but was pleasantly surprised by the actual flavors (though I did avoid ordering any extremely traditional items). Parking in the area wasn't too bad (plenty of street parking since it's kind of an off the main road area). For a Monday I was surprised there was any wait but there were a few people in line. We were seated very quickly though.

My friend and I were only looking for a super small dinner so this place was perfect. We ordered the following:

1) Shrimp Toast: Basically you tiao with shrimp on top and I'm not mad about it at all (ok I'm a bit upset by the $8 price) but it's an oil soaked delicious experience. (4/5)

2) Shrimp Cilantro Har Gow: I'm not the biggest Shrimp Har Gow person but the addition of the pork and cilantro was exactly what this dish has been missing. The skin itself was a bit thick but fine. (4/5)

3) King Dum XLB: These have been popping all around the internet and I just needed to try it for myself. I'm happy they were actually able to get a decent tasting soup in here but overall it's definitely a try once and never again item. The skin is very thick and the interior isn't anything special. I was very surprised that it's actually a good deal smaller than I thought. It's about the size of your palm but surprisingly shallow. The waitress recommended each person order their own because it's hard to share. We weren't hungry enough to do so but I agree (3/5)

Overall Dumpling Time was exactly what my friend and I were looking for that night, somewhere between a takeout booth and a proper full set restaurant meal. The flavors were good though the prices were a bit steep. Just come in knowing what to expect. Also from the look of the XLB, I'd probably avoid them and try some of their other items.
author: Vivian C.

description:
A rare 5 star review. Why you ask?  It is perfect for what it is. I went 6:30 on a Wednesday and while not slammed there was a wait for larger tables. Once my friend arrived we were seated immediately on the heated patio. You can see the chefs preparing the dumplings through a glass window.

We shared soup dumplings, snap peas, seafood pot stickers, lobster dumplings and standard pork dumplings. EVerything was above average and below average price. We shared a $15 bottle of Jumai Ginjo sake which was great for the money. For dessert, steamed buns with sweetened egg yolk and vanilla. Let me say I typically hate this dessert but I loved it here. Service was excellent and friendly. Highly recommended.
author: Jordan C.

description: My cousins took me here for my birthday. THE DIM SUM IS REALLY GOOD. We pretty much tried everything on the menu and everyhing was delicious. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!
author: Foodie Sushi Q.

description:
Dumpling Time is definitely a great introduction to dim sum for other ethnicities besides Chinese people. They offer modern, yet traditional dishes such as siu mai, har gow, XLB, etc. 

Personally, I think Dumpling Time is overrated. It's cool to see the chefs prepare the XLB, neon signs and cute decor, but all that is meaningless when the food is sub-par. The food is mediocre and very expensive for what it is. $6 for 4 pieces of siu mai?? What?? $6.50 for 3 char siu baos?! Crazy pricing for such mediocre food and that's my biggest concern with Dumpling Time. I hope people of all ethnicities eventually try traditional dim sum because that's where the good stuff is at.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
Heard about this place somewhere on an online video and totally wanted to try it sometime!

Came here on a weekend around 12 and there was a LONG line so we decided to just come back a different day.

Later on next week we decided to go on a sunday and since they open at 11am we decided to get there by 10:30 and camp out lol so that we would be part of the first batch of people to get in. Closer to 11am they bring out a sign in sheet which was covenient.

Seating: Few tables outside, and tables inside (we went with the outside seating and we were seated right next to the window where you could see them making everything, cool!)

Service: Nice and fast. Only thing I didn't like was the food came out one by one. It would have been nice if it all came out together.

Food: Ordered green beans, shrimp & cilantro har gow, pork dumpling, pork soup dumpling, pork bao, chicken gyoza = $50+ 

Price: Definitely pricey for dim sum, small portion for the price

Taste: Some items were really good but some were not worth it. What stood out to move was how soft their pork bao was, har gow was really as well because of the freshness, and the dumpling was tastey as well.

Overall: Food was good and fresh but pricey!!!
author: Michele G.

description:
I was in with a group of 3 for lunch on a Wednesday afternoon. It was packed for a Wednesday but worth the 20+ minute wait. Though after we got seated, it took awhile to get our orders placed. 

Food: the food was good though it was Americanized. No push carts but served a menu of options. We ordered a variety from noodles, xiao long baos, pot stickers to dumplings. Each dish had its unique taste, so that was good. The portion sizes on the noodles however were ridiculous. It was practically done in 3 bites. 

Presentation: the king dum was worth the hype and wait. My favorite were the baos. They come steamed and pan seared. They both were great! 

Location was a bit far from fidi. It's a bit of a trek out there so plan yourself. They were able to split 3 cards, so that was awesome too.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Got here around 6:20 pm on a Friday and was told our wait would be 45 min to 1 hour for a party of 8, so my friends and I went across the street to Saap Ver for a quick drink.

Unfortunately by the time we came back to Dumpling Time around 7, we were told that our name had already been called and skipped, so we had to re-add our name to the list again. This time we all stuck around and waited since we didn't want to miss it again. I wish they would let you leave a number when putting down your name.

Since we were a group of 8, we tried almost everything on the menu. There's too much to focus on every single item, but I'll give the highlights of the meal. Overall, the food was good but felt really bland across the board. It wasn't just me but everyone at the table who thought this.

A more in depth review on some of the items (* means recommended):

*Seafood gyoza: we tried the chicken and pork gyoza too but the seafood was the clear winner here. We all liked this so much we got a second round 

Pork bao: good but bland

Xi'an dumpling: it's good but pricey for what you get. Also it comes served with salad covering it so it doesn't even look like a dumpling dish

*Pork XLB: everything was perfect about the XLB (the thin-ness of the skin, the amount of soup, the tenderness of the pork) except that it was too bland. I'm hoping this isn't a consistent problem but just a problem with the dumplings on the night we went

Tom yum goong: Thai style XLB with pork belly, shrimp, and coconut milk in a beet skin. I think this dish is more for the gram; I wasn't super impressed with the taste 

*Trio of buns: great way to end the meal with a selection of their green tea, egg yolk, and taro bun. My favorite was the taro

They were out of the giant XLB (King-dum) by the time we were seated and ordered, which was a bummer. I didn't realize this was a possibility, so watch out for that!

The total came out to around $26 pp after tax and tip, which wasn't too bad for how much food we ordered. I would definitely recommend coming with a larger group so you can share family style and try more options.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Holy Toledo. I love dumplings. 

My friend and I ventured over here on a Sunday afternoon around 1pm and I was just hoping that the wait wasn't going to be insane. Dumpling Time is located on the outskirts of San Francisco, an area that I've rarely ventured to and when I did I was just surprise because one side had apartment complexes and the other side looked the complete opposite, but dang. Their food is good. 

They have about 4-5 spots outside this place, metered parking across the street and around the block has some time zone areas, too. Luckily it was a Sunday so my friend and I parked at a meter spot about a block away without having to worry about paying for it. The inside seems like a pretty good size, with seating outside as well. Bathrooms located all the way to the back. 

We were seated within 10 minutes of waiting I want to say? So it wasn't bad and it definitely goes by fast so don't worry too much about a long line. The menu for this place is also super simple, limited options under each category and sadly, they were out of the King Dum XLB when we got here so that's on my to do list for next time.. right next to waking up early for it. 

We ordered the regular pork XLB, tom yum XLB, seared char siu bao, shrimp har gow, pork gyoza, seared pork bao, and trio buns for dessert. Everything was good besides the seared pork bao. Pork was just too stiff to bite into, definitely get the char siu one over those. But everything else was delicious, except food does take a while to come out so you're gonna have to be patient. 

Between 2 people, we spent $53 and that's not too bad. Would totally come back again when I can.
author: Venus L.

description:
"I expect my dim sum restaurants to be grimier" - Chinese friend.

The Xiao Long Bao's arrived in little tin foils designed to catch any amount of poppage and drippage. Designer t-shirts and well-kept shoes were saved against the onslaught of porky soup. For myself, I have come to expect every third XLB to be just an absolute wreckage. At Dumpling Time - this wasn't the case.

The pork dumplings sat like a layer of top-soil beneath a garden of red peppers, green sprouts, and white radishes. The garden looked so well-organized that I felt compelled to delicately pick away at the flowers until I reached the fresh food below rather than to violently scoop down and unearth the soil.

Sesame seeds carefully dotted the tops of the green beans which came out in a boat-shaped dish. A communal spoon and fork slid beneath the veggies to provide a specific sense of decency, reflecting a set of preferences not-often doled out in dim sum restaurants.

Shu mai, har gow, Beijing noodles, pork ribletts all were served with a similar amount of decoration and pomp, and all tasted great.

Ultimately, the taste of Dumpling Time was on point. Yet, the presentation and the ambiance created a version of dim sum just a bit more groomed than a feeling of home.

Oh and...the Har Gow is a solid 9/10.
author: Willy X.

description: My experience here was quite enjoyable. The wait time was very quick for such a popular restaurant. We enjoyed superb dumplings and gyoza while we eat there. I highly recommend the pork dumplings, as well as the garlic noodles. Not to mention, the atmosphere is quite nice, almost welcoming if you will. I will most certainly come back again. This is would be an all time favorite restaurant for me. 10/10 would eat again.!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Great location near my house and fairly easy parking but the service is inattentive and the food meh.  It would have been better to order at a counter.  Decor is like a cafeteria. 

Cucumber salad: ok for what it is but nothing special 
Crispy vegetarian rolls: sent back, oily and hardly any vegetables the sauce was tasteless
Chicken gyoza: bland and thick dough
Shrimp dumplings: very watery and filling fell out of the casings 

Mediocre, and while fairly cheap just not worth coming back to.
author: Inga W.

description:
If this restaurant was a person, it would be the love child of a first generation Chinese American and a hipster from Portland. 

I don't know if I would say the food is authentic or not. It definitely has authentic influences, but it obviously has a modern fusion take on it. I like that it is pushing the boundaries of what Chinese food looks like, esp to non-Chinese people. The interior is hipster, with some communal tables and unique glassware. The projected K-pop stuff on the wall was weird and distracting. 

For two we had:
- shrimp toast $8 (my favorite dish of the night, greasy though)
- Beijing noodle $9 (my least favorite. Not bad, just bland and average) 
- king-dum $8 (cute gimmick decorated with edible flowers. I took the pic, then plucked the flowers right off. I am not going to eat dumplings with flowers on them. It goes against my Chinese blood!)
- pork XLB $8 (solid XLB. Soup nicely sealed inside. Served with red vinegar.)
- tom yum XLB $9 (tasted pretty much identical to the pork XLB. Pretty with the red skin, but I couldn't taste the coconut milk)

Everything tasted okay. Everything was presented beautifully. It is pricey for what it is, especially since dumplings are considered "cheap Chinese food". Luckily, when we arrived at 6, we snagged the last open seats without a wait. But when we left, there was a good crowd waiting outside. Parking is not bad at all. 

Last comment, each little XLB has a foil cupcake liner. I know, it prevents sticking so you can have the optimum amount of soup.. but I hope they can think of an alternative. I don't want piles of them to go straight to landfill.
author: Kim W.

description:
My go to dim sum spot in SOMA. They are very close to authentic chinese/Cantonese cuisine. I'm from Beijing and the best way I can describe this is that they serve traditional Chinese dishes with a small twist, aimed at a younger crowd. They incorporate ingredients like mayo, Tom yum soup(and its ingredients), and peanut butter, which are great additions but are not used in traditional Chinese cuisine.  

We loved everything we've tried: Sautéed and gingered snap peas, pickled lotus root, shrimp toast, shrimp and cilantro har row, pork XLB, and Tom yum XLB. Each dim sum comes with it's own sauce which compliment each other quite well. My husband and I definitely over ordered and were so stuffed afterwards we could barely walk. 

Tips:
1. They don't take reservations or do takeout or delivery. Come at an off hour or plan to wait for 15-30 minutes. 
2. They have a covered outdoor patio for people with dogs.
author: Tata X.

description:
Came around 1pm on a Saturday. Tried asking the hostess how long the wait was but she just kept telling me the same thing - "We're setting up some tables; please put your name down." Ok, but I want to know how long the wait is before I put my name down!! So that was a little annoying. Once we were actually seated, less than 15 minutes later (why couldn't she have just told me this??) we ordered:

Shrimp toast - the "toast" is Chinese cruller, and it's more of a shrimp paste- this was a little too heavy
Pork gyoza - Very nicely fried, this was #2 fave
Pork xi'an dumpling - bland, lacking
Tom yum goong XLB - #1 fave, loved the flavor (fell apart a bit though, so I just slurped it straight from the tin foil

Hit or miss, depending what you order. Don't really like the snooty attitude they have- would much rather eat more authentic food at a homestyle restaurant elsewhere.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Yikes...

After waiting about an hour for a table for four, we were sat down at a table outside this Cal-Asian bistro where we could watch the dumpling makers roll out the dough and craft their food. That was also probably the highlight of the entire meal.

I came into dinner thinking it was going to be some Din Tai Fung quality dumplings but everything just came out bland and needing copious dipping into vinegar, soy sauce, or chili to make it palatable.

The xiao long bao's were pretty decent but if you're really going for that "edgy and hip" dining experience here, get the tom yun goong XLB wrapped in a beet flavored skin. It's a great switch up both taste wise and for your food picture aesthetic.

Everything else just sort of fell through as mentioned above. The har gow, pork dumplings, seafood gyoza, and Beijing noodles. They were all just missing flavors you'd come to expect from these dishes.

The price point for the amount that we've ordered was also a little disproportionate too. You're better off heading to Alameda or elsewhere for some quality dumplings.
author: Jonathan N.

description:
TL;DR: if you're willing to travel a bit for dim sum, go to Dim Sum King in Daly City.  If you're willing to travel a lot, Din Tai Fung in San Jose is still the best.  Otherwise, you're outta luck and should come here. :p

So first of all this place is buuuusy.  We came Sunday at ~2pm (they close at 3) hoping the crowds have cleared, but it was still a 30-40 min wait!  Luckily when they say they close at 3 they actually mean last call at 3, so we were able to eat comfortably.

Now, about the food... I was super excited about a dim sum place opening since there aren't any others nearby!  The menu is definitely much smaller than a standard dim sum menu, but have all the major dishes.  So we got:

-Shrimp toast: it's literally 5 shrimps on Chinese doughnut cut into 5 equal lengths.  If you like shrimp and Chinese doughnut, you'll probably like this.  For me, it was too greasy.

-Seaweed salad: fresh, vinegary, strong garlic flavor - loved it.

-XLB: very good; thin skin, good soup, and a great meaty flavor!  Not as good as Ding Tai Fung of course, but still very good.  Came with a red vinegar (?) sauce that didn't taste like anything

-Shrimp har gow: this was the worst har gow I've ever had.  The shrimp was clearly very, very poor quality.  It was obviously frozen, watery, and the meat tasted like it was slightly disintegrating.  It also tasted milky... overall it was just disgusting.  I usually love har gow but will never get it here again.  It also came with a creamy parsley sauce?

-fried pork buns: the "fried" part didn't really come through, other than that fluffy outside, good filling, I'll probably get it not fried next time.

-seafood gyoza: not crispy at all, skin was a bit dough-y, almost undercooked.  The inside, was basically all the same disgusting har gow shrimp

-for those looking for king dim... it's not always available :(

And then the other weird stuff... so this is clearly a Chinese dim sum place, but all the utensils were clearly Japanese.  A lot of the dim sum had non-traditional sauce on it like mayonnaise and butter.  The TV is playing K-pop.  Not a deal breaker, but just kinda weird.

Overall, the place is just meh.  It's only popular because there aren't any other dim sum alternatives nearby lol.  But if you're willing to travel a bit go to Dim Sum King in Daly City - it's soooooo much better and less pricy.  And of course DTF is still the best dim sum place to go :)

I may come back if I'm suuper craving dim sum and suuuper lazy haha.
author: Jeannie Z.

description: 1st time here, loved it! We pretty much had 1 of everything, not joking...I think there was maybe 4 or 5 things we didn't try. In a group of 4 we put away a lot. You get what you pay for, and I don't mind the price tag when the food was that good! The pork belly bun was my personal favorite for the entree while the egg yolk bun was my favorite...try all 3 dessert buns...worth it to find out what is your favorite! The waiters messed up our order but it was a happy accident because it gave us time to pace ourselves and make room for more. Overall really happy with service, food and the atmosphere. Would make a trip to SF just for this place!
author: Andrew M.

description:
Came here for a "small lunch" on my most recent trip to SF with some friends. This place is located in like the "arts district" or according to google maps, "Design District". Depending on which way you are coming from, you may not see it so easily. Their sign is blocked in one way by their exterior seating. The restaurant opens at 11AM but people will start signing up on the list at probably 1030AM or so. Parking is fairly ample but you see a lot of people arriving by Uber/Lyft. We were like the 2nd or 3rd group to arrive. They started seating people promptly at 11AM.

After being seated, of course we referred to Yelp for some suggestions. Shrimp toast and Trio of Buns were one of the top recommendations so thats what we got and a few other things 

Shrimp Toast ($8)

Unlike the typical "toast", this shrimp toast uses "you tiao/yao tiu", a traditional chinese breakfast favorite which is like a chinese donut. The shrimp is a paste of chopped shrimp lined inbetween the groove you'd typically see in you tiao. The shrimp had a pretty good texture and flavor. Unfortunately the you tiao was cold and not that crispy. If they were able to keep it crispy and warm, it would be great ! 4/5 rating 

Chicken Bao (3pc/$5.5) - Chicken ,green onion, wood ear mushroom, ginger
Char-Siu Bao (3pc/$6) - Char-siu roast pork belly, touch of peanut butter
Bao may also be ordered crispy (pan seared)

The baos were pretty tasty. The char-siu pork was actually fairly light in flavor. The chicken reminded me of the "big buns" i get with meat filled. Both were pretty nice in flavor. The bao itself was soft. Not as chewy i had hoped for in a well made bun. Doesn't give that "bounce". 4/5 rating ! 

Pork Xi'An Dumpling (8pc/$9) - Pork, cabbage, green onion decorated with thinly sliced radish, micro greens 

The xi'an dumpling, despite the pretty presentation in a bowl, was probably the most disappointing of them all. Dumpling was a bit plain in flavor and the xi'an sauce was a bit plain in flavor as well. As with all their other stuff, the wrapping is self-made in-house. 2/5 rating

King-Dum Xiao Long Bao (1pc/$8) - Soup dumpling large enough that you'll need a straw
Pork XLB (6pc/$8) - Pork belly, savory soup, shao-sing wine
Tom Yum Goong XLB (6pc/$9) - Pork belly, shrimp, coconut milk, wrapped in a beet skin

The Pork XLB and Tom Yum Goong XLB came out at the same time. Served in an aluminum cup like most places do nowadays since people cant pick up XLB without breaking it, even if their lives depended on it. Flavor wise, they both were fairly similar. You can taste a slight more tartness to the Tom Yum Goong version (maybe it was just me) but flavor wise, really similar. 

Personally, i didn't order the King-Dum but my friend did. It was served with a boba straw (Ow..?) Huge meat ball inside with some meat. The steamer is served on a small dish/bowl, which was a great idea and saving grace because his King-Dum popped on the bottom and all the soup went. The soup was fairly light, not too fatty. He said the normal XLBs were better in comparison in terms of skin thickness, flavor, etc. 

Trio of Buns (3pc/$5.5) consisting of Green Tea & Milk Bun, Beet & Taro Bun, and Egg Yolk Bun

When this was served, the same friend who ordered the King-Dum and I heard Egg Yolk Bun. Our hopes were peaked when we had imagined it to be like the runny yolk inside like some dim sum places offer. We saved this for last, but unfortunately 2 other friends tried this first and killed our hopes.. The egg yolk bun was like a custard. The Green Tea & Milk bun was very fragrant and smelled amazing. Probably the best of the 3 IMO. Beet and Taro bun was nice with the taro filling as well. Good way to try all 3 "Happy Endings". 

----------------

Overall, the place is nice to try, but im unsure if i would return again. Unique offerings but nothing too great in comparison to ones ive had in the past. Its all personal preference. Its great they make their wrapping/skins all themselves as its not really something a lot of places do anymore. Kind of pricey for the things offered but we were decently satisfied. We had a lot more other foods that day to save room for HEHE
author: Andrew C.

description:
Xiao Long Bao! Or can I say a delectable soup dumpling?

I was pleasantly surprised to see this place so close to where I work every day and had heard rumors of how great the XLB's here are. I just had to try it!

I went with a friend who is just as asian as I am and soup dumplings are definitely a top favorite! We went just after 12:30pm and there was a bit of a wait (15-20mins) but not bad. There are chairs to sit while waiting and then we were seated inside shortly afterwards.

We ordered the Pork Xiao Long Bao (2 orders because it was super tasty and we ate it too quickly) and some regular dumplings. The dumplings were just okay (tasted like the ones you can get at your typical asian market grocer).

Service was just so-so as they were busy and sometimes you do have to flag down a server like your typical asian restaurant. But if you come here for soup dumplings, you will not be disappointed!
author: Sue D.

description:
You're sitting in line waiting on a weekend day and thinking - hmm is this going to be worth it? 
The answer is yes. Why?

 Simply lip-spankin' delicious


Think of Dumpling Time as Din Tai Fung (quality/taste) x SF Bay Area/Silicon Valley (innovation/hipster)

Dumpling Time is the perfect place to go for a unique twist on your traditional dumplings + nice ambiance (you can take your out of town guests here no problem). High quality ingredients, clean open kitchen, reasonable (for SF) prices, innovative food items, and great tasting dumplings make me give this a Jeffrey 5 Star Rating. 


Side note/pro tip:
-Get the green tea dessert milk baos. Perfect way to end your savory meal. 
-Get the Tom Yum Goong - this is simply innovation. 
-I would not get the Lobster Siu Mai again since it's pretty similar to your average shrimp. Unless you're there for your first time, then might as well get it and try.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description:
Holy god the dumplings here changed my life.   I saw god.   I'm an atheist and I saw god in these dumplings.   Also god tastes like delicious pork xiao long bao.   

Also go order the pork xiao long bao.  And the seafood gyoza.  And the shrimp and pork siu mai.   Order everything on the menu and then die happy.
author: Bradley H.

description:
A modern and Americanized take on traditional dim sum, this isn't your greasy Chinatown joint, it's a bit pricier but better in service and ambience.

Order:
- Shu Mai: the best thing on the menu. Shrimp has good crunch, not too oily, fresh and served hot
