- Shrimp Toast: crispy melty shrimp goodness on a Chinese donut. Fairly long and 1 order is enough for 3 people
- Char Shu bun: sweet red pork in a soft white bun. Very tasty 
- Short ribs: dim sum marinated short ribs, takes the longest to prepare so order early 
- pork XLB (soup dumpling): good but not great. Everyone liked it a lot but I prefer din tai fung's soup dumplings  
- Dessert: egg custard bun and green tea bun. The egg custard is sweeter and creamier than the green tea bun. Skip the red bun, it's bland and forgettable.

Skip:
- The big soup dumpling (king dum I think): it's difficult to split and average tasting. Order it for the novelty if anything 
- Pork bun: it's the soup dumpling filling in a soft white bun
- Dumpling time soup dumpling: it's got a weird tart flavored broth that wasn't my thing

$7-10 per order, and very packed so if you're coming on a weekend show up before they open because there's always a line that forms outside.
author: Bryan B.

description:
If you don't want to deal with the lines and wait, don't come here during dinner or on weekends. I ended up coming here on a Monday for lunch and was seated immediately. SCORE! If you come with the mindset that you're here for some cheap dim sum or XLB then you're going to be sorely disappointed by the price. 

Ok now that we've reframed our expectations, Dumpling Time is a newer, cleaner, and slightly more upscale place to get your dumpling fix on. With that comes increased price. I mean 4 pieces of har gow goes for $6 here when you can something similar on Clement St. for $2. However, Dumpling Time goes a bit non-traditional with its addition of cream cheese or cilantro to their har gow. In many dishes this place does things just a bit differently. Like their seafood gyoza...you can really taste all the crab and scallop and shrimp but wrapped in their spinach skin ($9.50 for 5 pc) or their ginormous King-Dum XLB ($8 for 1) that is garnished with rose petals and other edible flowers.

Overall, I like the place and the flavors are pretty spot on with their unique twist. However, lunch for 2 came out to $42 with tax/tip and we were both still pretty hungry. This place doesn't quite meet my price/satiety standard but the easy parking, no wait for weekday lunchtime and the fierce ladies cranking out those dumplings behind the large glass windows bumps this place up from A-ok to "Yay! I'm a fan."
author: Sam L.

description:
Okay okay okay! So ever since I saw a picture of the huge soup dumpling from top restaurants sf instagram page, I wanted to come here soo soo badly!

Finally came here today! Make sure you come early because even before the restaurant was opened, there was a line forming already! 

As soon as we were sat down, the servers literally ignored us for over 10 minutes. We had to try to wave them down to even try to get them to notice us so that we could place our orders... So we ordered the shrimp toast, seafood gyoza, pork bao crispy ( somehow got chicken instead) , beijing noodles, shrimp and cilantro har gow, pork dumpling , king dum, pork xlb and trio buns ! The first few dishes came out quickly but after the first 4 dishes, nothing came out for another 20 minutes. Hence we sat there just waiting, waiting and waiting for something just to come out...As you may expect, we started to become frustrated. Asked the servers were was our food and all they could say was it's coming.,, okay... took forever but it finally all came ! 

Overall, the food was definitely mediocre! If you want authenticity, this is not the place to come to! The hype is not real at all! I've had much better dumplings and noodles at Chinatown... Presentations are definitely deceiving ! Looks good but taste ehh ! Don't think I'll come back again. Not worth it.

Oh yeah forgot! One more thing ! We were sat at a table that was meant for 6 people at most , but since we only had 3 people, we had to share the table which was fine until they SHOVED 4 more individual to the table ! Hence there was 7 people at the table, making it feel so cramped ! It's hard enjoying your food when you can't even move your arms... 

Only pro was that there was this mid age old man, who I saw was definitely a super hard working server/cleaner ! Much props to him for doing his job so well! If I could only tip him, I would !
author: Shirley G.

description: So the wait here is usually 10-30 min, but there is a bar across the street that you can wait in;) I've been to this spot over 8 times and I can't get over how yummy the soup dumplings are. The coconut milk dumplings are great. They have the big soup dumplings that are sooo insta-worthy. My boyfriend and I will over probably 9ish things (small dimsum style). Everything here is great. The service is a bit slow but the food is awesome!
author: Amy C.

description:
I absolutely adore Dumpling Time!  There is ample parking around the restaurant and there is a shaded waiting area in front as there is usually a small wait during rush hours.  The menu is simple and i always walk out of here full and happy!

My favorites are:
-Beijing Noodles: fresh noodles topped with meat- must add the hot chili sauce to this for a spicy & savory delight!  
-Pan Seared BBQ Pork Buns: so good you can eat it for dessert as well.
-Pork XLB: these suckers are so yummy!
-Seafood Gyoza with Spinach Skin: it's unique with the green spinach skin

 Make sure you make time for some Dumpling Time!  Your asian craving's will be satisfied!
author: Melanie N.

description:
There are not a ton of options for vegetarians and/or pescatarians. (Pork is in some of the seafood dishes.) But listen! The tofu is the best tofu I've ever had. You may get in a physical altercation over the last piece of crust.

Seafood Gyoza was also amazing with the butter aioli !

Go here.

Marcella was a great server.
author: Whitney H.

description:
We were sat on the outdoor patio where you have a view of the chefs making all of the dumplings. 
Service was very fast. Waited about 15 minutes to be seated on a Friday night. Orders were brought out within a few minutes. 
The Char-Siu Bao was delicious. Ordered seconds of it because we all loved them! 
Would highly recommend!
author: Andrea A.

description:
Any time is a great time for dumplings- especially when you know they're fresh, handmade, quality dumplings that are bursting with flavor. 

This place was pure heaven from start to finish- hitting all of my foodie pleasure zones with gold stars. Service, atmosphere, presentation, and flavor were all amazing!

From the moment you walk in, you can see a trio of chefs carefully stuffing and rolling each dumpling.

I ordered the shrimp dumpling, seafood gyoza, soup dumpling, and green tea and milk bao.

The shrimp dumpling was perfect- not too much dough, and packed with huge chunks of shrimp, cilantro, and pork filling. 

The seafood gyoza was as beautiful as it was delicious. It's filled with shrimp, scallops, and crab and it's all packaged in a green spinach wrap. It's good on its own, but out of this world once you dip it in the frothy chili butter sauce. 

The soup bao was a fun experience to try- comes with a straw and once you carefully poke s hole in the side, you can slurp the hot gingery broth and later, scoop out the pork belly laying inside.

The green tea milk baos are the perfect warm, fluffy, creamy dessert to top it all off. 

Try this place ASAP. It will have you fantasizing about coming back even before you finish your meal.
author: Mitzi G.

description: The shrimp toast is amazing! You don't wanna miss out on it. I think the giant soup dumpling is overhyped. It's problematic to eat and slurp the burning hot soup from that. Instead of the giant one get the regular size they are definitely delicious. The chicken gyoza, the pork dumplings, the buns. Everything is littttt.
author: Natthawan P.

description:
Came without high expectations here and actually were surprised to see the ahort list of menu. However, everyhing we ordered were pretty good! If you have party bigger than 4, expect to wait for a while. Most of their tables only fit 2-4 people and a communal table inside, so they have to combine table for bigger parties. Parking can be challenging too, but we were lucky and got parking in front of the kitchen store next door. We ordered:
- shrimp toast(good, wish it had more shrimps!)
- garlicky green beans(tasty)
- pork gyoza(good, hubby likes this more than the seafood gyoza)
- seafood gyoza(good, i like this one more than the pork)
- char-siu bao(decent, would skip next time)
- beijing noodles(not bad)
- pork xlb(good, juicy)
- tom yum xlb(very good, our favorite!)
- green tea and milk bun(decent)
- egg yolk bun(good)
- king dum(taste the same as pork xlb, just bigger)
author: Prisilia P.

description:
When I think of yum cha, or dim sum, I think of the hustle and bustle of the food carts, one pot filled with tea, one pot filled with hot water, cheap eats and variety of dishes. 
Dumpling Time is a different and modern take on a classic dining experience:

[Ambience]
Modern! All the time I've been here, my party was always seated outside so I can't say much about inside. I get cold really easily, so sitting outside kinda sucks sometimes, however, the tent is really good at blocking out the wind! I just wish there were a couple more heaters lol. Don't waste your time trying to get a table inside when outside seating is just as good as being indoors.
Another great thing about sitting outside is that I got to bring my pup Kuma! We weren't entirely sure if they allowed dogs to be honest, lol. If they don't allow it, I guess Kuma was just too cute to refuse!

[Service]
We usually get really great service at the beginning of our meal, and then when it comes time to order more or grab the check, it always takes a while to flag someone down. This is probably because by the time we finish, servers are experiencing table turn around, helping other customers close out and get ready for the next set of customers, so it's totally understandable.
The servers are incredibly sweet here! They even took Kuma into consideration and made a make shift water bowl for him. I felt bad telling them I had a portable water bowl for him already.. Lol. Thumbs up for thinking about him!

[Food]
The food is really good!! I was a little bit afraid that it wouldn't have lived up to the standards of other great San Francisco dim sum restaurants. With that being said, Dumpling Time holds their own. Nothing on their menu is bad, lol. 
What drew me to this place at first was the Tom Yum soup dumplings. I don't know what I was expecting but these dumplings were definitely.. different. I'd skip these.
My favorite dishes are probably the shrimp toast (whoever thought of putting minced shrimp and mayo on a chinese donut is a freaking genius), seafood gyoza (the sauce on the side is so good!) and also the egg yolk & green tea buns.

[Worth it???]
Just like everyone is saying, Dumpling Time is on the pricier side. If I were to take my boyfriend's family here, they would probably think these prices are laughable. But, the food is good! Price point, not so good.
I would come here with friends or even family to show them a more modern yum cha experience. (Just without the tea because the tea here is expensive and not worth the price per person!)
author: Audrey G.

description:
To be honest, the giant dumpling is why I wanted to come here. Luckily, I liked the other items as well.

I came on a Friday night a little before 6pm and luckily we were able to quickly able to get a seat as I heard it gets pretty busy here. Between the 2 of us, we got 4 items and it was enough to feed 2 girls.

Of course I got the giant dumpling (King-Dum) and though it was cool, it tasted like an normal soup dumpling except since you're suppose to slurp all the soup out first, it just takes like filling and a ton of dough. It was cool, but not my favorite of the night. We also got the shrimp toast which was good as the shrimp had great flavor and the chinese donut was deliciously fried, the seafood gyoza which was good and the tom yum goong which was my favorite and tasted like tom yum XLB and reminded my of my thailand trip the month before except the flavor wasn't as prominent.

Overall, it was good food. The bill kind of added up fast, but it was kind of expected for a non-hole in the wall dim sum like restaurant in SF.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
4 stars for the food (fresh ingredients, pretty delicious), the vibe is blatantly bougie, and knocking off 1 star for some disturbing things:

Chefs (all asian) making dumplings are 'on display' in this glass room--is this a zoo? There were actual people taking pictures of these chefs with their dslrs...

XLB served in tin foil cups that stuck to the xlb... how do I dip (and cool) the bottom of my xlb in the sauce? What is logic? The xlb RIPS because the heaviest part is at the bottom/the skin is thin so it's hard to take it out all in one piece, but if you do get it out in one piece the rounded spoon that is too small to hold the xlb will not allow you to have that sauce:xlb ratio. If you decide to eat it in the cup, good luck using the sauce and keeping the soup from spilling everywhere...I know perhaps the cups are used to catch the soup/ stabilize it when it steams but you can do that with FLAT SPOONS too. And if foil cups are the secret to a thin-skin, well-steamed xlb, maybe use cups that are easier to pry the xlbs from (hint: more rigs? larger cup?). Please, logic over aesthetics for once. 

The veggie xian dumpling was good because they used really young chives. The pork gyoza was alright but not mindblowing. Great presentation on all dishes but like all bougie things, you are basically paying the price for better presentation since everything beneath stays mad ordinary.
author: Lydia Z.

description: This is another one time place for me. Pork steamed dumplings were a little under average. XLB is pretty standard. The king Bao is only worth it for the pics. Incredibly hard to eat. In my opinion the skins for all the dumplings were too thick. The dessert baos and the shrimp toast are pretty good though. I would recommend those. Do not get the Beijing noodles, they're terrible versions of jiajiangmien
author: Tatiana T.

description:
I am no dumpling expert, but these to me were tasty dumplings. I really enjoy eating most manner of dumplings, but I enjoyed Dumpling Time because it didn't cost as much as Yank Sing, but didn't make me run for the toilet like Good Luck Dim Sum or other hole in the wall places around the City to make my own organic dump(l)ing. 

Trendy decor, moderately priced menu items, and fresh, non-greasy dumplings make for a good meal, and Dumpling Time is on point. The wait is brutal, but that's old hat by now. Everyone waits an eternity for good dumplings. Besides the xiao long bao and baos, the garlicky green beans topped with flower petals, and pickled lotus root were standouts. We shared the Beijing noodles, but they didn't really do it for me and I'd pass on them next time. Dumplings and veggies are where it's at here.

I can't comment on the authenticity but most everything I ate tasted authentically good so that works for me. It's a small and packed place with a fun and playful atmosphere and smiley service.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Long story short, the presentation is better than the flavor/quality. 

I came during lunch hour and there was already a long list of people waiting. There's a lot of space to wait outside and a bench you can sit on. After 20 minutes, I went inside to check on the list and found that our name was already crossed off! After informing the hostess, she said that they called our name and someone else claimed it. Since we were sitting outside on the bench (which is further from the entrance) we didn't even hear the host call out any names. Apparently it's a "thing" that happens often here. Luckily the host told us that they had a table ready for us so we were seated right after. 

The food was mediocre at best. We ordered tom yum XLB, the king dum, pork gyoza, and the bun trio. Our waitress suggested that we ordered one more item because it's small portions so we opted for the Beijing noodles. I definitely prefer chewy-textured hand made noodles and the Beijing noodles were more like a dry ramen with ground beef. I was really excited for the tom yum XLB because I've never seen anything like it but unfortunately it didn't taste like tom yum at all, definitely not worth $9 for 6 pieces. The king dum was also a bit of a let-down. They give you a thick straw to drink the soup inside but it's almost impossible to suck anything up and all the soup ended up dripping down to the plate under the bamboo container. When we tried to cut it, it fell apart and the skin became mushy. If you're looking for authentic XLBs, this is not the place to go. 

The best thing about our meal was the pink taro bun that came with the bun trio. The filling is real taro and complimented the bun very well. The other buns that came in the trio was green tea and your typical white custard bun. The green tea didn't taste anything like green tea either. Dumpling Time is a bit overrated and pricey for what it is. You're basically paying for pretty looking dumplings and baos. In terms of quality and authenticity, there are definitely better places to go in SF.
author: Cecille W.

description:
Definitely worth a try!

I came here for lunch (around 1pm on a Friday), yes, there was a wait but not unbearable.All the staff is super welcoming and friendly. With their open kitchen layout, you're able to watch the kitchen make dumplings. it's a fun experience while you wait, just don't block the sign up list area. 

What we ordered:
- Xiao Long Baos (came in an order of six)
- King-Dum (their GIANT xlb, NO LIE, this was HUGE. It came with a boba straw for you to drink the soup from, while I used it to poke holes to release some of the steam so I wouldn't burn my tongue)
- Chicken Gyozas (one of my favs)
- Pork Gyozas (wish it was a bit more pan fried)
- Beijing Noodles (basically jiajiang mien, not bad)
- Shrimp Toast (most raved about items, aside from the King-Dum)

I definitely think they should have some merchandise of their dumpling logo, it's ADORABLE!
author: Eva O.

description: Had the ginormous soup dumpling and it was goood. Lots of soup, meat, and skin goodness. Fun to drink it out of a straw, just be careful not to burn your throat.
author: Adrienne L.

description:
Not a huge fan of this weird hipster fusion dim sum place. Fancy little flowers and watermelon radishes scattered haphazardly on buns are good for the picture, nothing more. I went around 11:30 on a weekday, and it was still super busy, full inside the restaurant at the large communal tables and outside in their patio area. 

All of their dishes cost around $5-10, and most of them consist of 3-4 buns or dumplings. Essentially, you're paying more than $2 for each of these buns, and the worst part is that they don't even taste good. I skipped the XL Bao because it's probably an L at most - it's pretty small when you see the basket it comes in, which is smaller than the one that contains the xiao long bao. 

Shrimp toast was good - I especially liked the cream that they put on it, though there was just a drop of it on each piece. The shrimp dumplings with cilantro sauce were interesting because the sauce gave it a strange flavor typically associated with burrito innards. The Bun Trio, which contained the green tea, taro, and custard buns was disappointing because it seemed like they just bought frozen buns and steamed them in the kitchen. Nothing was as bad as the noodles, though, which were incredibly bland even after I heaped hot sauce on them. 

Yes, this place is exciting because of the neon signs and hip interior, but if that's all you want, just drop by and take a peek. For good dim sum, go somewhere else.
author: Sophie W.

description:
The food here was really great! My friend and I shared the Gan ban noodles, pan seared char-siu bao, and the tomyum XLB! The noodles could have used a little more flavor, but we put soy sauce and the chili sauce on it and it tasted a lot better. The char siu bao and the tomyum XLB were really good! I love that the tomyum XLB were beet colored; it was a nice touch. 

We got there around 11:15 AM and there was no wait at all. The service was really nice and attentive and the food came really quickly. Overall, we were very satisfied with the food and service here. I definitely would come back to try the other dishes on the menu!
author: Hanna K.

description:
A very popular spot for sure.

We waited for almost an hour for a table for 4 on a Friday evening at around 7pm. They have a little bench outside. It also helps that the patio seating lets you check out the food as the servers carry it around to get you ready to dive into dim sum world! 

Shrimp and coriander was probably my favorite. Simple and very flavorful. 

Other favorites included the pork bao. Soft and interesting peanut butter combination. 

The soup dumplings were very soy and fat flavored. Powerful and wonderful kick for your taste buds.

We topped it up with trio buns. They were decent too. 

Very pleasant service. Chill ambience. 

I'd love to go back someday! I wish they had more dim sum options!
author: Soundarya C.

description:
I was finally able to try out this place after hearing of all the hype about it and I must say, dumpling time did not disappoint! The only disappointment was probably the semi long wait, but our group did come on a Saturday afternoon... so I guess I'll let that slide. As far as food goes, we pretty much ordered everything off the menu, and the stand outs were the xiao long baos, gyozas, and Beijing noodles. The gang bang noodles on the other hand was not as good. (I'm just kidding, it's called gan ban noodles) 

The thing that was a pleasant surprise was every dish came with its own sauce(s) which I thought was a nice touch. The xlbs were also surprisingly soupy, just how they're suppose to be. Also, we got the giant dumpling as well, but you can skip that unless you want the ig fame. The tom yum dumplings were interesting, but I felt like it tasted similar to the regular ones except with an extra kick of lemongrass flavor. I also forgot to mention about the shrimp toasts... get it lol.

So overall, I thought this was just a hyped up dumpling spot, but it was actually quite good. Although prices are a bit higher than traditional dumpling shops, but that's expected at this type of location.
author: Marco M.

description: I'm not a huge fan of rating on comparisons, BUT, I have to make an exception here because it's soup dumplings! I've had some exceptional soup dumplings in the past and the ones here are just fine. Other dishes were good, although the veggie Xi'an dumplings were a bit bland. Outdoor seating is great, service is prompt, everything came out quickly, and I'm in a mini dumpling coma so there it is.
author: Ted M.

description:
Good dim sum and boujee presentation? I'm down.

You wouldn't have thought there'd be delicious dim sum in soma, but that's where you're wrong. Seriously, the building it's in looks like some random dull warehouse. Good thing that didn't deter me and my friend from trying it out. Came in around 11:30am on a Sunday, and only had to wait 5 minutes for a table. If you come around 12:30, be prepared for a long wait.There's a clipboard to sign in on the waitlist, and there's indoor/outdoor seating. If you can't find super close parking, just park a block or 2 away for the 4 hour street parking. Trust me, 4 hour street parking spots are a rare find in SF.

STORY: My friend and I initially ordered the king xlb, but the waiter said they're out. Then I ask the hostess what times do they run out by and why they ran out? Later we see the table next to us get them, so we asked the waiter from before if we can get them now. Got them.

TIP: So the King-Dum Xiao Long Bao comes in batches and runs outs super fast. If they don't have it at the moment, ask again later.

Ordered the Shrimp Toast, Seafood Gyoza, Pork Dumplings, King-Dum, Pork XLB, Tom Yum Goong, and Trio of Buns.

1) Shrimp Toast: (4/5) Not the crispiest fried dough, but its still tasty.
2) Seafood Gyoza: (4/5) Only got it for the green exterior. Tastes good.
3) Pork Dumplings: (0/5) Nasty af like why. All that decoration but terrible taste. It's like I was eating olives.
4) Pork XLB: (5/5) HELLA SOUP INSIDE YES I APPROVE.
5) Tom Yum Goong: (5/5) Tasted amazing! Apparently doesn't taste sour as Tom Yum should, but still good.
6) King-Dum: (5/5) It's the real reason why I came, and I was not disappointed! Soup is hot inside so be careful when you drink through a straw.
7) Trio of Buns: (5/5) Yes, thank you for doing the yolk buns justice. The green and standard one tasted almost the same but the green is slightly sweeter. The red tastes like that red bean dessert soup you get at chinese restaurants.

Can't wait to come back someday.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Really good authentic dumplings. Definite plus for quality. We ordered the har gow, char siu bao, xlb, and green tea milk buns. The har gow skin was perfectly thin but had cream cheese in it, which was a little odd. The char siu bao were good but fairly average - nothing amazing. The xlb were very good for the Bay Area - light thin skin with plenty of fresh broth inside. The meat filling was soft and juicy. Definitely would recommend. The green tea milk buns were sweet and soft but again nothing extraordinary. 

Overall the quality was very good, but a bit pricey. It's somewhere you would go to eat very good dumplings in small quantities vs binge on 20+ cheap and not as high quality dumplings.
author: Hali M.

description:
This place is amazing! A good mix of Shanghai style and Dim Sum. Dumplings are delicious, good presentation, and great service!!!! We went there at rush hour, so we waited about 30 minutes which is not bad for SF. There's plenty parking on the street. I am fan! Love this place! :) 

Ps vegetarian friendly!
author: Sophia S.

description:
Dumpling Time is only less than fifteen minutes away from me! Easy to get to without too much traffic. When we came, it was around maybe 6pm? We didn't have to wait at all. We were seated inside, by the windows. I honestly wish we were seated somewhere else because the sun was just shining on me the whole entire meal. I felt extremely hot.. they gotta order some shades or something!

Anyways, the main reason I wanted to try this place was for their king XLB. I wanted to have the experience of drinking the soup out of my dumpling with straw, can ya blame me? Lol. The waitress recommended we ordered as much as we could because if we ordered anything else later, it'd probably be an extra 15-20 minutes to get our food.  So of course we ordered their king XLB ($8), beijing noodles ($9), seafood gyoza (5 pc/$9), and their pork xlb (6pc/$8.) I really really liked their beijing noodles - it was similar to the minced pork noodles at Din Tai Fung. And the seafood gyoza. It was really good with sauce and it had the perfect crisp imo, not overly fried. It was green too! The XLBs were good. The king XLB was definitely something I was only going to have for that one time. 

Definitely on the pricier side of things, but I enjoyed it. Doesn't beat DTF in LA though which is why I'm going with the four stars.
author: Sydney C.

description:
This is a cute/hip dumpling spot. For those who know damn good legit dim sum and dumpling houses in SF-keep an open mind. I've grown up eating better dim sum and dumplings from hole in the wall spots around the city so for me the food was mediocre but the one thing Dumpling Time offers that other hole in the wall places can't, is a great dining experience with nice staff:) 

They have a nice annex where people can host large parties in! Would be a cute place to celebrate birthdays!
author: Kimmie C.

description:
Dragged my boyfriend here to try the King Dum after reading about it in the Chronicle. It was a good experience overall. 

As others have mentioned, the biggest downside was the wait. We arrived about 15 minutes after opening on a Sunday and were greeted by the sight of about 50 other people who I guess got there before they opened or right when they did. We waited about 45-60 minutes for a party of 2. 

To get your name on the list you need to either go inside and write your name and party size on the clipboard, or aggressively flag down the host when they are in possession of the clipboard. Two parties got on the list ahead of me because I was slow to grasp the "rules". 

Once seated, service was prompt and brisk. As far as food goes our favorite item was the char-siu bao; they were crispy on the outside and the pork was very flavorful. Our second favorite was the shrimp and cilantro har gow, which were chock full of seafood and came with a delicious sauce. The King Dum is presented beautifully but does not have a ton of flavor and is difficult to eat. Worth getting for the novelty though! The pork gyoza and trio of desert buns were unremarkable. 

We'd definitely consider coming back to enjoy our favorite items at a time when the wait wasn't so punishing!
author: Christine G.

description: A pretty neat non-Cantonese style dim sum restaurant. The soup dumplings were good although I had better ones somewhere else. The shrimp toast, Beijing noodle, and pork gyoza were all delicious. All dishes are reasonably priced. A big plus!
author: Frank L.

description:
Love this place!  Small intimate inside with communal tables as well as covered outdoor available but tasty dishes are simply perfect!  

From first impression it reminds me of Din Tai Fung with the open glass windows guests can observe workers creating their dumplings or Siu bao.

Went for the very first time.  Tried to call ahead but phone kept ringing no answer.  There was a clipboard so I put name down and party size.  Waited about 20 minutes and got seated at a communal table inside.

The menu was short straight to the point and had a resemble of "simplified" version of din Tai fung menu as well.  I love everything ordered.  their dishes had flavor and texture leaving your tastebuds wanting to order seconds and thirds servings.  The steamed bbq pork buns are smaller than most but the flavor is spot on.  The XLB steamed are filled with delicious juicy goodness ready to burst open with flavors in your mouth.  However be careful as you can burn your mouth if not careful.  They could really use offer more sliced ginger in their seasonings.

So much more I wanted to order but I will have to come back soon.
author: Emi J.

description:
Came here on Friday @6PM and had to wait about 10 minutes for a table. It was completely packed with yuppies and instagram/yelpers having fun drinking beer/ pretending to watch the basketball game on the two giant TV screens.

The GOOD:
+ Their regular sized XLB had a mild skin, lots of yummy broth, and a good mouthfeel. Would definitely recommend them both (tomyum & the regular pork).
+ Beijing noodles were good, but ya'll should get 2+ servings if you plan to share 
+ a few (8-10) parking spots for the early/ lucky birds 
+ Waiters were aplenty and pretty cool and attentive too... i think - not sure too much noise coming from everywhere. 

The MEH:
- Don't get their extra large XLB. If you do want a cheaper alternative, go to "Xiao Long Bao Kitchen" instead. They have some for $3 and it's souper meaty and filling. But here, at $8, these were not worth it. Please consult pictures -- you can see them falling apart pretty easily. The chefs knew this and added a bowl on the bottom to catch all the soup. Somehow a buncha soup still managed to get onto my pants... meh. I recommend putting the XLXLB in a bowl, so atleast it can capture the soup immediately. 
- Big price tags for so little food... great for dieting, not so great for bulking or getting full LOL
- Noisy, not good for convos or dates imo - unless you're drunk or yelling at the TV.
author: Vy T.

description:
My daughter K was excited about the opening of Dumpling Time around the corner, so we gave them try. The wait yesterday was about 25 minutes at 7:15. The restaurant is small with many communal tables. Minimally decorated, with a projection TV that shows K-Pop videos with out sound on a white wall. The menu is simple and we ordered 80% of all the items. The noise level is beyond loud and very hard to have a conversation. The food is not traditional but good and the presentations are excellent. Lots of vegetable and micro greens garnishes. Here is what we had:

Green Beans 4 stars
Garlic seaweed 5 stars for taste tiny portions
Gan Ban Noodles 3 stars very bland needed to add soy and chili sauce 
Tom Yum Goong 5 stars best of the XLBs 
Pork XLBs 3 stars non traditional comes in aluminum tins hard to eats ( aluminum​ tins help hold the dumpling skins together but is a cheat)
Xian pork dumpling 4 stars
King XLB. 4 stars 
Shrimp and cilantro Hargow 4 stars
Chicken Gyoza 4 stars
Seafood Gyoza 5 stars best of the night fish and shrimp filling, get this one
Trio of buns dessert Baos 4 stars 

Service was decent for a busy restaurant and limited staff. Our server was all over the place trying to keep up. They need more staff. Parking is street parking. Try to get a spot before you get to the public cardboard shanty village. $95 before tip.
author: George F.

description: Moving from from Orange County where great dim sum/Asian cuisine places are found around each corner, I did not expect to find something this good in the city. We got there a little before 12PM on Sunday, waited about 30 minutes (which isn't long for this place), and just barely missed the rush of people. If I could change one thing about my order, I would've ordered more Green Tea Milk and Egg Yolk buns without the Taro buns (they were bland and unsweet compared to the other 2). Overall perfect fluffy buns, flavorful fillings, good service, and fun/intimate atmosphere.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Went here with a couple friends before a Giants game.  Service was quick, food was good and we hardly had to wait by showing up when they opened at 5pm.

Favorites were seafood gyoza, the ribs and the Tom Yum soup dumplings.  Only one I didnt care for was the lamb dumpling.

If I lived closer I'd be back.
author: J. B.

description:
Arrived 6min before opening time on a Sunday and wrote our names down about 9th on the list. Took awhile to get seated, but we got to choose between indoor or outdoor patio. 

They have a simplified menu, offering only a few choices in multiple categories. We tried to order a bit of each.

Ingredients (for 2 very full servings):
- garlic green beans
- beijing noodle
- chicken gyoza
- shrimp haw gao
- king dum (XL XLB) 
- desert buns trio

Garlicky green beans could have been more garlicky and less salty. The Beijing noodle was amazinly delish, although I wish the noodles were more solid. The fried dumplings had too much going on... between the mushroom and the fried and the crunchy red strands and the chili oil dip, it was confusing on what it was trying to be. I was afraid the cream cheese on the shrimp would be too overwhelming, but it was perfect with the green sauce. 

The King dum!! What fun. Beautifully decorated with edible flowers, it also comes with a tapioca straw for drinking (although it way too hot to use in the beginning). You have to fork and spoon and chopstick your way, and then slurp up whats left on the bottom. Bigger is not always better, but in this case it definitely is!!

...and my favorite. After we were both stuffed silly, we weren't sure if we could manage to finish these pink, green and white yummies. I wasn't even interested in food at this point. But they were so... delightful! Each had just the right amount of its unique filling, creamy and aromatic, pleasing to eyes, nose and mouth. And touch too, because they were so fun to poke and so soft to eat. I would come back just for this.
author: Katy Q.

description:
I spend a lot of my time searching for decadent and irresistible soup dumplings, and with time, Dumpling Time may be my favorite. Possibly even better than Din Tai Fung....

We went at around 8:15pm on a Monday night, and the surrounding buildings were empty as it was after the work day and there is not much else in the area. The restaurant springs up out of no where--neon lights, lovely crowd, and K-pop music videos. 

We waited about 35 minutes for a table for 3. There were lots of open tables, but since it seemed like the staff was still learning how to be efficient. 

We ordered the soup dumplings, tom yum soup dumplings, shrimp/cilantro har gow, shrimp toast, seafood gyoza, and trio of buns for dessert. They were sold out of the large King-Dum, so we will have to be back.

The fillings of all the dumplings tasted incredible, but with exception of the gyoza, the dumpling wrappers needed some work. For both soup dumplings, the bottom of the dumpling stuck to the aluminum, so it was hard to get a good bite. There is a lot of soup in the soup dumplings, and the flavor of the broth is amazing. Best in the city quite possibly. The har gow wrapper seemed way too thick for har gow. 

The shrimp toast was so. good. You have to get it. 

Their alcoholic beverage license isn't approved yet, so other tables around us brought their own beer. I'd recommend doing the same, or have Postmates deliver a six pack while you wait for your table.
author: Anthony G.

description:
This is a good place to spend a lot of money if you don't watch it.

This place is located in SOMA near the old Galleria and Showplace Design Center buildings. There's not a lot of restaurants that are open on the weekends around there yet, so this is an oasis in the neighborhood. On the weekends, parking is a challenge, but not impossible. 

Other reviews and photos had told us to expect a line, and that's what we got. But it went smoothly and there are some chairs outside to accommodate the folks who need to sit.

Servers were cute, sweet, fast and were easy to understand. They didn't volunteer a lot of info, though, about serving size and such. It would have been appreciated.

We started with Salt & Szechuan peppercorn Edamame. Pretty much the same as every other good salted Edamame you've had elsewhere. Would have been nice with a little more pepper, because that's why we ordered them.

We were told in line that the Shrimp Toasts were just ok. They looked better than that, but we didn't order them because I've been fooled by Shrimp Toast before.

The centerpieces were Mom's Secret Recipe Boiled Pork Dumplings and the soup dumplings which are very tasty and small. You can pop them in your mouth very quickly, they are very good. We ordered the Tom Yum Goong variety. They were gone in a flash. Mom's SRBPD were awesome. We could have eaten 3 times as many. And they were beautifully garnished with micro-greens, chives and flower petals. Lovely.

A woman at the next table shared her Beet & Taro bun as a dessert because she was full. Pink and very tasty, but nothing sent off fireworks. It was just an appreciated sweet ending.

At the end of all this, we were still hungry and were ready to go somewhere else to finish the meal. But instead, we shared a beer, which was very cold and satisfying. It filled us up sufficiently so we paid the bill somewhere around $50.

Next time, we'll have one of the two noodle dishes on the menu. That should fill us up a little better and might save $10. There's lots of places in the City with Shanghai Dumplings, but this is certainly one of the nicest. Totally recommend it.
author: Marty R.

description:
**3.5 Stars**

Trendy and new dumpling spot from the team behind high end Omakase and izakaya Okane. 

The space is modern and hip with music, on wall TV, and quick and friendly service. 

The menu is varied with lots of dumpling options as well as a few Noodle and vegetable choices.  The alcoholic beverages are listed but it's BYOB until their license gets approved.  We arrived before opening hour and found a crowd waiting, but once opening time came, we were seated in a prompt and orderly fashion. 

The interior isn't huge but it fits a good number of people. Most of the people waiting before opening were seated in the first seating.  Our order:

Pork XLB - $8.  We watched as the staff wrapped Dumplings and these came out quickly.  Piping hot, filled with broth, and supposedly made with Pork belly.  As we watched the staff wrap the Dumplings and place in a tin cup, we noticed how white the Pork meat looked. Likely fat, but it leads to a distinct dumpling flavor that is more fatty than I liked.  The dumpling skin is on the thicker side as well. Overall, solid dumpling served Hot with plentiful broth but not the best I've had. 

Tom Yum Goong - $9. A nice variation on the traditional with beet red dumpling skins and a subtle Tom yum broth.  I liked these better but still thick skin and similar dumpling Pork meat. 

King-dum - $8. Perfect for selfies but very thick skin given the size.  The Pork meat was the most white and fatty in this one but of note, there was a lot of broth and it was served with a nice boba straw and piping hot.  A one time order thing. 

Shrimp Dumplings - $6. Basically har gow but a slight twist with cream cheese and a cilantro dipping sauce. Both were subtle twists that didn't detract from the large and high quality shrimp inside. 

Seafood Gyoza - $9.5.  Another slight variation with green Gyoza skin and lots of high quality seafood and Pork.  Cooked very nicely and juicy with a crispy exterior.  The butter dipping sauce and traditional soy dipping sauce were nice additions. 

Beijing Noodles - $9. Basic dish with delicious house made noodles and a simple but tasty stir fried Tan Tan sauce. Solid. 

Xian Pork Dumplings - $6.  Beautifully garnished but standard frozen thick skin boiled Pork Dumplings. Tasty sauce but otherwise unremarkable. 

Snap Peas - they ran out of their popular green beans but this was a nice substitute.  

Char Siu Bao - $6.  Pan Fried version and nicely done with a crispy bottom.  Good quality char Siu meat. 

Overall, Dumpling Time was a solid spot.  I actually was most impressed by the shrimp
Dumplings and seafood Gyoza instead of the Xiao Long Bao.  Prices are a tad higher given the trendy environment but solid ingredients.  I wasn't a fan of the thicker dumpling skin and Pork meat used but everything was tasty and solid. 

Dumpling Time accepts credit cards including Amex.
author: Randy F.

description:
I have been craving dumplings for quite some time now especially from Dumpling Time so we finally made our way out there 

When we first arrived as the doors opened there was a long line but have no fear they will seat you quickly and honestly once the first wave is done there isn't a huge wait time 

Across the board, most things were done well but the true stand outs were the noodles, shrimp toast, and the regular sized Shanghai dumplings. While the king size is fun to post, it's a pain to share/eat and execution is slightly flawed with the wrapper 

Draft beer selection is good, really enjoyed the holycraft  harajuku 

Service is as fast as they can be but keep in mind tables are small so if you order a lot you better eat fast otherwise you'll have no room 

Overal Thoughts

While Dumpling time delivers solid dumplings, it's not my go to spot in the city
author: Eddie W.

description:
The foods are beyond expectation, the hipster-look is a little off i guess. After sitting in I do not understand the k pop music video at all. And I strongly recommend some other videos instead lol. I was seating way inside the restaurant in a rainy day, there was almost no air inside. Too dense i guess. 

Strongly recommend;
- shrimp toast 
- har gow 
- tom yum goong xiao long bao
- seafood gyoza

After all, a good rainy dinner xoxo
author: Mu C.

description: Great new find! Hip, Good food, great prices, casual dress. Patio is enclosed and heaters.
author: J S.

description:
I wanted to come here to try their King Dum XLB...the one where you need a straw. 
Ok. First thing first, find parking. Parking around isn't too bad and we went on a Saturday. Once you find parking, you put your name down on the wait list. Make sure your party is there or near by, they don't sit you unless everyone is there. The wait isn't too bad, around 12:30pm the wait was about 30mins? When we were finally called, we pretty much one thing of each section (or more) LOL. Oh and there is about 25mins-30mins wait on making the Large XLB.

We started off with the garlicky green beans. Wasn't impressed. It would be something I make at home and I wished they had more garlic. 

Noodles: We got the Beijing noodles...Kinda disappointed as well. Wasn't something that tasted unbelievable. The portion is enough for maybe 1 person... SAD...

Gyoza: Had the seafood Gyoza, this hit the spot! Now thats what I'm talking about! I recommend getting this one. You don't normally see green gyoza and...hardly can find SEAFOOD ones.

Bao: We chose Cha siu bao, make sure to have them pan sear it. It is quite yummy. They also hold the red dye in the cha siu, this is a plus.

Dumplings: Ok I thought this was very odd. I usually eat my dumplings just steamed/boiled and with the sauce, this came with cherry tomatoes and some greens. Too hipster LOL. Nothing too special on these ones.

Now to the XLB:
We ordered the regular ones, not bad. Tasted pretty good.
The LARGE one...NEEDS A STRAW?!?! Actually I felt like you don't need it. You use it to poke a hole to let the steam out and have it chill before you can drink it. But the XLB is so big you can even pick it up with a spoon and chopsticks so...there isn't much to using the straw. COOL idea but not needed. Awesome it came with a small dish so the soup you couldn't drink will be on that dish and you just drink it after you finish the XLB. The XLB itself was pretty good, just a jumbo size (a bit inconvenient to eat) XLB.

Would I come back? Maybe if I was in the area :)
author: Jade L.

description: Love the food here! The beet dumplings are super creative - it's great that they use natural coloring from veggies instead of artificial ones. I really like their shrimp dumplings (har gow) too. They have great side dishes like beans sautéed in a ginger sauce. Come with a group so you can order everything!
author: Weich Y.

description:
Dumplings! Dumplings! Dumplings!  I'm so glad I tried this place with friends when they first opened.  They have worked out a few of their service kinks from the beginning and are very much on their game now.  

I've been pretty lucky going with very little waiting.  Though I will admit the first time I went I was there like 4:00 PM to see if I could get my name on a list.  After that, the other couple of times were less than 10 minutes.  While I like their xiao long bao, the gyoza are actually my favorite here.  Something about how they pan sear their gyoza and steamed buns just draws me to them.  Food is definitely fresh and delicious.  Service can be chaotic, but food comes out hot from the kitchen.  I only wish the glasses for water were a bit bigger, but then again, I usually have so many dishes ordered, there's no room for much else.

Go with a large group so you can try everything.  And I mean everything!  The menu is big, but not so big that 6 of you together can't just order it all and be done.  You'll enjoy it!
author: Maria S.

description:
Food: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Ambiance: 3.5/5
Overall: very good in taste but sort of in a random area.  If you do come...come before it opens otherwise expect a wait.

The extended review...

Food:

Ha gaw (shrimp dumplings) - it's up there with the other ha gaw I've had.  Good flavor and the skin wasn't breaking.

Beijing noodles - Definitely one of my favorite dishes.  Meat and thick chewy noodles uh yes.

Shrimp toast - a good take on dim
Sum.  Haven't had shrimp atop a porridge donut.  Pretty tasty.

Tom yum goong - can't complain about this.  The soup wasn't absorbed into the skin which was nice.  

Green tea Milk bun - good dessert option with a very sweet and tasty filling.  I'm a fan!

Service: very friendly and attentive staff.  Be warned...only full parties will be seated.

Ambiance: pretty modern and clean.  Gets very busy and can be noisy though.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Grew up in China, I have really high expectation for dumpling restaurant, because there are a ton of cheap and tasty dumplings in China. This one overall did not surprise me nor let me down. We waited for about 20minutes to get in and ordered different kinds of dumplings, including seafood gyozu海鲜煎饺(not authentic Chinese name BTW), pork dumplings猪肉水饺, vegetable dumplings, xiaolongbao小笼包, and Gabban noodles，zhajiang noodles炸酱面，and the three color buns. 

Thumb up for Ganban Noodles干拌面 and seafood Gyozu海鲜煎饺, I can say the Ganban Noodles is very authentic and the best here! The others are mediocre, and little bit sugary. Also this restaurant lacks of lots of different types of authentic dumplings in China, such as pork with celery and beef with carrot, which I really want to have. Also the portion is too small.
author: Kelvin Y.

description: Came here with my friend around 5:00pm on a Friday and were expecting a wait, but to our surprise we got seated right away. The place was filled inside...people really do eat dumpling at any time here. We ordered the tom yum goong, king dum, seafood gyoza, and pork & shrimp sui mai. All were really good except the king dum. This once looks IG worthy but the taste isn't as special as the other ones. Def recommend this place if you are a foodie and want those pretty pics as well as something satisfying.
author: Tiffany B.

description:
Dumpling Time is most known for their Xiao Long Bao with a straw! They serve a variety of different dumplings and noodle dishes. 

The ambience is hyped and modern. I love the neon signs, Canto-rap vibes, and Shanghai landscape line art. You can watch your dinner being made in the window as well. There is outdoor seating to enjoy the chill SF air. 

There is often a wait so come prepared. I was lucky enough to come early on a weeknight, so there was no wait for me. I've heard that the wait could take up to an hour and a half. 

I ordered the King Dum (the large XLB), regular & tom yum XLB, shrimp toast, the noodles, and the trio dessert buns. Out of all the dumplings that we tried, I would definitely say that their large XLB was my favorite. The regular and tom yum had a good amount of soup, but the wrapping was a little thick on the top. I would definitely pass on the tom yum ones next time. I was surprised by how much I liked the shrimp toast. It was a Chinese fried doughnut with shrimp paste. It was yummy, crunchy, and not too oily for a fried item. Their noodles were a yummy, dry-mix noodle. I thought the portion was a little scarce, but the noodle texture was good and the flavors were yummy. Mmm, the dessert buns were the yummiest. Soft and a good amount of filling. There was a taro, matcha, and custard. My favorite was definitely the custard, but all were a lovely way to top off the meal. 

It was a good dinner spot with a lot of variety for a group sharing. I would come back with friends who want to try.
author: Tina Y.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but I'd say it's just a pricier hipster dumpling spot. I'm a HUGE dumplings fan, and I've been to many in San Francisco, but this doesn't make the top dumplings place on my list. The presentation was good, especially for the king xlb and pork dumplings, but see below for my comments on each dish we ordered. 

Wait time: We arrived around 5:10 pm on a Friday and added ourselves to the waitlist. There were already a few groups hanging around also waiting outside. (It opens at 5:30 pm). 

Design: 
- There's a big window at the entrance that shows the chefs preparing the handmade dumplings. 
- Indoor and outdoor seating 
- Modern & hipster 

What we ordered: 

1. First to come out was the pork xian ($9 for 8 pieces). The presentation was nice - it was loaded with garlic and chives on top. The skin was very smooth and soft!! You can tell it was freshly made. But in my opinion, the skin was just the best part of this dish. 

2. Second to arrive was the seafood gyoza ($9.50 for 5 pieces). I only ordered this because other Yelp reviews claimed it was good. To be honest, it wasn't anything great. The buttery sauce that came with it was awkward and didn't mix well, but the other soy sauce with it mixed better. It was more like a green skinned ha gaw. Pricey for just 5 pieces of mediocre gyoza :/ 

3. Third to arrive was the pork XLB ($8 for 8 pieces). Again, the skin was good, but it wasn't anything better than I've had before. :( 

4. Last to arrive was the King XLB. ($8 for one piece). This dish apparently takes 25 minutes to cook, so it'd be best to order this immediately upon sitting/ordering. This was the only reason why we wanted to come. I've been wanting to go to a dumpling place with a straw to drink the soup (I've only seen this in la). I believe Dumpling Time is the first place in NorCal to have this. It's definitely the biggest soup dumplings I've had, and the first I've drank with a straw! This was the best dish we've ordered all night. It was large, juicy, soft, and flavorful. The soup was fresh, and so were the tender pork and skin. Yes, it can get messy and the soup eventually seeps through the bottom. 

We ordered 2 king xlb's but the second one took FOREVER to come out. We waited so long, and saw so many other people's King xlb's come out that we eventually got frustrated and asked our waiter to check up on it. She said "it's coming" 2 times, but we still waited and waited. She then came back and said it would take another 3 minutes. At that point; we didn't want to wait anymore. She gave us the option to wait or cancel the order, so we did cancel it. After we canceled it, her whole demeanor changed. She wasn't nice or friendly, and the way she grabbed our bill and gave it back was with attitude. Hello...it's not our fault the food took forever to come out. There's no reason to give us attitude when we're the paying customers that waited and didn't ask to cancel until she gave us that option. 

All in all, this was definitely a one time experience. I understand why this would be a "hit spot" in SoMa because there's not many in that area. But from my experience, there's a lot more better priced dumplings and flavorful tastes in other parts of SF.
author: Miranda T.

description:
If you want authentic Chinese cuisine, this place is not for you. This place is catered more towards Westerners, but regardless the food was clean and savory. I have a higher standard for xiao long bao and other dumplings.

The environment is very hip and modern, good for a first (or third) date but probably will not return again. 

We ordered the shrimp gyoza, pork buns, pork Xiao long bao and the seaweed salad. Portions were fairly small so we went to another tapas place after, hah!
author: Kevin Y.

description:
Dumpling Time was just ok. Mostly just overpriced, mediocre dumplings.

Came here on a Friday night and surprisingly the wait was only about 15 mins for a party of 2.

We received dirty and stained menus, which isn't the best first impression. 

FOOD - We got the seafood gyoza, beijing noodles, pork dumplings, pan fried cha siu bao, ha gao, and their pork xiao long baos.

Each dish was nicely presented and came with a ton of dipping sauces. I'm all for dipping sauces, but it seemed like the dumplings were all so bland and lacking in flavor that they needed the sauces to be palatable. The skins on the xiao long bao were not as thin as I'd prefer. The bbq pork buns were lacking the traditional cha siu flavor. On the plus side, the seafood gyoza and ha gow were nicely filled with plump pieces of shrimp.

SERVICE - Service here could be improved. We sat with our menus for a good 10 minutes or so before someone came to get our order. Also, after all our last few dishes came out, they immediately handed us the check along with the food, which definitely came as a surprise. What if I wanted to order more?!

Although we ordered quite a few dishes, I left feeling unsatisfied. What was supposed to be a great Friday night meal turned out to be quite a lackluster experience.

I probably wouldn't come back TBH.
author: Shirley H.

description:
The Tom Yum Xiao Long Bao is definitely worth going back for. They're pretty in pink and oh so delicious. If you decide to come here, get these soup dumplings in your belly! The regular soup dumplings are very good too, but the Tom Yum is better in my opinion. 

I think the place gets pretty noisy since our waitress had a hard time hearing our order and got it mixed up. Other than that, no other problems.
author: Allyson L.

description:
Came for lunch on a Saturday and had to wait around half an hour for a table. The wait didn't seem too bad because they have a nice and spacious patio where customers can sit. There's also a window where people can view the staff making the soup dumplings and etc., sort of similar to Din Tai Fung.

Ordered the Tom yum soup XLB, pork XLB, Beijing noodles, and the trio of buns. Both flavors of the XLB were super delicious. The skin was a little on the thick side, but I didn't mind it at all, considering it helped prevent the soup from breaking through. The noodles were more on the bland side, but I still enjoyed it. Just needed to add a bit of hot sauce to it. Lastly, the trio of buns was the best way to end the meal. The green tea and milk custard was my favorite, by far. The taro bun and the egg custard bun were also good, but next time I come, definitely getting an order of only the green tea buns. 

Can't wait to come back!
author: Annie H.

description:
A popular new SoMa venue that probably needs some more time to work out the kinks.

Inside, there are only 54 seats, all at tables of 2, 4, or 6. If you're a party of 2 or less, you'll likely need to share a table with others, and here the orders can get mixed up, as the servers will know to deliver to the right table, but not to the right seat or the right party at that table. 

While the fact that everything is made fresh to order is a huge selling point, the drawback to this is that you'll probably need to wait a while for your food after sitting down, which limits the amount of turnover that this place gets from a business perspective.

Add all this to the fact that there's a large, covered, and heated outdoor patio that's currently used as a waiting area - instead of extra dining space that could easily fit 20-30 more people - and you have a situation where waiting times can cascade spectacularly.

As for the food, all the items I tried were quite decent. The shrimp har gow, for example, had some extra fatty flavor to it thanks to a dab of cream cheese (!) and some pork filling. Each dumpling, however, was sized rather diminutively. The pork Xi'an dumplings were merely OK, and the tom yum goong (xiao long bao with pork belly, shrimp, and coconut milk, all wrapped in beet-colored skin) were decent too. Also, they can't serve alcohol at the moment, so it's either soft drinks, tea, or BYOB.

It's an OK experience overall if you're in the area and you're really craving dumplings. If you're more about value than quality, however, then cheap, run-of-the-mill dim sum bakeries in Chinatown can be just as satisfying.
author: Vincent L.

description:
3.5 STARS. Upon reviewing their Yelp while waiting in line on Christmas Day (2017), my boyfriend and I noticed that Dumpling Time has significantly increased their prices within the past year. For example, the char siu bao increased in price from $5 to $6 and the tom yum goong from $7 to $9. The wait wasn't too long and the heaters outside made the patio bearable. Service was quick and attentive. Now onto the dim sum. 

~ CHAR SIU BAO (3pcs/$6; 4/5): I like char siu bao and this tasted like any other one I've had. Good, but nothing special.
~ KING DUM ($9; 3/5): My boyfriend wanted this "for the gram"... I didn't think it was worth it at all. The soup was hard to drink out of the giant bao and the bao itself was difficult to eat since it was so large. And because it was so large you can't eat it with the soup without it spilling everywhere. In turn, you're not getting the true XLB effect.
~ TOM YUM GOONG (6 pcs/$9.50; 4/5): I was drawn towards these not only because they were red but also because of the pork, shrimp and coconut milk combo. I didn't really taste any coconut at all and these were pretty basic XLB. Not worth almost $10 in my book.  
~ MAIN LOBSTER SIU MAI (4pcs/$12; 3/5): These were super disappointing... Not only were they stupid overly priced for what you got, I couldn't even taste any truffle. The siu mai themselves just tasted like shrimp, not the fancy main lobster they claim it to be. 
~ SHRIMP TOAST ($12; 4/5): This dish was my favorite of the meal. The "toast" was crispy and the shrimp on top was generous. The sauce that was drizzled on seemed to be some kind of sriracha sauce which was pretty tasty.

Overall, Dumpling Time is definitely unwarrantedly overpriced dim sum. Although the dishes were generally good, there wasn't anything spectacular that I would want to come back for or couldn't get from somewhere else.
author: Annie N.

description:
Dumpling Time is truly a place to discover different kinds of dumplings. They do not take reservations but the waiting time was just 15min which is nothing for a New Yorker ;) 
We ordered dumplings a-la-family-style, baos, gyozas and some vegetables. Everything was really tasty. Also try their white or oolong tea.
author: Nin H.

description:
Dumpling Time is great! 

Its in our neighborhood and a "local gem".

The service is prompt, attentive and friendly. Their dumplings are very good and worth the wait during lunch. Food to watch them prepare via a glass window too!
author: Mike R.

description:
Located in the design district, dumpling time is a very unique dim sum place that certainly looks nothing like a usual dim sum joint. With Asian looking decorations and kpop projected on the wall, this was definitely a unique SF restaurant. 

Although the decor and aesthetics were really pretty, the food is the most important part, and I would say it was rather disappointing. The shrimp dumplings were pretty basic, and more expensive than other dim sum places. It came with this really delicious green dipping sauce, but I'm not sure if that was worth the price. The Beijing noodles were probably the most disappointing, with such a small portion and quite dry. It seemed like they were trying to make a "fancy" version of basic Chinese food, and I'm not sure they succeeded. However, judging by the long lineups and packed restaurant, they seem to be doing quite well.
author: Carl C.

description:
Great addition to this area! It's a fun modern take on the dumpling house.

If you're familiar with Din Tai Fung, there are some similarities: service style - your order receipt is left on table so that the servers check off what has already been brought to you, clear window panes to see the dumplings being made in real-time, long wait times (depending on day & time you arrive).

Faves:  shrimp toast (shrimp paste on a traditional Taiwanese long donut), shrimp & cilantro har gow

Pork XLB was good; better than most places, but I wouldn't put it at the same level as Din Tai Fung. Would like to try the big "king dum" next time.

Pork Xi'An dumpling was visually stunning with its flower decor, but the dumplings themselves weren't all that great.

Made the mistake of ordering the plain pork bao instead of the char siu bao. Filling was meh (pretty much the same as the pork xi'an dumpling).

Was shocked to see cream cheese as an ingredient in the other har gow option! To me, cream cheese is an ultimate no-no for Asian food.

Outdoor patio still in progress, but looks like a great use of space.

Parking can be hit or miss in the area, but you might luck out and get a free curb spot nearby!
author: Tina W.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE dim sum. I've been here with my family twice and I'm already excited for my next visit here. :) To secure a spot when it opens, put your name down on the list 15-20 minutes before it opens! If it looks like no one is around, it's usually because people are waiting in their cars cause it's cold/windy. So don't be alarmed by a huge crowd when it opens! 

It may take a while for the food to come around within the first hour because the kitchen is backed up on orders, but it's worth it! I wouldn't get the shrimp toast because the fried toast isn't as fresh as the ones you can get at Chinatown. It has a very unique taste with the spicy mayo on top and a small piece of shrimp inside the toast. The har gow skin is really delicate that it breaks once you try to lift it from its tray. I would recommend the siu mai! It tastes just like how it should at other dim sum restaurants! The XLB is a MUST. In fact, get three orders of it because you can easily finish it. My favorite part of the meal is the dessert. The green tea milk bun is the best one. Condensed milk cream in the middle and green tea as the base. A nice mix. 

I am docking one star off for the customer service. I understand that it can be chaotic because of so many people you need to be aware of. But some of the workers would display their annoyance that made it difficult to ask for something like more napkins or a refill of tea. We wouldn't know whether or not our requests would actually come through. 

Other than that, food is delicious.
author: Sarah F.

description: This place exceed my expectations. The quality of food, taste, service, presentation and staff were exceptional. The waiter provide his recommendations on the bbq pork Bao seared and seafood gyoza, both were very delicious. It was not overly expensive and definitely filling. I would definitely come back again.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Service: 3 stars
Food: 3.5 stars for price and taste

I feel like this place is overhyped by our generation and is overpriced... 
I thought this would be a bit like dim sum kind of vibe so I brought my grandparents, parents, and husband here. 
I saw that this place opens up at 11am so we all arrived at 10:45 to hopefully avoid the long waiting time. 

We were the first people there along with one other couple until they open. The door to the restaurant was originally opened and the servers saw us waiting around for a bit and decided to close the doors to the restaurant... I felt like they could have taken our names down first before doing that. Once the restaurant opened, there was quite a crowd of people already and the server that saw us several times gave the list to someone that just came.

Our bill came out to be $151.38 for 14 dishes with 18% gratuity for a party of 5 or more... we ordered the three-sum baos to go and they charged us the 18% gratuity for it too... it's not much but still weird in my book. 

Some of the dishes I regret ordering the most were:

Lobster siu mai ($12 for 4 pieces... it tasted like regular sui mai)
The shrimp toast ($8 for a roll of Chinese donut with a very small amount of shrimp in the middle. So small that my dad didn't even noticed there were shrimp. Definitely not even a third of the amount as one of the yelp picture of it shows)
Cucumber salad ($5 for a tiny bowl of pickled cucumber..)
Beijing and gan ban noodles ($9.50 for small bowl of oily noodles)

Dishes that were good but were still a bit overpriced:

King-dum XLB ($9 for one... comes with a straw to drink the scorching hot soup before eating the dumpling. I recommend transferring it to another bowl cause it was no easy to drink it)
Tom yum goong XLB ($9.50 for 6 pcs)
Pork dumpling ($9 for 8 pieces, tasted like average dumpling with colorful veggies decoration like cherry tomatoes and red radishes)
Shrimp and pork siu mai ($6 for 4 pieces)
Crispy tofu squares ($5, not crispy like the name)

Dishes I will order again in the off chance I ever end up there again:

Taro and beet bao ($6 for 3)
Green tea and milk bao ($6 for 3)
Three-sum ($6 for 3, very awkward to order but I recommend trying this; they're unique and yummy)
Shrimp and cilantro har gow ($6.50 for 4 pieces, this was really good and their cilantro sauce adds a refreshing taste to it)
author: Heidi V.

description:
Great hipster dumpling spot! We arrived at 1:45p and apparently that's the perfect time to go. No wait, not too crowded and only one item was sold out (tear but we survived without it).

Shrimp toast: I love any fried food and this was a Chinese fried donut topped w a grounded/chopped shrimp (YUM).

XLB: was very soupy (wished the vinegar was more acidic tho).

The seared chicken buns (you can also get them steamed) w the addition of black mushrooms was seasoned well and the bun itself was nice and springy.

Seafood gyoza: had a cool thin crispy crunchy paper like bottoms. Haven't seen these anywhere before.

Good to know...
Outdoor patio is opening up very soon and this part of town is generally sunny.
You get to see the Chefs rolling dumplings in the window when you arrive. 
Service can be slow when they are busy (but thats anywhere you go). 
ENJOY!
author: Liz N.

description:
Really a 3.5 star, but I bumped it up since good XLB places are still kinda rare in NorCal. 

I arrived right when the doors opened at 5pm with Jessica D. and waited about 10 minutes before we were seated at a two-person table. 

Thank god we got here at 5. If not, we would have been seated at their weird 6-person communal table! I have nothing against communal tables but those tables put you right up against your neighbor. I think Dumpling Time could benefit from a different table set up: more 2/4 person table and do away with the awkward 6-person tables in the middle. 

We ended up ordering: 
1) Pork XLB (3/5): I had high exceptions and these were honestly a disappointment. The skin was the right thickness and consistency, but the soup was pretty bland. Other XLB places have much more flavorful dumpling broth. 

2)Tom Yum Goong XLB (5/5): Favorite dumpling ever! Both of us LOVED these.  There's a hint of beet flavor from the skin, but nothing overwhelming. There's also a nice little kick from the meat which makes these dumplings amazing. The soup was also very flavorful! I could gobble up at least a dozen of these!

3)Seafood Gyoza (3/5): These were alright. I will admit I got it for the spinach skin.... Nothing that blew me away. The aioli sauce was a bit weird. Both of us avoided that. 

As long as there's no wait and I'm already in the area, I'll come back and order several rounds of the Tom Yum Goong XLBs.
author: Angela W.

description:
Came here on a week night with my boyfriend and my friend for dinner. We were super interested in what Dumpling Time had to offer since it was listed as Hot & New on yelp. We got here around 6pm and there was at least an hour and half wait. We were seated outside in a small table (usually it's for two people) but we were hungry so we didn't really care and got seated. The waitress brought the menu and we were looking through what to order. To be honest, the waiters weren't very attentive with our table it seems since they never really came around to check up on us unless they brought our foods out. 

So for our dinner, we ordered the shrimp toast, xiao long baos (comes in 6), king dum (giant xlb with a straw lol), chicken gyoza, char-siu bao (pan seared), beijing noodles, shrimp & cilantro har gow, and trio of buns. Shrimp toast was plain. XLB were good and honestly you can never go wrong with that. Kim Dum was yummy but all the soup just came out the moment it was served. It was so hard to suck up the soup through the straw too but the concept was cute. Char-siu bao was pretty good though and the beijing noodles were flavorful. Shrimp & cilantro was alright, nothing special. 

Pricing isn't too bad at this place. It's cheaper than DTF but I think I enjoyed DTF more to be honest. I wish the XLB came with more than 6 pieces lol. 

Overall, we had a good time but I don't think it was amazing.
author: Monica W.

description:
Came here with a group of people and had a really great dinner sampling something from each part of the menu. Yeah, there's usually a bit of a wait. The food was pretty rich and good all-around, with no complaints, and I only knocked it a star because I like cheaper food.

Highlights were: the fried tofu (so silky and delicious), the fried donut with shrimp, the regular XLB, the tom yum XLB (contrary to some reviews, I liked it as much as the regular ones!), the wagyu dumplings, and the beijing noodles (tasted handmade!) in that order. We got one of the king dumplings just to try, as well. The happy ending dessert buns were good, too. The only one I didn't like was the xi-an vegetarian dumpling, which sadly lacked taste and flavor.

I do recommend going with a group of maybe 5 people so you can sample more of the menu since each order usually comes with 4-6 pieces but ordering several for yourself would be costly. Hoping to come back here to celebrate an occasion with family sometime.

Go here and then go to Milk Bomb for dessert afterwards (10 min walking distance) for a happy time!
author: Electra C.

description:
Zoh Em Gee! Came today (Saturday) at noon without having to wait (whuuut) 

SERVICE:excellent 
PRICE: reasonable 
AMBIANCE: Casual
WHAT YOU MUST GET: Garlic green beans, shrimp toast (Chinese donut), pork XLB, Char siu Bao (seared)

PSA: Patio dining/set up is coming up, bigger and better menu also coming soon 

When we left around 1pm, the line got really long (probably 45 min wait) so lucky we beat that rush!
author: Gwen M.

description:
For nut allergies, don't use the hot chili oil, there are peanuts in it.

SF needed something like this. An Americanized dim sum place lol. It's in the perfect location and is awesome for Instagram pics. Knock yourself out. You'll love it.
author: Joshua F.

description: The line moves fast. The food comes out even faster and you will find yourself full really quick, which is disappointing because I'm sure you may have ordered more then you can handle. We did that during our first visit, and I'm sure that will happen during our 2nd, 3rd, and 4th visits. Oh well that's the risk you take when you're eating good food.
author: Mel P.

description:
Pretty good dim sum! Not the traditional one I'm used to, but still pretty good.

Easy parking, a little expensive, but definitely worth it.
author: Jeremy Anne C.

description: The space and food is good and they definitely cater to a younger crowd but I feel like I could get the same thing and even more food for the price you pay at any other decent dim sum place in the city. Glad I came but won't be going twice.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I really like that the dim sum is good despite the fact that this place caters to non-Asians. Keep in mind, though, that the menu is limited, and, since they're new and popular, they haven't mastered not running out of food. There's currently a one per table cap on regular-sized xlb, which seems to be working better than no xlb, but it's kinda a bummer. 

I'll return when they're more established.
author: Paulina F.

description:
Quality dumplings!! My new favorite spot for Dumplings in the Bay Area. 

Wait: They seem to be working out the kinks for wait times etc but the wait times are nowhere near as long as Din Tai Fung in San Jose. However, you may get a table all to yourself. I ended up sharing a table with a different group who was already seated. 

Food: Delicious Dumplings for reasonable prices! The food came out fresh and steaming hot. 

Fried BBQ Pork Buns- The BBQ pork filling was delicious and I really enjoyed having the buns seared a bit on the outside. 

Steamed Chicken Buns- The chicken filling was not as savory as the BBQ pork filling. I liked the steamed buns equally compared to the Fried version because they place a cute stamp on each bun when you get it steamed. 

XLB- So much broth! I loved it! I was definitely making slurping sounds eating each dumpling. Though the dumplings were small, each is hand made and delicate. 

Beet XLB- I was a bit disappointed that these wrappers turned out to be brown and not purple as expected. Nonetheless the filling was still delicious. There was noticeably less broth compared to the regular XLBs but still worth a try. 

Seafood Dumplings- I loved the filling and butter sauce! These are filled with quality seafood that went amazing with the butter sauce. I experimented and combined the soy sauce with butter sauce and I recommend it :) 

If you love dumplings, you will have a marvelous time eating here.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Date & Time:  Monday May 22, 2017 @ 5:30pm
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  Techies Dine Alongside Groups of Trendy Shanghai Kids in Rebecca Minkoff Blush or Little Black Dresses Paired w/ Tory Burch Ruffled Sneakers & YSL Cross-Body Bags
Music:  Asian Rap
Decor:  Nicely Painted Mural  & Lighted Sign on Walls.  Small Dumpling Bar, Tables for Two or Small Groups and Communal Tables
Service: Enthusiastic, Energetic, Efficient
Imbibe:  Lychee Tea
Devour:  Shrimp Toast, Beijing Noodles, King-Dum, Pork Dumpling, Trio of Buns
Total:  $45.56
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Might be the best soup dumplings in San Francisco. The food was very good and I like mostly everything. Dumpling time just opened therefore needs improvement. Major issue was it took 30 mins for our food to come out and the first dish was our dessert buns. They told us not to open it to keep it warm but we were hungry had to eat our desserts first after a long wait to be seated. The buns were soft and not dry. They also ran out seafood gyoza out, was so sad. If they gave us those first instead of the sweet buns. Just saying. 

Pork XLB - My favorite. Thin skin, a lot of soup and the soup is sweet. Very tasty. 
Shrimp Toast - Too dry. Not enough flavor. Too much mayo. 
Pork Gyoza - like another pot-stickers. But its still good and crispy. Really wanted to try the seafood one. 
Tom Yum Goong - It was good but the soup is not as good as the regular pork. 
Cha Siu Bao - Love it. Small but very soft and tasty. The cha siu was not red which was awesome. 
Beijing Noodles - I like the noodles, not oily and the meat was very tender and full of flavor. 
Bao Trio - Green Tea & Milk, Egg Yolk, Beet & Taro - I think all their buns are well made. Not over cooked and soft.

My friend and I got there at 615pm on a Friday night and waited a little over an 1 hour for a table of two. 4 stars for the food but whole delivery of the food needs a lot of work.
author: Sandy B.

description: Really good dumplings. Noodles were ok. Green beans were great. The green and white dessert buns were very tasty, red was only ok. There were a lot of people waiting but we didn't have to wait long to be seated (Sunday at 7pmish only waited like 20 mins) Only one vegetarian option for dumplings which was a bummer. Had to share a table with strangers and I didn't like that but it got us seated.
author: Dinah D.

description:
I thought the food was 4.5 stars but the service was just okay. Price to quantity ratio isnt great

I got the cucumber salad, garlic green beans, shrimp gyoza, vegetable dumplings, and gan ban noodles to share, along with tea. Everything was delicious, and the vegetable dumplings were surprisingly delicious.
