The odd thing is that the waiters kept on placing the plates on the very edge of the table, next to my boyfriend's elbow when ever they reached the table, even when the center of the table had room. I even directed them at one point "put it in the middle of the table", while making ample room for it, and the waiter didnt respond and left it in the corner in distance for elbows to just knock the entire dish off. Weird.

The ambience and plating is nicer than most Chinese restaurants, so if you want to impress someone and have Chinese food, this might be the place.
author: Crystal Y.

description:
My friend and I came here on a Saturday before 5:30pm to beat the dinnertime crowds. This place fills up fast! We shared the following:

SEAFOOD GYOZA
This was my favorite. Amply stuffed with shrimp!
CRISPY CHAR-SIU BAO 
PORK XLB
I thought the foil trays that these came in were rather convenient for catching spilled soup!
XI'AN VEGETARIAN DUMPLINGS
These dumplings were beautifully garnished with what seemed like a whole salad of radishes, sprouts, dill, cherry tomatoes, and red hot chili peppers. Beware of the peppers! They are quite spicy. As for the dumplings themselves, I wasn't so keen of the mushy filling. I'm used to filling that is of a firmer consistency. 
SHRIMP TOAST
I'm not a fan of Chinese doughnut so the toast part was a bit too greasy and overpowering for me.

Overall, everything was delicious and we went away with full bellies. I would definitely come back here to try other items on the menu and order the yummy seafood gyoza again.
author: Lauren H.

description: First tried this place for lunch with coworker... Had to try it for dinner. Very busy.  So I got take out.  Ha gow are my favorite. I don't normally like sui mai but wow these were awesome.  Change my mind on them.  This may sound strange but I really like the chili oil... It had peanuts in it... Wonder if I could buy it by the bottle.  Also tried the lobster siu mai... Seems like over kill... Don't think you can really appreciate the lobster in this format. Imo.  Another favorite place added to my list.
author: William L.

description:
Average dumplings for a premium price. There was almost no soup in my 'soup dumplings' and the skin would rip when taking it out of the the tin cup. When I got my giant sized xlb, the soup was already at the bottom of the plate, the straw wasn't necessary

My Beijing noodles were bland and plain, but at least it wasn't as greasy as other places.

$40 for 2 orders of xlb, beijing noodles, and one king sized xlb.

We came at opening around 11:40 and there was already a line out the door.  We waited 15 minutes to get a spot at the communal table and an addition 20-30 for food.  Maybe we came on an off day, but that's just me. I won't come back.
author: Angelica C.

description:
My friend was gonna take me to Thai place on the opposite side of the street but since this was open and new we tried Dumpling Time out.

It's a busy and Noisy place.  Small and tight space.  Big screen with videos on and loud music so everyone was shouting to be heard.

Food I tried was just so-so.  Dumplings were tiny and tasted ok, gyoza was good, but tiny.  Green beans salty.  Pickled veggies were ok.  Sweet buns 3 different ones were mild with some cream inside.

Kinda pricey.  I might go back, but not in any hurry.
author: Ann L.

description:
Lunch time is Dumpling Time! He wanted to have an early lunch around 11am, which was the perfect opportunity to try out this new popular spot. He immediately noticed how hipster the restaurant is.

LA Yi Z. would've been appalled by the prices here but SF Yi Z. glanced over the menu and calmly ordered 5 items:
-Pork XLB (6 dumplings)
-Tom Yum Goong XLB (6 dumplings)
-Pork Gyoza (5 dumplings)
-Shrimp Toast (6 pieces)
-Char Siu Bao (3 buns)

The XLB are individually put into tins for steaming. This is not my preferred presentation for XLB; I would rather not have to struggle to get the dumplings out of the containers when it's time to eat. Both were solid choices and both were juicy. 4.5*

The Char Siu Bao was pretty good as well. This is not a dish I usually order at dim sum and I did enjoy the pan-fried surface to give it more texture. 4.5*

Shrimp Toast is a Chinese donut filled with shrimp paste. I liked the interpretation of this dish. It's a little oily but quite satisfying. 4*

The Pork Gyoza was disappointing to me. It needed more crunch on the bottom. It felt soggy. 3*

Overall, not a bad option if you're craving Chinese food and you're in the area. Total for two including tax & tip = $50.
author: Yi Z.

description:
DUMPLING TIME
My friend and I were the first ones to arrive a little before opening.  There's an outdoor patio area with benches where people can sit and wait.  A few people trickled in and we were all waiting by the benches.  I saw two people arrive and headed inside to place their name on the waiting list.  They were turned away when the hostess said she'll take names once they open.  Oh heck no, I arrived first so Imma be first.  I got up and made my way to the front and stood in front of the door.  

Shrimp Toast - the toast was nice and crispy and the shrimp was perfectly cooked. Good with and w/o soy sauce
Cha Siu Bao (pan fried) - they don't serve pan friend dumplings so this was the closest thing to it.  I normally don't eat cha siu baos but these were god.  The bao was soft and the meat had good flavor
Tom Yum Goong - some places make it really good and others really bad.  This was really good.  Nice and soupy, skin had nice texture, 
Green Tea Milk Bun - Nice and soft and the custard was tasty, not too sweet

Overall, good service, good food
author: Linda N.

description:
Dinner review.

Shrimp toast - 5/5
Har gow - 4/5
Pork Gyoza - 3/5
Seafood Gyoza - 5/5 - The best. Order this.
Char siu bao - 5/5
Pork XLB - 5/5
Pork dumpling xi'an - 3/5
Beijing noodles - 5/5

Egg yolk buns - 5/5

Overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
BYOB for the next monthish till they get their license to ill YES there's drank on the menu NO none of it's orderable NO idk ytf reviewers didn't feel like mentioning this importantazz fact :p #nothatin

fun small crowded place. you & your frendos be prepared to waitlist behind hegga asians lol or #realballersonly just walk tf in like i did seated right away trick.

(^_^) Shrimp Toast $8 (http://bit.ly/2pWn5tv)
do what all these beezys say just getit

(^_^) Seafood Gyoza $7.5per5 (http://bit.ly/2q7k8RM)
tastin hezza dipped... saucy

(-_^) Tom Yum Goong $7per6 (http://bit.ly/2qFzKQC)
tony jaa muhfuhs
"beet skin" not as wilinout as you think

(-_-) XL BBQ Pork Bao $7 (http://bit.ly/2roVoZU)
just ok

3some next to me ordered 6 dishes did they get full? ::shrug:: i had 4 dishes like a snizzack. n #donteventrip abt the xl "so big you need a straw" "so big take it back to the ffffn office" items rltk they ain't jumbo #thatswhatshesaid

tl;wgaf either pregame #DomM byob or don't go yet wait like a month for lit status. 3.5 for nows.
author: Dan B.

description:
This place has been officially open for less than a week, and while it has its flaws, it's still a welcome addition to the SOMA restaurant scene.

The prices are reasonable, around $1/XLB, for the quality and taste of the dishes. The pork XLBs are about as good as I've had in other places, with a very thin skin that's not too doughy, while maintaining a hearty serving of soup in each bite. The other standouts are the baos, I most enjoyed the pork bao, followed by the chicken bao, and then char-siu. The pork was the most well seasoned and flavorful. I got them all pan seared and the quality and taste of the dough really made them standout.

The gyoza were OK, nothing too special about them. Same for the regular har gow, I did not bother to try the cream cheese har gow. The shrimp toast was tasty and unique, but on my way out I was disappointed to see that they were using store bought bread and just adding the shrimp paste. I guess this is no different from restaurants that buy their pasta instead of making it fresh, and it won't stop me from getting the shrimp toast again, I just hope they change that in the future.

Overall, this place is off to a good start and as long as they don't keep bumping up their prices (seems some items have gone up from opening day) and maintain the consistency, it will be a SOMA go-to spot.

Large groups beware, lines form quickly. And be sure to get our entire order in at once since if you stagger it, you may wait a long time between orders (the wait staff is good about warning you).
author: Gonzalo S.

description:
In every job, we have to deal with different personalities and annoying co-workers. 

Probably one of the most annoying things is when someone sends you an email, and before you can even take a sip of your tea/coffee, you find them behind you, breathing down your neck: "Did you see my email? I sent it 29 seconds ago!" And, then they stand there and stare at you until you respond over email. 

Granted, emergencies come up that require your urgent response. But, when they're asking for bakery recommendations and what color fondant they should get for their bf's birthday cake that's 2 months and 11 days away...GTFOH! (Ok, I would never say that but c'mon now).

As you walk in, Dumpling Time has a dumpling exhibition area like Din Tai Fung. Here, you even enjoy your meal in front of the dumpling makers and watch the magic happen. Much props to them for having to deal with people watching their every move, snapping pics, and videotaping them (I was one of them). Imagine if someone watched us 24/7 at our cubicle/office. Yeaaa, PornHub will just have to wait. 

Dumpling Time softly opened yesterday (thanks, Ann S. for the heads up) in the former Source and Dusty Buns space. It's walk-in only and no reservations. 

The menu is comprised of Chinese and Japanese dumplings with a CA twist, baos, noodles, and small veggie side dishes. Everything is super reasonably priced with nothing over $9. Beer and wine only. 

Mr. Diva likes to order a sh*t ton of food which I'm always down for. How else are you going to get a good sampling of the menu? We ordered the following:

*Cucumber Salad ($3)
*Pickled Lotus ($3)
*Shrimp Toast ($6): http://bit.ly/2rslRT3
*Shrimp Har Gow (4 pc - $6): http://bit.ly/2qxNaMu
*Seafood Gyoza w/ spinach skin, spiced chili butter aioli (5 pc - $7.50): http://bit.ly/2r25QXw
*Pork Gyoza (5 pc - $6.25): http://bit.ly/2rs2NEu
*Pork XLB: Heritage pork, savory soup, shao-sing wine (6 pc - $6): http://bit.ly/2qSUN34
*Tom Yum Goong: Heritage pork, black tiger shrimp, coconut milk, beet skin (6 pc - $7): http://bit.ly/2qtVX3U
*Cha Siu Bao (BBQ Pork), pan seared (3 pc - $5): http://bit.ly/2pMi46l
*Beijing Noodles w/ pork, green onion, ginger, soybean paste ($9): http://bit.ly/2rgk46Y
*Bao Trio: Green Tea & Milk, Egg Yolk, Beet & Taro ($5): http://bit.ly/2rslFUj

My favorites...
The Shrimp Toast was a halved youtiao (Chinese cruller) that's topped with shrimp paste and a dollop of spicy aioli. Crunchy and chewy with a good amount of fresh shrimp paste. Carby goodness. 

The Pork XLBs are the best in SF next to Yank Sing and Crystal Jade (better than DTF which is overrated IMO). The skin is thin and these bad boys are hella juicy. When you pick it up with your chopstick, the XLB sags like big 'ol tatas which is a good sign. I like to switch it up by biting a hole at the top and sucking the broth out, and popping a whole one in my mouth. If you do the latter, be prepared for a wonderful broth EXPLOSION in your mouth! It's served with red wine vinegar and ginger. Personally, I like black vinegar more (smoky) so I hope they have that option in the future. 

The Cha Siu Bao (pan seared) had nicely browned, crisp bottoms and fluffy tops with a savory pork filling. The filling is slightly creamier than the traditional filling since they add peanut butter. 

I love har gow and these were a good fusion rendition with a cream cheese filling and a chimichurri-like dipping sauce. The barely translucent skin had a good stretchy chew and was generously filled with plump shrimp. I know it sounds a little odd but the combo of cheese, shrimp, and the herby green sauce had delicious layers of flavors. 

The Green Tea & Milk Bao was the perfect ending to our meal. Didn't taste much green tea but the bao was soft and the filling was like a creamy milky custard. Very yummy. 

My least favorite was the Beijing Noodles (Zhajiangmian). The handmade noodles were overcooked and soggy. 

The staff was friendly but a little on the green side. It wasn't clear who are server was was so ended up flagging down various servers when we didn't receive certain orders. Totally understandable given it was day one and I'm sure they'll ramp up soon. 

The owner did a great job revamping the former Source and Dusty Bun space into a hip and chic yet casual space with a hand drawn mural, a beautifully statuesque floral arrangement in the center of the dining room, and Chinese movies playing on the wall. There's ample seating so it's great for a casual date or for a small group dinner. Can't wait until they open their front patio so I can bring TT along. 

Parking can be tough on the weekdays because of nearby offices but it's super easy on the weekends. 

Solid food and properly made dumplings that will appease both Chinese traditionalists and modernists, and most importantly, at non-gentrification prices (please don't compare this to your fav hole-in-the-wall on Clement), Dumpling Time is going to be the new hot spot in SF!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Tried for the first time today while I was in the area. I am on a budget but needed to get lunch in the area. It was me on my own, so wasn't looking for anything special or fancy, just something that would fill me up. 

I opted for something under the Soup Dumplings section of the menu, thinking that this would be a soup with dumplings in it. The item was Pork XLB- pork belly, savory soup, shao-sing wine. I asked a waitress to help me make a choice, but she didn't mention that this was just 6 steamed dumplings with soup inside. 

I definitely don't hold her responsible for this mix-up, but the menu could certainly be clearer. 'steamed dumplings filled with soup' might be a better way of putting it, as I (not unreasonably) assumed that the words were in a slightly unconventional order (but that's not unusual for this area) but effectively just meant it was a soup with dumplings in it. 

I'm definitely not a dumpling aficionado, and have never been to a dumpling place before, so I know nothing about the lingo that's used and what it all means. A little more explanation, maybe even a hipster-ish pencil representation of each style of dumpling, would be helpful for anyone that, like, isn't an expert because it's what they grew up eating. 

I had that problem with a lot of the dishes - couldn't understand what it would look like and if it would be just a couple of bites or a full entree. Something like this "Shrimp toast: Chinese donut, minced shrimp, spicy aoli $8" - I was interested but had no idea what to expect, so didn't order it. Is it like 1 slice of sliced bread, kind of size? Or is it a few slices of this dish? What is Chinese donut anyway, I've never heard of it?

Anyway the soup dumplings were tasty enough, but I couldn't help thinking how weird is this, these little tiny bite-size dumplings with a little pork and some hot SOUP inside and dipping sauce? A little weird in my world. I added lots of chili sauce as the dish was lacking flavor a little. 

I ordered this dish thinking it would be my lunch - it certainly wasn't enough for a lunch. More like an appetizer for one person. $8.50 was too much for 6 small dumplings that could basically be eaten in 6 bites. If two people were dining together, and all portions are about the same size, I would definitely recommend at least 3 dumpling dishes. 

As I was about to go into a meeting, I needed more sustenance. So I asked to see the menu again (added a picture of it here) and picked the only thing on the menu that I perceived to be a filling dish - noodles. Luckily I had time to order again and wait for another dish to be prepared. Can't go wrong there, right, it's noodles? Well, they were pretty good - certainly didn't disappoint. 

I was hoping it wouldn't be a tiny 6-bite portion, and it was not. It was a medium size bowl of delicious noodles, green onions, ginger, soybean paste and savory pork very well flavored and seasoned, unlike the dumplings which were just a touch bland and like anything you can get from the cheap Chinatown vendors with the huge bamboo baskets. I had a similar dish to this at a hip noodle place in LA, but have to admit the LA place blew this one out of the water. 

I would love to see more of a combo platter of different dumplings for the solo diner, as there is no way of getting a variety of dumplings except if you have a large group and order 10 different dishes. I know this kind of thing is probably anti-hipster rules though and would offend the purist. 

Doubt I will be back as the experience was too perplexing and I rarely have a need to be in this part of the City, but I must admit I had some reasonably good food, though I was trying to find a value-for-money place for lunch and had no idea that I'd be spending $23.75 for 2 dishes and nothing else, with the tip and the obligatory sales tax AND 'SF Mandate Tax 4%'. I was hoping to keep it around $10 all in, ouch.
author: Zoe L.

description: Great service and delicious food - the egg buns at the end are the best. We went back twice in one week and I am left wishing this were a chain we could find in the DC area.
author: Papaya M.

description:
I would rate this place a 3.5, but because I don't have that option, a 4 it is! 

We ordered garlicky green beans, ban gan noodles, a variety of xiao long bao, a variety of dumplings, steamed bao and shrimp toast. 

I am obsessed with the garlicky green beans, garlicky and crunchy, it was hands down my favorite thing we ordered. Right behind the green beans was the shrimp toast. 

The pork soup dumplings were pretty good. The tom yum soup dumplings had a slight lemon grassy flavor but it wasn't too obvious. Not my fav, but just ok. The vegetable and shrimp dumplings were ok too. Good in flavor but I've had better. 

I was caught off guard by a shrimp and cream cheese dumpling. I didn't realize what was inside, but that cream cheese really threw me off. 

The noodles were bland and didn't really have flavor. 

Service was lacking, it didn't feel personable. I felt rushed, but it could have been that it was close to closing time. The atmosphere was nice and definitely targeted towards a younger crowd.
author: Emie S.

description:
1. Expensive tasty dumplings 
2. Be patient because the line can be long
3. Best for more formal occasions
author: Eileen H.

description:
Overhyped - Overpriced - only for the gram - Bland bok gwai food

Been wanting to come here since they've opened. Unfortunately, it wasn't as great as I hoped it'd be. Menu choices are limited, prices and seasoning seems to be catered to the hipsters/bok gwai.. even their chili oil paste wasn't spicy, too bad. Only thing we enjoyed was their Beijing Noodles, after we pretty much emptied their chili oil container. Worst of all, their greasy, soggy barely any vegetable egg rolls - skip and save your money. 

Food was mediocre - Service was crap
author: Flo F.

description:
Definitely come here early if you want the large XLB! I came here on a Saturday afternoon and waited about 90 minutes before we got seated. Sadly they were out of the large XLB, but noneless they also had other yummy items on the menu.

My friend and I got:
The Shrimp Toast
Tom Yum XLB
Pork XLB
Seafood Gyoza
Trio Dessert Bun

If you guys are here to take pictures of everything for your instagram this isn't the place for you LOL. The food comes periodically go you can enjoy your food one dish at a time while they are still hot. Unless you want to be extra like me and wait, but your food will be cold!

Anyway, the shrimp toast and the seafood Gyoza were delicious! The you tiao or "toast" part of the dish were super crispy and compliments the shrimp. I was a bit disappointed with the XLB because ours came really dry. I saw that the table next to us got fresh fluffy ones so we must have got the last batch before they started a new batch.

Btw even though we didn't get the large XLB, according to one of the server, the tom yum  XLB taste just like it. My friend really liked the tom yum ones as it has a kick to the typical pork XLB.

The trio buns were so good as well! My favorite one out of the trio was the taro bun because they use real taro as the filling.

Overall, I would give this place a 4/5. I minus one star because the XLB could have been better, but everything else was delicious. It is a bit pricey for dumplings, but I do think some of the dishes taste better than some dim sum resturants.
I recommend this place if you want to try a twist on your traditional dumplings, but definitely come early!
author: Grace Z.

description:
Dumpling Time is going to be a super cool spot once they get their wine and beer license...but for now it's just okay. Most of the dumplings have a nice thin skin but sadly aren't actually very flavorful. I liked the Tom Yum dumplings because the filling had a nice little kick I wasn't expecting, and the King-Dum (a giant XLB that fills a small steamer) is great for the gram. Unfortunately, the XLBs both big and small aren't the best I've had compared to other dumpling spots, and the soup is thinner than the rich, gelatinous-y kind I'm a fan of.

Skip the chicken gyoza and the dessert buns--there is barely any flavor in either of them! The star of the show is definitely the shrimp toast: shrimp paste stuffed into Chinese donuts and fried before getting topped with some yummy aioli.
author: Grace C.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here around 2pm on a Saturday and the wait list was kind of long. I didn't think we were going to make it but we were seated at 2:30pm (half an hour before closing time). Good thing we knew exactly what we wanted to order so the waitress took our order right away. I was afraid they ran out of the King-Dum by the time we were seated but luckily we made it! Phew!

* Tom Yum Goong (Pork belly, shrimp, coconut milk, wrapped in a beet skin) 6pcs/$9.50 - 5 stars
This dish was very unique. It actually has Tom Yum flavor inside!! The texture of the dough was just right. It was so bomb!

* King-Dum (So big, you'll need a straw!) 1pc/$9 - 4 stars
It was good but a bit too doughy. Not as good as the soup dumpling but it was still good to try. I like how you can drink the soup through a straw! Definitely something different. Be careful when you drink the soup, let it cool down before sucking! It's very hot! 

* Beijing Noodles (Pork, green onion, ginger, soybean paste) $9.50 - 5 stars
The noodles were very fresh and the texture was perfect. The flavor was great! I just wish the portion was bigger.

*Three-sum (Green tea & milk bun, Beet & taro bun, Egg yolk bun) 3pcs/$6 - 5 stars
We got the trio buns! All the flavors were there and the buns were moist. It was indeed a happy ending!

We both came here with low expectations since there were mixed reviews about this place. But the food turned out a lot better than we expected! The atmosphere was nice. I like how you can see the workers make fresh dumplings through the glass windows. 

They have a mixture of indoor and outdoor seating. They have a few communal tables so if you don't mind eating at the same table with others then they could seat you right away. The space can get pretty tight when it's busy. We sat in the middle communal tables and some people/waiters kept bumping into my seat. I had to really scoot my seat in..

Service was good, but not great. We had to wait a while for someone to bring us the bill and it took some time for them to come back with our credit card after. We completely understand since everyone was so busy running tables. Parking is very limited outside their driveway but there are some street parking nearby. Overall, I think their food was delicious! We will definitely come back to try other items on their menu!
author: Thanh T.

description:
Food was good but service was spotty and they ran out of a bunch of items. 

I will wait to come back in a month after the kinks have been worked out and revisit my review
author: Matthew R.

description:
Nice spot for modern bougie dim sum. It gets an extra star for being different! It's located in the design district, a bit far out in SF. Both times I've went on a Saturday, I had to wait at least 20 minutes. They do have outdoor seating with heaters and inside which is a bit cramped. 

-Pork XLB: Very tasty and enough soup. Came out hot and even ordered 2 at once! 
-Seafood gyoza: SO good! The filling was tasty but I loved the spiced chili butter with it! 
-Gan Ban noodles: I was a bit disappointed when it arrived as I was expecting something different. The tasty was okay but didn't really satisfied me. If you don't want peanuts, let them know in advance or they will scold you for wasting them..
-Shrimp & cilantro har gow: Regular har gow but the sauce took it to another level!
-Green tea & milk bun: MY FAV. I don't like green tea items and I hardly tasted it. Its just green bao with a delicious milk filling.
*My first time I tried the "three-sum" which consist of all three baos. I don't regret the 3 because you get to try them all! 

Overall, great food, but way overpriced to come every weekend.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Hipster dumpling / bao joint. Really good and I'd recommend it even though it's a little pricey for what you get. 

Tried the following:

Shrimp Toast (3/5): I love the concept. Chinese donut + batter of shrimp. It was decent, but the ingredients didn't seem to really mesh together. Felt like I got a lot of the Chinese donut/toast and it didn't extremely go well with the shrimp. Sauce made everything better though. 

Seafood Gyoza (5/5): A must try. This was unique and fresh. I've tried similar renditions elsewhere, but this felt special on top of being tasty.

Pork XLB (4/5): Delicious with its copious amount of soup inside. However it was not the perfect temperature (too hot when served) and the skin was a bit flimsy. I think I've been spoiled by Ding Tai Fung.

Tom Yum Goong (4/5): Tasted pretty similar to the pork xlb so pretty much the same comments here. I did like the slightly sweet/sour discrepancy. 

Trio Dessert Buns (4/5): Three different flavored sweet buns. Each was great and more than satisfied my sweet tooth.  

I'd highly recommend ordering everything here on my list except maybe the shrimp toast.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I got lured here by the king dumpling, but unfortunately they were all out :( I arrived around 12:30, and waited about 40 mins for a table for 2. I wish they would had mentioned they were out of the king dumpling when we put our name down. 

While you wait, there are glass windows to see the chefs make dumplings. Unfortunately, with so many people constantly moving around, they don't let you stay to watch. 

We got seated outdoors, which we really wish we waited a little longer for an table indoors. The wind was pretty strong that day and constantly blowing our napkins and made the experience a little less pleasant. 

What we ordered:
Pork Xi'an dumplings- wasn't a fan of these. Will pass. 
Beijing noodles- just minced pork over noodles. Decent flavor but a little too salty. 
Seafood gyoza- our favorite of the entire meal. Huge pieces of shrimp and perfect crisp. 
Tom yum XLB- I've had better but it wasn't bad. 
Crispy pork bao- the bread was a little mushy. Get another order of XLB instead. 

Overall, I don't think I'll be coming back. Definitely more of a one time thing. There are so many better places for dumplings at half the cost.
author: Wendy L.

description: Great dumplings. This isn't a 5 star place overall (some of the dumplings could be better), but some dumplings deserve 5 stars. I would go here again
author: Jared G.

description:
In dining order, we ate: garlicky green beans, pickled lotus, cucumber, Pork XLB, tom yum goong, pork dumplings, the 3 gyoza dishes, the 2 noodle dishes, and egg yolk bun. 

We waited for an hour on a Tuesday night to get seated, which seems reasonable given how new and popular it is, and that there are no other dumpling places in the area. 

The Good: Food quality was everything I hoped for in my Chinese food, especially the XLB which is hit or miss at other Chinese restaurants. Other than that, the green beans were notable and had a powerful taste. Everything else was good, but in the sea of delicious dumplings and noodles it all blended out in my memory. 

The Bad: They ran out of the King-Dum, which I was really looking forward to!  And the price was a bit high for a dumplings dinner; we paid about $48 each including tax and tip. You can go to dumpling kitchen out in Sunset for half the price (although I acknowledge it's really far). 

I don't need to go again, but I'm happy to have experienced what the hype is about!
author: Sheewon B.

description:
When I first saw dumpling time on Yelp, I was skeptical because I knew there are no legitimate Asian restaurants in this area but given the positive reviews, I decided to give it a shot even though I (accurately) guessed that the people who wrote these reviews have no idea what good ethnic food is. The food was completely tasteless at a 30% surcharge to what it would cost in the Sunset.

When I arrived at the restaurant, I took a walk through the restaurant and was pleasantly surprised to find Asian employees making the food and it alleviated my concern of inauthenticity and appropriation. Although that feeling was instantly reversed when I saw the menu, tasted the food, and left the restaurant to eat at another restaurant because I was still hungry after sharing 6 dishes between 3 people.

When I saw that xiao long bao was labeled 'xlb' on the menu, I instantly knew I had made a mistake. No self respecting Chinese speaker would ever abbreviate the dish this way, that is a westernized bastardization of the name. Despite this, we had sat down and it was too late to turn back so we ordered the pork dumplings, xiao long bao, tom yum goong, green beans, Bei Jing noodles, and shui Mai.

When the food came out, the appearance was fine but once we took a bite, we realized that the food was the same as the restaurant - all exterior appearance and no content. 

Pork dumplings - first of all, the dumplings were covered in sliced radishes and some kind of cabbage vegetable - what the heck is the chef thinking throwing these random raw vegetables on dumplings? In any case, it's hard to mess up dumplings and they tasted fine. Although I'd rather pay 3 dollars less for a frozen bag with 5x the quantity at 99 ranch for the same quality and taste.

Green beans - this dish had great reviews and actually looked delicious but unfortunately, we can't see taste. These were the blandest green beans I'd ever had in my life. I was confused because the dish looked liked it would be super flavorful smothered in garlic but it literally had no taste.

BeiJing noodles - similar to the green beans this dish had the appearance of deliciousness, noodles covered in meat paste, but the taste was a huge let down. The meat paste tasted decent but that flavor did not transfer to the noodles. A let down.

Xiao long bao and Tom yum goong - the Tom yum goong is basically the same as the xiao long bao except the skin is made of beets. Overall, the dishes were fine - texture of the skin was thin and the meat and soup in the dumplings tasted fine. But they were no better than any other dumpling house and I'd opt to eat at the restaurants in the sunset for 30 percent more quantity at 70 percent the cost.

Shui Mai - this dish was fine but again, no better than any hole in the wall dim sum stand you'd find in the sunset, Richmond, or Chinatown. The only difference is that they cost 3x more here.

All in all, my friends and I were let down by our experience here. For the amount we paid, we should not have left hungry. But we left hungry and desiring food with flavor. There isn't a single dumpling restaurant in the city that is worse than dumpling time. Dumpling time creates picturesque food and did everything right in terms of setting up the restaurant, such as employing people of the same culture to make their food, but there is no substance and taste to anything here. Save your money and go to the dumpling houses in the Sunset or Richmond.
author: Howard C.

description:
I really wanted to love the food here, based on the menu it seemed promising and even had some Beijing-style noodles to bring me back to my University days. 

I think this is an excellent example of Americanized Chinese food, dumbed down and losing the zing and pizzaz that makes authentic Chinese so good. 

For a late dinner we ordered the shrimp toast which is a clever take on the hipster dish, on top of a Chinese style dumpling. Next were the pork baos which were mediocre and a bit bland. More seasoning and meat in the filling would be a huge improvement. 

We also ordered the beijing noodles which I was very excited to try. Perhaps not surprisingly they lacked the flavor and heartiness that I came to expect in their namesake city. Definitely add chili sauce to spice it up a bit

Overall  I'd say there are way better options for Chinese and dumplings in the city but the ambiance is trendy if you're looking for a quick bite.
author: Ian G.

description: Delicious food, trendy vibe, fast and friendly service. A little pricey but would highly recommend.
author: Veronica G.

description:
These are the best dumplings in the city.

* (already) Extremely popular.
* Prices are excellent for the value.
* Very, very, loud. 
* Excellent dumplings.
* Hipster. 

They open at 5PM and do not take reservations. If you want to be guaranteed a seat get here 20 minutes early, especially on Friday or Saturday. The first time we tried to come everything was already SOLD OUT at 7:15 so if you're serious about amazing dumplings don't hesitate.

Everything we had was excellent. The value is great. Between three of us, the total was about $60 +tax and tip. At the time we were here ABC had not graced them with a B&W.

- Pork XLB - Excellent soup dumplings. Get it!
- Shrimp Toast! - Holy Cow! Very rich. Get it! 
- Har Gow Shrimp - The menu said, "...juicy pork goodness." and it is!
- Vegetarian Dumpling Salad - Is that what it's called? There were green vegetarian dumplings 
   with lettuce. I really liked it. Refreshing and new for me. She didn't like it so much. 
- Happy Endings - We had three or four. She liked them all but I wasn't so much of a fan. I accept this to be a personal flaw of my own. You'll probably like 'em.   

We will be back ASAP! I usually try not to write a review until things blow over but my spidey sense tells me it's only going to get worse. I highly recommend that you make every effort to get in here before it's too late. 

The wait staff was still working out some minor kinks. I assume mostly attributed to working at 100% from open to close. This will get better. We were well attended to but it was a little off.  

!! Go here now. It's awesome.
author: Justin S.

description: The best dumplings i've had in SF. The dough and fillings are outstanding. This place gets busy, but totally worth it
author: Jesus M.

description: I love this place for its dumplings and it definitely leaves my tummy happy. The wait time can be around half an hour at peak dinner times. I have had crispy vegetable spring rolls, chicken gyoza, chicken bao and egg yolk bun here. The bao is amazing and the egg yolk bun is the yummiest dessert one could get ! The soft, warm bites are very satisfying. The service was good. Although they kept trying to serve the egg yolk bun during main course even after we asked them to serve it at end, there were some noodles we ordered but did not appear to look like what we expected....the restaurant did take it back on our request. I was actually surprised that they happily obliged. I just wish they start serving some chicken soup dumplings in future.
author: Tejashree M.

description:
I wouldn't mind going again, definitely stay for the XLB. The rest were kind of Instagram worthy but no so great. The Tom Yum XLB was lacking in Thai spices.... Usually Tom yum is creamy, lemongrass herbs, sweet and tangy. It was cool because it was dark maroon colored but I couldn't taste the tom yum nor the beets too well.

The Beijing noodles we're delicious, I didn't really care about the other noodle dish too much(forgot what it was called).

I had a good experience, the wait staff was friendly. Everything came out at random times. Noodles all came out towards the end when people were done eating. Maybe they were busy?
author: Raymond L.

description: Fast service without being rushed, helpful wait staff and some of the best dumplings are found at Dumpling Time!
author: Sarah B.

description:
We luckily scored a spot during a very busy lunch time.  We shared the following:

Seafood Gyoza (with spinach wrap):
SO yum!  Lots of shrimp and amazing sauce to go with it!  My fav also!

Char-Siu Bao:
Good amount of Char-siu, not too fatty and not too much bao.  Would love more sauce/filling!

Xi'an dumplings:
Also another one of my fav dishes, loved the chilli, dill, grape tomatoes, radishes and sprouts. Made the dish unique and extra tasty, as I haven't had dumplings served like this before.  

Noodles with pork:
Very flavourful with green onions.  Love the thick noodles and good amount of sauce.  They ran out of the other noodles, would have like to try those one as well.

Soup dumplings
Great soup dumplings!  Hard for me to get them out of the tin foil and ended up breaking a couple of them (to my friend's delight...haha!).  Really tasty though would love to have them served without the tin foil.

Great spot in the design district where there are not a lot of Asian restaurants.  Would love to try the taro dumplings/bao next time.  Really noisy during lunch, not sure if there can be anything to help reduce the noise as we thought it was really loud.  

Would love to try the other items next time, be sure to come with an empty belly as there are lots of good dishes to try out!  More pricey than your average place in Chinatown, though the quality seemed really fresh for the price.

Almost forgot my suitcase on the way out, would be good to have more storage/space for bags/coats as the restaurant seemed really cramped for space. 

Thanks for a great lunch!
author: Carolyn L.

description:
3.25/5 stars. I was pleasantly surprised by Dumpling Time and had been waiting for a decent Chinese restaurant to open up in the area. The restaurant is rather hidden in Soma in a warehouse area with a nice little patio seating and spacious seating inside. Upon entering, you can see the chefs hand-making the dumplings as you wait about 15 minutes for a table for dinner. I went at 7pm with a friend and we ended up getting seated with another pair at a communal table. 

[Dinner]
There is about a 15-20 minute wait for dumplings. It is definitely recommended to get 2-3 dishes per person as the portion sizes are extremely small. My friend and I ordered the Beijing Noodles, Xian pork dumplings, Tom Yum dumplings, King Dum, and an order of regular XLB that was messed up because the kitchen gave us another order of Tom Yum instead. There is a limit of one King Dum per table. I really liked the Beijing Noodles and Xian pork dumplings. The Tom Yum dumplings are an interesting twist on the regular XLB dumplings with a beet skin and slightly sweet and sour soup. I would recommend trying this once. The King Dum was disappointing as the skin ripped and all the soup fell out before we could drink it with our straws. The dumpling itself tasted a little bland. 

[Service]
The service is pretty basic. I think the restaurant is understaffed, with servers scrambling to clean, take orders, and serve all at the same time. However, Dumpling Time is pretty new so I'm sure this will improve. There was a mistake with the kitchen and we ended up receiving two orders of Tom Yum dumplings instead of one of each of the XLBs. Our server was very nice and did not charge us for the messed up order of Tom Yum. 

[Decor]
Music in the restaurant is really really loud. I would recommend turning this down since there are lot of patrons generating noise as well. I like the open kitchen where you can see the dumpling making, but I would enjoy not having the Giants game playing on the wall as I'm eating. The whole combination is really strange. 

Overall, ordering 2-3 dishes here can get pricey, so I would recommend bringing a friend and ordering more dumplings to try. The dumplings  are tasty and good quality, and a very welcome addition to SOMA!
author: Alice Z.

description:
Beat the crowd. Time your visit well to beat the crowd. We waited less than 5 mins.

The food was very satisfying and delicious. Although we didn't know if it was because it was actually good or if we were just hella hungry. Sure you can easily find better and cheaper dim sum in SoCal, but we went for the king bao.
The king bao was a major disappointment. The pictures and the advertisement made it look like a decent size. It was small. Imagine 2.5 normal sized baos put together. That's all. The soup was good though. Drink it fast or it will leak down to the bottom plate. 

The service was slow too. We ordered within 5 mins of sitting down. But we had to wait more than 30 mins for our food to come. There were a decent number of workers but they kept forgetting things for our table.
author: Aaron H.

description:
Overall good but not worth a 20min wait on a Th night for a really mixed menu in terms of deliciousness. I'd give this 3.5 stars. Here is what our group of tried:

Really good: 
Seafood gyoza - favorite dish of the night - came with a butter sauce, mmm

Pretty good: 
- Shrimp toast - these use yuo tiao (Chinese fried donut) for the toast! 
- tom yum XLB - this twist on the usual was interesting 
- Ha gao (both regular and with cilantro) - skin on these guys was kind of thick, but really soft (maybe too much water?)
- trio of dessert buns 

Okay but better elsewhere: 
- regular xlb - too many other places make this better 
- cha su buns 
- veg dumpling - these looked pretty bc there were sliced radishes and micro-greens scattered about.. but still bland 


Dinner came out to $26 per person - not bad, I would rather spend that on crazy amounts of dim sum/dumplings at Koi Palace, HK Lounge, Dragon Beaux, or King of Noodle.
author: Jean L.

description:
Worst dumplings I've had in California (NorCal or SoCal) - which is quite ironic given their name!

Simply said the food here is all very under-seasoned. It is certainly well prepared and well cooked, however the flavor just isn't there. The Shrimp Toast was the best dish.

Service is nice and the wait was only ~30min on a Sunday before Noon! Won't be back here however - there is too much amazing dim sum in SF to return to somewhere mediocre.

P.S. Flowers and frilliness are no substitute for flavor ;)
author: Nathan L.

description: This place was a bit overrated for me. First off parking was a bit odd, and although parking in the city is always quite the task, the location of the restaurant made parking even more difficult. Secondly, the menu seemed a little condensed or maybe too fusion? Definitely somethings that I don't think you'd fine popular in authentic restaurants. Lastly, the prices were not worth it.  This place was more hype and instagram aesthetic then anything else. I would recommend going elsewhere if dumplings are something you are craving.
author: Franchesca B.

description: While visiting for a month in the Bay Area I went here twice for those beet dumplings. I loved the other dumplings as well but if you are coming here for the first time, get the beet dumplings. The best thing I have ever had in dumpling form.
author: Amy P.

description:
If you don't mind the district, and are looking for the trendiest dumpling place, then look no further!

Reservations are not taken, so its important to be there at 5:30. Granted, my boyfriend and I came tonight (a Sunday) and it wasn't particularly slammed-busy. We got there around 5:20 and there were a few groups already ahead of us. The doors opened a little behind schedule. Once they did open though, they seated everyone pretty quickly.

As all dumpling places prefer, it's best to order all at once. They told us they were out of the shrimp toast, when we tried to order it. However, we did noticed that as our meal was ended, another table had ordered it and received it. It would have been nice maybe for our server to let us know it had become available, since we'd asked... but I guess a reason to go back.

We got the cucumber with fresno chilis, har gow, (the one with shrimp, cream cheese, and pork), one King XLB EACH (or King Dum), one order of the regular XLB's, and the Tom Yum Goong. That one has pork belly, shrimp, coconut milk, wrapped in a beet skin. (Which is really just dyed with beet juice, we learned.) We also got the Char-siu pork bun, which says it comes with "a touch of peanut butter." Then, we got the trio for dessert which is 3 buns, one of each of their flavors. Green Tea and Milk, Beet and Taro, and an Egg Yolk bun. 

The cucumber was good, albeit a bit oily, plus came with a cilantro leaf, which I find odd since its not meant to be in the dish. Potentially overlap from another appetizer, however I feel like restaurants nowadays should be more careful with stuff like this, to avoid allergies.

The har gow was very luscious with the cream cheese. it might have been melted, or watered down, but it still was a great combo. The Char-siu was also pretty decadent, due to the peanut butter, but it wasn't overwhelming. I only had a tiny bite and I did enjoy it. Our server recommended pan fried, so that's what we got. Def enjoyed it. 

Now, to the XLB's. Of course we had to get the King Dum. Now, before you order, it's not as big as people thing... Also, there are no instructions, and my boyfriend literally asked our server: "So.... what do we do?" She said most people drink the broth, and let it cool down, and then kind of just go at it with the spoon lmao. We had to wait for the broth too cool, after poking the hole, and then got that juicy soupyness. Cooling time was a bit but once that was the right temp, we went to town. Lol. 

For the broth - quantity was alright, however, it was lacking that "oopmh" of flavor. It was yummy, don't get my wrong, but not that amazing "wow" I want. The regular XLB's are the same, as you might imagine. They come in little individual foils, which is nice, and the wrapper was pretty thick, so it was nice not to lose any due to that breaking. However, there is even less broth in these, and if you let them cool down too much, your window of time is closed and the foil will stick to the wrapper. Thick wrappers work against you in that matter lol. 

The Tom Yum Goong were a different story all together! That beet wrapper as a flavor all on its own though, prob from the juice and that broth seemed to have a hint of spiciness! Or some kind of acidity? I -loved- it. I would hands down come back just for these. Same problem with the wrapper and foil tho, however I was quicker with these lmao. 

The trio was also good - we didn't pay attention and were going to order 1 order of the Green tea and 1 order of the beet taro, but she must have realized that, so she was like ok 3 each? We caught ourselves and just got the trio because why not try the egg yolk? 

Turns out that was the best decision. That was by far the best of the 3 buns. I guess I have to fight my boyfriend next time for the last one, when we get just that order. 

It is a very cute interior, perfect to instagram, and some of their items were really quite good. Otherwise, I think they tried a little too hard to be trendy or fusion or something? Maybe trying to add to the neighborhood as well. Lol I'm kidding mostly.  But if we had gotten the shrimp toast, maybe I'd feel differently. 

Will be back!
author: Rachel W.

description:
Great menu with dumplings from all over Asia. 

My only issue with the menu, is I didn't know what is what as the descriptions are fairly open to interpretation, saying that even though the dishes were different than what I expected everything was tasty. 

Service was fast - except for drinks, food arrived before the wine and beer and they never asked if we wanted more to drink.

Would be interesting so see what they could do with a Nepalese Momo. 

I will be back.
author: Ken D.

description:
Food: 4/5     Price: 3/5      Service: 5/5    Ambience: 4/5

Must haves: Bejiing Noodles, Har Gow with Cilantro, XLB Pork and Tom Yum, and individual hot teas (Plum and Date Tea, White Tea).

Second time enjoying this spot in the Design District. Usually there's a line for dinner, so be forewarned! Your belly will thank you at the end for the wait. The service here is excellent, especially how quick-paced,
and crowded the restaurant is. The above are my growing favorite go-to dishes that are so delicious above the other dumpling restaurants. The okay dishes are the pan-fried dumplings, baos, gyozas. If you do get the bao, order it pan-seared! It takes it to the next level!!

The Bejiing Noodles are served in a large bowl with greens and you have to mix it yourself before eating. You can definitely share this easily with 2-4 people. 

The Har Gow with Cilantro -- DOUBLE THE ORDER! The cilantro inside makes it so delicious and the cilantro sauce is must try! 


**Hot tip -- if you think you might want more dishes, order while you are eating with the current delicacies on your table. Do not wait until you finish because you may wait for awhile. Also, you can ask for more vinegar for your dishes and more hot water for your tea!!

Enjoy! Leave happy with a food coma!
author: Ava Elizabeth T.

description: If I could eat here every day for the rest of my life I would die happy.
author: Morgan G.

description:
Picked up take out at Dumpling Time and liked my meal!  I ordered:
- the vegetarian xi'an dumplings (probably my favorite, and comes with some radishes and tomatoes)
- the gai-ban noodles (okay, actually has some good toppings)
- the chicken bao (moist and tasty)
- the seafood gyoza (which reminded me more of har gow than gyoza -
they have a spinach skin and a huge shrimp/seafood ball in the middle). 

Having just come back from Hong Kong and Japan, this is definitely more of an Americanized version or fusion form of dumplings, with thick skin and coarser fillings, but I'm a huge fan of dumplings so I'll still be coming back.  The line was definitely quite long, so be prepared to wait!
author: Vivian W.

description:
We came here on a Thursday at around 8:10pm or so and put my name on the list. The place is modern looking, with a projector protecting Korean music videos on the wall. The hostess said that as long as you are there, you will be seated if your name is on the list. There were about 18 groups of people ahead of us that were in groups of 2-3, with an additional 2-3 groups of 6. We were able to get seated by 8:55pm mainly because I think people thought the wait was too long and have up waiting.

Food: (4/5)
They ran out of the giant XLB, which is what I really wanted to try.
- Shrimp Toast aka Youtiao or Chinese doughnut with shrimp ($8) - Nice and crispy with yummy shrimp
- Chicken bao (pan fried) ($5.50) - Was ok.
- Tom Yum Goong xlb ($9) - juicy with soup, but not much different than the pork xlb
- Pork xlb ($8) - juicy, but took kind of long to get
- seafood gyoza ($9.50) - Lots of shrimp inside. Pretty good

Service: (3/5)
They didn't really check on us that much and they kinda forgot to give us our last dish so we were there longer...

Overall score: (3.5/5)
Overall, the food was decent. Would I come again? Probably not, unless it's to try and get the giant xlb.
author: Gilda W.

description:
It's always time for dumpling time especially when they're prepared with such warmth and delicateness as they are at Dumpling Time in the SOMA area of San Francisco. Christine and I came on a Sunday afternoon right after the Giants game where we drove from Parking Lot A in China Basin to the Design District where Dumpling Time resides. It only took about five minutes to get there by car and by 5pm we already found at least ten people ahead of us waiting to put their name down and for the doors to open which tells you how revered this place has already become in just four months of being open for business.

Dumpling Time is from the team behind Okane, Live Sushi Bar, and the Michelin-starred Omakase and they smartly decided to that this venture would focus on traditional Asian dumplings with a very distinctive California twist. We were sat within the first ten minutes of them opening as we chose to be sat outside on their patio since the day was still quite warm. We were lucky enough to get the table by the window where we saw dumplings being made in the glass-enclosed dumpling room. Perfect weather and table, it doesn't get any better than that.

The menu is small but mighty at Dumpling Time, as we obviously came for the Dumplings and the Soup Dumplings, otherwise known as the Xiao Long Baos. In terms of traditional Xiao Long Baos, they have two options pork and tom yum goong which are baos filled with pork belly, shrimp, coconut milk and it was uniquely wrapped in a beet skin. The more traditional option was the pork belly, savory soup and shao sing wine. Both were warm to the touch and filled with juicy broth that anyone would sip up if there was overflow, which of course there wasn't any. We also really liked the Xi'an Dumplings as we got the ones filled with pork, cabbage and green onion, they were their mother's "secret recipe" and they were plated with such beauty and creativity it was if you were eating artwork with the chives, cherry tomatoes, and radish slices, although they didn't taste as refined as the Xiao Long Baos. We also tried out both the Pork and Chicken Gyozas both of which you can taste the freshness from it being made and fried that moment, one had pork, green onion, ginger and cilantro while the other had chicken, shiitake mushroom, wood ear mushroom, green onion and cilantro. Taste wise, I like the pork better since they were heartier. We also wanted to try the one of the noodle dishes and since there were only two choices, we went with the meat filled Beijing Noodles with minced ground pork, green onion, ginger and soybean paste, my dining mates and I were slightly disappointed in the lack of quantity in the noodles and overall flavor profile. Next time we'd probably skip their noodle dishes and gorge ourselves with all of their dumplings.

But we didn't skip dessert, as we sampled their Trio of Buns, filled with Green Tea & Milk, Beet & Taro, and Egg Yolk. It was a nice way to sample which of the buns we liked the best, I always go for the traditional egg yolk mainly because it's the least complicated of the bunch and I was right, the egg yolk was sweet and savory all rolled into one.I really like what Dumpling Time is trying to accomplish by mixing in traditional Taiwanese and Chinese cuisine with artisanal fresh flavors and platework you can't go wrong by trying it out for yourself. Just be prepared to wait out in front for a table no matter the time of day!
author: Jason F.

description:
This was a nice place in an area of SF that I am not so familiar with.  I learned about Dumpling Time from seeing it in one of my FB friends post.  

I brought my mom and daughter here after we picked up my mom from SFO.  We were quickly seated at 11 am on a Saturday morning.  We parked a few blocks from the restaurant.  The menu was simple, and you won't be able to help but see what people have in their tables.  Upon entry you will see a glass wall where you can see two people making dumplings.

We ordered two all Xiao Long Bao- pork, tom yum and King Dum, we also ordered the shrimp & pork siu mai and Main lobster siu mai, shrimp and cilantro har gow and crispy tofu squares.

All of the entrees were good but small.  If you are a someone with a small appetite or someone who likes to try new places dumpling time is a good place, but if you expect more food for your money, you will be disappointed because you won't be full coming out of Dumpling Time, unless you order double or don't share your entrees.

Dumpling time is great!!
author: Melinda R.

description: Cute ambiance. Super fun to watch the chefs make the dumplings from the outside large window. Really nice service and, of course, great food. Highly recommend. You can't really go wrong with any of their dumplings
author: Natashia S.

description:
3.5/4 stars,  i can't really decide between how man y stars to give them. We arrived just as they were opening and there were people already waiting for seats. We had to write our name on a lost and waited about half an hour more. There were benches along the side to sit while we waited but since there was so many people everyone just stood around by the door, which made it seem quite cramped.

When we got in we ordered what we wanted but I was very VERY surprised you had to buy tea. Every single dim sum I have went to you automatically get tea while you eat. And I've been to a lot both in the states and internationally. So I wanted tea, i had to buy tea and it's enough just for yourself so everyone else at my table? Tough luck you get water.

The food came out and it was delicious, it reminded me so much of home. You cam taste that everything was fresh and although it qas delicious, i don't see myself coming here much. Prices were pretty darn high for the portions and I left the place not being full. Granted I could have ordered more but I felt like I could get more bang for my buck elsewhere. Hence the 3.5/4 stars. Delicious food, but the downside for me was the pricing for the portions and the fact I had to pay for tea at a dim sum place.
author: Jenny L.

description: After following this restaurant on Instagram for a couple months, I finally had the chance to try it. Everything was delicious! I'm aware that dim sum prices are normally cheaper. However, I was not disappointed with the prices because the quality and flavor of the dishes was superior, in comparison to other dim sum places that I've tried. Without a doubt, the Shrimp Toast was my favorite dish. I also really enjoyed the Seafood Gyoza and the BBQ Pork Bao.
author: Kristen P.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm Shanghaiese. Not the ones that's born here. I lived in Shanghai. I grew up on XLB. Like literally wake up on the weekend n go to the market n get them fresh. My expectation and taste bud for XLB is very high! And i can only give 3 stars.

I got the Kin Dum, lots of soup on the inside. Which is awesome, but the meat are falling apart it suppose to be firm like one bite and not mushy! Meat def lack flavors, you can tell they used cheap meat instead of top sirloin or tenderloin. You need meat to contrast the meaty soup. The dough is well done. Al dente.

The Tum yum def is a disappointment! Lack flavors! 

The Beijing Noodle is just blah, the noodle are suppose to be chewy not soft and slimy... not authentic!

The shrimp cake is the best thing in the menu. 

Service was slow. We were the last few people there on a lunch rush and let's just say the last dish came out when my first dish were cold... price is ok. Meh get it together and get the concept straight. Is it Chinese or Japanese? Can't be trying to sell Chinese food with Japanese writing n shit. Tells me this place is not authentic
author: Kris J.

description:
I love this place! I came here for the first time last summer when it was still pretty new and became a huge fan. Recently returned, and it's just as good as I remember. Best to go with a group of people so you can try more dishes, and you'll want to share them all. The restaurant itself is pretty small, and when it's full for lunch or dinner, it's difficult to hear what someone is saying to you across the table. It's pricier than most dim sum style places - but I think the food is also of slightly higher quality. 

I like their veggies, especially the edamame, which they creatively season with Szechuan peppercorns, and their Garlicky Green Beans. 

I attempted to choose favorite main dishes but it's honestly too difficult because I've tried so many items on their menu and I've loved them all. The chicken gyoza, all the meat baos, xian dumplings, and the pork XLB are great and taste freshly made and delicious. Definitely consider ordering the Three-sum for dessert, so you can taste all three types of the dessert buns. I personally like the egg yolk bun the best, but others will have their favorites. 

Overall, a great selection of small dishes, and difficult to go wrong with any of the menu items.
author: Ellen L.

description: Watch out! They cheated the tips!! I cannot believe that. Even though it is not much money, I lost my feeling. Hope other will not face the same issue as me. So, I recommend dont go there
author: Ploy C.

description: Probably more of a 3.5, but had a perfectly adequate meal so no complaints! Came like very close to opening on a Sat night so no wait (around 6pm)! We shared green beans, the pork dumplings, pork soup dumplings, and the egg yolk bun. It was a good amount of food and we were pretty stuffed! The soup dumpling was pretty decent! Good flavor inside. The pork dumpling was good- a bit to doughy after awhile. The green beans were solid, and the egg bug was delicious- really soft and creamy! Really good way to end the meal.  Would return!
author: Vivian D.

description:
A bit pricey, but if you don't mind them fusion-ing it up a bit, this is a legitimately tasty option in the design district.

I especially liked their airy/fluffy baos. It's hard to get the doughiness balance on baos just right, and they nailed it.
author: Anthony W.

description:
Visiting from out of town. This is easily the best meal I've had in 6 months. Went with a bunch of meat waters and I was the only vegetarian, but I'm in charge of ordering usually. Got a bunch of the vegetable appetizers, chili cucumber, carrot and lotus root salad, ganban noodles, tofu squares. Everyone wanted more of the noodles and tofu, we got second order of tofu. The vegetable dumplings were amazing. They got the red xlb and regular xlb. It was difficult to eat bc skin was kind of falling apart a bit when trying to remove from the metal tin. Everything was delicious.

The meat eaters thanked me for ordering a well balanced meal. For you meat eaters, order some veggies! Vegetables at so so so good in Chinese cooking. You will be deliciously surprised.
author: Jessica M.

description: This was probably on my bookmarks for almost or already a year now and what can I say that I finally got to try this place! Came here just in time for lunch and there was about a ten minute wait, but it wasn't so bad since it's Coachella weekend, compared to what I heard about their usual lines. The restaurant itself is pretty spacious, but tiny since most of their tables are super close to each other. They also have outside seating if you want to enjoy the nice sunny day. For the two of us, we ordered the regular pork xlb, the kingdum which was a giant version of the xlb, and the trio buns. Food came out fairly quick and the service was nice as well. The pork xlb was definitely worth the hype, super flavorful and the soup just explodes after you take a bite into the wonton skin. The kingdum, also know as the giant xlb was huge! It was so big that they give you a straw to consume all the soup inside the dumpling before devouring it. As for the buns, they were tender and I love how the filling wasn't a giant blob, it was more of a paste consistency if I'm wording it correctly. Out of the three buns, the one that tastes best was the matcha! Dumpling Time is such a cute restaurant with great food, I'd definitely come back to try their Beijing Noodles and other dim sum!
author: Lisa W.

description:
This place is super popular, there's always a wait.
I like it and its in my top-10 for Dumplings in SF.
The thing that differentiates it from other dumpling places is the choices of booze - Sake, Sparkling and some other stuff. Not just 2 buck chuck.
author: Tom S.

description:
Been here twice over the past month and ate my fill of delicious dumplings! This location has had a bit of turnover in the past 5-6 years so I'm hoping it sticks around. If the food is any indication, it should be. And if they want to expand to the East Bay, I'd say hallelujah!

Okay, the food. The seafood gyoza is a definite winner--moist, flavorful on the inside and crispy on the outside. The pork xi'an dumplings and the Tom Yum Goong xiao long bao made warm and fuzzy--though the sake may have also had an influence. The garlicky green beans are a must to complement the dumplings. The tea choices are also lovely. 

For 2 people, with tea or sake, and 3-4 dishes to share, we paid $50. For this quality of food and selection, what a bargain! Service was also friendly and attentive. Parking is a breeze after 5-6 pm because the working folks in the area have clocked out. I've read about the weekend lines and would rather breeze in on a Monday at 6 pm with no wait and everything freshly made!
author: Mi-Yung R.

description:
I am writing my review as a pescatarian that doesn't like oily food, so this may not apply to you.
Environment: trendy and busy. Expect to wait outside for a while so bring a jacket. 
Food: My husband loved everything except my vegetarian options which he tried. I agreed that they could be better. The seafood gyoza was really good and the shrimp toast was also good- but I dont think you can eat more than 1-2, because it is so oily.
Service: Our server was amazing. She didn't judge us at all for ordering of $100 worth of dumplings for 2 people. I mean c'mon- we love dumplings and what is $100 for dinner when you live in SF!?
author: Julianna I.

description:
The shrimp toasts!!!!

I came here a while back and was not able to get the King Dumpling :( 

But it was good nevertheless! I loved their XLB and the other coconut based one. Ordered a few appetizers and they were all pretty good. Service is excellent during the off hour and honestly no complaints about prices of the food because after all ... this is SF.

I like this location because it's generally easier to park and it's close to a lot of random things that are equally good in case you need a drink, to kill time, or find an alternative restaurant to wait it out at. Definitely the wait is not awesome during peak hours but that's where you just need to chalk it up to popularity. 

I would definitely come back to try the king dumpling some time.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Very clean
Extremely tasty
Very fast service
Fresh dumplings
Very nice setup
This place is amazing! Definitely going back
author: Joe D.

description:
I think this is one of those places where you just have to know what you're getting into. Dumpling Time isn't particularly authentic (but honestly, I feel like you should have figured that out from the name), but the food is solid and delicious. Also, there can be a bit of a wait, but I think the hype has died down and the line is a lot more reasonable (10-15min or so).

What to Order:
- Dumplings! The xiao long bao is pretty good, though most people familiar with dumplings will ask "why are they in metal tins?" Other than that weirdness, the xiao long bao is pretty tasty and the skin is nice and thick. There's also a giant xiao long bao on the menu, but I've been told it's more for show than for taste.
- Beijing Noodles: These noodles are really good, but also a little more like "spaghetti" than Beijing Noodles I've had in the past.
- Shrimp Toast: This is a pretty unique appetizer, worth trying once.
- Green beans or snow peas: Not particularly special, but mostly just to get some vegetables in your diet.
- Dessert buns: These are fluffy and soft and not too sweet, my ideal type of dessert
- Side Note: Prices can add up once you start ordering a lot of food.

The location is a little strange, deep in SoMa near the design district, so there's not much else in the area. There's a lot of seating, both indoors and outdoors. If you sit indoors, they play Asian music videos on one of the walls, which is always pretty amusing (and a little confusing). Staff is friendly and helpful (probably another hint that this isn't a traditional/authentic place).

Good place to get your dumpling fix closer to downtown if you're too lazy to make the trek out to Richmond/Sunset.
author: Brittany C.

description: Good flavor dumplings. A bit too expensive for what you get.
author: Qiaosi C.

description:
Dumpling Time is a great addition to the dumpling scene in the Bay Area. I came on a Saturday afternoon, and they were already really busy at 11:25; however, there were still a few tables available so we were seated right away. There was definitely a line when we left, so come early to avoid any wait! Make sure you put your name on the list at the table right away, and their host/hostess will call you once they have a table ready. They recommend ordering 2-3 dishes per person, and I tried:

-Shrimp Toast ($8, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SphRhGZouOsj6OAvz8JxvA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=4-gRG1S357m-QfmGmgNuHA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Super unique, since they place a fried shrimp patty on top of half a Chinese donut. I liked this dish, but it was too greasy and filling, and I wish they allowed half orders of this. It's definitely worth trying once, but I would rather order more dumplings the next time around.
-Crispy Char-Siu Bao (Roasted Pork Belly, Peanut Butter, 3pc/$6, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=a6RlV7FKmyrDu9lJVdr1jw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Xldninai73zyZjQL9z1Niw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): We opted to get this crispy/pan seared, but I didn't think the sear added much to the bao. The filling was good, and the pork belly flavorful. However, you don't taste much peanut butter, and there was too much bun to filling ratio. Although this was good, I would rather order more dumplings the next time around.
-Pork XLB (6pc/$8, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=_Ar5Ob985vipanRvucmphA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- this is one of the better version of xlb I've had in a while! The skin was thin, and there was ample soup inside. The meat filling was also seasoned well, and good quality- A must order!
-Tom Yum Goong (Pork Belly, Shrimp, Coconut Milk, Wrapped in Beet Skin, 6pc/$9, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=wFpkoQaYcBvmgiP02PBgWw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Not that great- the beet skin was thicker, and the coconut milk didn't quite work with the other flavors in this dumpling. I wouldn't get this again.
-Trio of Buns (Egg Yolk Bun, Green Tea & Milk Bun, Beet & Taro Bun, $5.50, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=pNwIWwIOUsIWqP_1GFBFDw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=nF27eKYYYj3PZSaDtGpAOQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=lyTkiQd42noVkb2Z47HKpg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): All were good, and I loved how super fluffy the buns were! The green tea was my favorite, and I liked the subtle milk filling. The egg yolk was super creamy, and the beet and taro was the least favorite just because it didn't have as much flavor as the others. However, I'd definitely recommend ordering the trio once to try all three buns.

Our server was good, and the food came out really quickly. It was nice that they had a homemade chili sauce at the table, but it wasn't spicy at all, and could have used more chili oil. I will definitely be back for more xlb and buns, and also to try their other types of dumplings! There isn't much parking available in this area, but there are some metered street parking spots.
author: Amy D.

description:
Better than DTF? Get the F out! Y'all never had the real DTF in Taiwan. The DTF in the Americas are still a step behind when compared to the real deal. 

As for this place, not even close.. Better than some dumpling places, Yes! The Xiao Lung Bao that we ordered couldn't keep together and maybe half of it breaks when you try to lift it. This doesn't happen at the real DTF. Also they do not care for how many folds in each piece. 

Things to order: 
-Beijing Noodles with the hot sauce on the table is a winner. 
-Regular Xiao Lung Bao.. skip the Tong Yum Version and skip the big fat whopper version for instagram.. 
-Shrimp Toast is decent if you need a filler. 
-Cucumbers were good. 

The wait? Nah, i'll skip this place if I had to wait. 
oh, they charge the mandated tax.. so expect 4% more on your bill.
author: Eric Y.

description: Solid 4 I guess you can argue 3.5 stars simply because of the price, some dishes are standouts like the shrimp toast, green beans, seafood gyoza and xi'an pork dumplings...the Maine lobster siu mai were good but overpriced at $12 for 4 dumplings...the dessert bao's are delicious,if your in the area I would definitely check them out...
author: jonathan h.

description: Came here for an early lunch to beat the crowd in design district and boy!, the place gets packed with people waiting right around noon. Dumplings are delicious, noodles are so so.. I was there for garlic seaweed but they took it off the menu.
author: Craig W.

description:
Dumpling Time, which has an indicative name, serves high caliber dumplings that are a tier above your ordinary dumplings. I would definitely go back.

Food: The dumplings at Dumpling Time have the exquisite taste of traditional dumplings with the added bonus of colorful and whimsical presentation. They have a wide breadth of dumpling styles due the multicultural nature of the restaurant. It's a bit pricey.
Service: The restaurant seemed new so there I was a bit lenient on the service. The staff was nice and accommodating, but they seem to be very unorganized. The food was very slow to come out. Two parties that sat down 30m after us got their food before us, which is frustrating when you're hungry. There was also a long wait due to the hype surrounding the restaurant's opening.
Ambiance: Located in the Design District in SF. The restaurant looks very modern and relatively spacious. There is a glass window where you can see the chefs making dumplings. It's quiet enough to have a conversation.

I ordered:
Shrimp toast - made from Youtiao (chinese donut) and shrimp. Surprisingly good, would definitely get.
Xiaolong bao (soup dumpling) - superior. Really good skins, tasty soup. Get a lot of these.
Charsui bao (bbq pork dumpling) - decent
Hargaw (shrimp dumpling) - average
The really big dumpling (forgot the name) - I wasn't a huge fan, but it was an interesting experience, worth getting once.
Dessert dumplings (matcha, egg, redbean) - I only got to eat the egg bun, but it was really good.
Seafood dumplings - pretty good 

Quantitative ratings:
Food: 5/5
Service: 4/5 (adjusted because business is new, would be 3/5)
Ambience: 4/5
Value: 4/5
author: Sean W.

description: Solid 3 star dumpling restaurant in the SoMa area. Every dish was well made and beautifully presented but severely lacking in taste and salt. Just had the XLB and a noodle dish - both of which I had to drench in soy sauce and vinegar before consuming. The wait was about 30 mins for two people on a Sunday afternoon around 1pm. Service was good. I wouldn't come again, however, as the dumplings were so underwhelming.
author: Laura Y.

description: Ate here about a month ago with my boyfriend. We waited a good 30-45 minutes to be seated, so our game plan was to scan the menu while we waited so we could then place our order as soon as we got to our table. We ordered the tom kha xiao long bao, shrimp toast, beijing noodles, & the green tea dessert bun. My favorite things were the xiao long bao & the shrimp toast-- I've always loved chinese donuts, always thought there should be another way to eat them other than alongside congee-- So Dumpling Time really made me happy with their take on the chinese donut with shrimp, aioli & sliced pepper. I just really wish the portions were bigger on everything, but that might just be me being filipino af.
author: Celine L.

description:
Had to get the staples, pork Xao Long Bao, Beiijing Noodles, pork Xi'an dumplings, and seared pork bao. Add to that shrimp toast and their dessert trio of buns, and that was our meal. 

The highlights of the dinner:
Shrimp Toast and the Trio of Buns Dessert. 

Shrimp Toast was Soo good. I wish I could have that with porridge all the time. It's basically a roided-up chinese donut. The spicy mayo on it wasn't spicy at all. The shrimp was like the shrimp paste that they steam and deep fry for dim sum. 

The trio of buns included green tea/milk, beet/taro, egg yoke. We ate it in that order. The first two were not that memorable. That egg yoke one though, delish. If a Bao and a egg start had a baby, it would be that. 

Everything else was pretty lackluster. The noodles didn't have much flavor. Most of the dumplings had a watered down flavor. It's nice that they can pan fry the baos, but the meat to Bao ratio didn't make it really worth it. 

Don't get me wrong, it's a ok spot. Hip and cool and perfect for a date night with someone who has never had dumplings. But if you are truly a purist, stick wtih kingdom of dumplings or Shanghai dumpling king.
author: A L.

description: Highly recommend the happy ending trio. My favorite place to eat in the city right now, and I also am always so surprised at how affordable it is. I would eat there every week if I could!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Always bomb . The shrimp toast is AMAZING   as well as the chicken gyoza ( I always get extra ) . Found this place on a file and now I'm addicted !!!!!
author: Nikaiyah B.

description:
Overall rating: 4/5
Parking: Easy and free parking
Best time to go: I haven't checked out the lunch rush yet but before 6pm on a weeknight

I've been wanting to try this place for so long and I finally tried it this past Tuesday, thanks to my great friend for taking me! I've heard that this place wasn't good and was overpriced so I came here with low expectations. This place opens at 5:30pm for dinner and there was already a wait at 5:22pm!! Yep, it's one of those places where lines form even before they open..

Everyone was seated easily since the line wasn't long at all. There is a waitlist where you have to write your name down. Your entire party needs to be present in order for them to seat you. We witnessed a group that was not complete and were not seated until their whole party was there even though the restaurant was practically empty so be sure to come together! The restaurant is pretty big with at least 20+ tables.

The waiters and chefs were so nice! The service is great and our water carafes were always refilled before it was empty and we had a tiny table with a ton of food and our dishes were cleared fairly quickly.

We had the chance to try sooo much food between two people so don't judge :p

Garlicky Green Beans - $8 (Rating: 3.25/5)
