I've had better at Kingdom of Dumplings. They were ok but not great and they weren't hot when they came out. The sauce wasn't too flavorful but if you are someone who doesn't need much flavor, you'll like it!

Shrimp Toast - $8 (Rating: 3.5/5)
After reading all the reviews prior to coming here, I was expecting this dish to be the bombb! It's literally a chinese donut (which was cooked well and crispy) with a bit of shrimp mixture placed in a hole on top. There was some sort of chinese mustard/mayo lined under the bottom for extra taste which complemented it well. I think this dish is all hype but definitely something you should try yourself. You'll like it if you're a fan of chinese donut/have never tried.

Seafood Gyoza - $9.50 for 5 pieces (Rating: 4/5)
The gyoza (potsticker) came out with a green skin made of spinach! The filling had crab, scallop and shrimp and was so flavorful! We almost didn't order gyoza since we didn't think it would be anything special but I'm glad we tried it! There was a semi-crispy layer under the gyoza which is a plus but my friend was hoping it would have been a little crispier. However, I recommend this dish!

Beijing Noodles - $9 (Rating: 4/5)
Reviews raved about this dish so I had to get it! It was good, but it wasn't as amazing as everyone made it sound. I do recommend ordering this dish though because it was flavorful. The noodles were a bit too soft for me but still good. The portion wasn't too big and was easily split into two small bowls but it was perfect for us since there were only two of us. I would order this again!

Shrimp & Cilantro Har Gow - $6 for 4 pieces (Rating: 3.75/5)
Shrimp, cilantro, juicy pork goodness?! I didn't expect to like this dish but I did! The skin was made well and the flavors were good. If you like har gow, I recommend this since their regular one comes with cream cheese and I'm not sure how I would like that.. but it sounds different?

King-Dum Xiao Long Bao - $8 for 1 large one! (Rating: 4/5)
Such a cute name! To my surprise, it was pretty good. It's large enough you get a straw to drink the soup out of it! It was kind of hard to eat but you definitely have to order it if you like taking pictures of your food. It was cool to drink my soup through a straw out of the top of my dumpling.

Pork XLB - $8 for 6 pieces (Rating: 4/5)
The smaller version of the large XLB ^ and it was good. The skin isn't as thin as Din Tai Fung's but it's still pretty good!

Tom Yum Goong XLB - $9 for 6 pieces (Rating: 4/5)
Pork belly, shrimp, coconut milk, wrapped in a beet skin which made the skin a bright wine color! To my surprise, I liked this dish a lot because it's different. The flavors were good because I do love Tom Yum soup! I recommend trying this dish.

Trio of Buns "Happy Endings" - $5.50 for 3 pieces (Rating: 3.5/5)
Have you ever tried a bun with custard or milk filling inside? It's pretty good here! There's 3 different colored buns with either custard or milk filling inside. The green one has a green tea flavored bun. We were too full to try the red one to see how the bun tasted. The filling inside isn't the liquidy texture but it's still good. I've had better but the bun flavor is a really cool concept. I'd recommend trying it if you've never tried it.

Overall, this restaurant surprised us! We didn't expect to walk out liking it and eat as much as we did. Of course we had a lot of leftovers but we got to try almost everything! It was easy to find parking in this area so that was a huge plus. I'll definitely be back to try more!
author: Valerie T.

description: This was our first meal in SF and it did not disappoint. The shrimp toast and noodles were the best items we ordered. The consistency of the noodles were good. I didn't really enjoy the dumplings as much. Nothing too exciting about them. I rather go to Chinatown and get dumplings there. The steamed pork ribs were good and the meat was very tender.
author: Michelle K.

description: Amazing! Not an extensive menu but everything we ordered was delicious.   The king dumpling was fun to take pics of but the tom yum XLB was so yummy. The wait was not too long and overall experience was good.
author: cindy n.

description:
Came in to Dumpling Time during the night. My best friend and I just got tattoos done and were starving! Came to Yelp to find a place that's open and good reviews, so we decided to try this place out!
Just wanted to say that this place was really nice! Great service and the food tasted great. We ordered the Pork Bao, Pork Xiao Long Bao, Pork Gyoza, Siu Mai, and Har Gao. They all were very flavorful. The downside for us was that most of our food were only warm, not hot. We still liked our food, but just wish that it came to us hot. We would definitely come back again and try more of the dishes. Recommend to come for the experience and food.
author: Vivian T.

description: I love this place! I love their Thai dumplings and very much so the fried Chinese doughnut.
author: Jaclyn E.

description: First meal in San Fran and it set the tone for sure!! I ordered one of almost everything because it was all so appealing... and not just the food - The prices are mind blowing for it being one of the most expensive cities in the world. Super affordable, food location and amazing, fresh, food!
author: Allison H.

description: Went to Dumpling Time with a couple of very hungry co-workers tonight. We ordered A LOT and was very surprised that the bill was only $120. The food here is fantastic. The only reason I am giving them four stars is because we were told to wait outside in the cold while waiting for our table to be cleaned in a very rude manner. There was plenty of space for us to stand in the entrance. Anyways moving on from that incident, the food was honestly outstanding. The presentation was beautiful, the beer was so cold and the food was served hot and fresh. We ordered 12 dishes total (not going to list them all) but I'll list my top three. The seafood gyoza was the best I've ever had and so beautiful. The shrimp toast was scrumptioussss. It was like a buttery donut with shrimp. I also really liked the Gan Ban Noodles. Coming up with my top three was difficult though bc I loved everything. AND THEN there was dessert... oh my god get the trio because all of them were amazing. This place rocked but the staff should work on their hospitality.
author: Sam P.

description: We got there and had to wait about 15-20min for a table, and no wonder this place has become so popular. Everything was amazing - the Tom Yum Goong (beetroot skin soup dumplings) and Seafood dumplings were incredible!
author: Maria R.

description: Looking to eat high quality dumplings but don't want to drive 45min to the south bay and wait 60-90min? Look no further as this place is as good if not slightly better than DTF. Although this place has a simpler menu, their customer service and quality of food is superb! Parking is very limited and the neighborhood is a bit sketchy. Highly recommend and can't wait to come back!
author: Cee B.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place for a while and finally I made it.

It was only my friend and myself so we were seated right away. We decided to try a little bit of everything to feel the place out. We started out with the garlicky green beans and the shrimp dumplings. Then we ordered the pork bao and the extra large soup dumplings. 

I'd have to say my favorite thing was the garlicky green beans which is probably not good since it's a dumpling restaurant.  The other thing I didn't like was we had a small table so once we had all of the food we really had no room( normally I order a lot of food so this is always a pet peeve of mine).

Overall I'd have to say the dumplings were good, but I was expecting it to taste better LOL. This is definitely more of a laid-back dumpling spot where you could come meet friends for a bite to eat.  If you're looking for a bigger variety of dumplings I say go to Chinatown in SF
author: Marshawna C.

description: Pretty good dumplings! Line is always long.  Not easy to park.  I'll be coming back for more juicy dumplings!
author: Urban E.

description:
V solid dumpling spot / fusion spot with lots of decisions to try. Good to go with 3/4 people as this allows you to try many decisions and get a good sampling of each!

I want to start off as I wasn't BLOWN AWAY by this place, nor was it an "authentic" spot to go to. It's just tapas style dumplings, noodles, and appetizers, and because its fusion the price gets jacked up 15% HAHAHHA 

BUT was pleasantly surprised and everything was very yummy
+ Pork XLB (4/5) 6 pieces -- good and very tasty
+ Tom Yum BLX (4/5) 6 pieces -- unique flavor, soupy, and satisfying
+ Beijing noodles (4/5) -- would have loved this more if they had more noodles instead of beef, and it wasn't saucy enough, but overall I was very satisfied with this!
+ Seafood gyoza with spiced chili butter (5/5) 5 pieces -- THIS was my favorite, and pretty unique cause it was def a fusion type of dish. Wonderfully crispy! 
+ Shrimp and pork siu mai (3/5) 4 pieces -- it was alright, tender, and dipping it in spicy sauce made it taste better, nothing of a must get.
+ Shrimp toast (4/5) (it was basically classic chinese morning breakfast donut, with aioli and shrimp inside), another classic fusion dish and while i didn't love it, i would order it again cause flavor was pretty unique
+ egg yolk bun for desert!!!! loved this, and was a great way to wrap up the meal with something sweet yet kind of savory :P
author: Cathy Y.

description: I am so excited that this place exists! We came here for a post-happy hour team dinner and everything we got was delicious. The complimentary cucumber salad tasted super authentic and was a great signal that we were in for a treat. We ordered some of the green beans and sadly, I did not think they were very good, but they were the only low point of the meal. I think we ordered every kind of dumpling they had, however I don't eat anything from a pig, so I only tried the pork-free ones. However, my coworkers said they were all delicious. Re the chicken and shrimp ones, I have to say I was very pleased. The skins are all perfectly soft and slightly chewy and they were generously stuffed with super savory fillings. The dessert milk buns are to DIE for and the staff here is really sweet. HIGHLY recommend, however if you are a vegetarian, you might find it hard to eat here.
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
I give this place a 3.5. They have great food presentation but I've had better XLBs elsewhere. If you consider yourself a dumpling connoisseur, you probably won't rank their food so highly. But if you're just looking to try fancy-plated decently yummy dumplings and a place with a great atmosphere, this is your spot. 

Notable dishes: The tom yum XLB, dessert trio buns, shrimp toast, and the Kingdum.

Pro-tip: If you order the Kingdum XLB, make sure to drink the soup with the provided straw fairly soon (my friend and I made the mistake of waiting too long and there was barely any soup left!).
author: Diana Y.

description:
Love this place. Super yummy every time, with a really great menu. I think they understand how to take more uncommon Chinese menu items and find what's acceptable to Americans. But in the best possible way. Reminds me heavily of going to a high end dumpling house in shanghai, seeing the workers make the dumplings is mesmerizing. Love their char siu bao with peanut butter of all things! It works! Don't forget to get the bao seared - steam it and do a really nice dry sear that adds a good textural contrast and a bit of flavor via the Maillard reaction between heat and the sugar in the dough.

Love the string beans, ambience is decent... only problem is the price! It is expensive, but on occasion totally worth it.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Their colorful dishes snagged my attention. I believe I arrived around 11:30 am on a weekday; thirty minutes after they just opened. It started getting busy around 12-12:30. So I highly recommend going around the time they open. 
I got the king dumpling (1 pc $8), shrimp toast ($8), pork xlb (pork soup dumplings 6 pc $8), trio of buns (3 pc $5.50), green beans and steamed shrimp dumplings (shrimp har gow 4pc/$6). The king dumpling came with a mini boba straw to drink the soup but sadly didn't come with the colorful decoration of petals on top like I've been seeing in pictures. I was a bit disappointed by that. However, the green beans came beautifully covered in colorful petals and were really delicious; possibly my favorite dish. I honestly ordered the trio of buns for the picture. I love sweets but for some reason I don't really like sweet custard baos, so I was unsure how I would feel about this dish. I was surprised by how light the sweetness was without it being bland.  The white bun (I'm not sure of the flavor) is my favorite. I believe the red bun is red bean and the green bun is green tea. All three buns have a custard filling inside. All the dishes I ordered were freshly made and very delicious.
Around the time they got busy, they seem to have forgotten about our last dish- the steamed shrimp dumplings. I understood and assumed they were backed up with orders so decided to wait fifteen minutes before bringing it to their attention. I then asked about our shrimp dumplings and they came back with the news that they are now preparing it. Even though our dish was forgotten, it was worth the wait. 
I love their set up and decor. They had a projecter that played Kpop music videos (I think) on their blank wall. Their seating can seem a bit crammed, especially for the tables that seat two people since they are situated pretty close to another party of two. They also have outdoor seating too which is great when the weather is really nice.
author: Kristin H.

description: This place is pretty good, excellent atmosphere and great for photos. My favorite thing was the shrimp toast, the dumplings are just okay. Sure if xianlongbao (soup dumplings) are new to you you may think this place is amazing but Dumpling Kitchen in the sunset is much more authentic and has better dumplings. The King Dum (giant xianlongbao) was cute as heck tho, I had not had this in the states before. Be prepared to wait 45 minutes to an hour to be seated.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Great ambience. Love the food! So authentic and modern. My favorite has to be the shrimp toast and the chicken dumpling. Service is really good the time we went(: 

Overall, a MUST for foodies.
author: Angeline K.

description:
I recently ate here this past Sunday and surprisingly enjoyed my meal! I thought this place would be overrated but the food tasted fresh and great. 
My friend and I got a couple things: 
Vegetable dumplings-- I assumed this was going to be bland but it was actually the best item we ordered. Super juicy and tasty! 
Pork Bao-- The seared buns def made it an elevated version of the normal buns but pretty average. 
Shrimp and Pork Siu Mai--Standard tasting Siu Mai, did not expect any less of this item. 
Gan Ban Noodles-- the hand cut noodles were so chewy in a good way! The sauce and veggies went well with it too. 
Kind Dum--the XL Xiao Long Bao!  The most iconic and popular item. The skin was thin with a juicy hot soupy filling! I would probably get the normal sized XLB next time though. 
Three Sum--the trio of the dessert buns offered on the menu. The egg yolk and green tea & milk was pretty good, nothing wrong with them! Taro wasn't too bad but I'm not a big fan of it.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Great dumplings in an avant-garde space!

They have an outside-tented patio along with a decent interior dining room where a large projection screen adds to their ambiance. Sound absorbing panels line the ceiling yet this animated crowd stretches its limits. The kitchen is clearly visible and service is prompt and informative. For the price, what they offer is really good.

At $2.95 individual glass and stainless steel tea-steepers allow a table to share a variety of teas. We tried both, the Da Hong Pao Oolong and the Bi Lou Chun Green teas both flavorful and not at all bitter.

At $10.00 the Seafood Gyoza was our favorite. Spinach skin wrapped crab, scallop & shrimp with a chili butter dipping sauce that provided a wonderful juxtaposition of texture and flavor.

At $6.50 the steamed Shrimp and Cilantro Har Gow with its puréed cilantro dipping sauce was moist and delicious. 

At $6.00 the Chicken Bao was packed with green onion, mushroom and ginger, mmm mmm.

And, at $9.50 the Tom Yum Goong wrapped in beet skin is their version of a shanghai soup dumpling. With a shredded ginger dipping sauce be gentile or you'll loose the soup; another favorite.

I have attached seven photos to better relay our experience; hope your Dumpling Time® is as good as ours was.
author: Caesar A.

description: It's Dumpling Time! Need I say more? Well, it's only the best Xiao Long Bao in the city. If you are looking for the juicy fillings wrapped in delicate skin that somehow manages to not break when you lift it up, and the multicolored deliciousness combo that rivals the authentic stuff you find in Shanghai, then this is the place. Basically it's the only Xiao Long Bao place within SF that compares to Din Tai Fung. Sure the lines are long and the price tag is Americanized, but like I always say, unless you want to buy a plane ticket to China...or drive to South Bay...this is as good as it gets. Order the other stuff on the menu too, I've tried everything and they are all good. There's the giant dumpling you can drink the soup with a straw, that's also pretty rare to see in the US. Good stuff, get it.
author: Yi Y.

description:
Everytime we drive past this place, there are always people waiting outside. Finally we decided to try right when it's open at 5:30pm. We waited about twenty minutes, which was not too bad. 

Pork XLB lived up to my expectations. In other restaurants that I've been to, the soup inside XLB is kinda greasy. But not here. The broth was clear and tasty and the skin was very thin. Thumbs up. 

Beijing Noodles were not very good. They were not chewy and had no texture. Watiress suggested adding soy and chilie sauce from the table. 

Shrimp toast was interesting. Big bites of shrimp cake on top of Chinese Youtiao (fried donut). A little greasy but not too bad. 

Steamed Egg yolk buns were soft. Loved egg custard filling! Perfect closure to the meal. 

As a Shanghai native, I will go again for the XLB and steamed egg yolk buns. Some of the other items look interesting on the menu too. Will definitely visit soon.
author: Carrie Z.

description: Came here on a whim while in the area on a busy Saturday night. Although the wait to be seated was rather long, once we got our table everything moved quickly and the service was great! We ordered the pork XLB, the seafood gyoza, and the gan ban noodles-- definitely stick to dumplings when you come, as the noodles fell short of our expectations. When it's Dumpling Time, it's definitely dumpling time!
author: Elina Y.

description:
We had a wonderful experience here.
We ordered the Shanghai dumplings two ways.  One large that came with a straw and then the traditional ones.  We also had vegetable salad and a noodle dish and everything was delicious.
author: Edwina O.

description: The King Dum was a little disappointing, I expected it to be more flavorful, the Beijing Noodles fell short, not flavorful and the noodles were undercooked. My daughter loved the pork XLB and I really enjoyed the Tom Yum Goong XLB because the flavor is different and tasty! Next time I'll try the happy ending sweet filled baos. The servers were really friendly and attentive.
author: Evelyn N.

description: Good dumplings for a reasonable price. It's just a shame you cannot book in advance. I came at 6pm to put my name down and when we came back at 8:15 we still had to wait 20min to get seated (party of 4). Wish dumplings didn't come one by one. Everything was a bit too slow for my taste. But will come back to try gyozas and noodles. If you don't mind waiting, go it's cool.
author: Clémentine C.

description: This is probably my favorite modern dumpling house in San Francisco.  I love the k-pop videos.  I equally love the incredibly delicious dishes that are very nicely priced.  The service is also good.  My only request is that you provide at least one more non- meat eater menu option.
author: Erin S.

description:
I'll make this short and quick.

Overpriced asian fusion food. I guess it's not a knock since all fusion is overpriced. If you must throw away your money, throw it away at their seafood gyoza. That thing is delicious. I want more. NOW!!

xlb = okay(i never understood the hype and i don't know why i always have to order it)
seafood gyoza = yumz 5/5(green potsticker wrapper with shrimp inside)
pork dumpling = okay

The service is good and the food is okay. It's worth it if you have money to throw away.  You aren't going to see any asian grandmas here for some authentic asian food.
author: Ronald C.

description:
I remember passing by when Dumpling Time first opened and their lines looked ridiculously long. Thank god I never had to experience that. I came once during lunch on a weekday, and another time during dinner but right when they opened. Don't get intimidated by the wait time, the food is so worth it.

I've tried a handful of dishes, and for the most part I love them all. My favorites have to be the shrimp toast and seafood gyoza. There are a couple of underwhelming dishes, the biggest being the King-Dum. It just didn't hit the spot for me and I could definitely do without it.

It is a bit on the pricey side but I would say it's worth it!!!

Minus one star because they have no AC in the restaurant. I went once during the nasty heat wave and it was so hot inside :(
author: Susan P.

description:
NEW FAVE LUNCH. 

Working in Portrero Hill doesn't allow for a plethora of fast and delicious lunch options and Dumpling Time has filled the dearth of some great Chinese food. The service is fast and efficient, and it's much like an Asian tapas place. 

Yes, the prices are bit more than I would normally like to pay for Chinese food, but everything was clean, orderly, fast, and delicious and it's in the middle of Portrero Hill, so what are you really going to complain about?

Highly recommend the 
Beijing noodles - great blend of sweet and savory and the noodles were perfect! (this is a pretty small portion)
seafood gyoza - they don't skimp on the seafood
garlicky green beans - love the floral touch to cut up the greasiness of these fried string beans

Looking forward to my next visit already!
author: Annie S.

description: I love this place. I definitely recommend this place to mu friend and relatives. I will make sure to bring my mother. She would love this place
author: Nyamka N.

description:
I rather enjoyed most of the dumplings I had here at Dumpling Time. While the price can add up, it is very reasonable for San Francisco. We spent 80 dollars among 4 people while not stuffing ourselves.

We arrived half an hour before opening and were third in line. It wasn't necessary, but we honestly didn't have anywhere else to go at the time. They fill up real quick after opening though, and the wait can get long on the weekends.

My favorite items were the Shrimp Toast (which is a surprise because A) I don't like shrimp and B) it didn't look as good as it tastes,) as well as the char siu steamed buns (finished on the pan). Both of these were very well executed in regards to flavor.

The xiao long bao (pork and Tom Yum Goong) were both pretty good, the latter of which had a surprising hint of spice to it.

Their pork dumplings were okay - the presentation was nice but the flavors weren't too interesting to me.

And the dessert baos weren't that appealing to me - maybe I'm not used to them, but they kind of tasted like mush in a bao.

I don't see myself making the trip back here - as a visitor now, it is kind of a try it once kind of place.
author: Kevin L.

description: Must get the shrimp toast and pork xiao lung bao! Unique presentation of the dishes and an abundance of soup in the dumplings. Very tasty and authentic dumplings. The portion sizes are small, would come again during non-peak times and when I'm not that hungry.
author: Andrea C.

description:
Dim sum heaven! The long wait to get seated was worth it. Dumpling Time is located in a somewhat obscure area and I would have never known about this place had my friends had not told me. This place is so popular though that it attracts so many lyfts and ubers dropping/picking up people for the sole purpose of eating dim sum. 

The menu itself is pretty straightforward and my friends and I ordered a variety of items to share family-style. We ordered 2 beijing beef noodles (1 for every 2 people), seared char-siu bao, dumplings, shrimp har gow, 2 orders of xiao long bao, and shao mai. It was soo much food but we managed to finish it all because it was so delicious! The cilantro sauce (that I believe comes with the shrimp har gow) is divine and pairs so well with everything. I could prob just lick the sauce off my spoon - it was that good! 

By the time the dessert menu rolled around, we were stuffed. However, it looks like they offer some yummy dessert buns on their menu as well. They also have a cute outdoor seating area. Overall, great place to get some delicious dim sum and catch up with friends!
author: Kris C.

description:
This is an okay spot. The wait is long, and the food doesn't really deliver in quality, especially with its price. 
The big Soup Dumpling is a good idea, but you really don't get much meat or soup... more of just the flour of the dumpling... 
Also, the other dumplings are good in taste, don't get me wrong, but its just not worth the wait or the money imo. 

It is one of the only dumpling spots in the area, so if your'e craving dumplings this is the place to go...
author: Justin S.

description: Wonderful food and ambience, been there many times, but the hostess really needs to brush up on her customer service and english, sorry i dont speak chinese nor should i have to just to get seated lol
author: Nina A.

description:
Dumpling Time is a great addition to SFs growing obsession with dim sum, especially if you want to go somewhere outside of Chinatown/Sunset/Richmond with a bit more of a trendy vibe. Heads up, this place has been opened for a few months and still faces long wait times (30-1hr) during peak hours. So be prepared, but I think the food is well worth the wait. When you get there, put your name down and if time allows, go get wine or beer from The Grove :).

I've been here a few times so I'll just detail the items below, but definitely pair your dumplings with these house chili oil - it is outstanding! And go in a group to try the most!

Beijing Noodles: This is one of my favorite things to order! The noodles are perfectly cooked, but the winner is the ground pork in this dish. It just lends SO much incredible flavor with the ginger and soybean paste! Highly recommend!

Gan Ban Noodles: If you're vegetarian or not, I think this dish is solid and differs a lot from the Beijing Noodles to give variety. They are generous with the veggies and it comes in this tasty light peanut flavored sauce. Super good!

Shrimp + Cilantro Har Gow: My group wasn't big into cream cheese so we got this one and boy is it yummy! The cilantro just goes so well with the shrimp and the har gow wrapper is perfectly sticky - great texture and flavor combined!

Pork Xi'an Dumpling: These were the dumplings with the most subtle flavor in my opinion, but I also think they tasted the freshest. So don't expect outrageous flavor, but it's done well if you appreciate the subtlety :).

Pork XLB: I think Dumpling Time did these well, but I don't think it's the best you can find in SF. The broth was flavorful, but didn't have a wow factor and the dumplings were smaller than I'd have elsewhere. I still think Hunan Home is the best place for XLB. That being said, this is still a great place to go when you need your soup dumpling fix and I'd argue it's better than the Din Tai Fung in San Jose.

Seafood Gyoza: These might have been my favorite from the dumplings. The gyoza comes out nice and crispy and I just loved the spinach skin, holding a sizeable amount of flavorful seafood inside. I'd recommend these for gyoza fans :). 

Overall, I'd recommend this trendy spot! Come with a group to share and try many of their delicious dishes.
author: Sabina S.

description:
My friend and I researched this place before coming and was pretty excited. However,we left very dissatisfied. First off, the good: the decor was very nice and modern. They also had a window where you can see how the dumplings are made, similar to ding tai fun. 
The bad: we ordered the king-dum, pan seared  chicken humbao, and trio of dessert bun. The king dum was a total fail. By the time we got it, the soup have soaked most of the bottom layer and was dripping out of the dish so we barely had any soup to drink.the rest was just standard. The chicken bao was also a failed. It was supposed to be pan seared, yet you can only see slight marks on them, the bao otself was still soft like a regular humbao. And it lacked in flavor, we all had to use a lot of soy sauce. The trio of dessert was just ok. The egg yolk was probably the most flavorful, but they should have name it egg custard. The taro and beet was too dense and had no flavor. And the green one was just very milky. Price wise, it was very expensive. For those 3 dishes, it was around $25! And we were still very hungry. Maybe im picky because Seattle has really good dumplings place, but this was not a good place.
author: Huong L.

description: What is not to love about dumplings?! Dumpling Time does it right. Everything made to order, each dish, better than the previous. Good food, great service, fun atmosphere. Can't wait to go back and try all the dishes I missed the first time around. My new favorite place for dumplings in San Francisco.
author: Rich S.

description:
Excellent dumpling and amazing server "Pat" is excellent server aside from the food is great customer service is excellent!!!!

I love the pan fry dumplings
author: Marie R.

description:
This place is a solid option for those who don't want to go and wait for a full dim sum experience. The menu is full of various dumpling options and the cool part is they are all made on site and you can see them making it. The location is fairly accessible, but during the week it can be hard to find parking. Also to note if you park on the street to be aware of your surroundings as some parts are a bit sketchy.
The service here was fast and friendly and the lay out of the place is causal and open. Menu is straight forward with various dumpling, bao, har gow, gyoza options. While not as authentic as other dumpling/dim sum places it's a good place to bring novices to try as they don't have the more interesting items the more traditional places have.
During my visit tried the pork gyoza, pork bao, pork and shrimp soup dumplings, and shrimp & cilantro har gow. Gyoza was ok, crispy with a decent dipping sauce. The bao was soft as a pillow filled with porky goodness. Soup dumplings were ok as well. My favorite was the har gow, as it had large pieces of shrimp and were cooked perfectly. Overall this place is a good option to stop by if you're having a craving for some dumplings, but if you want a true dim sum experience go try some of the more traditional places in the Richmond neighborhood.
author: Peter P.

description: Nice ambiance, good service, on par food taste in terms of authenticity--sans the adorable garnishes they put on top, but in line with most everything in South Beach/SoMa these days: completely overpriced, by as much at 100% or more. Amazing what people will pay these days in these parts. It's nice to see people trying dumplings for the first time, or homesick folks from Beijing trying to comfort their souls, but these are just jiaozi dumplings, for heck's sake, and at $11 or more per serving, it is just predatory price gouging. There are many places just as good-- sans the adorable garnishes-- for half the price or more.
author: Brian J.

description:
If I had not been sweating like a rabid monkey while eating here I could see myself bumping my rating up to 4 stars.  

Don't sit inside if it's a hot day...it's HOT AF and they have no AC and poor ventilation.

The king dum is aight...no matter what I say about it I'm sure all you peoples will order it anyways so my only advice is don't be a noob and just drink all the soup, and then cut the dumpling in half with extreme skill.  I saw many people pick at it and scratch their heads on how to eat it..don't be like those people.

The veggie xian dumplings were aight and so were the tom yum XLBs.  I'd says its better than DTF since everything we got served was hot n fresh vs the past couple times ive been to DTF, everything was luke warm. (DTF = ding tai fung for all you sick minded pervs)

The Beijing noodles were ok, they were a little wet so if you like it wet and slippery then there ya go..order that bad boy.

come her with a table of 4 so you can try everything on the menu
author: Vince L.

description:
Please listen to the people Dumpling Time and stop putting XLB in tin foil cups... 

food: 3
interior: 3.5
authenticity: 3
service: 3.5

If I have to pick only one thing to eat for the rest of my life, dumpling would arguably be my choice. Needless to say I was beyond excited when I saw Dumpling Time on the "Hot & New" list, especially given that they seem to focus on Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings). 

However, after looking at the menu I felt a bit deflated. When you see Beijing noodle (炸酱面) and Shanghai XLB on the same menu, you shall be very alarmed. Beijing and Shanghai, the two metro cities are rivals of each other, and their palates also have some irreconcilable differences. In fact, even today in Beijing you could hardly find a decent Shanghai dumpling place, and most Shanghainese people would not appreciate the saltiness of Beijing noodle. Growing up in Beijing and spent quite some time in Shanghai thanks to my Shanghainese mom, I have *some* reservation about putting these two items on the same menu. 

Despite my doubts I decided to keep an open mind and try it for myself. Sadly it didn't pay off this time. 

XLB: 
+ Soup was actually very good.
- Stuffing is bad, lacks texture and falls apart easily.
- I don't even know how well the skin hold up because it came in a tin foil cup! No self respecting dumpling place should serve XLB like that.  It was very difficult to dip the dumpling in vinegar or even taking a bite because they just get stuck at the bottom. 

Beijing noodles: 
+ It's tasty.
-  It's nothing like Beijing noodles. Beijing noodle comes with very specific thick & salty sauce, very fatty bits of pork belly (not mince meat), and at least 2 veggie toppings (thinly chopped cucumber and bean sprouts are most common). This dish has none of those. As a Beijing person I'm mildly offended. Call it anything but Beijing noodles plz.

Other dishes: 
~ While some dishes sound quite creative, none of them was very memorable. 

Interior: 
The space looked very chic in photos but confusing in real life. 
Side #1: A glass wall with people making dumplings behind it. Since Ding Tai Fung did this in all of their locations this became a trend in restaurants that serve xlb. 
Side #2: A counter, semi open kitchen, some neon signs, then a very hipster white wall with wall art. 
Side #3: A white wall with non-stop Korean(!) music video projected on it. Why?
Side #4: Windows & two toned (white & greenish blue) wall. Hello 1980. 
What are you trying to express Dumpling Time? Make up your mind.

Service: 
While our servers were nice, we were told to order everything all at once and wouldn't be able to add anything later.

In general, I'd agree that Asian Fusion is the accurate category for this restaurant and I was very disappointed. Give it a try if 1) you haven't had great XLB before  2) there's no line, it's not worth the wait otherwise.
author: Rachel Z.

description: Fast service. Better than a typical dimsum place: not greasy for the savor and not too sweet for dessert buns. Great tea to be pair with sweet buns too.
author: Meo M.

description: I love this place, I come here all the time, best dumplings in the city. Thanks to all the workers.
author: Pamela P.

description:
The menu is varied and the small portions mean you can order variety, which I like.   It's bustling and steamy.    It appears that they refuse reservations, which results in a line out the front door - I suspect that this is by design, to look trendy.  The wait has always been under 30 mins for a table for 2, which is fine.   
  
The staff is competent and friendly.  Last time I ate there I think we had 4 or 5 servers in one meal, which results in some confusion - but it's not fine-dining, it's more noodle-house (or dumpling house, I suppose) and includes community tables to help get people in and fed faster.
author: Steve B.

description: Amazing dumplings!!!!! I went with two friends and among the three of us we split about 8-9 dishes, and the overall price wasn't so bad. and the flavors!!!!!! SOOOOOO GOOOOOOD!!!
author: Paula J.

description: It was okay, don't get me wrong but I've eaten dumplings, dim sum and other favorites in many places. The atmosphere was cool and hip, felt like we were sitting in a hole in the wall in middle of Hong Kong. Wait was about 30 minutes on a Friday night. Staff were very friendly and service was not to shabby considering everything is made fresh.
author: Brenda L.

description:
I had my fair share of XLBs and dumplings but I'm no expert.  This place is cute and definitely not a mom and pop type of shop but the xlb just ain't quite right.

I ordered the
Shrimp toast
garlicky green beans
Beijing noodles 
XLBs
Tom yum dumpling
King XLB

The shrimp toast was probably my favorite because it's interesting and it tasted pretty good.  It's a fried Chinese donut with the shrimp mixture in the middle with a mayo-based sauce.  It wasn't overwhelming since the shrimp was in the middle and it wasn't too much of it.  

Garlicky green beans - eh it was okay, there wasn't much of a crunch or snap like traditional Chinese restaurant and I feel like it's a bit too oily

Beijing noodles - I don't know how I feel abut this one, i feel like I was eating bland noodles, even with all the ingredients mixed in.  I had to add hot sauce and it just didn't taste right.  

XLB - the soup was okay, but the meat, it didn't taste like traditional XLB, it taste like regular store-bought dumplings.  Most XLBs filling has more of a fattier taste and this one just tasted like regular pan fried dumplings.  Also, it has a bit of a funky smell to it (I don't know how to explain it in English)

Tom yum - at least this was a bit different and it wasn't too bad but again, nothing that was out of this world.  Also, didn't taste like tom yum lol.

King XLB - I don't even know anyone does this, it's really for looks.  The skin was a bit too thick (obviously) but just sucking on the soup through the straw which isn't that easy and you just chunks of the filling.  I don't know but I was turned off by it!

I see the appeal of this time but I was not a fan of the food
author: Laurie W.

description:
first time coming her. I have very high expectation since so many people have told me about it and also last time I went to another restaurant nearby, I saw a long line in front of dumpling time. So i thought this must be really good. 

my friend and i went here on weekday 1130. There's no line yet. We ordered about 5-6 items. the service is good. The food is really just ok. It's not like traditional dim sum. Everything is good but i probably won't come again because the price is really kind of high for a dim sum place. in sunset and Richmond area of san francisco, there are a bunch of dim sum places which i think the food is the same quality but the price is so much lower.
author: Tina H.

description: Perfect little hipster spot with a satisfying taste for those craving an asian authenticity right around the ball park.  Got here early around 6:00pm and was able to get seated right away.  Best part about the dumplings were the soup didn't leak out unlike many other dumpling spots.  The shrimp toast was my favorite of all the dishes and it's rarity makes it even more pleasurable.  Will definitely come back to try the other baos and dumplings.
author: Derek L.

description: I love it. The food in here is amazing. And I love the buns it's so colorful so cute. I enjoyed it so much
author: Clancy Y.

description: Craving dumplings but wanna watch the game so we decided this was a good place to try. I'm all for traditional XLB. But Wow!!! Their tom yum XLB was really tasty. As for the Chinese shrimp donut, I found it a little oily but definitely worth trying. The pork dumplings were..meh. We finished off with the trio bun which were soft and delightful too! Would I come back? Definitely yes!!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
We first noticed this place driving by because there was a bunch of people standing outside.  There was a waitlist and we ended up waiting for about 35-40 minutes.  When we finally sat down, they took our order quickly and food was at our table 6 minutes later.  

We ended up ordering the Da Hong Pao Oolong Tea, the Shrimp Toast, Seafood Gyoza, Tom Yum Xiao Long Bao, King Dum, Beijing Noodles, and the Three Sum. 

The tea was suppose to have red dates and purple plums.  I taste a hint of dates but not the plums.  It was fragrant though.  

The shrimp toast was made of shrimp paste on a Chinese donut.  It was creative and the donut was delightfully crispy.  

The seafood gyoza was in between a potsticker and a boiled dumpling.  It came with a spiced chili butter sauce that was so addicting.  I liked the sauce better than the gyoza itself because I'm not a big seafood fan, but it went well together.  

Next the tom yum xiao long bao.  It came with a beet red color skin.  It tasted pretty much like tom yum goong to me, but my husband couldn't tell.  It was interesting to try this unique dish, but personal preference I don't love tom yum goong, so while it was good, I probably could eat more of the regular xiao long bao.  

The King dum was interesting but we wouldn't order it again.  The skin was thick and overall it was ok but not great.  More of a novelty item.  

The Beijing noodle were ok.  It wasn't too special and the bowl of noodles was relatively small.  

Extra points for the three-sum option of a variety of buns.  I liked them in the order, beet and taro, egg yolk, and my favorite the green tea milk bun.  The green tea tastes the most unique.  It has a milky filling, but tasted a bit coconutty too.  

The meal was somewhat expensive but we did order a lot of food and the food was unique.  Nice little dim sum treat!
author: S Y.

description:
Been here several times for the soup dumplings and I must say YUM! They have the traditional, the Tom yum flavor, and the king soup dumpling! All are so delicious! They have other traditional dim sum items as well such as ha gow, siu mai, etc. A few of my favorites are the garlic string beans, soup dumplings, gyoza, and the green tea milk buns. 

The location does bring a bit of wait especially during the lunch hour but it is worth the wait and my server was nice enough to allow my group to order while waiting so the food would be ready upon getting seated. 

Prices here are a bit expensive compared to other dim sum restaurants but it is a less traditional restaurant, friendly staff, cleanly space. 

Highly recommend if you are in the area! Best part: they have a few parking spaces out front!
author: Lushi Z.

description:
More accurately 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4 for swiftness of service (not to be confused with swiftness of getting seated) and food. Came here with a friend as a belated birthday lunch, and spent a little less than an hour waiting. The waiting experience is further dampened by the fact that Dumpling Time isn't surrounded by any shops or places you can wander around. 

Dumpling Time is a pretty good novelty dim sum experience. I would maybe even come back, if my friends were up for getting there before they open. But the quality of food is underwhelming for how much it costs. The xian dumplings all had broken skin, and the Beijing noodles were salty enough to make me feel parched for the rest of the day. The xiaolongbao were good, but nothing distinguishes them from the xiaolongbao you can get at another dimsum place for half the wait. I have to say that the shrimp toast (shrimp on youtiao) was my favorite, it's a big pull factor for returning.

This is one of those try it once places, but pleasantry of experience will probably be contingent on getting there early and not expecting anything radically different from normal dim sum.
author: Amy J.

description:
My friends and I were lured here by all the pretty pictures and glowing reviews. The wait was about 30 minutes for a party of 4 on Tuesday night at 7:15pm. There were 13 parties ahead of us when we first put our name on the list but 40-50% of them left so we didn't have to wait as long. 

I should preface by saying I am a snob when it comes to asian food. I only like authentic asian cuisines and this restaurant should be classified as asian fusion. 

First of all - This is not a Dim Sum restaurant. Dim Sum is cantonese and XLB are shanghainese. Jiao Zi and XLB is not Dim Sum. (XLB is commonly eaten at dimsum but it is not dim sum. It's Shanghainese) They do serve a weird version of "har gow" and a very americanized cha siu bao but those are the only items that can be considered dim sum. 

We shared a number of items between the 4 of us. 

Shrimp Toast - my friends like this one but I couldn't have it because it contained butter. What chinese restaurant uses butter? -- eek! definitely asian fusion. 
Actually all of their dishes are asian fusion. Nothing that authentic. 
Pork XLB - this one tasted okay, but they all came with diapers. I know they did this because americans can't pick up a xiao long bao properly with chopsticks, but just no. They also give you red vinegar to go with this dish. No. Pork XLB should be served with black vinegar. -__-
Tom Yum XLB - My friends liked this one too, but I'm born and raised in shanghai and this dish is terrible. 
Giant Bao - this one is the giant XLB that everyone sees in pictures. Ours did not come out looking pretty or tasting great. it was okay. 
Xian Jiao Zi (Dumplings) - this was probably my favorite. They serve this like a little floral salad. It's pretty but I like my dumplings without extra olive oil. 
Beijing Noodles - comes with ground pork. It's pretty good, but very oily. 
Pork Bao & Cha Siu Bao - both very small compared to other restaurants and nothing special. 

Portion sizes for everything were very small. Tasted above average for an americanized dumpling shop, but way way overpriced. Presentation is a novelty and really didn't add much -- sometimes it added negatively like in the case of XLB diapers. 

If you don't eat asian food often and you want pay extra, waiters/waitresses that speak perfect english, plenty of inefficiencies just like a typical american restaurant then come to dumpling time! 
If you actually want to experience real authentic chinese dumplings at a real chinese restaurant, do yourself a favor and head over to sunset, inner richmond (within SF) or millbrae, Cupertino. You'll get much better chinese dumplings at much better prices.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Dumpling Time is a fun, cute place to go with friends. A bit out of the way, and waits can be long, but it's worth the journey.

I didn't have high expectations for the food, since the restaurant seems to cater to the Instagram/Snapchat crowd, a phenomenon in which taste is inversely correlated with post-worthy aesthetics. See: "Dragon's Breath" liquid nitrogen puffs, Unicorn Frappucinos, etc. But my group ordered Dumpling Time's two most novel offerings, the Tom Yum Goong XLB, wrapped in a pretty red beet skin, and the King Dum, a giant XLB whose soup you have to drink with a straw, and they were both excellent.

They certainly don't beat Din Tai Fung or other good, legit Asian joints, but the food was still great. 

My only gripes: 
- A lot of the soup escaped the King Dum, and we had to drink it from the dish it fell into, which I guess is natural, but annoying. It was hard to break apart into smaller pieces, too. I guess that is one of the cons of giant, Instagrammable food. 
- The place is pretty expensive (for me - typical for a trendy restaurant in the city), and dishes are small. We each paid about $30 before tip.
- Servers didn't offer refills on our teapot, which was also expensive (and it's supposed to be for one person, but we stretched it out to two). I know this isn't an authentic Asian restaurant, but seriously... It's hot water. And as a tea enthusiast, part of the tea experience is drinking it through multiple steepings, especially with a complex tea like our pu-erh.

Finally, I wanted to say I'm really disappointed that the dessert section of the menu is called "Happy Endings," especially since the owner is Asian. So many Asian women are stereotyped, assumed to be sex workers who give "happy endings" just because of their race, and sexually harassed or assaulted. It also just contributes to the hypersexualization of Asian women in general. I've personally been harassed on the street by men who ask if I can give them a happy ending (along with other brilliant lines like "suki suki" and "will you love me long time?"). Treating this like a fun joke only perpetuates things. Seriously, just change it, please.
author: Maya K.

description:
Wow...I seriously can't believe how much the Yelp community has let me down on this place.

We came here a little before closing at the end of lunch in order to avoid a wait, and it worked. We only ordered an order of the king size xlb and the tom yum goong xlb just to try the place out. 

The tom yum goong xlb came individually in a tin pan that you normally get an egg tart in. It's a bit shocking as I've never seen a place take the easy way and cheat like that. If you're a xlb place, you should have the technique down to not need a pan to hold these dumplings together. Even the mom and pop place in Newark got that technique down. The other issue with it is that it is difficult to get it out of the pan without breaking the entire thing. The skin was thin but the top was so thick that all you can taste was the dough. This was the same issue with the king size xlb as well (which the soup did not flow out when you poke the straw into it, like the server had told us it would, I poked it 4 times trying to get the soup to flow until I realized there was not much soup in it to begin with). The filling for the tom yum goong was better than the pork as the pork was lacking flavor. The other issue is with the soup, I've never had xlb broth this bland. It tasted as if it came from a bunch of meatless chicken bones and a smidge of msg. There was also not enough ginger in the dipping vinegar sauce. 

Honestly if this place was in anywhere else other than SF, I would not be as critical. In SF, you have such great places to get great xlb in the sunset or outer Richmond or even the peninsula. Dumpling Time should have been able to do better research on taste anywhere in the city or even looked into Din Tai Fung, instead of just focusing on making that king xlb instagramable. Coming from a team that has garnered a Michelin star for omakase, I'm a bit appalled and shocked. 

Maybe we came on an off day, but I don't think I'd risk coming back for mediocre xlb.
author: Linh H.

description: I didn't have the opportunity to eat here because we arrived 30 minutes before closing. They turned us away because they were only taking to go orders. I even called ahead of time to make sure they'll take us and rushed over.
author: Shelley L.

description: Came here because our cousin recommended it to us. We ordered the king-dum, shrimp & cilantro hargow, pork dumpling, and garlic green beans. Everything has a lot of flavor and taste great. The king-dum was different because you poke a straw in it and drink the soup, but isn't worth the price. Waiters and waitresses were very attentive and helpful. Overall we had a good experience.
author: Jason Y.

description:
Dim sum right by my house!! Yay!! 

We ordered quite a bit for our table, but I'm vegetarian so I ordered the veggie dumplings which were steamed ones not buns. They were flavorful and nice. I also got the noodles which sucked..there was no sauce which really confused me. We got the garlic green beans which were good but nothing mind boggling. I got the tiny cucumber salad which was also not as good as other cucumber salads I have tried before. 

The dessert buns were good! And it's cool you can get 3 of them in one order. 

Overall, it was good, but nothing amazing. It's in a convenient location for me, so I'll likely come back, but not rushing back.
author: Aria S.

description:
Solid Chinese flavors and yummy fare overall, but not super authentic. However, you do get a hip / trendy atmosphere, clean dining area, and nice servers!

Will start with what I loved: Trio of buns were pillowy and delicious as a dessert. Green beans were also really flavorful. 

What was just okay/good: Beijing noodles and seafood gyoza were both good but not amazing. 

Fail for me: Kim-Dum or XXL XLB. soup tasted off... first time having a huge XLB and disappointed (I've had traditional XLB too many times to count). beware of trying to get the soup from the straw - you can get burned!
author: Claudia C.

description:
Finally got to try dumpling time!

This place is a great place to get your XLBs (soup dumplings) and get some good dry noodles

I would recommend the Beijing noodles, the toast, the Xiao long baos and the seafood gyoza

I would not recommend you to get their XL soup dumplings, they are way too big to enjoy thoroughly and it's hard to share and it's expensive for what you get. 

I also would not recommend getting their Xi'an dumplings even though it's their family recipe. I personally think the pan fried seafood gyoza is wayyy better

Overall it's a pretty good place for soup dumplings! Here you can get out of the usual spots like the Richmond, sunset and Chinatown and explore the dogpatch. It's a pretty nice restaurant and the service is okay and polite (unlike lots of Chinatown places)
author: Sean S.

description:
Quick tip: You will get seated faster if you are party of 2.  We have to wait for an hour because were 4. They have long tables inside and make sure you are open on sharing tables.

Beijing noodles, shrimp toast and lobster siu mai are a must order. Thieir pork XLB is just ok. We also ordered the King dum and its probably worth of your IG picture. The food will come out quick. Enjoy!
author: roderick s.

description:
TL; DR As far as I'm concerned, Dumpling Time is severely underrated on Yelp. I came here last night honestly not expecting much (except a long line). I left extremely content. 

I will say there was a long line out front when we arrived. There were likely 10 groups ahead of us and we got seated in 20 minutes. It wasn't a long wait at all despite looking daunting at first. 

We ordered the Vegetarian Xi'an Dumplings, Chicken Gyoza, Char-Siu Bao, Pork XLB, and egg yolk buns for dessert. Everything was brought out very quickly. We were probably only there for about 40 minutes. 

The Xi'an Dumplings were decent. They tasted somewhat like a veggie spring roll. Same fresh taste. Not really up my alley but that's just me. 

The chicken gyoza was excellent. They had a good amount of heat and a nice crunch to them. 

The Char-Siu Bao were probably my favorite item that I tried. Quite possibly the best pork buns I've had (and I've had a lot). They weren't too doughy which is a nice change since some pork buns are more dough than filling. 

The pork xlb were extremely gingery. I don't mind ginger but this was a bit much. However, when you pair it with the red vinegar sauce they give you it was perfect! Took the bite out of the ginger. Great pairing!

Lastly, the egg yolk buns were really really great. It's basically a steam bun filled with a thick custard. I was a huge fan! I'll definitely be coming back here.
author: Nick D.

description:
7.14.16 
3.5 STARS! 

This place reminds me of a smaller and more limited version of Dragon Beaux. Trendy dim sum with a modern twist with added colors and creativity. 

DIM SUM:
The menu is very limited as it is only 1 page consisting of xiao long baos, buns, gyozas, noodles, chinese donuts and of course their XL xiao long bao. We ordered: 
+ Tom Yum XLB $9/6: My friends weren't the biggest fan of the flavor, but I actually thought it tasted pretty good with a kick of spiciness
+ XL XLB $8: Apparently they only have a limited number of these per day. The concept is definitely unique and originated from Shanghai. The bun itself is really pretty, but the content on the inside is lacking meat and mostly contains pork juice. Not sure it's worth $8. 
+ Trio of yolk buns $5.50: matcha bun, regular yolk bun and beet and taro bun. The matcha bun has very subtle flavor, taro and beet was voted least favored in our group and yolk bun was most favored. 
+ Pork Gyoza $5: tasted like any other gyoza with added decoration that makes the dish look more appealing. 
+ Sui Mai $5: this was their special of the day. It tasted like any other sui mai at typical dim sum places, but I did appreciate that it didn't have chucks of fat in it like some lower quality places. 

SERVICE: 
Friendly waiters, although it does take awhile to flag someone down when it gets super busy. The food came out somewhat promptly considering how busy it was. We came here 10min before they opened and there was already a crowd - we ended up waiting about 1 hr to be seated. 

AMBIANCE: 
There is plenty of parking nearby so that's a big bonus. There is seating inside and outside, but not very big compared to typical dum sum restaurant. Very clean and brightly lit. You can also watch cooks make the XLB while you wait! 

Verdict: Overall, I think I would rather just go to Dragon Beaux or other dim sum shops, but this new location appeals to the latest modern dim sum trend.
author: Samantha F.

description: Worth the wait. The dumplings were good the service as well. They have great variety. The atmosphere is good for groups or families. Food comes out as it is ready, a plus when hungry. Their seaweed salad was really good. The steam buns were decent. Overall, I enjoyed it and would definitely return.
author: Jonathan P.

description: Amazing dumplings!! Great service ! Wonderful dinner! Great environment! Great to bring a family
author: Arlene V.

description: Good dumplings from a decent selection, although they are on the expensive side compared to other dumpling shops in SF. For the novelty factor, order the giant soup dumpling - you need a straw to properly eat this. Overall, Dumpling Time is a nice place for groups, but call ahead if possible because you will have to wait quite awhile at around dinnertime.
author: Andrew Y.

description: This place did not disappoint! Four of us went on a Saturday night and expected to wait a while but we only waited less than 30 mins. We ordered everything ha! Loved every single thing we ordered, see pictures for more detail. Service was wonderful, and really sad this place is not back home!
author: Christina W.

description:
Amazing!!!

Will be back for sure and I will be bringing all my foodie friends !!!

Orders 1 of everything hahahahaha

No but seriously I ordered a lot and then we said ok that was great do it again hahahaha
author: Azikiwee A.

description:
I like the concept: Modern, hipster, fusion dumpling spot. Wasn't bad, but didn't quite live up to its hype. 

We ordered:
- Cucumber salad: Holy crap. This is so overpriced for $5, it was almost comical. Luckily it tasted great, but for $5, I expected something larger than a drink coaster-sized container of thiny sliced cucumbers.
- All the XLB, including the King-Dum, Pork XLB, and Tom Yum Goong: I liked the Tom Yum Goong the best because it was the most unique. Everything was overall not bad, but I didn't think any of these were nearly as flavorful as XLB should be. Plus some of them fell apart while lifting them out of the bamboo steamers, which is a big no-no. The King-Dum was fun to order and eat though because they give you a straw.
- Shrimp & Cilantro Har Gow: Not bad, not very memorable.
- Beijing Noodles: Definitely their best dish, but portions were small.
- Chicken Gyoza: More shiitake mushroom than chicken, which I didn't mind. Tasted pretty good.
- Trio of buns (egg yolk, green tea & milk, beet & taro): Came out piping hot, which I liked. The beet & taro was by far the least sweet, so pick that one if you're sensitive to sugar! Green tea & milk and the egg yolk bun were both very creamy, though the green tea could've used more green tea to differentiate it.

For a place named Dumpling Time, I don't think they do a great job at making dumplings. They did have some other great tasting dishes, but for the price tag, it was overall just okay.
author: Sara L.

description:
Seared Pork Bao was ok. Tom Yum Goong XLB was good. Pork Xi'an was dry... Expected much better based on the reviews. However, after trying a bunch of other dumpling places in SF this is the best one.

I returned and stuck to the good stuff Tom Yum Goong XLB, pork XLB, and seafood gyoza - the seafood gyoza is amazing!! Possibly the best item. Basically stick to that and XLB and avoid the bao and xi'an and probably the har gow and siu mai too. I also tried the shrimp toast but wouldn't get it again. It's ok I guess but very greasy.

And I went to the San Jose Din Tai Fung recently and was disappointed.... Dumpling Time might be the best dumplings in the Bay Area. But DTF over in Hong Kong is better :P
author: J D.

description:
Wow, great place to eat!
Started with oolong tea and pickled lotus root. Pickled root was mild but flavorful. Just the right amount of salty ness. Followed by pork BAO. They were good just a little too sweet for me. Seafood goyza were amazing! Bright green wrapper and super delicious inside. Finished with an order of XLB which were very very good.

Service was attentive without making you feel rushed. Loved the ambiance. 

We will be back!
author: Kerry B.

description:
I've been here a few times now and it is pretty good. If you're in the mood for dumplings, it definitely hits the spot. The decor and ambiance is a bit more hip than the typical Chinese restaurant. 

The seating area is pretty loud, with the option of long communal tables inside. There are a few smaller tables for groups, but generally you will hear your neighbors next to you and it can feel crowded. They really pack you in there.

The dumpling options are good. Although they aren't the best dumplings I've ever had, they're still pretty delicious and they have a few options I don't normally see, such as Maine Lobster Siu Mai and Tom Yum XLB. Both were great although quite pricey. For $12 you get 4 pieces of lobster siu mai. Another favorite was the seafood gyoza, which was soft and tender on the inside, crispy on the bottom. I was not a fan of the beef noodles, which were pretty flavorless. 

Overall this place is okay. It hits the spot, but it's a bit pricey for what you're getting. While the trendy atmosphere can be fun, it can also be too noisy.
author: Sara S.

description: I'm a sucker for dumplings and dumpling time is probably one of the best and most reasonably priced dumpling spots in the city. I only had the shrimp and cilantro har gao and the pork soup dumplings - but both were absolutely on-point. The soup dumplings were hot but not scalding (as in some places) and perfectly juicy and delicious. The har gao was a little bit sticky but otherwise really good. I'm also a huge fan of their chili oil (the real reason I eat dumplings)
author: Sam M.

description: Great tasty food.  Love their little twist on the classics.  My favorite was the Tom Yum Goong which came out hot and a little spicy.  The Three-Sum at the end made me happy and content.  Most plates are about $8-$10.
author: Aaron K.

description: This place is walking distance to my job and it is so so good. I haven't had anything I haven't liked. If you haven't been here get here you won't be sorry. Oh make sure you're early or late because the waiting can be long, but it's worth it!!
author: Cynthia D.

description:
First let me start off by letting you all know I'm Chinese and therefore a harder critic of Asian food.

We visited this restaurant half an hour before closing, short wait of 20 mins, but they ran out of the two items I wanted to try big dumpling and the shrimp toast therefore this review is not complete. 

We ordered the xian dumplings, BBQ pork bao steamed, Beijing noodles, and pork dumplings.

The xian dumplings were the best warm and the soup would explode loaded with flavors. We meant to order the BBQ buns fried not steamed and they were Taiwanese style. The noodles were okay fresh but with hot sauce it was good. The pork dumplings lacked flavor.

Overall the restaurant was really cute!! They have indoor and outdoor seating. The staff very attentive and fast!! The average price on the menu is $8 per dish. Can't go wrong!! Can't wait to come back and try the 2 items they sold out of that night.
author: Choi C.

description:
Note: i am a big critic of XLB so if it's your first time having them, you will have a COMPLETELY different experience, guaranteed. I'm a huge fan of XLB so when I saw that Dumpling Time had an XL XLB (extra large or King-Dum as they call it on their menu), I needed to have it. My group of 3 was seated out on the patio within minutes of arriving. There is a window where you can watch the Dumpling masters. We ordered all three varieties of XLB, Beijing Noodles, pork XiAn dumplings, cucumber Fresno salad and the dessert bun trio. Of all the items we ordered, we were only satisfied with the two varieties of normal sized XLB and the dessert bun trio. The large XLB was too big and all the soupy flavor was lost. The noodles lacked a lot of flavor and the type of noodle they chose did not stick to the sauce. The cucumber Fresno salad also lacked flavor as it should have been more vinegary. It felt as though, the cucumber were just dipped in vinegar 15 min prior. The pork Xi'An dumplings were also very disappointing. There was no flavor at all. Now that I've critiqued those dishes, I'll go through the dishes that I enjoyed. The soup in both of the XLB was flavorful (especially the Tom Yum one) and the Dumpling wrapper was light and thin, exactly what they should be!!! The tom yum variety was also very unique which I appreciated. The dessert bun trio was great as we got to try all the varieties shared. The bread part was deliciously sweet and light in texture. The filling was smooth and the perfect amount of sweet. 

If you are a seasoned XLB eater, stick to the XLB only! (And dessert if that tickles your fancy).
author: Angela M.

description:
After multiple recommendations for this place, I finally made it here the other day, it definitely lived up to the hype.

I'm a pretty big fan of dumplings coming from Delhi, where street-sides 'momos' are a common sight and loved by millions.

We came on a weekday, and were seated immediately, The menu cuts right to the chase and there's not much to choose from, which is great because I struggle with fomo a fair bit.

Went for the Xiao Long bao, shrimp cilantro, as well as cream-cheese har gow (was disappointed to find that the shrimp har gow had pork broth, I've had pescatarian friendly shrimp dumplings elsewhere). Also got the veggie dumplings.

The xlb was as good as I hoped for, scalding my mouth with the burning soup (I have no patience when it comes to dumplings).

Both har gows were phenomenal, and we went for seconds. 

The cilantro sauce was especially great, and the food came pretty quick.
author: Siddhartha G.

description:
~tl;dr~ Dumpling Time is a an amazing, fresh take on a classic few dim-sum dishes in the heart of the Design district (though there sadly are no push-carts.)  This is the prettiest dim sum you'll ever eat.

For the full-review, I'll be going over all the dishes (in order) my girlfriend and I ordered on very empty stomachs after a BART ride: 

~ THE FOOD ~

For an appetizer, we ordered the Pickled Lotus, $5 - it's basically a lighter version of a classic lotus dish.  It had more of a vinegar taste and not long marinated, but if you like lotus and that satisfying crunch, it was a really refreshing take and fantastic palate cleanser between later dishes.

The first main item that arrived was the Seafood Gyoza, $9.5 for 5pc.  Holy crap.  This was an instant 10/10, beyond amazing with the paired sauces.  Everything about it tasted amazing, the seafood mixture, sauces, and crispiness of the pan-fried bottom was paired perfectly.  Definitely order this if you like anything seafood related or a texture/flavor bomb.

We later ordered Chicken Gyoza, $7 got 5pc, btw.  It was still great (like a 8/10 relative to the seafood gyoza) but didn't have that euphoric food wars-esque feeling when we ate it.

Moving onto bao's, we got the Char-Siu Bao, $6 for 3pc.  We weren't unanimous on our love for it, but overall it was really good.  The char-siu flavor wasn't super strong or candied tasting, but the peanut butter worked really well actually - it was more like a peanut satay sauce.  The actual dough was super light, fluffy, and mildly sweet with a perfect proportion of filling to bun.  I wish I tried the pan-seared option though, heads up that you can take advantage of that.

Now for the real reason we came here initially: the xiao long bao, specically the KING DUM, $8 for 1 ~massive~ piece.  The King Dum is by far, the prettiest, largest, soupiest xiaolongbao I've ever had.  It was literally a massive XLB, everything else was the same, except it came with a bunch of pretty flowers and stuff on top too.  It definitely had a ton of soup, and the novelty to drink soup out of a boba straw is worth it the first time.  Otherwise, it's clearly not a go-to dish to share with friends or order beyond the initial holyfriggincrapsnapchat factor.

Pork Xiao long bao, $8 for 6pcs.  Now I would get this on a daily basis if I could.  This is just a traditional, perfectly executed rendition of the nostalgic XLB we all crave.  The price is pretty fair imo - for comparison, Berkeley's cheapest is around $6-7 for 6pcs.

Onto dessert, the Happy Endings (lmao).  We ordered the Trio of Buns, $5.50 for 3pcs.  It's pretty much what you would expect.  The egg yolk was definitely the best, had a fantastic rich flavor with that filling.  The green tea and milk was mainly milky tasting, and the beet and taro was essentially a colorful taro bun with minimal flavor.  They were all good and light tasting, but the egg custard bun would be my sole order next time.

~ PRICE, AMBIANCE ~

Grand total was about $35/person after everything, and it was definitely worth it (especially considering SF food prices).  My girlfriend and I were both stuffed with dim-sum beyond the grade of a traditional restaurant.  Even though it didn't have the entertaining push-cart system where you point, over-order, and get a wide plethora of dishes, I still loved the experience.  Dishes came really fast, though you could hear them preparing it fresh in the kitchen after you ordered.

On that note, tips: If you seat near the kitchen, the sizzling is super, super loud.  You have the option of sitting outside, though it could also get some street noise or wind.  Otherwise the restaurant is bright, nicely decorated, and casual.

10/10 would seafood gyoza again
author: Bryan T.

description:
Overall, a very solid 4.

Are there cheaper and better places in the city? Of course. However, the prices are fair considering the location and quality of food.
Now city folks can rejoice in being able to get yummy dumplings without having to venture into Chinatown or Sunset!

Modern, clean interior. Fast-casual sit down restaurant with plenty of seating inside and a semi-outdoor patio outside. A bit cramped and loud. Patrons consist more of the early 20's-30's Instagram crowd and young SOMA residents who live in the immediate area.

Service staff is super nice, fast, and come equipped with excellent recommendations. Props to the server who was able to seat us 5 mins before closing time (2:55 PM!!). We literally had to order right when we sat down and nicely assisted us with recommendations without rushing us completely. Some restaurants are super strict about closing time and don't even seat people 15 minutes before closing, so much appreciated!

SHRIMP TOAST - Nothing special for me, exactly what you would expect based on the pictures (shrimp in the fried Chinese doughnut dough). Yeah, it's good (B/C FRIED!!) but it's not out of the ordinary and I wouldn't recommend ordering it unless it's your first time trying Chinese doughnut!

SEAFOOD GYOZA $9.5 for 5 - My second favorite! The filling was delicious (creamy and sea-foody) but the bottoms could be crispier and more fried.

CHAR SIU BAO $6 for 3 - just OK for me, though if you really love char siu baos and don't often get to have it, this would be a solid option. The dough was fragrant and fluffy and the filling was good.

BEIJING NOODLES $9 - very good but the noodles were just a touch too soft for me. Right amount of filling and spot-on with the sauce.

VEGETARIAN XI AN DUMPLING $8 - MEH. Just meh. Skip.

PORK XLB - My favorite! SUPER juicy and skin was nice and thin!

TOM YUM GOONG XLB - also very good but it tasted nearly identical to the pork XLB and the skin was a bit thicker. Order the regular one.
author: Emily C.

description: Long wait but yummy. King Dum not really appetizing. Too large. But the non beef non pork options that I ate were tasty. Green beans were good.
author: Peter B.

description:
We came here on a happy Sunday evening and got in without too much waiting. It was super warm inside and interestingly decorated. There were some random kpop/jpop music videos playing on the wall. It is called contemporary art.

The shrimp gyoza was definitely my favorite. It came with an aioli sauce that went really well with it, covering all fishy sense. (Aioli is vegan fyi!) I'd recommend. 

The xiao long bao was fine but felt very Americanized in its little tin container. This place is certainly not a dumpling house for one seeking straight-up Chinese dim sum, but a cute hipster fusion #sosf place for when your tummy strikes dumpling o' clock.
author: Juliana P.

description:
Super long wait - not worth it. Some people sit here and chat after they eat. No. Don't do that when there are 15 groups waiting outside. Take that chatter out to any other bar or restaurant.

Anyways, the Pork XLB was not great, the Siu Mai (not on the menu) was good, the Xi An Dumplings had stuff on there that doesn't come with dumplings, like cherry tomatoes, and other weird stuff. Overall, not worth the wait. Go to Din Tai Fung instead!
author: Michael K.

description: More upscale dumpling spot. Limited menu but the food was good. For more dumpling variety, you can go to a spot in the Richmond or Sunset neighborhoods. Good thing was, we didn't have to wait long because we got there early.
author: Lillian B.

description:
This place takes the cake and eats it too.
Better than Din Tai Fung...? I came to DT with the highest expectations, thanks Yelp...but DT definitely delivered. Like DTF, you can view the dumplings and baos being made while you wait outside, which is super cool. There was quite a wait when it just opened but they had a nice system for seating people swiftly. The parking lot is rather small so it may be a good idea to get street parking. DT, like it's name, focuses on dumplings and baos instead of entrees like DTF's vegetable stir fries and what not. The items on the menu may seem novelty (I'm looking at you giant dumpling and tom yum XLB!), but after trying the tom yum XLB, I was incredibly surprised that the food here wasn't just a fad or merely instagrammable and actually crazy tasty! Food price I'd say is ranked just before pricey (on a treat yourself note, maybe not for a college student like me), but is well worth the cost from time to time. Every dish tasted delicious and the sauce following the XLB were incredible! I loved everything we ordered and will be back again. The staff were incredibly friendly and welcoming and the ambience of the restaurant, which is a little dark for my taste, was quite nice. I was in awe of the projector on the wall, showing us Kpop music videos...that is such a creative idea. I usually itch for dessert after a good meal but after being so wow-ed and full from the food at Dumpling Time I was perfectly content without it all the way home. And even slept in a great food coma afterwards...if you've wanted to try it and enjoy dumplings, go to DT and give it a shot.
author: Bonnie T.

description:
King Dum - This is why you heard of this place, this is why you came here. Just as you expect, it's made for social media, instagram, snapchat, etc, but hows it taste? Meh. Lots of broth, but if you wanted it just for the broth, u would have gotten soup. Once you drink the broth out of the boba straw, your wondering how do I eat this thing? My choice was to pull it out of the steamer and put it on the plate that was under it. Put the sauces on it and eat it with the won ton soup spoon. I didnt think chopticks would work well and I didnt have a knife. Not something I should get again thats for sure.

XLB - Pretty good and exactly what you expect. No surprises, just solid XLB

TOM YUM GOONG - This one surprised me. Better than the XLB and the best thing I had here for sure. More flavor and it just stood out.

Shrimp Toast - It got better with every bite. It was a great starter and something I would definately get again.

Cucumber, fresno chili salad - overpriced and not worth it. Fairly bland and the cucumber salad i typically get for $3 at a thai place is way better and larger portion.

CHICKEN BAO  - I didnt care for this. Chicken is never my choice when picking items unless its wings or fried. Chicken just doesnt have much flavor.. Besides the chicken, I didnt care for any of it. It was all fairly bland.

Just a heads up on the King Dums, if you go, go early. I was there around 1230 and it was sold out. Luckily the waiter came back after we ordered and said the kitchen made a couple more. Service was very friendly and helpful. They were a little slow after we got our food and wanted to pay to get out, but the first half was great. It was also fairly busy so I don't blame them for being a little slow towards the end.
author: Davide M.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night, came here 30 minutes before they open buffering time to find parking. We were very lucky to find parking right in front. This place gets packed at 5:10PM. 

Service: All staffs was very friendly and informative. They made sure you are like the food how you like it. 

Food: 

Shrimp Toast -5 STAR:- a MUST TRY, the chinese donut is so crunchy on the outside and so soft and chewy on the inside. A drop of spicy sauce made it a complete perfection.
