XLB (small) - only a 2 star because I definitely had better and not as flavorful. 

XLB (LARGE) - 3 in a half star - Loved the fact that there was so much soup! Very juicy and not mushy at all. 

BBQ Pan Fried Pork Bun; 5 star - a must get! The BBQ pork was very on point. Just enough pork and sauce. The bun itself was very soft and fresh.

Trio Buns: Matcha, Beet & Taro and Egg Yolk bun 3 Star- Matcha milk bun was just OK, didn't have much matcha flavor. I think if the bun had more matcha flavor it would be a 5 star. The beet and taro just tasted like a taro bun and Egg Yolk bun was just OK, soft bun with some custard.
author: Cyndi L.

description: The bbq pork buns and the garlicky green beans they are the best. The line can get pretty long waiting for dinner so I usually go for lunch when there isn't any wait and the dining room is pretty empty. It's the best place near the Design Center for some really good lunch!
author: Erin R.

description:
Food: We ordered the Pork XLB, Tom Yum Goong, King Dum, Shrimp & Pork Siu Mai, Pork Gyoza, & Shrimp Toast.  For the Shanghai dumpings, in general, the skin was a bit too thick for my liking (the top part). Ours didn't have as much broth inside as I would like, it was inconsistent, and the dumpings aren't as flavorful as I'd like it. For the Tom Yum dumpings, it was "meh," I see where you're trying to go with this, but I didn't think it meshed well in my opinion; like nice try, I'll give you that one. BUT, the highlight would be the Shrimp Toast, that was amazing. The toast was crispy and fluffy, and the shrimp was flavorful.  The other 2 items we ordered were average.

Atmosphere: It's your typical-catered-to-Caucasian-restaurant-in-SF. Clean setting.

Verdict: It's a good place to try out.  Would I recommend it to someone? Yes. BUT, with disclaimers. It is one of the better dumpling places in the Bay Area, but compared to the other titans. This place would be at the bottom of the list. Koi Palace Shanghai dumpings, in my opinion, are better (and their Siu Mai, plus you have a plethora of choices.) Also, it doesn't come close to Din Tai Fung. Then there's the pricing, its SF, so its not going to be "cheap." (That's pretty obvious.) But, this pricing is par to Din Tai Fung and at that point, I'd rather go to Din Tai Fung.
author: Kim D.

description: I had high hopes for this place but it just didn't satisfy my tastebuds. I recently have moved back to the Bay Area and I'm so spoiled back home where I have Journey to the dumpling down the street . Dumpling time dumplings are not even that great they are just bleh ! No taste but medium temperature broth and little bit of meat . I did how ever enjoy the King soup dumpling. We also had the shrimp toast which was a complete joke and we had the hard as a rock potstickers. Ever if I'm ever in the mood for dumplings I'll go to Din Tai Fung or Journey to the Dumpling . Or better yet have you tried the soup dumplings at Trader Joe's ??!!!! LOL
author: Monica M.

description: Great spot for delicious dumplings without having to trek to the Richmond or the sunset. Prepare to wait on weekends. Approx 20-30 min wait for 2 people in a Saturday night around 8pm.  But worth it.
author: Christine K.

description: This place is a hidden gem! It looks like an empty hole in the wall when you first see it but then you open the door and it's POPPIN. There were music videos playing on one of the walls; Chinese hip hop to be exact and it was appropriate! The food was really good. I wish they offered more dessert options though. I ordered the King Dumpling and then the trio of steamed buns. All really great. Service was okay
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
I am from out of town, and an avid Chinese-food lover. I spent nearly two years living and working in Taiwan/China, and I'm picky about Chinese food. When this place was recommended by a friend, I knew I had to try.

This place had the best Chinese food I have ever experienced in the USA. The presentation was fantastic, food was hot and fresh, and authentically flavorful. I also loved that they played Mando-Pop Top 100. 

Though some may find wine a strange experience with 水饺，I love it. The waiter came up with an awesome white wine (dry, not sweet) to complement the dish. Super friendly and gracious service too, and not the in-your-face-service you can get a lot of the bay area. 

I would recommend this place to anyone looking for a filling, flavorful Chinese meal. I will definitely be back next time I'm in town.
author: Courtney L.

description: Looks good but tiny serve on all the dishes. Doesn't worth the wait of 40 minutes neither. There are plenty more tasty places in San Francisco.
author: Charlie C.

description:
Food - Overall overrated. I came here with a friend and we both agreed we probably wouldn't be coming back. We ordered...
Shrimp and Cilantro Dumpling - Good, but you can get this at any Dim Sum restaurant. Do you really want to brave the long wait just for Dim Sum you can get anywhere?
King Dum (spelling?) - Difficult to eat, it was tough to suck in any juices through the straw. There was no other way to eat it then break through the skin and by then, most of soup seeped out. More isn't always better. But hey, worth getting for the gram? :P
Red soup dumplings (forgot what it's called) - Good, but nothing spectacular. 
Beijing Noodles - Tasty but too salty and greasy.

Service - Great services, staff was very attentive.

Ambiance - Casual. It's in the middle of nowhere in the Mission, but the ambiance inside is cool. The place is a bit small.

Tip - Arrive 10-15 min early before the restaurant opens if you plan on coming in on the weekend. King Dums are limited and the wait gets long.
author: Diana C.

description:
I almost let the low stars keep me from going to this restaurant, and I'm so glad I didn't! It's cool that you can watch them making the dumplings, and the food is also really good.

The chicken gyoza, steamed pork buns, and egg yolk dessert buns are must haves!

Two things to keep in mind if coming here:

1) We had to wait for a table, around 20-30min, but considering the amount of people, they got us in pretty fast. I would advise coming outside of peak time, this isn't a very big place so not great for large groups.

2) The ginger in the soup dumplings was a little overpowering, but when you pair them with a sauce it balances it out really well.
author: Elena K.

description: All the different types of soup dumplings were what I was looking for and more. Such rich flavors in such small things.  We also got the BBQ pork baos. Again, so much flavor in every bite.
author: Vanessa N.

description:
My go to stop when I'm SF  

The desert buns are my FAVE!

Service is fast and fun! Good place to catch up with friends! Very social environment. There hasn't been a item I haven't liked from this place! 

Highly recommend this place, just expect at least a 30 minute wait time at the least unless you get lucky!
author: Beverly A.

description: This place so awesome almost i dont want to let anybody know so i can have table all the time! Food was clean, tasty and prepared quick! Price was fair and staff was kind. I'll come often!
author: Jiyoung L.

description: We came here for dinner on a Friday night and surprisingly it wasn't overly crowded. We got seated right away and the servers were super fast to check in on us. I have to say... the naming convention of their food is kind of strange... we ordered the pork pot stickers, pork bao, three-sum, pork xl and king dum. Everything tasted amazing and pretty close to what I would eat in China. One thing I really liked was for all the pork fillings they mix it was cabbage, many dumpling places don't do that and it makes the filling kind of hard and dense. By adding in the cabbage (which I do at home also) make the filling more enjoyable and lighter on the stomach. As for the star of our meal, the king dum, I was expecting a full soup dumpling but there's actually meat inside as well! In a way I liked it, knowing I wasn't purely consuming fat, but it also made it kind of hard to drink the soup with the straw. Overall we would definitely come back again and recommend it to friends.
author: Nina Y.

description:
This place has some delicious food!

It's definitely not your traditional dumpling or dim sum restaurant.  It's more of a modern-looking asian-fusion restaurant that serve dim sum, but it is still really good.  Any time I take my friends to try this place for the first time, they always love it.  My favorites are the shrimp toast and the seafood gyoza.  I would recommend this place to everybody - everything on their menu is tasty.
author: Richelle L.

description:
3.5 stars (minus 1 star for the XLB liners , minus .5 for the staff) We got to the restaurant at 10:55am and was the second party in line. We scored parking in one of the few spots directly in front of the door. The restaurant has a nice outdoor patio that's covered. The restaurant  had someone with a clipboard come out at 11:02 to take our names and party size and went back inside. I didn't really see the point of taking down our names and party size if the restaurant wasn't even open?? And there were only 2 parties in line at that moment hahaha. Well, whatever. We were seated once my name was called. I've recently dined at Din Tai Fung, so I'm apologizing in advance because my comparisons seemed to be automatic.

As first timers we ordered
Starters:
-garlicky green beans: garlicky green beans are always a good idea. but they weren't perfectly blanched
-shrimp toast: not sure what they use as the "toast" part but i really enjoyed this item

Small Bites:
-cucumber salad: the cucumbers didn't have any peel and were sliced lengthwise. I prefer the cucumbers not sliced lengthwise and prefer the peel

Har Gow (steamed dumplings):
-shrimp : this has cream cheese but I could barely taste it
-shrimp & cilantro: i'm not big on cilantro and will only eat it when necessary. the combo of shrimp and cilantro with the paired cilantro dipping sauce was complementing

Noodles: 
-beijing noodles: a tad bit bland but my son loves noodles and still loved it

Gyoza (pan crisped dumplings):
-chicken: filled with a lot of meat and the dumpling wrapped itself wasn't so thick. i think it maybe drizzled with a little spice (orange flakes on the picture) just fyi if you have kids. my son grabbed it so fast and licked the flakes and said "spicy" 

XLB (soup dumplings):
-king dum: instagram worthy for $8 
-pork xlb
-tom yum goong: red colored because of the beet wrapper
I LOVE XLB and these actually tasted good. BUT.... what I didn't like at all was that the XLB was lined with an aluminum liner. So actually, the bottom of the dumplings stuck to the liner! This made eating it soooo messy. We tried so many ways to remove the liner and even if you try to peel the liner off first instead of making a hole at the top , pulling the liner can create a hole and the soup spills from the bottom! I like eating XLB by putting it directly into the spoon. Isn't it supposed to be that way?? This was a big no no for me especially since XLB was my favorite and we ordered a lot of it. We got tired of making such a mess we just got over it and took it home. The left over XLB (we took home) didn't stick to the liners I guess because it was cold already.

And why is their plates soo small? It was literally just a little bigger than a teacup saucer but it was square shaped. The green beans barely fit the length of the plate. Fyi soda is served by the can. 

I wish they had chocolate XLB like DTF. That probably would've made me give them another star.

I enjoyed the food here and would dine here again only when they get rid of the aluminum liners for the XLB but I noticed that the staff serving you here aren't as knowledgeable as the staff as DTF. Example, as we were packing our food, we asked the waitress to get "extra of this sauce" (& was holding up the actual sauce to show her) and her response was "Which one is that?" Uhhh. YOU tell me which one that is. It's not even like there was barely any sauce left to tell what it was!

Oh and on this note I have to mention something about the bust boy or whatever their title is -- the ones who just clean up your dirty dishes!! He comes to our table to remove some dishes & I politely ask for napkins. I don't have an accent either. He nods his head and says "Ok." But then the waitress comes over and says "He said you needed something?" Uhh. Why can't he get me the napkin. Or why can't he tell her it is a "napkin"? Later on,  I asked him for "a FORK for my son please". He again nods his head and says "Ok." I was watching him and AGAIN, he tells our waitress to come to our table. With my own eyes I see that he doesn't tell her I need a "fork". That's weird to me. Unless it's a rule that he can't get the table anything and it must be a Waitress to do it??? But I highly doubt it. Maybe he can't understand English.
author: Sarina A.

description:
Good, but not amazing. I wonder why there's a super long line at this place?

We came here on a Wednesday so it was only a 10-15 minute wait. Our server was awkward and not super friendly....
Food is good, but not worth the long wait... The dumplings are made fresh and you can see through the glass window. As for the food, the winners were the pan seared pork belly bun, xiao long baos, and the beijing noodles! The vegetarian dumplings were meh and pretty flavorless. Dessert buns were okay.

Also, I would not recommend driving here. There's a homeless community around the corner and tons of cars get broken into here. I bet one of them stole my bike wheel that was locked up in the area! Grrr.
author: Janet H.

description: Pricey but really good.  The XLB was a little dry.  The service was efficient.  I would come back.  They don't have takeout and the lines are long - I recommend you get there right when dinner starts at 530p.  Plenty of street parking.
author: Chris L.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night at 7pm for dinner. My friend and I waited about 45 minutes for a table for 2. Per usual SF, street parking is the way to go. While waiting, there is a bench for you to sit on and plenty of space for you and your group to stand around. My friend and I talked through a storm and 45 minutes flew by fast. When walking into the restaurant, you can see their dumpling making station to the left (sort of like Din Tai Fung), as like any other SF restaurant, this place is pretty cramped and LOUD. We sat next to the built in "screen" in the corner of the restaurant and it was pretty hard to hear my friend and I speak to each other. Besides that, lets get on with the food.

Food - totally BOMB.com

We got the -
Shrimp Cilantro Har Gow - warning, there isn't any cilantro in the har gow, it is a cilantro sauce on the side. I wouldn't recommend getting this since this is something that I could totally get at another dim sum place, but the cilantro sauce was pretty tasty
Beijing Noodle - this dish has the fresh flour noodles and ground pork, this was very tasty and would high recommend trying (not too salty, just how I like it!)
Seafood Gyoza - this was fun and tasty! the wrapping was green and the white spicy sauce that they had on the side was not too spicy
King Dumpling - totally Instagram worthy pic, however, I would recommend eating this right away, since we waited a while as suggested, but I think it could of tasted better if we ate it right away. they give you a boba straw to drink the soup out of the dumpling first, I would recommend NOT sharing this item and getting your own, it was quite messy to share
Shrimp Toast - MUST GET!!!!! this was SOOO good and has the right amount of crunch/taste and great presentation.

4 stars because it felt like right when we sat down, the server already asked us what we wanted to order.... chill for a second, it wasn't like anyone gave us a menu while we were waiting outside to encourage us to look at so we can be ready to order.... the bill came right when we got all of our food and the server said no rush, but came back at least 3 times after to check on the bill. (shrug) The service was ok, the atmosphere was pretty cramped and loud, however the food is very well worth trying and waiting for!
author: Shelley L.

description:
Ordered five items for three people. Should have ordered more. The portions were not large.

The bottom of seared pork buns was not crispy enough. Felt like they were in a hurry to send the food out so the buns were not pan-fried long enough. 

The plating of the vegetable dumplings was  nice but they just lacked flavours.  The ones at Ding Tai Fung are way more flavourful. 

Pork XLB was good. The skin was thin and they were filled with soup. Chicken gyoza was pretty good too. 

Beijing noodle was ok. I can read Chinese but it was just not what the chinese name suggested. 

All in all, food tasted ok but they were americanized. If you want authentic dim sums, there are better choices in SF.
author: Joyce L.

description: Great atmosphere and dimsum. We came on Sunday around noon and waited for about 30 minutes to be seated. Presentation of every dish is on point. Love the micro green and flower garnishes. Quality of the food is top notch. The only items I wasn't too impressed with was the lobster shui mai. It seemed more like shrimp. Servers were very attentive as well.
author: Leah C.

description: Beet-case dumplings, home made noodles, maine lobster shu mai, allllll sooooo good. Great service, little wait. Go here, now!
author: lasok o.

description:
My boyfriend and I came before a show that was in the area and we LOVE dim sum. It was Monday night around 7. It was a bit crowded but not too bad. 

This isn't your typical dim sum spot where it's super affordable and simply good. These are all well made, flavorful, fresh and delicious. We ordered 4 different types of dumplings and  ended up trying 2 more and took another one to go. I've never spent $80 on dumplings, but I did here and it was worth it. I probably could sit there all day eating dumplings. Our waitress was awesome at recommending different items and being very patient with us during a busy dinner time hour.

I left out a star because our orders did take a long time to come out and the atmosphere is very loud. I could barely hear my boyfriend over the music and loud talking. The crowd seems to be the techie type. Some guy fell out of his chair and into the middle of the aisle because he was so glued to his phone and so was his date. SMH... But we are planning on going back and trying the other dumplings and noodles.
author: T A.

description: Prior to attending the Lane 8 show, we wanted to get some grub and by the line and reviews of this spot, we definitely wanted some dumplings. Luckily, we didn't have to wait long for a seat or our order to be taken. When the food arrived, it looked delicious, but once we bit into it, we quickly became disappointed. We ended up getting the gyoza, pork buns and the seared pork bao. It wasn't horrible tasting, but for the hype, it just didn't do it for us. Sad day to say we left hungry and unimpressed. Overall, if you're into hyped up mediocre dumplings then I guess this is the spot for you.
author: Cristal C.

description:
OVERALL: 
**Expect some wait if you're coming at a "popular" time
**No take-out
**Must try the XLB
**Sitting outside is A-OK cause they have heaters

Not sure about other times, but I came on a Friday evening at prime dinner time, AKA 6:45PM, and the wait outside this place was pretty long - around 45 minutes for 2 people. There aren't really any seats around for people waiting, and most people wait outside, so expect to stand for a bit, and don't leave yet -- the food is worth it and it doesn't take too long for the food to get to you once your seated. 

SERVICE:
We ended up sitting outside, and despite it being a bit windy, it wasn't bad at all since they have 4 (i think) overhead heaters. I was scared that the tables were placed too closely and you could hear each other's conversations, but it actually wasn't, so cheers to that!

Now, onto the delicious BAOSSS: 
**I love that all the dumplings come with their own specialized sauces**
1) Vegetarian Dumpling (2/5) - Of all of food I got, this was the most beautiful dish. Funny story actually - the dumpling wrap is a deep green spinach wrap, and it was topped with all these beautiful vegetables that the spinach wrap camouflaged with it so I thought I ordered a salad ---until I dug in and realized they were dumplings. Most of the filling were chives, and the skin is on the thicker side, but it was appropriate for this dish. However, I'm personally not too big of a fan of chives, and this dish didn't super stand out for me. The halved cherry tomatoes and slices of radish (?) also didn't really add to the flavor of the dish, only the aesthetics. The sauce was a must to improve the taste of a rather blander tasting dumpling. 
2) Chicken Gyoza (5/5) - I loveeee this dish! There wasn't really any extra dumpling skin like you see with most dumplings, and the skin is a bit more glutinous, though not thaat thick. The filling itself had a lot of texture and wholesomeness with the wood ear mushroom (crunch) and the shiitake mushroom and chicken. The sauce also complimented the dumplings very well, though I probably could have eaten it without it. Only thing I would say is that it wasn't that crispy on the exterior, if that's what really matters to you. 
3) Chicken Bao (4/5) - Their baos are very soft, and the filling was delicious, chicken and wood ear mushroom. However, I wouldn't say it's super wow or anything. 
4) Pork XLB (5/5) - Its not easy to find places that make perfect XLB and this place is no exception - I have a bit of a higher standard for XLB. What I loveee about it is that the skin is thin, filled with plenty of delicious soup with a slight note of ginger, and the flavor of the whole thing is delicious. My only drawbacks are 1) most XLB I've had at traditional places aren't cooked in individualized foil trays, which easily causes the thin skin to rip and precious soup to spill out and 2) the meat was a little too soft for my taste - it kind of broke apart in my mouth rather than for me to chew it down - I like my texture! However, these two drawbacks couldn't bring down my impression of these wonderful juicy XLB. 
5) Trio Bun (4/5) - Again, super soft baos and though very delicious, it didn't have a "WOW" factor. The egg custard bun was very similar to what'd you find at dim sum restaurants, the filling being more on the pasty side than the liquidy yolk. The matcha bun had a white filling, with the texture similar to the egg custard bun, but having a great matcha taste. The taro bun was filled with reaaaal taro, mashed to a smoother consistency with a little bit of chunkiness.
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
Delicious food. Quite pricy for such small portions. 


We got the soup dumpling*2(one pork, one beet) and king dum*3, and also steamed short ribs and taro stuff steamed buns. 

Each dish came in small, and expensive.
author: Tom Y.

description: Food was excellent as well as the Black Dot sake. Place is busy with a line out the door. Kind of loud with no barriers to diffuse sound, definitely casual, food and service are worthy of future visits.
author: Joanne B.

description:
I still prefer dim sum and dumplings at the more...'authentic' places. 

Popped in at around 1-2PM before leaving town. It was pretty busy, but we were able to get a table right away. The place itself is very a e s t h e t i c. Think of it as a Tumblr page where all you do is eat over priced dumplings. The presentation of the place as well as the food is setup for your friends who constantly use portrait mode for photos of their food.

And for the food...the food was alright. Honestly, for the amount of money you're spending, for it to be just 'alright' is disappointing, but what are you going to do. The atmosphere was very hipster SF, an annoying trait that is hard to avoid anywhere in the area. Also, the music is very loud.
author: Gabriel R.

description: This place never lets me down. Every dish is solid, but we have a few go-to favorites. Try the pork XLB soup dumplings and the Beijing noodles. And don't forget the sweet dessert buns to cap off your meal!
author: Kyle K.

description:
*** In Short ***

Decent food at indecent prices.

*** In Depth ***

I don't really have too much to say about Dumpling Time other than the SF/hipster tax is real here. While the food itself isn't bad, it's not significantly better than what you can get at other Chinese restaurants around the area. And while I'll admit that the craftsmanship and skill of their dumplings, and particularly the XLB, is better than most of these places, that alone doesn't justify almost double the price (i.e. 6 XLB at Dumpling Time will run you $8, while the same at Kingdom of Dumpling runs you a little under $5) when they otherwise pretty much taste the same.

If you still do insist on trying the place, the dumplings, of course, are their namesake, and what you should try, as their noodles and baos were a little lackluster.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The place is fairly spacious, but crowded, with little room to move between tables, so you'll have to wait for one of the side tables, either towards the front or back door, to clear up.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Probably my favorite pork xlb place in SF!

Husband and I arrived at noon on a Saturday and put our name down on the long waiting list. Most of the tables before us were parties of 2 and the list moved fairly fast. We were seated at 12:45am and were asked what we wanted to order fairly quickly. Left the restaurant at 1:55pm, but could have left at 1:45pm if it wasn't for waiting for the bill. 

FOOD
Wanted to order the super big xlb (that you drink with straw) but they ran out already!! Darn.
-Celery, yuba, peanut salad $5- fresh ingredients and good flavor. Only wished there was more
Shrimp toast $8- most yelpers like and recommend this one. I thought it was good, but I was not wowed.
-Tom yum goong xlb 6 pc/$9- cool reddish colored xlb. Skin was thin (some parts too thin and it broke!), juicy. Doesn't taste like Tom yum that much, was still worth it to try 
-Pork xlb 6 pc/$9- super juicy and the pork had good flavor, not mushy like other places!! Skin is thin and didn't break as much as Tom yum one. Delicious and the favorite item I had here
-Seafood gyoza 5pc/$9.5- wow super 'crunchy' but not very flavorful. Reminds me of 'ha gao (shrimp dumpling)' but less flavor. That's why it came with two different sauces, a spicy soy sauce-ish and a butter mayo-ish dipping sauce. 
-Trio of buns- one of each type of dessert bun: beet/taro, green tea/milk, egg/milk 3 pc/$5.5- better than I expected. At first I thought it tasted raw, but maybe it's just the flour taste. The texture is super fluffy and soft. Not too sweet. Good to share.

SERVICE
Service was alright. Most staff are young. We were seated quickly, had to share a table for four with another couple, but that was fine. Waiter came by to take order very fast, even before we were ready. No mistakes with our orders, but there was a long wait until we got our last dish- seafood gyoza. They bring whichever item is ready (regardless of savory or dessert item). Bus boys seem to not have very steady or quick hands. Husband accidentally spilled water on the table and nobody wiped it up for us. So even though the decor is super cute, this place is a spot that's super casual and quick where they try to quickly get as many people in and out. However, it took a while to get our bill and even longer for the waiter to come back to get our credit card. The table next to us saw that it was taking a while so he gave his credit card to the waiter when the waiter picked up our bill and credit card. When about to sign, husband saw that the credit card was not his... it was the other table's. So we gave it to them. When husband got his card, we realized we had the other table's bill. So they charged the card on the wrong bill. It was a $10 difference so I gave the other table a $10 bill. Aiyaaaaa...

DECOR/AMBIANCE
Not a huge space but brightly lit and comfortable. Larger communal tables in the center. There is a waiting area outside with heaters where you could wait outside and a window from where you can see xlb being made by hand. Noise level is fairly loud but not uncomfortable. 

Overall, I enjoyed the food, especially the pork xlb and would come back to try other items like the savory buns, noodles, and the super large xlb. Not recommended for big parties, 4 is max in my opinion. Service could be better, but perhaps that will come with time. Just have the mindset that this is a quick in and out Chinese restaurant and you won't be disappointed. :D
author: Iris H.

description:
So this is definitely more like an asian fusion place instead of Cantonese dim sum place. Went there on Saturday night around 7:00, and waited for like 30mins which is not too bad. Food rate(based on personal preference):
- Beijing Noodles: 4/5
- Gan Ban Noodles: 3/5
- Chicken Gyoza: 4/5
- Pork Gyoza: 3/5
- Chia Siu Bao: 4.5/5 (very authentic)
- Pork Xiaowei Long Bao: 3.5/5 (XLB is authentic, but the sauce is very fusion style...)
- Egg Yolk Bun: 3.5/5 (good, but the egg yolk inside didn't flow out)
author: Yuliana Z.

description:
Very, very overrated. 

To start, this place is always packed so be prepared to wait at least 30 minutes in line. I waited 1.5 hour and that was no not worth it.

The food was mediocre at best and pricey for dumplings. The dumpling skin was overcooked (over-steamed) so when I picked them up with chopsticks, the skin broke and the meat slipped out. Flavor wise, it was meh... nothing special. You can easily find something similar in the frozen section of 99 Ranch. 

One annoying thing is the vinegar. Who uses red vinegar for XLB? That's insulting to me was a Taiwanese / Shanghainese (i.e. Inventors of XLB + Din Tai Fung). 

The King Dum was the only thing I thought was good (but not great). The presentation is beautiful - In other words, "Instagram material." The soup and meat was flavorful enough but nothing special. 

Service was great though!
author: Betty T.

description:
Busy place. Expect to wait. We were a party of two and waited about 20 minutes on a Thursday night. 

Love the fact you can see them making the dumplings from scratch. Their food/dumplings are generally authentic but with a slight twist. Like their har gow (shrimp dumplings) are made with cream cheese. I know, I know. Seafood with cheese is a no no but trust me, it works. 

The other twist that I like here is that most dumpling dishes comes with a sauce. No, not your typical soy or vinegar but an actual sauce that they have to make and not just pour from a bottle. 

XLB has great flavor but the skin is a bit thick for my taste. 

Seafood gyoza is another dish that stands out for me.

Their Xi'an dumplings were very pretty (edible flowers) but underwhelmed compared to the other dumpling dishes.

Service is much better than what you would find at a typical Chinese restaurant but you are also paying more here. 

There are a few parking spots right in front but street parking isn't bad in this area either. 

Hope they expand their menu a little more but a great start!
author: Andy W.

description:
I think I should preface this review by saying that I'm probably not their target audience. I grew up eating my grandma's homemade dumplings every weekend, and my mom makes the best Beijing style noodles in the world. So I'm already pretty biased.

But Dumpling Time is right across the street from my apartment, so I had to try it. They really crammed the tables in here - my waitress had to ask me to scoot my chair in multiple times and we moved our table at a certain point so another waiter could get by. The wait wasn't too bad, but there was definitely a line as it got later into the night. There's one lone dumpling maker in the Din Tai Fung style glass room.

The good:
Their pork XLB had really good flavor. Their skins were a little too thin, and the waiters should really let people know how to eat them. There were a lot of confused people around me. But the XLB weren't too oily or greasy. Solid B+!

Garlic string beans were really tasty as well.

Pork gyoza weren't traditional, but the filling was tangy and flavorful.

The mediocre:
The giant XLB is definitely Instagram worthy, but the flavor was really bland.

The pork dumplings looked beautiful, but tasted very sweet. We didn't even finish them.

The Beijing noodles - where is the soybean paste? I just got a pile of noodles and ground pork. The paste is what makes them distinct!

For San Francisco standards, Dumpling Time isn't very expensive, but for dumplings themselves, they were very overpriced. I would say that if you didn't grow up eating traditional dumplings, you'll enjoy Dumpling Time. If you were like me, the XLB are worth a try, but don't expect your grandma's cooking!
author: Christina S.

description:
Service: 2/5

Food: 3/5

Pork xlb: 4/5

Tom yum xlb: 3/5

BBQ pan fried bun: 3/5

Beijing noodles: 3/5

Shrimp paste: 3/5

Green tea/ taro/ custard buns: 4/5
author: Kate W.

description:
Delicious food, quick service, and good atmosphere. New go-to spot for dim sum. Shrimp toast, shrimp & cilantro har gow, seafood gyoza and tom yum xiao long bao were my favs. Also tried Bejing noodles and pork bao but didn't find anything spectacular about either one. For tea, the green tea was 
mediocre, but the Da Hong Oolong tea was rich and delicious and lasts more than one brew.
author: Michelle K.

description: It was good but I felt like there was way too much hype. My favorite was the seafood gyoza. Great flavor and came with two different sauces. Definitely worth a try.
author: Christian N.

description:
As good as the hype and totally worth the wait!!!

We came here on a Sunday evening at about 730pm and waited about 30 minutes for a table (even though we were told the wait was 20 minutes when we got there) which we split with another couple. All of that was totally fine and worth it because the dumplings were great and so cheap. All of the buns were fresh, very flavorful, and clearly made with high quality ingredients. We had the pork soup buns, the seafood gyoza (each one was filled with tons of huge shrimp and scallops), the chicken bao, and the pork dumplings. We could not pick which was our favorite and we were stuffed at the end of it all.

I will absolutely come back here often to try more of the menu (including the giant soup bun, the noodles, and the desserts)!
author: Jeffrey S.

description: After much hype from our friends, my girlfriend and I stopped by yesterday for brunch after a workout class in the area. We were quite lucky--we waited in line for a total of fewer than 15 minutes and were quickly seated. I have the say, the price point is quite high for dumplings (think ~$10 for 8 xiao long baos, or 6 dumplings), but the presentation is pretty nice. Expect to spend around $30 per person if you're eating 'dim sum-like amounts'. Overall, I would come back here if I'm in the area, but this is probably not an establishment that I would seek out.
author: Nancy W.

description:
Service-5 super busy especially lunch and dinner time, service was good! Friendly and fast!
Food- 5! You get to try different dumplings. Beijing noodles, soup dumplings and dessert dumplings ( green tea and milk buns were so good!).
author: S H.

description:
Dumpling Time is absolutely one of my favorite places to eat in San Francisco. Tucked away behind Adobe and Zynga this modern Asian restaurant serves incredible food at reasonable price in a trendy (yet cramped) restaurant space.

Expect a short wait (even on weekdays) and try the pork belly baos. You won't regret it!
author: Michael M.

description: First time and won't be the last!  Yank Sing now has a very legitimate competitor for dumplings. And DT has no carts constantly circling, which creates a much calmer environment to enjoy excellent food!  Save room for the dessert buns.  Worth the (short) wait in line!
author: Ronaldo R.

description:
Stumbled upon this location by accident.  

Expect to wait. The lines just to get a table is about 20-30 min. Staff is friendly and quick. 

Keep in mind, since we arrive during the last opening hrs most of the items were all sold out. 

Gan Ban Noddles - bland, needed a bit more seasoning 
Pork Bao - 
King - Dum SOLD OUT :( 
Pork dumplings - 
Shrimp and cilantro har gow - if you are a cilantro lover you will enjoy this dish
author: Francisco A.

description:
First we heard this place was super yummy and 4 stars ...( don't know how they get that 4 stars ???)  so we decided to give it a try today. However we were very disappointed with their bad service, they don't even know how to put on a smile... we just sit down only 10min and the guy brought us the list foods that we order and prices, and they start cleaning dishes while we were eating ...so rude... like they want to rush us out. Never had this bad experiences before.
The foods: nothing special, just regular buns ....The differences are only the colorful decorations buns. 
Not coming back dued to bad services... not worth my time at all. See yaaaaa !!!
Funny: a Chinese restaurant but all waiters are Caucasian and they're really; I mean really look mad when serve you... 
I am not racist but seem like these waiters had no experiences at all or a welcome smile. Poor knowledge services. Definitely Not recommend anyone. Come on I don't need my day to be ruin by these poor waiters. Still gave them $5 tip... since bill was $60.. put on a smile guys..geezzz
author: Johnny T.

description:
King-Dum: The King Dum was more fun to take pictures of and poke than to taste an expected extraordinary flavor. The taste was about average. 

Tom Yum Goong XLB: I enjoyed the small portions of the Tom Yum Goong more than the large XLB. 

Both very appealing to the eyes. 

The Trio Dessert Buns were eh, nothing amazing to pay $5.50 for 3 Buns.
author: Megan L.

description: Food is good. The skin of the dumplings are a little too thick. Also I asked them to charge my phone since I saw they have an iPad being charged. But they refused.
author: Jorge G.

description:
I'm a fan! Ordered 8 items for a group of four and we were set. Service was quick, attentive, and very welcoming. Some standout orders to me were the xlb, seafood gyoza, and chasiu baos (gotta get it pan fried!) 
The wait builds up quick! We got there exactly at 5:30 and the restaurant was already busy so plan to get here ahead of time!
author: Brandon L.

description: Little underwhelming. I love dim sum and I love XLB  soup dumplings. We ordered the shrimp toast, pork gyoza, har gow, pork belly buns, tom yum goong and XLB. For dessert we ordered the trio of buns. The shrimp toast was too oily, the har gow was doughy but okay. The gyoza was nice but wished it was a seared a little more. The pork belly buns were good. To be honest the soup dumplings were only okay. There are plenty of places in the city that you can get great XLB (soup dumplings) from. Maybe this place was a little to hyped up for me. The best part of the meal were the dessert buns by far.
author: Chinh L.

description:
As a vegetarian / vegan, this is not the best place for you. But I'm going to give this place a 4 star because I probably had the best tofu I've had in my life here (and I have had a LOT of tofu in my life). The crispy sesame tofu squares melt in your mouth and although fried on the outside were so light. I would come here just for that. 

However, the waiter did a great job making a full meal for me by bringing me plain steamed noodles and I was able to mix that with the chili sauce, veggies (auteed and gingered snap peas and garlicky green beans), and tofu to make it an overall great meal. 

 Overall, recommend to everyone! Beware, this place does not take reservations and the wait can get pretty long!
author: Nidhi M.

description:
Yessss! The dumpling spot to answer all calls for dumplings. Given the location and ambiance, the prices are great. It's a clean and modern package for what is still mostly traditional dumplings, with welcome variations here and there. I love the neon signs and DTF-style dumpling prep station. 

SHRIMP TOAST starter $8
I was skeptical but this was indeed a must. It's one you tiao, with steamed minced shrimp (shrimp paste), cut into bite sized pieces and topped w habanero aioli.  

SEAFOOD GYOZA  5pc/$9.5
Spinach skin, crab, scallop, shrimp, spiced chili butter sauce
I liked this but because everything else was so good, this didn't really stand out. I like the spiced chili butter but still preferred the vinegar. 

BEIJING NOODLES $9
Pork, green onion, ginger, soybean paste
This is good, I liked the chewiness of the noodles.

PORK XLB  6pc/$8
Pork belly, savory soup, shao-sing wine
I can't think of a place on SF with better XLB. 

HAPPY ENDINGS
Trio of buns 3pc/$5.50:
Green tea & milk bun
Beet & taro bun
Egg yolk bun
I feel like you can skip this. But the only steamed sweet bun I normally like is liu sha bao.
author: Erika C.

description:
Probably the most memorable thing was the most surprising: the green beans. They were amazing. I've never had green beans that tasted like that. 

The King dumpling was a bit of a letdown, honestly. I'd order other things next time we visit. 

It's busy, and noisy, and not the cheapest, but everything tasted great and the service was good. Would go back.
author: Sam Z.

description:
Definitely a place I would recommend for some basic essential Dim Sim. Would say it's not a place recommended to go if you are looking for a full selection, but for what they do they do it well. Looks like they don't do reservation only waiting list the list outside the place so be prepared to wait. 

From the fact that they do fresh dough to wrap the dumplings to the fact the it tastes so fresh you are in for a delight.

Tips:
1. Tom Yum Soup Dumplings - They come in a nice reddish color to the outer layer of the dumpling which has a nice sauce to complement the pork inside
2. Shrimp and Chive Shu Mai - Jam packed is some juicy decent sized shrimp with some hints of chive to make it all have a nice decadent goodness
3. Egg Yolk Bun - So fluffy and the egg tastes amazing. A great way to finish off your meal with a nice treat
4. Tea - Not as strong and steeped with a tea bag it is a good way to cleanse while you are having your meal
author: Frank O.

description:
Our Saturday lunch at Dumpling Time blew us away. The service was so, so, so friendly (despite us having a very large group that included children), and the food was incredible.

Favorites:
Pork XLB
Tom Yum Goong (we were super skeptical, but everyone ended up loving these!)
Shrimp toast
Pork gyoza
Garlicky green beans
Cucumber, fresno chili salad
Xi'an dumplings

We also tried the Beijing noodles, but surprisingly everyone thought it was the weak link of the meal. The bao that we tried was also amazing -- I just loved the other items the most.

We'll be back!
author: K. D.

description:
Since this place is relatively new, it seems they still have a few kinks to fix with their management/service. Being fresh, hip, and new they had a line to the corner of the block on Saturday, but upon entering the place to use the restroom I noticed 3 clean tables were open with about 8 seats available. They also have four bar seats open but weren't seating folks there, super strange :/ I'm sure they will figure this out soon... but you may want to wait to try this place

Our server was friendly but had to let us down easy when explaining how a bunch of menu items were unavailable for lunch on Saturday (shed a few tears hearing I couldn't try the pink XLBs)

Seafood Gyoza - filling is similar to ha gow, densely packed with shrimp, except the wrapper is spinach and like a gyoza thickness. 

XL char siu bao - yummy! intrigued that they use Peanut Butter in the filling, i think it makes it a little creamier + sweeter.

Xiao Long Bao - probably my favorite of the dumplings!! ginger flavors come through and it's super juicy. Instead of serving on a bed of lettuce they serve them in individual tinfoil cups so even if you have some breakage, you don't lose the soup yippee

Vegetarian Xi'an Dumpling - this was v pretty! it came with radishes and edible flower pieces, arranged like a high-end restaurant dish. the chili oil on the side made the dumplings more palatable, alone they would have been a little bland. 

Chicken Bao - the mushrooms in this were a little overpowering for me, would pass but highly recommend getting the baos 'fried' to add a little texture
author: Hana S.

description: This place was OK not worth the long wait. It's not the best I've had. The shrimp toast was probably the only thing that tasted OK. The XLB was very average to me, the soup was lacking something. The King Dum was a bit doughy and not much soup. The Green Tea Milk Bun was nothing special, it was more on the bitter side. The worst would be the Gan Ban noodles, it was lacking in flavor and was really bland.
author: Susan K.

description: 4 stars for the food, however 3 stars for the environment. Too noisy and small. You could barely hear what your friend is talking. Not a place for a nice chat with friends.
author: Yunzhu C.

description:
Good vibes.
Friendly customer service. 
Cool Kpop music, esp. GD. 
Pretty/decorative dumplings. 
Fusion taste. 
Good table setting. 
Bit over-priced. 
Clean restrooms.
author: Youngree K.

description:
Yum! Came here on a Sunday around noon time and we were seated immediately. A line started forming after our party but the wait isn't too bad because the service is super quick and people were seated within 20 minutes of waiting. Parking is really limited in front of the store but there are more parking options around the corner in the more industrialized areas. Items are made to order so it is guaranteed fresh! We ordered the xlb, tom yum goong, seafood gyoza, king dum, and the seared bbq pork bao. The seafood gyoza was everyone's favorite with huge fresh shrimp pieces inside. The tom yum goong was my second favorite with a unique thai soup flavor. The seared bbq pork bao was alright and the peanut butter inside has a very mild taste that isn't too overpowering but rather compliments the bao. The xlb and king dum were okay; I wouldn't drive all the way back here for it and I mainly purchased the king dum for its novelty factor. 
Overall, it was a nice cute place to try out something new! (I would recommend double ordering for bigger parties or you might not be full when leaving)
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Dear Dumpling Time,

It is with a severely full belly I write to you today to inform you that you are, simply put, the best damn dumpling house this side of the bay. 
Seriously the most superb and soupiest xiao long bao I've had the pleasure of eating (over 15 of...) 
Your King Dum is the aptly named, lord and sovereign of dumplings. It's majesty is something to hold - with two hands. The choice to equip me with a straw was a wise one. 
The BBQ pork buns were so fluffy and juicy they blew my mind; but what truly made my jaw hit the floor was the size of your EXTRA BIG BUNS. My goodness. The crispy option for these guys really brought them home. 
To my rapidly expanding belly. 
While the journey was long, the trip ended with dessert, naturally. Crushed your coconut cream gooey bao. Wow. 

Thank you thank you thank you. 
It's such a joy to know I don't have to travel out to the sunset to curb my cravings for dumplings anymore! 
I'm looking forward to many, many more encounters.  

Best wishes,
The dude so full he almost fell asleep on the table and drooled bao juice.
author: Josh H.

description:
I looove dim sum and am not too picky about it, so this place was solid!

I came on a Saturday morning with a friend, right around 11:15am (they open at 11). By that time, we could add our names to a decent spot on the wait-list, but we hadn't made the cut for the first seating, so we had some time to kill. (We just walked to the nearest Philz to grab coffee and then came back.) I'd recommend coming around 10:45 or so, before they open, so you're seated in the first round!

We got the garlic green beans (YUM, a favorite), chicken bao, gan ban noodles (just OK), shrimp and cilantro har gow, and pork xlb, and then the trio of buns for dessert. Definitely enough food for the 2 of us, and super fast service.
author: Katie K.

description:
Perfect XLBs. Small parking lot with ~4 parking spaces in front.

Pork XLB - these come in tin holders for a reason. Pleased and surprised to find each dumpling was filled 1.5 spoonfuls of soup! Soup has great flavor.

Tom Yum XLB - tasted like a heftier, meatier, less soupy version of the traditional pork XLB. Was yummy, def for the meat lovers, not for someone looking for traditional Tom Yum flavor.

BBQ Pork Bun - perfect fluffy sweet with substantially sized chunks of pork 

Dessert Trio - beet, matcha, and regular buns with taro, milk, and egg yolk custard filling respectively. Tastes exactly how you'd expect!

Will be back for the giant $8 XLB that needs to be eaten with a straw
author: Susan C.

description: Excellent lobster siu mai. While the xlb was decent, I've had much better. The wagyu gyoza was meh... I wouldn't order that again.
author: Jen H.

description: I was excited to make a trip to dumpling time because people wouldn't stop raving about it but my friend and I were not thrilled with our experience. To start, we had the shrimp toast and this was honestly the best dish we had here -- the donut bread and shrimp in one bite was a satisfying combo. Next we ordered the vegetarian dumplings and the lobster dumplings. Both were pretty tasteless, and the lobster dumpling had barely any lobster in it. Without sauce, it felt like we were chewing just simply flavorless cooked dough. The presentation was nice, the prices were okay, and the environment was cool because of the group seating style. The service was not personable, they just dropped dishes off each time, but I liked that everything wasn't brought out all at the same time. Overall I would like to give this place another shot but other than the toast,  it wasn't memorable.
author: Mina D.

description:
I give this place 4.5 stars, le bf would give this place 5 stars, and when asked why, he said price.

Le bf and I came on a weekday night around 6:15pm. We came early because we read that if you came later, lots of things would be sold out, and you could tell that some people weren't very happy about it on Yelp. As we walked in, most of the tables were already filled, but luckily, there was a table for 2 by the window and we were quickly seated there. Having studied Yelp and the menu, we knew exactly what to get. At 6:15, we managed to order everything we wanted, and nothing at that time was sold out. 

We got:
1. Garlicky Green Beans ($8)
2. Shrimp Toast ($8)
3. Pork Gyoza ($7.50)
4. Char-Siu Bao ($6)
5. Shrimp Har Gow ($6)
6. Shrimp & Cilantro Har Gow ($6)
7. Pork XLB ($8)

As of 5/31, they still didn't have their alcohol license. You can purchase tea or soda at this time. 

Definitely get the garlic green beans. They were super garlic-y and cooked well. It was the first dish to arrive and we polished it off completely before our other items arrived. The shrimp toast was essentially shrimp on top of a chinese doughnut served with a spicy mayo sauce. It was good, but I don't think I will order it again. The pork gyoza was the biggest disappointment of the night. There was nothing special about it and the sauce it came with was extremely salty. You will regret ordering it. I don't really like char-siu baos, but lef bf wanted it. He said it was really, really good. He is a bbq pork bun connoisseur. The shrimp har gow would make my ancestors roll in their graves as it had cream cheese in it. It tasted good, and I really like how there were large chunks of shrimp in it. I also really liked the shrimp and cilantro ones. The sauce it came with was quite good, but at the end of the day, I still like it served with the dim sum red vinegar (which you can request). The pork XLB were better than I expected. For the price, and the amount of soup and flavor you get, we will definitely be back for these. Le bf liked these better than Din Tai Fung. He said that he could go to Dumpling Time versus having to drive all the way down to the South Bay for Din Tai Fung. 

Pro tip: Ask to keep the lid for the XLB steamer box. That way, you can keep your XLB nice and warm and you aren't in this huge rush to eat them before they get cold. Cold XLB = a no no. 

From the point we ordered to the point we asked for the check, we ate a full meal in under 35 minutes. WOW! And this isn't even considered fast food. For how full we were (we did take some shrimp toast home as well as one of the char-siu bao), the price was really good. Service was really good and the food came out fast! We will definitely be back. I really do recommend this place. Just make sure to come early to ensure that you get to try everything you want.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Dumpling time is my fav dumpling spot in SF. (For now) fresh dumplings hand made by dude in the window. It can't get any better than that....

NO reservations and first come first serve. I heard they sell out sometimes too because everything is made the day of. Come early and be prepared to wait... but trust, the wait is worth it. 

King-dump.. super sized XLB with a boba straw. Bomb!!! One can be shared among 2 people or one greedy person. 

Green seafood gyozas!! A must try... it comes with a sauce that transforms it into a prize for your mouth. 

There are some draw backs but not enough to take it down a star.... no alcohol (yet) they are working on their liquor license. Long waits and restrooms were not finished (had to use the one upstairs). It's a new spot sooooo I am sure they will finish them soon. 

You know what time it is...... dumpling time!!!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Food 10/10
Service 10/10
Space 9/10
Price point 10/10

Look for the freshly made food and stellar friendly service and fair prices this place deserves a 10/10. They ran out of some beers pretty quickly but that just means turnover is high. 

Favorites were crispy pork bao (def get crispy, adds some sweetness) and shrimp/cilantro steamed dumplings which were juicy salty and hot. 

Left very happy. Will def return.
author: Danbi L.

description:
Pretentious, no hostess or host.  Has the feel of a factory rather than a restaurant.  Went in on a not so busy Friday night -- not a good sign.  Saw there was no one on the list, so waited in the front entryway for who I thought was the host who was helping two other guests.  As I was waiting I observed quite a bit of food just sitting around--either waiting to be taken to tables or to-go orders.  The whole atmosphere I would describe as factory-like.

Host nor the servers walking by never acknowledged that there was anyone waiting.  The host then finished with the customers in front of me and instead of acknowledging that I was waiting in line the whole time -- instead went outside to the clipboard which passed by as I saw it was empty at the time and seated the person behind me in line.  Unreal, never had a host or hostess have such total lack of awareness and disregard for a customer before.

Decided to leave and went to go get Korean BBQ at Han Il Kwan and had a fantastic meal, so guess it all worked out in the end.
author: Matt B.

description:
We'd driven by Dumpling Time for the past month and finally had time to make plans to check it out. It's a really cool space, partly made up by a giant tent with space heaters. Which works in San Francisco.

They have beer and Saki in addition to a huge dumpling menu, which was fascinating to me because I'd never tried this style restaurant before.

The menu is heavy on pork, which I don't eat, but I did have seafood gyoza and chicken and mushroom dumplings that were piping hot and flavorful. My dinner companions had soup dumpling and a Beijing noodle dish which they raved about!

We ate until we were stuffed and went home in a happy food coma. It was wonderful and we'll be back.
author: Rachel L.

description:
First off, the food is on point.  Delicious and flavorful for the most part.  We almost ordered 3/4 of the items on the menu.  They did tell us they were out of a few things prior to ordering as they ran out during lunch.  Everything is fresh is why they run out. 

My friends got there at 4:15pm and were told they will not open at 5pm,  but 6pm.  They needed more time prepping, etc.   We get seated at 6pm and they were out of a few things and when we left alittle after 7pm, they were not accepting any more names as they will run out of food.  I just think they still have to work out the kinks to this place and maybe didn't project how busy they were going to be.  Give it a month or two for them to work it out as the food would be worth it.
author: James L.

description:
Been wanting to try this place for sometime. Finally gave it a go last night. They don't take ressies and there's always a wait. We didn't have to wait too long, 20 mins or so... possibly due to the rain. 

The staff were nice but our last dish took a long time to come. We also waited a long time for the to go boxes and check. So long so that we had to wave down another server to again ask for boxes and the check. 

We ordered 9 dishes. Overall, most of the dishes were pretty bland. We ordered: 

Garlicky green beans: bland oil flavored 

Seafood gyoza: tasty. We liked this one most. 

Char-Sui boa: nothing to rave about. 3/$6.50. Go to Chinatown, much cheaper and tastes better. 

Maine lobster: bland and mushy 

Shrimp toast: good 

Shrimp har gow: ok. The sauce that came w this also BLAND! 

Xi'an Pork dumpling: do not order! 

Pork XLB: bland

Tom yum goong XLB: also..... BLAND!

The hot chili oil on table is also bland!!! No spiciness to it at all! Looks spicy but not at all spicy! Lol. 

Needless to we were very disappointed. This place is over-rated. I'm glad I got a chance to try this place, but won't be coming back. 

Over-price dim sum.
author: Pampam W.

description:
A super hip and trendy new dumpling spot! 
We had the char siu bao, the shrimp hargao, the tom yum goong xiao long bao, and pork dumplings.  Omg every dish was flavorful and spot on.  The creativity of adding tom yum soup to the xiao long bao is commendable! The trio buns (red bean, egg custard, green tea) is a good way to sample their dessert.  Really enjoyed the casual yet trendy atmosphere and the outdoor seating is a total plus....
Pat (from Bangkok) was our server - he was super attentive and hilarious. He made our dumpling experience even more fun!!!
author: Bhavnak K.

description: Lots of different types of dumplings. My favourite is the xiao long bao and the bao trio. Absolutely delicious.
author: Lesley Y.

description: wow they possibly have the best egg custard bao in the bay!!  Especially the matcha green tea egg custard bao!  Anyways came here for dinner on Friday a little before 7pm and only waited for 5 minutes.  We ordered the shrimp toast, regular pork xlb, tom yum xlb, seafood gyoza, and three sum dessert bao.  Everything was so good!  The food came over fairly quick and it was hot and fresh.  Shrimp toast was super bomb, freshly made chinese donut with pieces of shrimp on top and the right amount of sauce.  Pork xlb was good and better than most places.  The tom yum xlb was also super bomb and must get!  seafood gyoza was also good stuffed with spinach and a good amount of meat.  And finally the three sum dessert bao: the red one consist of the beet and taro (so-so), the white one consist of egg yolk (bomb!!!) and the green one which was my favorite was made of matcha with egg custard (super bomb!!!!!)
author: Len L.

description: It's a bit of a novelty dim sum experience.  I was excited to order the king dumpling and try the Tom yum soup dumpling (which were great dishes) but at the end of the day, it just doesn't compare to an authentic dim sum restaurant in the Sunset district.
author: Colleen L.

description:
My party of 3 waited about 15 minutes for a table when we arrived at 7pm, no biggie. The ambiance was super hip with both outdoor and indoor seating (outdoor had heat lamps). They also make the dumplings behind a glass window that customers could see which was pretty cool.

An order was around $5-$9. I came for photos for my insta, unfortunately dinner time wasn't the time to go since the restaurant did not provide the lighting needed for a nice photo..

We ordered (Best to worst):
- Shrimp toast - Chinese donut with shrimp and spicy mayo sauce
- Char-siu bao - Came in orders of 3. Very soft, hint of sweetness, and the pork had just enough chewiness.
- Three-sum - Combination of the 3 dessert baos. Sweet but not overwhelming. Fresh and soft. We really enjoyed trying these.
- Shrimp & pork siu mai - I don't even like siu mai but I enjoyed these!
- Pork XLB - There were well made with a lot of soup inside them. I found the tin foils made it hard to eat the dumpling. While removing the foil the dumpling kept popping open and soup spilled everywhere..
- King dum - The straw is a little unnecessary imo. There was juice but not so much you need a boba straw for. Was difficult to eat.
- Pork dumpling - The order came in a bowl with some colorful veggies. The dumplings could use more flavor.

This may seem like a lot but the portions were quite small. My friends and I felt we could have gone elsewhere for a more filling dinner. I think this place is a should try since they have unique items on their menu, but for someone who grew up eating dim sum food, I don't think this will be my go-to place.
author: Sarah T.

description:
The wait was a bit long even though I saw some open tables and I received a dirty cup for water, but we left the place after eating full and happy. 

Husband and I ordered hargow, Beijing noodles, seared chicken bao, green beans, and shrimp toast. Total came out to be $41.07 without tip. Portions were decently sized. 

***The Beijing noodles and shrimp toast are must tries here.***  Beijing noodles are packed with flavor and shrimp toast wasn't as oily and greasy as I thought it would be. Shrimp toast here is like a savory donut. Crunchy, soft, sweet and salty all at the same time.
author: Jenn H.

description:
While I still prefer the dimsum in inner richmond, the food here was still good. There are many types of dumplings to choose from but I recommend the seafood gyoza (sooo good) and the xiao long baos. S

Sadly, I was not a fan of the pork baos, particularly since the dumpling is very starchy and heavy, but I did enjoy some of the dessert ones.

The tea selection is large and pairs well with the savory and sweet food. This is a great place to come with a large group.
author: Rishika S.

description:
I have to say, I had high hopes for the place bc of how hipster it looked, but I wasn't that impressed. The dumplings were just average. They were presented nicely (hipster Asian fusiony) but they just didn't taste as good as the more basic Chinese restaurants in sf. The restaurant was hip and new, and I overall enjoyed the setting and service. If you're looking for legit authentic dumplings though, I'd recommend going to another dumpling place (dumpling kitchen in taraval is amaaaaazing!).

The baos were just aiight. We got them panfried but they still seemed pretty doughy/fluffy (I was expecting something like shen jian bao but they weren't quite like that). The BBQ pork was pretty good (but I have to say, I just had the baked BBQ pork buns at Dragon Beaux and nothing compares to those!). Chicken/mushroom were fine too.

I found the xi'an dumplings kinda strange. They were presented with this super fancy/new American-esque fresh salad and cherry tomatoes but the dumplings themselves were still warm and tasted pretty similar to the gyoza meat we had so I wasn't really sure why it was presented in a salad. Not bad at all, just a little odd, lol.

Dessert buns (we got the trio) weren't that great, I'd pass. Usually lava buns are oozing with super soft almost liquid egg yolk but these weren't oozy at all! Flavor was okay but not as rich and luscious as the ones I'm used to (omg they are so amazing at dragon beaux - sorry I keep comparing the food to dragon beaux but it's hard because I was just there :p). I wasn't a fan of the green tea or beet dessert baos either. The bao dough just seemed super thick and overpowering!

Unfortunately we didn't try the xlbs bc our friend told us they weren't very good so I can't comment on those. I think my favorite ended up being the chicken gyoza and Beijing noodles. I wish they also served scallion pancakes, my fave!
author: Grace D.

description:
I had higher expectations because of the hype, but nothing was truly magical (was good, though!). I expected more for the price. Space is truly minimal, so come early if you can. 

This place is suuuuuuper busy, so there's a little place to wait outside (you can sign in and wait to be called). I waited about ~40 minutes on a Saturday at 6PM. It was weirdly cooler outside than it was inside (it was a hot day for SF, but seriously? The inside of the restaurant was roasting.) This place has a casual vibe, and it's pretty cute. 

I loved the shrimp toast (5 stars), seafood dumplings (4 stars), and thought the Tom Yum XLB were ok. They had a strong ginger taste and didn't really taste like tom yum at all to me. They were a huge let down (and why were the XLB in little tin foils?). Plus it took the kitchen ~40 minutes to make our XLB, so we were just chilling there for a good long while. 

The overall experience was underwhelming. I want to come back and try other items during non-peak time, but I expected more.
author: Ria D.

description:
I am so Lucky... my office is upstairs.
This is the real thing, 100% authentic in every dish, the preparations , presentation, ant the taste.......!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Ho Ho !! Words can not  describe, you need to try for your self.
author: Wilson C.

description:
Excited to see pretty legit Chinese food opening up in the area, particularly ones boasting a good XLB!

My fiancée and I came in on a weekday mid evening and had zero wait time. There were multiple tables open so we were able to ask to have a private rather than communal table (score!).

We ordered garlic fried green beans, Beijing noodles, chicken bao, char siu bao, pork xlb, and their trio of dessert buns.

While I liked the flavor of the filling and broth of the xlb, my fiancée complained that the skin was made improperly because the dumplings couldn't be picked up without bursting (hence, they were served in individual tins rather than free-standing). The green beans and beijing noodles were addictively good. Both baos were good but standard. What this tells me is that while their dough tastes fresh and is definitely made in house, they may still have a bit of tweaking to do for flavor and elasticity.

A big highlight of the meal was the dessert buns. I would honestly come back here and just eat dessert if there were no wait or if they offered pickup/takeaway. The egg yolk bun had the richness of eating an egg tart, but with a soft chewy bao exterior, and was by far our favorite, but for sure give the other two a try!
author: Neal B.

description: Great place for some yummy dumplings without the expensive prices like Yank Sing (which btw, I love to go there too).
author: Lisa S.

description: Do you know how hard it is to find good shrimp toast? I do. Dumpling time is the place for great shrimp toast. It has actual shrimp on it. Crispy and golden brown. One order has 8 pieces. So good, but so bad for your waistline! I usually get takeout at Dumpling time but the dining room is worth a visit as well. My Dad will eat here, because he can get American food as well. The fried chicken here is very good.
author: Macleod R.

description: First time here and it was good and worth the wait!!! You must try!!! The little soup dumplings were delish. Seafood dumplings were bomb, The shrimp toast is a MUST and they have these yummy dessert buns with sweet egg yolk in the center.. to die for! I wish I had photos of everything I ate... I will be back!
author: Rox N.

description: Their pork boa is amazing. They have this great chili sauce that has a slight kick, but isn't too spicy. Rates are fair.
author: Michelle V.

description: Really great lunch. Three of us tried 7 items, all very flavorful, great spices.plenty of food and the wonderful chrysanthemum tea. Nice location with outdoor seating. We may have just gotten lucky, but even the parking was easy! Will definitely go back.
author: Judy K.

description: This place is bomb!  Food is amazing, great service.  There was a wait when I arrived but went quickly and totally worth it.  In town on business but will definitely be back when I return.  Cucumber salad was refreshing, Asian green salad was HUGE, enough for 3 people, and XLB (soup dumplings) were hot, fresh and delicious.  Speedy service.  Do yourself a favor and come here.
author: Kristin R.

description: This was our first time here and it will definitely not be our last. The waiting time to get seated was about 10mins, they are pretty busy so make sure to write your name on the waiting list. Everything on the menu is tasty and flavorful. We had the chicken gyoza, siu mai Maine lobster and the har gow shrimp and cilantro (my favorite) definitely coming back to try the rest of the menu!
author: Celene Z.

description: The shrimp toast was amazing we got a second order and didn't last long crisp not greasy at all! Everything we had was great!
author: Nick N Parker S.

description:
It seems that all of a sudden dumpling joints just pop up left and right in the Bay Area and everyone is having a dumpling fever.  I love dumplings and it's my go to comfort food all the time.  

Got to DT early but they delayed the opening until 5:30pm instead of 5pm.  Place is small and there's a glass enclosure where you can see the c-fu "masters" making fresh dumplings from scratch.

Shrimp toast: props for the creativity of the dish by using Chinese fried donut as base instead of the usual white bread.  However, the shrimp toast wasn't properly fried (normally fried twice to extract the excess oil out) so every mouthful was full of oil.  $8 / order if you want to gain a few lbs.

XLB: It's fresh with thin wrapper and full of broth but need just a little bit more filling.  $6/6 - ok

Pork dumplings: Pretty presentation sprinkled with flower pedals and radish slices on top of the dumplings.  Surprisingly I prefer this one over the xlb as the dumplings had better flavor.  $8/8 - order

Seafood Gyoza: It's just haw-gow (dim sum) with spinach wrapper and pan fried.  $7.5/5 - pass

Beijing noodles: noodles seems to be made in house and the meat sauce is tasty.  $9 - order

Fried Chicken Bao: ordered because of the cute dumpling stamps on them, yea, ikr? but they came without the stamps on them :( and after eating the noodles we were too full to finish the bao.  $4.5/3 - Yet to try them at home.

Overall 3.5 stars and reasonable price range but place is kind of out of the way so go if you are around the area.
author: Shirley H.

description:
Absolutely amazing! This is by far the best dumpling house I've ever been too.

Food: We got the Shrimp Toast, Seafood Gyoza, Vegetarian Dumplings, Pork XLB, Shrimp Hargow, Seared Char-siu and Trio of Buns.  It was all so delicious. Just get everything... If you can afford it. It's not expensive at all. However it can rack up quickly.

Service: Great! We had Jean and she was one of the best servers I've ever seen. Friendly, professional, knowledgeable and fun. We were very impressed. 

Atmosphere: Casual and lively. Its nice being able to see the kitchen. Also the K-pop on the projector is a nice touch as well.
author: Rachel C.

description: Generally fine. Line was a little long. Food was decent but it leaned expensive for what it was. Overall casual and crowded vibe which was generally nice.
author: G L.

description:
Dumpling time is a cool concept of a restaurant. It's fun that they have dumplings from the different regions of Asian but I think because of that their dumplings are not as good as they could be. They are just trying to do too much and haven't perfected things. They are tasty but really not special. 
The Tom yum xiao long bao lacked the Tom yum flavor. You could barely taste it, i wanted more. The strings beans were good and and the noodles were probably my favorite. The dumplings had lots of garnishes which you can see in the picture. I thought that was really unnecessary and it did nothing visibly nor did it add to the dish. The big xiao bao was cool. We ordered it just to say we got it but it definitely is not as good as the little ones. Fun idea but fun is all that it really is.  
I think it's worth a one time visit. THe portions are small so you have to order a lot but for the most part the food is good. I wasn't that full leaving and it is a bit pricey for dumplings so that was a bit of a bummer. I enjoyed the overall experience but probably wouldn't go back again! It's just a one time kind of place for me.
author: Andrea W.

description: Great food and perfect service! Get there early. I would recommend the noodles and the chicken steamed buns.
author: Pam W.

description: I haven't had decent soup dumplings since Shanghai... until this place! Great flavors on pretty much everything I tried. In addition to the soup dumplings, the lotus root salad and bbq pork buns really stood out!
author: Cat M.

description: I've brought my friends here several times. I love this place but my recent experience was unbelievable. I'm extremely disappointed how we got treated when we've waited so long for their "party" to be over. We asked whether they had curtains at their outdoor seating since the sun was blinding us but when we brought it up, one of the servers bluntly said "We can't do anything about it" without hesitation nor concern in a snooty way. She didn't even offer another seat until one of the other servers noted it. It's terrible how we've been treated like this minutes right before we enter.
author: Juke J.

description: Came at 8pm on a Sunday and there was a list going with about 25 people ahead of us. We waited and it took about 30 mins before we got seated. Def worth the wait. All the food I ate tasted clean like it was made at home.  Reminded me of a dumpling place I went to in Taipei.
author: Gordon L.

description:
A restaurant that specializes in all kinds of Asian dumplings? Count me in! Came here with a friend who works nearby by at Adobe for lunch. The food was hit or miss. 

 - Shrimp Toast: yummy Chinese doughnuts pieces topped with a whole shrimp and aioli

 - Seafood Gyoza: nicely made gyoza with chunks of shrimp

 - Tom Yum Goong XLB: tasty but all of them except one fell apart when lifting them out of the individual tins, I'm not sure what the technique is but we didn't have it, might have been better if we had been able to eat the broth as well instead of having it dribble all over the place

 - BBQ Pork Bao (pan fried): small buns with bbq pork, the buns were just okay, the pan frying seemed to have been done with minimal oil, it looked and tasted like a steamed bun they just then browned on a dry pan with none of the good brown fried crispiness of real pan fried buns (NB: my friend commented it must be non-Asians who were so impressed by these)

Get there before noon because the tables fill up quickly. May be good for nearby work folks who want a nice place to expense meals but I don't think I'll be back any time soon.
author: Jean K.

description:
King-dum ($8): A modern, fun spin to a classic XLB. It was very pretty and didn't blow my mind or anything but is definitely worth the try! 8/10

Beijing Noodles ($9): Small serving, but pretty tasty! Enjoyed it. 8.5/10

Tom Yum Goong XLB ($9): Their take on Tom Yum soup dumplings...didn't taste like tom yum. It was a unique concept, and tasty, but didn't live up to what was advertised. It was just like any other pork xlb. 6.5/10

Pan-seared Cha-siu Bao ($6): Nothing special. 5/10

Trio Dessert Buns ($5.5): 
Green Tea Milk Bun- 6/10
Taro Beet Bun- 4.5/10 
Egg Yolk Bun- (aka Nai Wong Bao) 5/10 
Wasn't bad, just wasn't memorable. Definitely not worth $5.5 for 3 mini buns!
author: Emily L.

description: This place is AMAZING! Some of the best dumplings and buns in SF. Definitely a more trendy atmosphere as opposed to a dumpling spot in Chinatown but it's worth the wait! You can see them  making the dumplings right as you walk in. Love going here for dumpling cravings!
author: Megan W.

description: After our flight and it being past lunch time, this place was such a delight. Checking out other people's tables with various dishes (you know you do it, too) and the wonderful smell just had us anxious for all the food. I don't think we have any pictures because we got down to business as soon as the dumplings came out but all were good.
author: Jackie R.

description:
Disastrous on so many so many levels.

After waiting over half and hour to be seated (there was a long queue even at 2pm, half an hour before closing time) we were put in a dark corner in the patio in the freezing weather. Because we were starving by that time, we reluctabtly agreed to that seat. We waited another 15 mins to order, by that time many items we wanted were out, including the big XLB. So we settled for shrimp toast, xi'an pork dumpling, tom yum xlb, pork bun, trio dessert bun. For the most part, the food was medicre at best. The 2 disasters were the shrimp toast being way too greasy and the pork dumpling seems to have some off funky rotten smell to it. I woke up the next day with FOOD POISONING. 
 
And to add insult to injury, the service was the worst I have ever experienced. They forgot to serve vinegar with our dumpling so I requested vinegar and waited ages only to have the waitress (curly hair, works front of the house as well) come charging in and slammed the vinegar onto our table and didn't respond when we said "thank you". Honestly this was the first time in my life where I felt like I was slapped in the face with rudeness. 

Overall an appalling experience. Never again.
author: Linh B.

description: Excellent location and everything is made on-site.  Great to see the high quality process and attention to detail. Don't miss the lamb dumplings, those are my personal favorite.  Indoor and outdoor seating options so a great choice no matter the weather.
author: Lauren H.

description: Went here with some friends and ordered several types of dumplings and some other dishes. Everything was pretty good--nothing really blew me away, but decent flavors nonetheless. Atmosphere is lively and fun with the video screen.
author: Ryan R.

description:
Good food, efficient service, definitely coming back 
Best dumpling in sf 
Same owners of live sushi
author: Mina O.

description:
Decided to try them for my birthday brunch and wasn't disappointed.  We decided to show up just before opening at 11am and it paid off.  There were about 6 groups before us so we knew we'd get a table.  They didn't start seating us until past 11, no big deal unless you've been waiting all morning for some dumps and you're starving.
