It's been awhile since we've been in the area. The last time we were at this location it was Source.  I'm sure it was something else after them.  Hopefully they'll be here longer than the last two.  If you're not from the area and have to drive, we parked on Alameda about a block away (4hour free parking) since Division is mostly metered and hard to find space.

For starters, based on yelp reviews we got the shrimp toast followed by shrimp har gow, seafood gyoza and xlb tom yum goong.  They didn't arrive in that order but I guess that doesn't matter.  

Seafood gyoza came first and I couldn't get enough.  I loved the spinach skin and the healthy portion of seafood stuffing but most of all the spiced chili butter sauce was so good we didn't even touch the other sauce it came with.  
Shrimp toast came next and it's more a Chinese donut dough topped with shrimp paste.  It was crispy with plenty of shrimp flavor from the shrimp paste.  It was dotted with what tasted like sriracha mayo that I wish there was more of, yum.  
Shrimp har gow was different because it had cream cheese. It was mild but lent a creamy texture.  It comes with a green sauce you can spice up with a dab of chili from the table. It's also filled with plenty of shrimp.  
XLB tom yum goong was filled with so much soup you have to make sure you slurp it all before you lose it.  Lots of beet flavor from the skin and the soup.  Not too fond of the vinegar it comes with. I like the more traditional vinegar pairing.  

I realized that everything we ordered had shrimp and I was okay with that.  Craving lots of seafood lately.  I wanted to order more, like the happy endings trio buns but I had Mr Holmes cruffins and Tartine passion fruit lime Bavarian cake waiting for me. Perfect amount of food for two.  I can't wait to go back for more. 

It gets really loud when it's full.  Something I remember from Source.  Friendly service.
author: Naty D.

description: Yes! Everything at Dumpling Time is Five Stars! Soup Dumplings large and small! The purple ones are Beet Skin dumplings, my favorite! Also, be sure to check out the best Gyoza I have ever enjoyed. And great noodles too!
author: Kalen T.

description: Stopped by for lunch, food was sooo good! Not your typical dumpling stop, food was fresh, hand rolled, presented well and simply delicious. Loved there take on a Chinese donut, be sure to order the veggie dumplings and trio buns to go with your oolong tea. Service was great too, will be back!
author: paul k.

description:
I wouldn't say this place is the most authentic, but it's probably the best dumpling spot for San Francisco. I like to call it "hipster fusion" (haha) especially their xiao long bao. For example, they have a Tom Yum Goong XLB -- you would never find this anywhere in China. Anyways, I've tried a ton of XLB places in San Francisco but Dumpling Time is probably the highest quality at this point. Still wish there was a Din Tai Fung in the city! 

Besides their XLB, their other dishes are delicious as well including the noodles and veggies. Every time I've been here, the wait has been at least 20 minutes, so pack your patience...even during the middle of the week!
author: Lauren L.

description: Every time I passed this restaurant at dinner time there is a sizable line and a great smell. I don't know why I took so long to go here! I think this is the best dumpling place I've been to so far in SF. The red soup dumplings are the best. I was surprised to find I liked the shrimp bread considerably. It tastes like a light donut.
author: Gabs M.

description: This was a first time experience at dumpling time for me and my friends. I was on work travel from Washington DC area and was so pleased to find such good soup dumplings, noodles, and pork buns! Our waiter, Kent, was fantastic and explained each of his favorites on the menu. Highly recommend the soup dumplings, shrimp and cilantro, seafood dumplings, and Beijing noodles. Everything was incredible and delicious. Please open one of these on the east coast.
author: Aaron R.

description:
This place is amazing - most of the time I struggle with Chinese places I visit because I can't forget the taste of food from actual Chinese joints from China. 

This place not only comes close in their traditional department, it improves with new amazing combinations. There is quite a line in front of it, but it's definitely a place to go to!
author: Andrei K.

description: On a recent trip to San Francisco, my boyfriend and I stopped at Dumpling Time. We had eaten at a few other places on our trip and dumpling time was our last stop before we headed back to the airport, but we both said that we wished that we had eaten there earlier so that we could've come back a few times before our trip was over. These were some of the best dumplings I've ever had and the service was really quick. Some highlights for me were the lobster siu mai, the pork xlb and the king-dum. Wish we had a Dumpling Time in Portland, OR!
author: Taylor W.

description:
Amazing restaurant with very decent prices.
We came here 4 friends and had tons of fun and wonderful food
author: Nimrod Dado D.

description:
Had to try this place after seeing it blow up on IG & Yelp and it lived up to the hype!

FOOD
*We ordered family style for 4.
- Garlic seaweed +4/5
Knowing how much carbs we'd be ordered, this veggie side dish was definitely necessary but SO small. We shared it among 4 but 1 could have easily eaten all of it.
- Beijing Noodles +5/5
Wow, these were amazing. We ordered another one after killing the first (also small portions - 2 would easily finish 1, hence why we ordered another) - but AMAZING. 
- Tom Yum Goong +3.5/5
REALLY good flavor - these are the beet XLB's! Super tiny though.
- Pork XLBs +4/5
These are your traditional XLB's - also tiny - & were just ok..
- King XLB +4/5
The SOUP was amazing, the presentation was cute, but its really hard to eat (especially if you're sharing)
- Seafood Gyoza +4/5
We really liked this one bc 1) it was actually a decent size & 2) the flavor was so rich & filling!
- Trio of Buns +4.5/5
You could probably skip the beet/taro bun so I'd stick to just ordered the green tea or traditional egg yolk bun - these two killllled it.

While this place delivered both taste & aesthetics-wise, the portions were quite tiny. It's overall a young, hip place to come for dim sum but if you're absolutely starving & are looking to get filled, I'd go to the more traditional dim sums in town. But overall, a great addition to the asian foodie community in sf!
author: Rachel Y.

description:
It was really good. Great service. I am
Pretty spontaneous so it's nice to have a restaurant that doesn't accept reservations.

Good service. We did get handed a few things that were different from what we ordered. Pan fried bao instead of steamed...
Didn't mind us though.
author: Porter F.

description: Ok dumpling place but you can do better in the sunset or further south in the peninsula like idumpling. Lamb skewer here was a bit tough and not flavorful. Lamb dumplings also weren't great. Perhaps the pork is good (I don't eat it) but as far as the lamb, I wouldn't recommend it
author: Josh N.

description: Love this place!!! The food is soooo good! :) obsessed with dumplings! Highly recommend!
author: Stephanie K.

description: It is what you'd think it is. Over-priced, hipster, unauthentic Chinese food. But I don't think they're trying to present it as authentic Chinese food. Their website calls it "Cal-Asian". It's like paying a lot of money for avocado toast. Not worth it. Only thing I liked was the shrimp toast. Liked the creativity of using a chinese donut as "bread" for the toast. Fun to try but definitely won't return.
author: Chrisy C.

description:
I didn't believe the hype. But this is so good- my fiancé and I were comparing the xiao long bao to DTF- and even comparing means it's good. It's not quite there but it's the best XLB ive had in the city. This is authentic with a gourmet and fine dining twist, hence the nicer atmosphere and higher price than your average delicious hole in the wall. 
Our favorites were the XLB, vegetable dumplings, Beijing noodle, heck it was all good. I'll be back.
author: Caro C.

description:
Food: Dumpling Time has been on my list for a while because of those giant King Dum dumplings that keep popping up on my instagram feed. I finally made the trip and I'm glad I listened to everyone and ordered the regular sized xiao long bao instead. I went with my boyfriend and we shared an order of pork XLB (6 pcs), veggie dumplings (8 pcs), and pork bao (3 pcs). We were sufficiently full, but we did pre-game with some Mr. Holmes pastries a few hours earlier. The pork XLB had great flavor to it. They were nice and juicy and came with some dipping sauce. I really wanted to order the king dum XLB, but even the waitress said most people found it difficult to eat. The pork XLB was perfect for sharing with my boyfriend and there's plenty of colorful options on the menu to boost your instagram game. I ordered the veggie dumplings to offset all the pork we were going to eat and was very happy with the dish! The dumplings are green (get that color for your instagram shot!) and came with a variety of other colorful chopped veggies. I've never seen cherry tomatoes in a Chinese dish, but it worked for me. Maybe it's not what mom has been cooking at home, but it's worth giving a shot. The pork bao was okay, but they do come a little small. The flavor also wasn't much to brag about. It was standard bao that you can get at any corner dim sum shop. 

Logistics: We spent $25 on those 3 dishes (keep in mind though that we came in with a partially filled stomach). I've definitely been to cheaper dim sum places, but Dumpling Time isn't structured the way other dim sum restaurants are. I would probably come again for lunch with friends that I'm showing around the city, but I don't think I'd come back on my own for a casual visit. They do have some parking in front of the restaurant, but spots are limited. There are plenty of street parking spots around the area ($2.25/hour) and the storefronts are busy enough areas during the day that your car should be fine.
author: Rachel A.

description: Love this place! Super delicious food, decent prices, and fun atmosphere. Sf needs more spots like this.
author: Brian H.

description:
Went to Dumpling Time for dinner tonight. Dumplings are my favorite! 

Pros:
-Shrimp toast (so good we ordered another one)
-Tom Yum xlbs 
-Seafood gyozas (the side sauce was super good)
-Cucumber and seaweed sides

Cons/meh:
-Both noodle dishes were meh
-shrimp dumplings
-pan fried dumplings
-veggie dumplings
-the xl xlb was good and fun to drink but not worth $8
-the dessert buns were a let down too, sounds better than they taste

They only serve water, tea, and soda. No alcohol yet.
They don't take reservations either although it wasn't too busy on a Wednesday night. 

Service was good and the workers are all very hard working. There was a mix up at one point where they brought us an extra plate of gyoza and when we told them, they said we could have it. 5 mins later, they took it back and gave it to the table next to us. Um yeah we didn't touch it but still..

Prices are reasonable although I am not sure if I will go back. I do love dumplings so maybe if I have really mad cravings that can't be satisfied at any shanghai restaurant in the city.
author: Cicely T.

description:
For appetizers and small bites we ordered the snap peas and cold cucumber salad. 

Snap peas $8. Overcooked and nothing special as far as flavor. 

Cucumbers salad $5. Nice presentation but it was a little too sweet. It's really a "small bite". 

Next we had the Beijing noodles, steam pork bao and Xiao long bao. 

Beijing noodles $9. Very oily, not much flavor and again small portions. You might be able to spilt 3 tiny bowls if you're sharing. 

Steamed pork bao $5.5 for 3. The bun itself was very soft which I enjoyed. We asked for them to pan fried the bottom. I was expecting soup when I bit into it but it was really just a regular pork bao. Little disappointed. Flavor wise it was okay. 

Lastly, the Xiao long bao $8 for 6 pieces. This was very frustrating to eat. Thumbs up for the amount of soup each one had but all 6 of ours were stuck to the foil container. It was impossible to eat without breaking the skin and risk losing all the soup and flavor. Although they were juicy the pork could've used some more flavor. 

Presentation was okay.
Service not bad.
Portions are small.
Flavor wise was ehh. 

If I were to go back I would maybe reorder the XLB out of the 5 dishes. If you haven't tried, sure give it a try but I doubt I would suggest to go eat here again. 

If you know your Asian food this place might disappoint you. But if you're new to Asian food or dumplings you might enjoy it more.
author: Karen M.

description: At first I thought this place looked too westernized. But to my surprise the food was very tasty and authentic Chinese with a bit fusion twist. Pricier than even the high  end dim sum place. $10 for 6 potstickrts. Lol! $6 for 3 dessert buns. But it's tasty and fun to look at the beautiful food.  Definitely worth the experience.
author: Laura F.

description:
I waited about twenty minutes during lunch time on a Saturday. Got lucky with parking but there's a lot of street parking. We got all our food within ten minutes and everything was so good! The King XLB is a bit difficult to drink out of (?) but they give you an extra plate to figure it out. The green beans were a bit salty but goes well with the XLB! Definitely recommend the Xian dumplings! It's really good with the mixture of light vegetables.  The trio buns are a great way to finish your meal with three different flavors. 
Definitely have to come back here!
author: Kimberly G.

description: Really good, authentic dumplings. The soup dumplings are delicious, the servers are friendly and quick, and the ambiance is very nice. It is, however, very pricey!!
author: Hannah S.

description: This place was packed when we got here at about 6 on a Sunday, and the confusion about how to even get our name on the list was why I had to mark it down a star. The food was amazing, especially liked the pork buns! The decor was minimalistic but cute, think small neon signs and wood tables. If you're okay with community style dining this place is for you. Would definitely visit again for lunch or dinner!
author: Olivia J.

description:
This place is one of the best dim sum restaurants I have ever been to, and I have dabbled. A lot. Any of their noodle dishes are simply perfect, whether vegetarian or with meat. The pork bao come in an order of three, and they are astoundingly good if not a little small (but that leaves room for everything else). The red dumplings made with beet skin are not to be missed either. Finally, the king dumpling was amazing and also my personal favorite. It huge, and it comes with a boba straw so you can literally drink hot pork fat out of the top. It's heaven for a pork man. 
My advice is to arrive AT LEAST 20 minutes before they open to ensure your name on the list for first seating. Otherwise, it can be a long wait, although the turnover isn't bad. There's a rad thai restaurant with a bar across the street to cruise beers while you wait. 
This place is special.
author: Luke S.

description:
Presentation - 4/5
Taste -3/5

The XLB here is just average but kudos on the presentation!

The tom yum XLB was my favorite of them all but still only slightly above average.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Amazing dumplings! Such a great selection of dumplings. It's a busy restaurant so you may need to put your name down but the wait wasn't long at all for a table of 3. I highly recommend the Marine Lobster Siu Mai, Chicken Gyoza, King Dum and Green Beans. We also had the Chicken Bao and Veggie Dumplings, which were also delicious but you could miss these dishes. 
Overall, great restaurant, great staff and amazing food!
author: Monica D.

description: so so so good. Defs recommend to everyone who loves dumpling. I don't eat pork but they had amazing options otherwise. Defs try the Xi'an beef dumplings!
author: Omar D.

description: After coming here a second time here are our favorite items: char siu bao (seared), pork soup dumpling, pork dumplings, and did not like the seafood gyoza (so stick to pork or chicken next time). Table next to us ordered some noodles which looked amazing so might get those next time.
author: Laura D.

description:
I absolutely love dumplings, and having seen this as a must eat in San Francisco while doing research I was really excited to eat here! We came here on a Saturday night, and the place was bustling. There was an indoor waiting area, which is basically their outdoor eating area, but it was nice because it was heated, and absolutely freezing outside. However we ended up waiting for a table for almost 40 minutes, and it was cool to walk in and see people making dumplings. The atmosphere was really hip with vibrant neon signs. 

We got the:

- Crispy Sesame Tofu Squares ($5): i was not too crazy about this. It tasted incredibly salty and the sauce was way to sweet for my taste. The texture on the outside is perfectly crispy, while the inside is so soft that it almost melts into your mouth, which I thought was really interesting, but I am not sure I loved. 

- Chicken Bao ($6) : This was probably my favorite dish we got there. It was perfectly stuffed with the right ratio of meat to bao, and the filling was really good. 

- Chicken Gyoza ($7.50) : The Gyoza was really interesting it was really crispy almost fried at the bottom and I enjoyed the stuffing, and overall it was average. It was a little saltier than I expected, but it seemed like a lot of other gyozas I have had before. 

-Vegetable Dumplings ($8) : I really enjoyed the vegetable dumpling filling. However be careful because the dish comes in a really aesthetic bowl topped with several different toppings, and my friend thought one of those toppings were tomatoes, and there were halves of cherry tomatoes, but she accidentally picked up straight up red chili and burnt her tongue. When the chili seeds touch the edge of the dumpling and you accidentally eat it I am not sure how I feel about this. I really liked the filling for the dumpling as it was very flavorful, but I was not a fan of the exterior. It was rather watery and kept breaking quickly. 

-Three Sum ($6) : This was really good! I really especially enjoyed the Egg Yolk Bun, then the Green Tea & Milk Bun, and finally the Beet & Taro Bun. The Egg Yolk Bun was so good, and I kind of wish we had just got three of those. The Beet & Taro was not too flavorful, but was still good. 

Overall I think the service is amazing, but it kind of felt like they wanted us to leave because right when we finished a dish, someone would take it away, which maybe I am just not used to, but my friend mentioned feeling this way as well. I am not too sure if I would come here again because although it was incredibly good it seemed so overpriced and I feel like I have definetly had better food at other places.
author: Manisha P.

description: Excellent spot for delicious and piping hot dumplings. I suggest trying some of every style--steamed, seared, saucy, soupy. The hand pulled noodles were the perfect with the pork sauce. Everything is handmade at the restaurant so everything is super fresh. The matcha dessert buns are the perfect finish. Will be back for sure.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Our group came in Sunday for brunch and waited around 30 minutes for a table.

We ordered gyozas, pan-fried baos, and soup dumplings (pork and tom yum). Everything was delicious. Each were distinct in flavor and originality.
author: Kojo K.

description: This place is so freaking good! I went around dinner time on a Sunday and It gets packed so make sure you get there early! They start a list minutes before they open. I can't believe how delicious the food was! I loved everything I ordered. Their prices are good as well and now I can't stop thinking about these dumplings I want to go back already!!! It was also my first time trying dumplings so thank you Dumpling Time for my new dumpling addiction!
author: Karen V.

description:
Best Xiao in SF!
Amazing fresh noodles, a lot of care and craft go into all their dumplings.
author: Todd R.

description: My friend had been wanting to try this place out since they opened, but the wait was always too long.  We finally went there on a weeknight and the wait was not too bad, about 15-20 minutes, and I was looking forward to trying some XLB!  Been looking for a place that has XLB as good as what we've had in NYC and have yet to find a winner.  We ordered their king XLB, some appetizers, noodles, and other dumplings to try.  The king XLB is really gimmicky and didn't impress me at all.  The other dumplings were average at best.  The seaweed was tasty, but very small portion.  The noodles were also average at best.  The place was packed with people and there was loud music blaring with a large projection screen showing music videos.  I guess this place could be a cool hangout for the "youngins", but I won't be coming back for seconds.  My search continues...
author: Lily W.

description: I'm not one for dumplings but these are so so good! I highly recommend for both brunch and dinner. My go tos are the garlicky green beans, BBQ pork bao, pork gyoza and vegetable dumplings. I also highly recommend the dessert bao trio! They have a great tea selection as well. The service is not typical: they bring out the food as it is cooked so you may get something you wanted last first. If this bothers you, order in sections. It really doesn't bother me but some people hate it. Also, there's usually a line and they don't take reservations so just be prepared to wait.
author: Kendra W.

description:
clean, good vibes, indoor & outdoor seating, & delicious food! 

We LOVED this place - highly Recommend it! I'm sure weekend brunch is craY but we came on a Wednesday night around 6 so we didn't have to wait. 

I'd recommend going in a group so you can try a lotta things. There were 4 of us girls - perfect size group. The menu has enough options, but isn't overwhelming. Everything is fresh and made to order so it takes a little while but it's worth it. Their presentation is also nice 

We got:
- garlic green beans. Delish! We love chubby noodles' version and these are almost as
Good
- shrimp toast . Chinese donut w minced shrimp . Weird at first but really good
- garlic seaweed salad. The portion is tiny! And it's like actual seaweed, not the kind you get at poke or sushi places. It was a little sea-y-er (that's def
Not a real word) than I'm used to but still good
- shrimp dumpling - great! One girl can't eat cilantro so I wanna go back to try those too 
- gan ban noodles. Loaded w veggies 
- seafood gyoza - this was just ok, we agreed it was our least favorite of the night. There was a little too much going on inside the green pouch. Next time I'll try the pork or chicken
- crispy chicken bao . We liked the crispy option, makes them a little different 
- pork soup dumplings . Idk how people get the super big ones, it was weird enough looking at them at the table next to us. Stick to the small ones

They have that chili sauce on the tables & it added the perfect amount of spice to all the food 

& for dessert:
- green tea & milk buns
- beet & taro buns

Make sure you leave room for dessert! The buns are warm and gooey and have so much flavor... and they're pretty colors. The green tea was def my favorite but I'd recommend both - our group was split on the decision which were better 

Can't wait to go back *mouth watering* as I wrote this
author: danielle a.

description: Had to check this place out because our family LOVES dumplings. Safe to say we were not disappointed. We ordered the tom yum goong, pork gyoza,  char siu bao, and pork dumpling. Everything was super flavorful and delicious. The dough around the dumpling was especially soft and tasty. Also loved the red color to the tom yum goong. It really satisfied my cravings and we will definitely be back.
author: Kylie N.

description: Delicious dumplings. These veggie Xian dumplings with egg actually  turned out to be one of our faves, even for my meat-loving boyfriend.Everything we have tried here is great. Though there is often a wait to be seated it  goes pretty fast. And if you ever have to wait too  long for one of your dishes to come out they might give you a free while you wait great  customer service.
author: Pamela H.

description: Dumpling Time is now one of my favorite places to eat on SF. Service is quick and friendly. Everything we tried was excellent. You can watch them make the dumplings while you wait for a seat. Place fills up fast so get there early. The bao trio for dessert was so good that we ordered another one.
author: Carol N.

description:
New trendy restaurant in SF. 
Pork XLB: Mainly what I came for, very soupy inside, disappointed it came out rather cold. We were told that we could only place one order of XLB at a time. 
Overall, it was over hyped and over priced for the portion sizes. Cool ambiance, but you can get better dim sum at better price elsewhere.
author: Sherry F.

description:
Came here not long after it initially opened. Come early because the wait gets very long and they don't take reservations. There isn't much nearby so you can't really wait at a bar and come back. 

Of course we loved the soup dumplings. The huge dumpling was very novel and equally tasty as the small ones. However, the large dumpling is difficult to share so plan for one per person or per couple.

The only reason I haven't gone back is because they don't take reservations. Waiting an hour outside in the parking lot just isn't appealing to me given that there are so many other options in SF. Also, we like to be able to get a drink before or after dinner and there isn't really anything nearby.
author: Susan M.

description:
The wait wasn't too bad on a Sunday at 12:30 for 2 of us - maybe 15 minutes ? Parking is pretty easy, but note that there's a lot of broken glass from cars that got broken into, so don't leave anything worth stealing visible in your car. 

The menu is a little non traditional - cream cheese in har gow, Tom yum XLB, etc, but they have regular stuff, too. I was a little skeptical, but the food ended up being really solid. 

- Pickled cucumbers: well marinated, crisp 
- Seared chicken bao: the dough as a little sweet for me. It's not like the pan seared buns per se but has a light seat. The chicken and wood ear filling was good, and it was even better with he red vinegar 
- Pork dumplings: the prettiest dumpling dish I've had - garnished with radishes, fennel, nasturtium, etc - the skin had a good bite, and the filling had really good flavor 
- Pork XLB: great soup flavor, not too greasy. The skin was a little thicker than at DTF but wasn't too thick 
- Tom yum XLB: pretty red color. The flavors on this were more subtle than I expected, but the pork belly filling was tender 
- Egg yolk bun: smooth filling, light bun texture, not overly sweet 

Food came out pretty quickly.  Even though it's not traditional, it's nice that the XLBs are in mini tins so that you don't lose the soup picking it up from the basket - pretty brilliant! 

I would definitely get the pork dumplings and pork XLB again.  Since I liked the soup a lot, maybe I should try the King Dum (giant one with a straw) next time.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Food / Service / Decor: 5 stars. Strong asian and asian fusion flavored dumplings. Fast service. 

Only downside is that they don't do reservations and the line can be very long. I took off one star for this reason.

I like the dessert mix - it's a great item to take to-go.
author: Tim W.

description: I LOVE THIS RESTAURANT! Highly recommend the Gan Ban Noodles, Pork Xiao Long Bao, Trio of Buns (which comes with 1 match bun, taro/red bean bun, and a egg yolk bun) --hell even the Cucumber Chili Salad is delicious. The food is extremely high quality, flavorful, and isn't oily like a lot of other Chinese restaurants.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Loved it! All the dumplings were delicious. Nothing was too oily or fatty and the quality of meat was very good. Customer service was excellent.

I recommend the Tom yum soup dumplings (super unique!), seafood dumplings, and dessert trio. But honestly you can't lose with any of their dishes.

Expect a wait on busy nights like Friday or weekend.
author: Josie M.

description:
We arrived 15 minutes before opening (as advised by other Yelpers) on a Sunday, and not to our surprise, there were already several parties ahead of us waiting for the restaurant to open. Make sure to put your name down on the sign-in sheet upon arrival and have your whole party present when they call to seat you. We thought there was a physical line, but there wasn't- it was just people standing in the shade, which happened to look like a line. 

SERVICE- We were seated by 11.05am and our server didn't take our order until 11.25am, which is WAY TOO long. The menu isn't big, so they should know patrons won't be taking more than five minutes to decide want to order. Another note- our order wasn't taken in the same order as we were seated- there were six parties seated outside, we were seated fourth and LAST to order. 

FOOD- Food was just okay. Nothing memorable. We ordered the xiao long bao, BBQ pork bun, chicken potstickers, Beijing noodles, pork Xian dumplings, and trio of buns (dessert). The trio of buns was my favorite- each filled with a different yummy custard. 

PARKING- Plenty of street parking. 

Overall, expensive for mediocre food. Ambiance and presentation were what we were paying for. Wouldn't come back.
author: christina t.

description:
BEST. PORK GYOZAS. EVER. 

And the King Dum dumpling was nothing I've ever had and it was phenomenal. 

Will most definitely go again.
author: Payal R.

description: I don't even know what to say you absolutely have to come here if you are ever in San Francisco the dumplings are amazing!!!!
author: Kk S.

description: Been here twice.  This place is pretty good.  The XLB are decent but aren't quite on the same level as dTF(LA) or Joe's Shanghai (NY) but still quite good compared to most places in SF.  The shrimp toast, shrimp dumplings are worth a go, but the gyozas and the dumplings were underwhelming in my opinion. Service was attentive. Places like this is taking a different but modern approach to this type of Asian cuisine that's typically known to be greasy, a bit unsanitary and cheap.  I respect their concept.
author: Patrick C.

description: This place is awesome. The menu is just the right size, not an overwhelming amount of choices. All the dumplings were great. But the egg yolk and milk/green tea bao were really special. Never has anything like that before.
author: Jon P.

description: One of the most satisfying meals I have had in a long time. Upon visiting SF for Memorial Day weekend, my chef friend brought me here. The service was top notch and the servers were all friendly. All of the dumplings, bao, and gyoza we tried were incredible. The homemade noodles were also very, very good. One of the greatest takeaways was Dumpling Time's house chili sauce blend. Easily the most flavorful I have ever had. To cap it all off, I decided to order the dessert bao trio (green tea, egg yolk, and I believe, beet?) and was pleasantly surprised- each providing a distinctly different flavor and experience. All around, I would highly recommend Dumpling Time. Will return.
author: Jeff B.

description: I love me some dumplings. The staff at Dumpling Time were really sweet and patient. When we went a couple of months ago, I didn't know what to expect menu-wise. I loved everything we tried. The flavors were tasty, the sake was good and the wait was easy because we were able to sign up for Yelp's Nowait seating list system while we were driving there. Because of that, our wait time was fairly quick. I'll definitely come back to Dumpling Time.
author: Melissa S.

description: Good dumplings but severely overpriced. Like ramen, dim sum should be cheap eats. Dumpling time is anything but cheap. Nonetheless, I thought the dumplings were quite tasty.
author: Harry P.

description:
I have been at Dumpling Time, too many times and I have never posted anything. 

First time I heard about this place was over a Facebook ad, and I just wanted to go instantly because who doesn't love dumplings? ​

We went there and were seated in about 10 - 15 minutes to seat outdoors on a very warm and nice space. The staff is very friendly and fast, they give you amazing recommendations so listen to them. 

For a party of three, we got about 5 different things to share, the portions are just about right, I totally recommend​ you getting the Shrimp Toast ( I have been dreaming about it since the first day, love at first bite totally) also get the Pork Buns ALL OF THEM ARE AMAZING, the Dumplings and Potstickers​ are another things​ that are​ a must obviously, try the ones that have seafood​. Honestly not a very big fan of the noodles but that is just me, everyone at my table loved them, and the dessert is great, you might not need to eat a lot since for me was a lot of buns for one day but totally worth being a little more full. 

The drink selection is also pretty decent and the place itself also good, parking is very easy to find and I​ will recommend​​d going for sure, try to get there as soon as they open and the wait time will be 0 minutes.
author: Rebecca F.

description: Cozy place, can be a bit busy but wait time (weekday evening) was not long. Had a great set of lamb dumplings and shrimp and pork siu mai.
author: I C.

description: Here's what was great about this place. The dumplings came out fresh and fast and collectively we put down over a hundred of them. The place can be pretty great for groups -- we had 11 and they had no problem seating us quickly on a Wednesday evening around 6:30pm.
author: Leo I.

description:
Ehhh ... it was just subpar in my books . Had much better in New York . I think it's just a bit overrated for dumplings at this establishment . 
I don't mind paying for price but SF has such abundant hole in the wall places that serve better dumplings . Why would you be such an idiot standing in their lines .
author: Ro C.

description: Superb xlb and dumplings.  Highly recommended.  Pet friendly outdoor seating and friendly wait staff.
author: John Z.

description: Servers suck and don't really pay much attention. Food is ok too but not worth the haste really.
author: Pratham A.

description:
7/10

- overrated
- taste is good (doesn't compare to real dim sum but it isn't bad)
- portion size for everything is off for dim sum
- many things that should be avoided on an already small menu
- authenticity sacrificed in the interest of pleasing white people
author: Yuen Hsi C.

description: Best place for me in week end to taste variety of delicious foods . Food serving is very quick . Shanghai noodles is best taste for me here . And also enough parking place for car . This place is famous for Asian foods .
author: Santosh B.

description: I had a really nice time here, the vibe is chill, fun beers on the menu and the service was excellent. We only waited about 20 minutes, which sounds like a win compared to some others here. I was brain dead tired and so did not check Yelp for the review highlights like I usually do to get cues on what to order, and that was a mistake. We ordered 6 different kinds of dumplings and honestly I found the flavours underwhelming in all of them. Sort of like they had all been averaged out. I also found the dumpling skins a little thick, and I wished they had brought bottles of black vinegar and chilli paste to the table instead of tiny dishes of dipping sauce for us to share. All in all my impression was style over substance, though I appreciate the effort, I'll probably stick with places that specialize in one type of dumplings rather than trying to have it all.
author: Risa D.

description:
This is a pretty good spot for dumplings, but it's definitely not worth a long wait. 

If you don't have to wait or are seated quickly, it's a solid choice. 

My issue is that the food is always slightly warm at best. It's never hot. The temperature would indicate the kitchen is just churning out dishes in bulk and items sit there waiting to be served. 

The service is great and fast so I doubt they are leaving dishes sit and get cold, this issue is entirely with the kitchen. 

Let's face it - cold dumplings suck. As great as the flavors are here, if the food arrives and it's basically room temperature what's the point of eating here?
author: Matthew B.

description:
My parents and I were excited but more intrigued by what Dumpling Time had to offer. It has a pretty chic, hip vibe to it - huge windows to see the outside and an ongoing projector showing maybe kpop? My family ordered a ton of stuff but I'll go to the most memorable (the good, the bad, and the ugly).

The good: the Xian dumplings! The skin around the dumpling was thin and the pork stuffing was well balanced. Dipping it in soy sauce made it better! The flowers and sprouts on top were a nice touch but in all honesty, I'm biased because I'm a sucker for these things!

The bad and ugly  (I got a bit lazy, sorry): the siu mai and the big Xiao long bao. The siu mai was just any old siu mai at any old (and classic) dim sum place. It was nothing special and very ok according to my parents, but to be fair, they're priced more or less the same as other places so it's not like you're really taking a hit. The big Xiao long bao is more there for the WOW factor and Instagram/snapchat photos. The broth was good but it was so hard to eat, and in order to have such a big bao, the skin needs to be proportionally thicker. Because of the size, the skin was a bit dry. So sad. 

Overall, I'd come again but would not make it a regular spot and opt for other Chinese restaurants.
author: Sophie D.

description: What a great surprise. Braved the long lines and our small party of two was seated and in for quite a treat! Very creative and delicious food. Far more sophisticated than your run of the mill dumpling place.
author: T F.

description: This was my first time trying dumplings and they were so good. I don't eat pork or beef but we tried the chicken bao and chicken gyoza (spelling?) and they were both really good. I enjoyed the restaurant as a whole. You can watch people make dumplings in front of you. I'd recommend getting there early because you put yourself on a waitlist and it seems like if you arrive a little late you could be waiting for awhile. The service was fantastic. Last but not least we tried the trio dessert dumplings and they were delicious - probably my favorite part of the entire meal. Love the place and definitely recommend trying it out
author: Nesha P.

description: The pork dumplings were really tasty. I loved the crunch on the bottom to balance the hunk of meat you get. I prefer dumplings that have more dough in relation to meat filling, but I think they pride themselves on the filling. It was interesting to have a view of the creation process as workers stuff the dumplings through the front windows.
author: Been B.

description:
Ok this is a great place 
Kinda of don't want to share it as it's already very popular and it's a bit of a wait 
But the wait is well worth it and once you are seated you get awesome service and great food and beer 
We will be back many times for sure
author: Chris H.

description:
Came here early on a Saturday morning to avoid the long line and it worked. Sat down pretty quickly with a large table including two babies, right in front of the wall showing weird K-pop videos.

Tried the following:
- Shrimp Toast was ok, it was different, and filling, but I didn't think it was that amazing. It's basically just minced shrimp stuffed in fried dough. Perhaps I just like my Youtiao the old fashioned way dipped in soy milk.
- Beijing Noodles was really good if a little greasy. The noodles were tender with a bit of chewiness. 
- Celery Yuba Salad/Cucumber Salad were both lightly flavored and crunchy, but came in tiny portions. Probably would skip next time.
- Char Siu Bao were pretty small, didn't disappoint but nothing to write home about 
- Pork XLB/Tom Yum XLB were really good! Very soupy with thin skin. I know they come in the tin wrappers and people are all up in arms about it, but I honestly don't mind it and appreciate being able to salvage my soup if I accidentally poked a hole in the dumpling (and that actually didn't happen much with these).
- Trio Bun Dessert was a light sweet end to a filling meal, not a must have though.
author: Julie Z.

description: After stalking this place on Instagram, we finally ate here. Arrived at 10:20am, only to realize it doesn't open until 11am. Whoops. But that turned out to be a lucky accident because we were at the front of a very long line by the time it opened. Ordered an assortment of dishes, all yummy. Will definitely return!
author: Anne C.

description:
FOOD: Old school dumplings with a touch of Cali fusion--aka Chinese yumminess you AND your veg friends can enjoy at half the grease v. traditional places. 

I'm a sucker for microgreens and blossoms, which top nearly every dish! 

- Pork Gyoza: I was reluctant to order this as I have many all too greasy memories in mind from this staple offering at dumplingeries all over town. I was pleasantly surprised by its lack of grease (still more greasy than homemade though) with no sacrifice in flavor. I appreciated that the "pan fried" element was a quick sear to the bottom rather than a deeply brown and crunchy affair, allowing you to really taste the dumpling for what it is (rather than just the base deliciousness of thoroughly fried food).
- Pork Char-Siu Bao: Peanut butter... I had my doubts. But it was excellent! The bun was nice and fluffy, the pork was flavorful and not too fatty. I am still not a huge fan of peanut intruding in my BBQ goodness, but I appreciate the effort to innovate 
- Shrimp & Cilantro Har Gow: Would just go regular shrimp next time. This is another oldie but goodie for a reason. As a cilantro lover (not a soap taster), I found the cilantro too overpowering for the shrimp. It has a strong foreflavor, blocking out all the fragrant foreflavor of the shrimp and leaving that oceanic aftertaste I tolerate when eating shrimp.
- Xi 'An Vegetarian Dumpling: Tested this for vegetarian friends, and it is go! Flavorful and fun. The flavors aren't as umami-y as in the meat options, but a couple orders of these for a never had pork before veg friends will do wonders. 
- Pork XLB: I know the mini pie tins these arrive in are controversial, but I was absolutely enchanted by them. The flavor of the broth was spot on--my favorite in the city--and my only issue was with the wrapper itself, which unfortunately stuck to the bottom of the tin and tore prematurely every time I enjoyed one. Perhaps a thin slice of carrot (as done at other restaurants) or spray of oil at the bottom would allow the XLB to break free without breaking.
- Happy Endings Trio: Save room! These were the highlight of the meal. Loved the sweet but not too sweet end and the medley of Asian dessert flavors. Favorite was the egg yolk bun--the custard was so yummy.

SERVICE: Accommodating hosts (we switched from inside to outside) and upbeat service (have to be in such a busy space!). Server arrived promptly to take our order and food arrived not too long after. Definitely seemed a bit understaffed on (harried) waitstaff, so don't expect to be fawned over, but do expect service when you need it.

AMBIANCE: Fast paced, bright (with neon signs inside and out), and clean. Window where you can see staff rapidly making dumplings by hand, though that did make me a little sad too (hope they are paid enough!). Indoor seating and outdoor deck seating for when the weather's nice. Deck with cute lights and decor makes the best of an otherwise post-industrial new tech warehouse neighborhood.
author: Helen W.

description: It's a bit pricey for Chinese food but that's only because it's good quality and tasty. I usually don't even like Chinese food and dumplings but I actually really enjoyed their dumplings and buns. The atmosphere was also nice and the waiters were nice. Would definitely come back again!
author: Erica L.

description: Finally the XLB gets the trendy makeover! I'm not gonna hide the fact that Instagram pics of King Dum and red XLB brought me here. The space has an industrial feel with modern brown wooden tables in the enclosed outdoor patio where we sat. Props to them allowing doggo's in the patio! I expected XLB to be good and other dishes to be okay, and Dumpling Time surprised me in a good way. My party got the Tom Yum XLB which was not as different from regular XLB as I had imagined--it has just a hint of added sourness and coconut from the Tom Yum. It was a nice mild twist to the XLB. The shrimp toast was a strip of fried Chinese donut with shrimp paste down the middle lengthwise--think shrimp paste in crab claws or eggplant from dim sum--topped with a light drizzle of mayo. We also got the Beijing noodles which were delicious with the right amount of pork and sauce but slightly more oily than is my preference (though I'm not sure if this amount of oil is traditional). And last but not least, the green beans were way better than described in the reviews I read before coming here! They were beautifully presented in a textured stone-like oval bowl with little edible flowers, the portion was generous, and they were deliciously fried and garlicky. The four dishes came out to be $41 without tip which was reasonable for the area. To wrap it up, I would come back with friends to show them this trendy place for XLB and (pretty good) extras. If looking for a XLB place to take my Chinese parents this would not be my first choice due to the price point and younger / more hip clientele. So congrats Dumpling Time on making good Chinese food more accessible to the Mission Bay area. May the King Dum forever be a staple of foodies' Instagrams!
author: Jackie T.

description:
Dumpling Time? More like Happy Ending Time! (I'll explain later)

So straight to the dumplings, since that's in the restaurant's name, they're honestly pretty average. Nothing special, nothing particularly bad, nothing really stands out. But I looove dumplings, so I still found these so-so dumplings yummy, although a bit expensive.

I had the Pork Gyoza, the Pork Dumplings, and the Pork XLBs. The XLBs are in those shiny paper/foil cups, which I think makes it harder to eat. I'd much rather have them on a sheet in the basket.

I did have the KING-DUM, the giant soup dumpling. It's a great for photos but super awkward to eat. You basically have to poke it with a straw and drink all the soup first before you can eat the rest. It would difficult to pull the whole thing out of its container and bite it - you'd lose all the soup. It's also impossible to cut and split among people, again you'd lose all the soup. So at the end you're left eating the skin and meat with no soup. MEH, not really worth it.

For dessert I had the Happy Endings (buns). I got all 3 flavors (Trio of Buns) and they were sooo good! The Beet & Taro was my favorite, but they were all great. Super fresh, super warm, super moist, SUPER TASTY! I would come to this place and eat nothing but Happy Endings... who needs mediocre dumplings?
author: Posu Y.

description:
This place is baaaaaaaaaad. It's not authentic at all. If you are looking to take pretty photos of your dumplings, sure, swing by. But if you want hot, fresh, juicy dumplings, this is not the place. First--they serve XLB in cupcake tin foil (WTF?!?) it's appropriation of Asian culture, tbh. For 5 dishes, 2 drinks, it ended up being $90 with tax. I understand why it's popular, it's very picaresque in the age where photos are king. But it cannot be passed off as authentic "homemade" dumplings. The dumplings themselves weren't even cooked properly, overcooked imo. The meat was falling out--which is a no no. I thought the best dish were the string beans, which is saying something at a restaurant that primarily serves dumplings. 

They are trying to be din tai fung with the open viewing area where you can watch them make dumplings, but no, stop. It just doesn't work. Now if you want truly authentic Chinese dumplings, KING OF NOODLES (Irving and 17th) in the inner sunset is your place!
author: Angela H.

description:
If you eat here, you're ONLY doing it for the #gram and NOTHING else. The food is terrible. The pork dumpling was service on a plate topped with salad... That should give you a good idea of unauthentic the food is. 

The hostess was really rude too. The line was really long so I asked her if I could get a glass of water while I waited since it was a hot day outside. She aggrieved Y told me to just wait since she'll sit me soon. Then 20 minutes later and I was still waiting. Then she just walked by, shoved a can of coke in my hand, and said "I'll charge it to your tab". The level of rudeness and service from the hostess was so off putting. I asked for water while I waited in the heat and she just shoved a Coke in my hand 20 minutes later and charged it on the tab... Amazing.
author: Sue L.

description: The dumpling was awesome. Just that the king dum was hard to eat. The skin is a little thick. Also the space is pretty cramped in there. Other than that everything was really good.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Delicious, happy, delicate, affordable and the right amount of creativity. Our favorites are the  vegetarian xian dumplings and the game ban noodles(try it with their spicy mustard). The dessert buns are also amazing.
author: Amir M.

description:
That's a must try. Sooooooo goooooodddddd!!!! I loved everything. I don't understand how people can't be that harsh on their reviews for this place when everything is made from scratch (yes, you can actually see everything as the kitchen is open). It's fresh and pretty :) Yes! it looks beautiful too! 
As for the portions, they are to share ! Order a bunch and try everything! we were 3 and we odered maybe 8 dishes (meat and veggie based, as well as the trio dessert). It was $30 each, I was more than full :) 
The only down side: the line. We arrive at the opening so we had a table right away. But it worth the wait. I will definitely go back there.
author: Morgane M.

description:
get ready for unpopular opinion time. 

the sheng jing bao were kind of dry, and not crispy on the bottom, and were bland. xiao long bao were fine, but i wished there was more ginger in the vinegar dipping sauce. har gao were whatever. 

but what really got me were the noodles. we waited 40+ minutes for these noodles, after multiple waitresses came by to look at our ticket (which showed that we had not gotten the noodles), and after i inquired about their lack of presence. and then when they finally came to the table, the waitress recommended adding soy sauce and chili oil. WHAT? YOU KNOW THEY'RE SO BLAND THAT THEY REQUIRE DOCTORING? i don't get it. (and fyi, they needed copious amounts of both soy sauce and chili oil).

my friends insisted on getting sweet baos to round out the meal, even though i was done af with this place. they were soft and fluffy and filled with three different fillings. fine, but not worth it.

i was disappointed by this place. in a nutshell, it was bland and expensive and plain not worth it. go to an authentic dim sum place and be 359302923x happier.
author: Heather F.

description: One of those places I'm a little torn about. The food is basically a limited dim sum menu with a focus on all forms of dumplings. They make the trendy large soup dumplings and pan fry gyoza in the way they were suppose to be made. If it weren't for the higher prices and slightly awkward location I'd come here more often.
author: Ian C.

description: The best dumplings I've ever had.  We especially loved their desert dumplings!
author: Porter S.

description: This place is the real deal when it comes to tasty dimsums of different kinds, long waits outside with lots of young ppl on a weekday and still keep it packed at 8 30. We tried the fried chicken Japanese dumpling (my fav), veggie noodles, veggie, pork, lobster dumplings and veggie fried rolls and finished it with the sweet mix of beet, taro and green tea buns. Scrumptious
author: Gomz G.

description: Great place for dumplings, just slightly over-priced and more western style than authentic chinese style. They have a patio outside which is a plus for warm days. Food and service is fast.
author: Xi-Er D.

description: Fast, good service, food items were not bad, and attention to detail is not bad as well. Dumplings wise it's a world wide debate of what's what, but again, it's not bad. And mostly, I am not a foodie fuss. Dining is an experience for me, and I like fast, no 1hr lines, good service, and an honest environment if environment is not what it's about, blazingly beautiful environments, or a clean and balanced environment. Dumpling time's is the latter, and all the above. No fuss no headache for quick dinners or lunches. Recommend.
author: Juls C.

description:
There is something for everyone here.
The steamed dumplings (both the 4 piece and 8 piece) were excellent. I didn't love the gyoza as much as I wanted to. But the soup dumpling, wrapped in beet skin, was by far my favorite.  My friend and I were definitely satisfied but not uncomfortably stuffed.
author: Jeanine G.

description: I don't know what to think about this place. The dumpling are average, but so expensive. The waiting time is so long. I try a second time, not better. Go their for their Thai soup dampling. The reste is too average.
author: Cédric F.

description: My first experience with soup dumplings and I am so glad it was at Dumpling Time, their pork XLB is DELICIOUS and we ended up with a second order even though we were already full. We also got the garlicky green beans, Tom Yum Goong, Char-Siu Bao and Chicken Gyoza. Apart from the Pork XLB, my favorites were the Char-Siu Bao and chicken gyoza. I was stuffed and the price was reasonable, I will definitely be back for my dumpling fix!
author: Rachel N.

description: My friend and I planned a trip to SF just to try this place. We got there a little after 5:30PM and there were a lot of people already waiting and people were already seated. We thought the wait was going to be long but to our surpise we only waited about 15 minutes! We sat down, looked and our menu, and about 5 minutes, our server greeted us and took our order. We ordered the bejing noodles, the seafood gyoza, the pan seared pork bao, the king-dum (the giant xiao long bao), and the tiro. Our food came out one at a time but it didn't bother us and was expected but they came out pretty fast. The food was fresh and delicious. And, also Instagram pretty! Haha. Although, I genuinely enjoyed all the food, I definitely recommend trying their bejing noodles and their pan seared pork bao; my favorites. Overall, we had a great first time experience. The employees were friendly, especially our server. I wish I could remember his name because he was very helpful. Surprisingly, didn't have any issues finding parking. Restaurant is clean. Food was delicious. We'll definitey be back to try more things on the menu! 5 stars all around!
author: Misty T.

description: OMG! My only complaint is there isn't one closer to us inWalnut Creek. Price, service and quality of food number one
author: Sean B.

description:
this place needs work

If I were rating this place only on soup dumplings they would be a 4. But they have a lot of little issues that they need to fix. I do consider this to be top 3 dim sum in San Francisco, but dim sum in SF is sub par or over the top expensive ( why are you soup dumplings so expensive yank sing?)

In regards to their soup dumplings (xiao long bao) they are delicious. They have excellent broth with a great meat ratio but, they still have problems with tearing wrappers. They insist on those little foil cups for the dumplings and make the dumpling too large. The dumpling inevitably droops over the side of the foil cup and becomes stuck causing a tear when you try to disconnect the dumpling from foil. The XLB are just too large here. Too large for the foil cups and too large for the spoons provided. Din Tai Fung remains the master of XLB and I wish the owners of Dumpling Time would study them a little bit more. These XLB taste delicious and are the best in the city behind yank sing's over priced option.

The shrimp shumai with cilantro are some of the best tasting  shumai I have ever had. The quality of the shrimp seems high with a coarse chop and the cilantro adding great freshness. Again the wrappers are just not there. They tear very easily. 

So the service..... The service needs a lot of work. The people are friendly and totally unorganized and seeming confused. They appear to have enough staff but nobody in charge orchestrating the mass confusion. There does not appear to be any real system in place and nobody has the others back. Seems like a bunch of individual servers running around in a large space lost not working as a harmonious group. If these kids could get their stuff together they would change turn over time dramatically. On both of my visits we easily could have eaten in about 50% the time. This restaurant could turn and burn much more effectively but every server seems in the weeds. 

I really like this place and will continue to come back. Its good but it could be great. If it wanted to this place could get a Michelin star but they are very far from that currently. The flavors are excellent and some of the best in the bay.
author: Peter M.

description:
What time is it? That's right! Its Dumpling Time! Let me start by saying I'm a bit of a dumpling snob. I can be quite particular when it comes to these delicate little savory balls of dough. That said, I was incredibly pleased with this batch of NumNum! 

First up were the go-to Xiao Long Bao... For all you non-dumpling eating peasants, these are more commonly called Soup Dumplings. Why? Because they are dumplings that literally have soup inside of them. Duh. These were delicious! Perfect ratio of soup to skin (STS as I like to call it), perfect balance of flavor, and they came with a "soy-based with a bit of spicy" sauce that I poured over top (after piercing each with the chopstick to ensure perfect penetration of flavor). I have to say, they could have been hotter, but considering I ordered delivery I'm not mad. At all. 
Next up were the Seafood Gyoza with Spiced Chili Butter. These little gems of the sea must be what Ariel would get on special occasions, because they were fu**ing DELICIOUS. The green spinach wrappers did the job of making me feel like I was still being healthy... The inside was a harmonious and delectable mix of crab, shrimp, scallop, and cilantro. Once again the STS was perfect (in this case, stuffing, not soup). They came with two sauces, one of which was a basic gyoza sauce but the other was this amazing slightly spicy creamy butter sauce. These things were so good that even non seafood eaters would love them! Ok, I'm not sure about that because I wouldn't share with anyone who asked to try them... But I would bet so!

Last sample of the evening were the Maine Lobster Siu Mai. Holy S**t. Have you ever traveled to Portland? (Maine, not Oregon). Well, if you have, you know that near the wharf there are several little amazing lobster shacks, and as soon as you step anywhere near them, you can practically taste the deliciousness of the fresh crustacean in the air. Now, imagine being able to bottle up that intensity and compact it into a bite sized gem of steamed dough with chives, butter, and white truffle oil. That's exactly what these bad boys tasted like. Amazing. They did not require any sauce, but myself being a Saucy Sam, tried at least one with each of the previously mentioned sauces, and I would be lying if I said it did not make them even better. 

All in all, I ate 15 dumplings. 6 soup dumplings, 4 lobster sui may, and 5 gyoza. I could have EASILY eaten double that. Partly because I'm fat and eat too much, partly because when something is so delicious I just want to keep eating it far after I am full, but also because these bad boys are a little bit on the small side as far as dumplings go... My suggestion? Order quite a bit more than you would normally think you want, you will NOT be disappointed. And I forgot to mention... They also gave me this side of pickled Lotus and Carrot. Never had Lotus before, it was delicious.   

I cannot wait to go to this place and literally order everything off the menu. Oh damn! I think it may be Dumpling Time again....
author: Dennis P.

description:
Delicious gem at King and Division. Some seats outside, more tables inside and a nice kitchen steaming and cooking delicious dumplings and noddles.

Try the seafood gyoza they are unique, and I love the fresh noodles.
author: Yann K.

description:
I really liked many of their items and a few not as much.  We got there shortly after it opened so we didn't have to wait and got a large table to ourselves.  My top picks were:
XIao Pork XLB, Shrimp Har Gow, Pork Dumplings

Not as much:
Vegetarian Dumplings, Shrimp Toast

We also tried the Pork Bao and the sauteed snap peas.  Both were ok but nothing special.
author: Deb R.

description: The hype for this place is definitely over rated, however the food was adequate so I was not entirely disappointed. Portions are small and prices are high, but the real winner here are the dessert buns! Each flavor was unique and enjoyable. Unfortunately service can be exceptionally slow, but that is understandable considering the popularity. My reason for 4 stars rather than 5 is certainly the price of the meager portions.  Either add a dumpling or two to each order or lower the price - it's ridiculous
author: James B.

description:
Dumpling Time. Dumpling Time... Mmm mmm.  I went on a Sunday with two friends.  It was good, the stars were definitely the Pork XLB, the shrimp Har Gow and the Egg Yolk Bun for dessert.  The King Dum was a nice novelty, but I wouldn't get it again.  The soup had drained out of it by the time I got it and it was just pretty to look at, the taste was, meh.  

I would go back in a pinch, if I were in the neighborhood, but I'm not going to make a special trip for it.  I don't like the pretentiousness of a table sitting outside with a list for your name and you have to get there half an hour before it opens to have a chance and then they slowly seat people, one by one.  SF is so stuck up sometimes.

A definite plus is the patio, with a big window to watch dumplings being made.  I love watching the chefs at work and see how precise they are.  Inside was a bit crowded. They have a couple of communal tables and a movie screen at one end of the room, so if you want to entertain the littles while you eat, you have that.

The service was quick and attentive, no complaints.  Parking was easy on the street, no problems, but it was Sunday. I didn't feel that it was overly pricey for what you got in SF, but I think you could have more/same quality outside the city for less.
author: Sharon W.

description: My new favorite dumpling place. Perfect for lunch. They are quick and all of their soup dumplings are yummy.
author: Khushboo B.

description: Other people have accurately said the food is great.  The dim sum is very fresh and made with great ingredients that shine.  The service was also very good.  Our server was attentive, informative and did not rush us out of our table.  There was a bit of a wait and it can get loud in the main room so think about that if you want quiet conversation.  The sheltered patio would be better if you don't want a lot of noise.  Might also be easier for small groups to be seated.
author: Kat M.

description:
I THINK WORTH THE HYPE.
I would love to tell you, if I could, I'd eat XLBs everyday of my life. However, that sounds extremely unhealthy, so I will not do that.

As an avid, instagram food stalker, I try to find really worth it places, and this place has met my goals. I ordered the Tom Yum XLB, the King-dum (The huge XLB), Seafood Gyoza and some Char-Siu Bao (Seared, high key recommend getting them seared).

Food, it tasted great! My favorite was the Char Siu Bao honestly because it was so savory yet highly sweetened by that peanut butter sauce inside that delicious piece. The seared option was totally worth for that textured dimension. Second, the seafood gyoza caught me by surprise about how good it was, especially with the side sauce. IT WAS THICK, AND SO CREAMY. The King-dum tasted like a regular XLB, but it was obviously bigger. The soup was so savory and rich! The Tom Yum XLB, honestly are you know... ordered for aesthetics. I feel like my only problem with this meal is if you advertise a XLB to be Tom Yum, I'd kind of would except Hot Pot dripping into my mouth. The red vinegar sauce however that accompanied it was a good contrast between flavor combos!

Service: It was fast, easy, simple. I don't mind waiting, I really don't. To be fair, and to be considered, most of the time it's not the server's fault if food comes out late. Usually it's a factor of things and servers are the face of the issues set upon. But, our server came, gave us a time, and updates, and we got our food in about 15 minutes! Only thing I could be nic-picky on with this place is I asked for some food for to-go for later on the meal but they brought us just the boxes and the food in the way if it was for serving to be eaten there and we had to take care of it ourselves, which I'm not tripping that much about because they looked busy, but that's just me.

ALL IN ALL, 10/10, I'd eat here again!
author: Diane N.

description: There are so many choices and each was absolutely delicious!  Do be aware that the line can be long but the wait is not too bad and it is quite worth the time spent.  Ended up with take home boxes.  Yummy!
author: David C.

description: The food is okay, nothing to write home about.  Small portions but full portion prices.  It was busy when we went on a Tuesday night, and the service was horrible.  They took our food (three times) without asking if we were finished with it (obviously there's food left) when we were just chatting.  When the check came, the waiter stood there over our table and waited for our credit cards.  I had to tell him to give us a minute.  Don't believe we will come back.  Basically, fancy-looking dumplings with so so taste and small portions.
author: Lilian T.

description: I get the hype and don't get me wrong you have to appreciate seeing the work being done as soon as you walk in, but it sort of stops there. Presentation they are all A's, but flavors were sort of bland and it's expensive of course. Service needs work as they are slammed and can't seem to understand needs/anticipation. No one seemed to have a grip on anything here beyond the initial host. I understand that's it tough, fast and a ton of people but when it takes a while to even get greeted, that's never a good sign and ruins the overall experience. I will say however once you order that everything does begin to pick up. The XLB is a must get and I actually enjoyed the custard bun for dessert but everything else we ordered, which was most of the menu could be skipped. I don't think we'll be back.
author: Guisela L.

description: Since the XLBs at Hakkasan has been hit or miss of late (sometimes the skin would be too thick, the death of any respectable XlB), I turned my attention to see whether this place can be a replacement. Can't say it's my favorite XLB - weird to have the morsels served in little foils but the most annoying part was the vinegar  -- I prefer black vinegar but they only offer the weird tasting red ones that I do not like, and no ginger strips. Sigh. I had come when they first opened and had a really nice yuba celery salad with boiled peanuts; sadly on this second visit, he dish was botched with the weird tasting red vinegar sauce on it and chunks of carrots. It no longer tasted authentic (and is way overpriced for such a tiny portion for $5). The dumplings looked really pretty but I prefer the ones from Sang Tung. Chicken buns weredecent but ones from Out The Door are better. Good thing was that I avoided the wait entirely by coming at 2:15pm. I would not have been so happy had I have to wait for this. Solid but not great.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Overall rating: 3.5 Stars 

Came here for dinner with 2 friends to see what all the hype was about. The food was good, not mind blowing but tasty. As many others have stated, if you are a true dumpling connoisseur, then this is not the most authentic option. However, the presentation of each dish is absolutely stunning, everything comes out piping hot and the service was great, hence the 3.5 stars.

We got the following dishes:
- Garlicky green beans: Simple, straightforward veggie dish. A bit on the salty side for my taste.
- Beijing Noodles: Probably my favorite dish we got and would recommend it. The meat had lots of flavor and the noodles looked like they were very fresh, possibly hand made. Added some chili sauce and thought it was great. TIP: make sure to mix all of the noodles with the meat well, otherwise they'll seem bland.
- Char-Sui Bao (steamed): Also good. The pork filling was not overly fatty and these had good flavor. 
- Pork Xi'an Dumpling: Not my favorite. Everything was topped with edible flowers, radishes and sliced tomatoes, which did nothing to enhance the dish. I found the texture to be a bit mushy as well. I've definitely had better pork dumpling and didn't think these were anything special.
- Pork XLB: Not the best I've ever had (if you're looking for top quality XLB in the Bay Area, still have to go to Din Tai Fung), but they were good. The soup in the dumplings had good flavor, but I found them hard to eat since it was quite a challenge to pull off of the foil cups without popping them and accidentally draining the soup. 
- Tom Yum Goong XLB: To be honest, this was the dish I was most disappointed in. Don't get me wrong, they were still tasty, but I didn't thing the coconut milk flavor came through at all. Glad we tried them, but thought these were just a slightly less tasty version of the Pork XLB.
- Trio of Sweet Buns: My favorite was the Green Tea & Milk Bun, hands down, and would get these again for sure, but my friends also enjoyed the Egg Yolk Bun. Was glad we got the trio to try them all, but I was underwhelmed by the beet and taro.

I'd come back again if I was in the area. There are also a few other dishes I wouldn't mind trying, like the King Dumpling and seems like the Gyoza are popular as well, but probably wouldn't go out of my way.
author: Katie S.

description: i thought dumpling time was pretty good. and the prices are okay given the prime location - i can get XLB's within walking distance of my apartment! came here with a friend on a monday night at 6 and the place was already bustling. waited for about 15 minutes and were seated at a communal table. i wanted to try EVERYTHING, but we ordered rationally.  we got the har gow, xlb's, pan seared pork bun, seafood dumpling and an app of spicy seaweed ($5!!!! - this was ridiculous and the dish they gave you was TINY). dinner was about $30 pp after tax + tip without any drinks. i'd come back again, but only if there was no wait.
author: Christina L.

description: Here ye, here ye. King-dum has come and so i'd so it's time to bao down for some extremely tasty noms. Furthermore, the ambiance is casual and trendy and food is insta-worthy:) The shrimp toast and dessert of egg yolk buns alone would have me coming back for more. The ginormous xiao long bao aptly named King-dum is a picture worth a thousand words and comes with a tapioca straw to sip the salty goodyness that is the broth. I'll be back!
author: P C.

description: i loved Dumpling Time.  The food was terrific, fresh and just plain fun!
author: Frank S.

description: Tasty food. Love the ambiance of that place. Waiters are so dang friendly! Overall you should go!
author: Ravahere A.

description:
Located in a renovated (cough, gentrifying, cough) corridor with one of the nicest roundabouts I've seen in a while, Dumpling Time is pretty inconspicuous. But you'll recognize it by the crowds of people standing around its front parking lot. Granted, we came on Sunday afternoon, literally 15 (!!!) minutes after the restaurant opened so it was expected to be faced with a line. The restaurant isn't as big as a regular dimsum restaurant, at least not as big as the ones in the 626 or SF Chinatown. There are communal benches/tables inside the restaurant, which we snagged a table at. Pricing definitely more expensive than regular dimsum restaurants, without the push carts. The nice waitress told us that everything's made to order so you basically should order everything you want at once. 
We ordered the tom yum soup dumplings, the regular ones, the pan fried pork buns, and the shrimp toast. I loved the shrimp toast. It's so innovative, especially since I love you tiaos (they're so bad for you but its so gooooddd). They somehow spread the shrimp paste on top and fry it together. The tom yum soup dumplings has a coconut soup base and was like drinking the bottled coconut water. Nice to stop every once in a while when I dont want to drive to Chinatown.
author: Michelle R.

description: Come back again!!! Today I got my favorite dishes again. There are Xue long buo, pork dumping and trio bun. They're so good. I recommend these dishes!!! Love this place.
author: Nam T.

description:
This place is really more like a 3.5 stars.  

I came here when they were still relatively new.  It seemed they didn't quite have their operation down yet.  We waited for about 15 minutes which wasn't bad and the guy who ended up seating us was quite apologetic (though it really wasn't even his fault).

Between my boyfriend and I, we ordered the har gow, pork XLB, xi'an pork dumplings, gan ban noodles, and the happy endings buns (trio).  The har gow and xi'an pork dumplings were  good.  However, I was disappointed by the XLB.  I was hoping this place would have good XLB since it's a dumpling place, but the XLB weren't as soupy as I thought and the skin was kind of thick.  The gan ban noodles also were meh.  To be fair, we really wanted the beijing noodles, but they sold out when we were there.  

The (desert) trio buns were pretty good.

Overall, I'd still go back to this place because it's the closest asian place to my house (probably).  I'd like to go back and try the beijing noodles, but I'd stay away from the XLB.
author: Carrie L.

description:
Very tasty and handmade fresh food with excellent service. Every single items on the menu is freshly house made by hand, which not many dim sum places actually can do, so I should say it's very reasonable price. Waiters look busy but skilled and give their tables enough attention and friendly service. Good job! 
Baijing noodles, shrimp haw gao (with house made cilantro source), and seafood gyoza(with house made chili butter source) are must. 
I tried every single items on the menu and everything is good but you should definitely try those ones if you are going for the first time.
author: Chika O.

description: Nice presentation and taste. It is good to try the new way of dumping. It will explore your mind:)
author: Mindy Y.

description: Incredible good at a jaw-dropping low price! Highly recommend! The line is intimidating at first, but it goes by really quickly. Great atmosphere, awesome food, and kind staff!
author: Sana I.

description:
Food is good, typical Chinese food restaurant service( take down what you want, serve you, and leave you alone until you are done), pretty hipster place. My wife and I had shrimp toast (fried shrimp paste patty over Chinese doughnut) which was surprisingly good, soup dumplings, shrimp gyoza, pork dumplings, and trio dessert baos. A little pricey for what it was, but quality was good and I didn't have to catch an elbow from a little Chinese lady trying order dim sum. All in all, I'd come back. 

I do have to say that it was a little weird to have the soup dumplings served in little egg tart dishes.
author: Michael H.

description: My favorite spot in the design district. They always have a line so make sure to get here early. The food is definitely Asian fusion but based on the large number Asians that frequent the establishment, you can be assured you're in good hands. Try out the all the different categories. You can't go wrong
author: Kenzan T.

description: Solid addition to the neighborhood. Great variety and great staff. They get overwhelmed when they get busy and the wait can be a bit taxing so I encourage, if you can, to just do takeout as you can get the great food in a fraction of the time and enjoy it in a much less chaotic setting.  Definitely ask for staff recommendations. They will steer you right.
author: Jake W.

description: LOVE this place. A little gem that opened in my neighborhood. Always great food, fast. But be prepared to wait, they have a following!
author: The Style R.

description: Loved this place.  Shrimp toast is a must.  Their gyozas are also delicious and so is their soup dumplings.  There's a wait but you can sit in a communal table if you want!
author: Raphael R.

description:
It's worth going to if you want this kind of food in SF, but just tamper your expectations on the xiao long bao.

Food:
The Beijing noodles were good. The pork and chicken gyoza (pan-fried dumplings) were good. The chicken bao (steamed bun) was good... But the xiao long baos (soup dumplings) left something to be desired -- we tried the pork xlb and the tom yum goong. With the name of the place being Dumpling Time, I was expecting the soup dumplings to be the star of the show, but they were not. They were on the bland side and did not have a satisfying balance of skin, soup and filling. I've definitely had better xlb, especially since I'm from the San Gabriel Valley where there is a lot of good Chinese food.

Environment:
Definitely not the classic Chinese restaurant vibe -- but that's not a bad thing, it's just different. I could tell that this is more modernized or Americanized, or that it is Asian fusion. Again, not a bad thing. The interior is comfortable and clean and there is the choice of outdoor seating as well. There is the luxury of free street parking nearby. Service was fast and friendly.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Nice! The food was delicious and creative, the service was excellent and I was really pretty happy.

We were a large group and tried almost everything dim sum on the menu. And they were all great;  not one miss. The ginger garlic snap peas were good to cut down on some of the porky richness and I wish we'd ordered more vegetables. Oh well.

Drawbacks
It was loud and hard to talk across the table. Also it's not cheap, but definitely a fair price for what you get. And the bathroom is through an empty warehouse...a little creepy. If I'd brought a bottle of wine I wouldn't have cared about any of that! Next time.
author: El B.
