description: Very cute ambiance, I came here a few times but the wait was over an hour so we always left. This time we came 10mins before they opened at11am on a Saturday and was seated right at 11! We came for the king xiao long bao that was so well known for the size and how you have to drink it with a boba straw. It was very juicy and delicious. We also ordered the shrimp toast, shrimp and chive dumpling and trio bun. All very tasty which is good when you're paying a premium for the ambiance and Instagram worthy foods.
author: Judy N.

description: Trending fun spot to dine, extremely popular among the young San Franciscans. Definitely worth it to try and judge for your self. Creative big bun, small bun, and sweet bun desserts! I would vote 5 star for the desserts. The shrimp paste is quite popular here too. Overall it's not a place I will keep coming back, but definitely creative.
author: Dilys S.

description: When we got here, I expected the wait to be pretty long, since it is a trendy asian fusion place in the trendy hip dog patch area near SOMA and AT&T park.  The wait wasn't too long (~15 min) for Sunday noon time, and parking was not bad either.  The server was very nice and recommended pretty good items.  We had the shrimp toast (crispy fried chinese donut topped with a savory shrimp paste), Beijing noodles (minced pork in a savory black bean paste sauce with cold noodles), pork gyoza (pan fried), char siu bao (pan fried bbq pork buns), and pork xiao long bao (small steammed dumplings containing pork ginger and some soup/broth).  Overall the food was great.  Portions on the lighter side compared to the price, but guessing it is quality over quantity, and paying for the trendy environment.  Besides the price and somewhat smaller space (especially if you have a kid, as I do), the only other drawback preventing me from giving this place a 5 is they sold out of the giant Xiao Long Bao (literally a super size version of the pork xiao long bao, where you need a straw to drink the soup out of the dumpling).  They said that only about 25 are made for lunch and dinner service, each, so get there early for either service to get your chance at it.
author: Raymond F.

description:
My fellow dumpling enthusiast friend and I were really excited to try this new place on a Monday afternoon right before the lunch crowd. We found metered parking across the street and were seated immediately. 

Items ordered: 

1. Shrimp Toast / $8 for 6 pieces: Shrimp paste topped on a youtiao (Chinese donut) w/ spicy alioli and cilantro garnish. The shrimp and alioli paired well but our youtiao was clearly a leftover because they had to refry it. The inner portion that should be doughy was overfried, drenched in oil, and way too crunchy. 

2. Beijing Noodles/ $9: Good chewy noodles topped with seasoned ground pork. 

3. Tom Yum Goong/ $7 for 6 pieces: The beet skin turned an unsavory color after being steamed but what was really disappointing was the lack of Tom Yum flavor. The coconut flavor was really subtle and I'm not sure you can really call it Tom Yum if it lacks the tanginess of the lime or kick of lemongrass, chilis, etc. The pork filling was also a bit mushy. 

4. Xi'an Pork Dumplings / $8 for 8 pieces: This dish was probably the most disappointing of all. The dish was topped with sliced radishes, halved cherry tomatoes and sprouts that did nothing to enhance the flavor. The skin was too doughy and even stuck to my teeth as I chewed it. The filling was also mushy and nearly tasteless. 

5. Egg Yolk Bun / $5.50 for 3 buns: This was probably the best of the bunch. The bun consistency was fluffy and the filling was tasty. 

It was great to try some place new but hopefully they improve their recipes because the ideas are creative but execution was poor.
author: Connie C.

description: I'm not a huge fan of XLB (I know, I know, don't judge!) but I enjoyed Dumpling Time. We ordered the Tom Yum Goong and King-Dum XLB. The King-Dum was okay, ordered mainly for the gram. It was just too big and not very practical to eat while trying to slurp up soup. My favorite dish was the green tea and milk bun. Yum! The wait here is kinda long, but typical for most SF restaurants. There isn't much else to do in the area, but we managed to kill time by getting boba from Urban Rituals down the block. Parking here is fairly easy--street parking with no meters.
author: Lily Z.

description: This place is amazing!!!! Shrimp toast is way better then it sounds! Dumpling did. It disappoint either. It's a little out of the way but worth it.
author: Richard P.

description: It is ok for me except XLB is good (soupy)
author: Liz S.

description:
We came early for the Saturday 5:30 seating. There were at least 40 people ahead of us but we made the first seating. The room is noisy and hard to talk to people across the table. FYI, No liquor license and we did not ask if it was ok for BYOB.  We tried every category for a variety and some 2x. The orders were brought out at randomly. The spicy green bean appetizer came out last??? 
Some of our favorites were: 
 Pork XLB - $8. Yummy! Piping hot, filled with broth and Pork belly
Tom Yum Goong - $9. My Favorite! The beet red dumpling skins with Pork and a Tom yum broth.  

Least Favorite: Shrimp toast. Greasy calories.

We will be back! Time it so you do not have to wait too long.  Good value, good variety and a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Jane H.

description: Besides my family, I don't know if I love anything more than dumpling time. The soup dumplings are a colorful explosion of flavor in your mouth, it is cheap, quick, and delicious. Whatever hardship you are having in your life can be mended by dumpling time.
author: Landon E.

description:
Restaurant's team can't manage time flow to save their lives. We got an estimate of 20-30min wait time that turned into over 1hr and 15min.

Food was good, but totally not worth the wait. Staff was not helpful and service simply overall sucked. Waited 30min to get a glass a water. Server communication and recommendations are non existent.

Note to management: if you don't take reservations, at least put someone outside of the door who knows what's happening. Also, hire someone who had experience tending customers.
author: Chip S.

description: I like like like it, the food is tasty and the ingredients are fresh. Modern dumpling!
author: FL D.

description:
I wanted to love this place. Saw this place on Yelp and was attracted to their plating and how pretty all their dishes looked, but it looks better than it tastes. 

My friends and I all really liked the tom yom XLB. I think that one had more flavor than the pork XLB. We also got their specialty dumplings that reminded me of the spicy wontons from Din Tai Fung. Beijing noodles were good but not something I would order again. The noodles itself were soft and chewy. 

We came about 20 mins early, wrote our name down on the waitlist and walked around. They didn't start seating people until 11:05? 

Service was quick and friendly. Not your typical Asian restaurant with poor service.
author: Lynn H.

description:
This place was pretty cool, and had some decent Xiao Long Bao.  We had the Shrimp Dumplings, Tom Yum Xiao Long Bao, and the giant Xiao Long Bao.  
I thought all the food was pretty good, our server was pretty friendly and informative, and the atmosphere was nice.  

The main item we had come for was the giant Xiao Long Bao, and they were pretty good, but nothing amazing.  It was interesting seeing how large they were and drinking the soup through the boba straw (what do they do with the other half of the straw??) but beyond the novelty factor it was just alright.  

I'd probably come back here if I happened to be in the area, it was a fairly nice place with some interesting food.
author: Keith C.

description: This place broke da mouth!  Ono kind grinds.  Best dim sum I may have ever had!  Wonderful flavor combinations backed by raucous atmosphere complete with k-pop wall of videos, killer quick and knowledgeable staff.  The meal we've all been waiting for.   I cannot praise this place and it's offerings enough. Genius Shanghai noodles, soup dumplings to lift the spirits, mixed seafood dumplings with incredible spicy garlic sauce.  Pillowy char Su Bao, shiu mai that smells like heaven with a gorgeous texture and none of the usual pitfalls.  All of this and tons more - not to mention the with masterful sauce work.  I shall return again and again with more and more friends.  This place is the stuff of legends.
author: Sonia K.

description: Horrible customer service. They would not seat my group of 4. 6 groups went ahead of us. I asked why it was taking so long for our group to get in, the lady at the told me that they only had seats of 2 or 3, not 4 so we couldn't get in. there's no wait time, there only SEAT WAIT. you're literally fucking waiting for an exact number of seats. They don't prioritize bigger groups either. We literally got there at 12, and waited till 12:40 and watched countless of groups that came before us go in. Horrible strategy. It's definitely NOT FIRST COME FIRST SERVED.
author: Michelle N.

description: Came here a few weeks ago - wait time was fine for a Thursday evening. LOVED the bbq pork dumplings (steamed and fried). Loved the shrimp and pork shao mai and of course the pork XLB. We had some great sake as well!
author: N M.

description: Shrimp toast, seafood gyoza, pan fried pork bao, shrimp har gow, pork and shrimp siumai. That should be your order. Thank me later
author: Teresa Z.

description: This business is open from 5-11pm on Saturday. We came at 6:35pm. They said they would not take our name down (a party of two) because they will have no more food by the time they get to us. There were only about 15 parties on the list ahead of where we would have been. You're telling me you can only manage 90 minutes of service in a 6 hour dinner window? That's so completely unacceptable and unprofessional. I will definitely not return here - especially since it also happens to be located in a very sketchy area.
author: Tay H.

description: Hands down the most authentic dumplings you'll have in the city. So many unique types of dumplings and dim sums that are all savory, authentic and delicious! :-) very easy parking is also another plus!
author: Risako S.

description: This was our first time here and it won't be our last. The staff was very friendly and provided great service. The food was delicious. Everything was freshly prepared and flavorful. The plates were beautifully prepared.
author: Myra D.

description: 09/20/18 evening Service was super slow they have 1 server taking orders . For the whole place indoor and 2 person running orders to customers . Got to the restaurant was 20 minutes wait . Got seated the guys running orders serve brought a carafe if water but no cups 7 to 10 mins later our sever came by saw that we got no cups decide to give us cups . Then 5 to 10 mins later to take our orders . Honestly if they want more customers I would advice getting more server cause 1 server to take orders for the whole restaurant no wonder there's a long wait time . The food was ok not sure if the fusion works for dim sum . BBQ pork bun with peanuts it's ok not authentic at all  wouldn't order it again . Wayu goza I wouldn't waste good beef on a goza . Shrimp toast was good without the sauce. The noodles was ok not what I like wouldn't order it again . Not sure is this place consider dim sum too much fusion in the menu . Not sure if the wanted the place to be Chinese dim sum , Thai dim sum , Japanese dim sum or American version dim sum . The spare ribs lacks flavors . There's just too much fusion in the food . I would rather prefer authentic Chinese dim sum versus the fusion  . The fusion makes the place look lost and trying to find its identity where it look lost and can't find its own identity. Service was also slow couldn't order more drinks due to 1 server it also took another 15 mins just to pay the bill . Would I come back if the add more servers maybe I would but the food was ok not worth my time to wait... ...
author: Hannah M.

description:
Way too overpriced mediocre food. Service is good but not worth the price. Quality is just ok. You can be in sunset or Richmond and get same quality for double the amount for half the price.

Price:
Let me be more specific. We spent $20/person ended up with a half filled stomach without ordering drink. So in order to fill us up, it would've cost $40 without drink. But given the environment, this place should cost $30 with a drink per person.

Environment:
Noisy, crowded, long wait for the table, long wait for food.

Food:
Most are ok level, very small portion. Beijing Noodle is terrible. The flavor is wrong, the way they cook it is wrong, and it taste like oily dust, and it's a $9 noodle that would normally cost you $3.5 (because the portion is only half as much as other places). 
All dumplings have the same filling although they were given different names. And they are very small. If you think 10 dumplings can fill you up, you need 20 here. 
String bean is as good as you can get in any Chinese restaurants. 
And they give you one dish at a time, with another 5 min wait time for the next dish.
Overall unimpressive taste, tiny portion, slow process.

Service:
Good (not great). 

Overall:
Don't waste your time/money. You can find better Chinese food in sunset/chinatown for half the price or less. Or you can spend the same amount for a much fancier place.
They think they can give you good enough service in a crappy environment with mediocre food and charge you money like a fancier fine dine. But it's just fast food quality with fine dine speed.
author: Edmund L.

description:
This is one of those "cursed" locations where restaurants come and go with little notice. Dumpling Time looks like it could have a good run by the line of people waiting to be seated. We arrived at 6:30 and were not seated until 7. 

This is a VERY very meaty place. We are pescatarians and so do not usually have a problem finding what to enjoy from a menu but Dumpling Time insists on adding PORK to nearly every dish. Why? Oh, why, spoil shrimps and cilantro by adding "juicy" pork? The vegetarian dumplings just plain tasted bad but looked attractive. The best items for us were the garlicky green beans and ginger beans. Not much to fill up on. Our friends (meat eaters) enjoyed it.. My husband and I will not be returning.
author: Lynka A.

description:
The food was tasty but I didn't like how the portions were small. You need to order 2-3 items per person to be full. The Beijing noodles topped with meat bits and sauce  was good but was finished in 5 bites. The Xian pork dumplings (boiled dumplings) were also good but wasn't the highlight. The pork XLBs were the star of the show. Lots of soup inside although not a lot of meat filling. I liked how the juice bursts in your mouth filling it with flavor.  The egg yolk buns tasted like something you can get from any ol Chinese restaurant. I probably won't get this again. 

Overall good food but overpriced for the portions in comparison to other dumpling places.  Seems more of a trendy establishment. 3.5 stars.
author: Ali F.

description:
Overrated and overpriced. 

Beijing noodles, great. Really Small portions. 

Good XLBs are never in foils. 

The end.
author: Ken C.

description:
Hipster dim sum. While I can understand that some people love this place, the prices do not justify the quantity/quality for me. Also, this is a fun place for dinner with friends, but probably not for your Asian grandparents. I would note that their food presentation is pretty good if you're trying to flex on Instagram.

What I liked:
* Fun, hip environment. They have K-Pop videos projected on the wall and the restaurant looks almost like a diner to me. 
* The dishes we ordered were overall tasty (xiao long bao, har gow, vegetable dumplings, green tea & milk bun, beet & taro bun). I really enjoyed the green tea & milk buns in particular and they were the perfect sweetness level for me.

What I disliked:
* Prices don't justify the food in my opinion. $8.50 for six pieces of xiao long bao? Xiao long bao are already small, comon man.

If it wasn't for the prices, I would have rated it 4 stars.
author: Michael M.

description: Great ingredients, authentic tea choices, some parking spots, worth the price. One of the better Chinese restaurants around San Francisco
author: Wats S.

description: Some of the best dumplings in SF! A little pricier than your typical dumpling and usually a long wait for the table but it is so worth it.
author: Madie H.

description:
I was lucky enough to attend the preopening party last night and had such a great time. The restaurant is airy and the seating is comfortable and not too crowded. Of the dishes I tried yesterday, I really loved the Xi'an vegetarian dumpling. The flavor of the vegetables and the dumpling skin was the perfect amount of chewy yet tender. The XLB may just be the best I've had in the city so far - tons of broth inside, the top knot was soft, the skin was very thin. The shrimp toast was another favorite - perfectly crispy on the outside, just enough chewy on the inside without being overly oily and really fresh shrimp paste. The pan seared pork and veggie bao (生煎包) was also really tasty. The bottom was just seared just enough without being tough or burnt tasting and the filling was flavorful and moist, just like it should be! The green tea bun with creamy milk filling was the perfect amount of sweet to end the meal. 

As a novice home cook, I loved watching the dumplings and baos being made in the glass enclosed room. The amount of skill used to perfect the many different types of dumpling skins and bao doughs is awe-inspiring and I can just watch the chefs work all day. 

Dumpling Time is a perfect place to bring your date, your family, your birthday gathering and your kids will love watching the dumplings being made. What a great addition to the neighborhood and the city as a whole! I really look forward to their official opening because I can't wait to try more of their dumplings and revisit my favorites.
author: Veronica C.

description:
My current favorite Dumpling spot. I have enjoyed almost everything I have had here.
The Shrimp Toast, Seafood Gyoza and the TOM YUM GOONG are my top choice.
Lunches can involve a wait. The prices are higher than traditional dumpling restaurants. I think it is worth it
author: Dennis M.

description:
3.5 stars.  We ordered shrimp toast, seafood gyoza, tom yum goong xlb, and pork gyoza.  The shrimp toast was awesome.  Best item by far.  The dough for the gyoza and xlb we ordered got unappealingly soft very quickly, so the dumplings are better if you eat them very quickly.  Like right as they are set down.  The seafood gyoza - if eaten quickly - are really good, especially in the butter sauce, which is like a thin beurre blanc.  The xlb was decent, but a little sweet for me.  I think they switched the filling of the pork gyoza with the cabbage and pork dumpling.  Maybe just an error.  I didn't ask, as we had already been there for awhile.  But next time, I would specify before ordering to make sure.  It was pretty chunky with unexpected pieces of cabbage.  I definitely missed the advertised ginger.  

The restaurant is new and busy and the service is still finding it's way.  It was a little chaotic with multiple people trying to take our order and checking in often, but everyone was very earnest and friendly.  I'm sure it will iron out.
author: Amber B.

description:
My husband and i happen to live across the street (note to another reviewer: the neighborhood isn't THAT sketchy) - as in, we can see Dumpling Time from our bedroom window. Luckily, as a result, we noticed it opened a few days early and popped over for dinner on Thursday before the lines started to wrap around the block.

Everything was absolutely fantastic! Full disclosure: I'm pregnant, so we ordered about 80% of the menu since my only remaining vice is food. We loved everything we got - my favorites were the pork gyoza, pork dumplings, and pork bao (sensing a theme?); my husband LOVED the seafood gyoza and shrimp dumplings (another theme).

We did notice by Friday & Saturday people were lining up early and wait times seemed long - I'm surprised they had ANYTHING left for dinner on Saturday after the insane lunch crowd.

We're big fans of the Omakase Restaurant Group (Kash and Edgar always impress!), and I'm confident any kinks will be worked out in a matter of days.

In the meantime, I'm just hoping for the lines to die down so I can go eat there more often!
author: Carrie W.

description:
This place would have been a 5/5 if I were just judging based on XLBs. But unfortunately, I ordered other dishes and was disappointed with them. 

Came here on a Tuesday night around 6pm, there wasn't really a wait, probably 5 minutes, but after we left, there were definitely more people, perhaps 6 parties waiting. Parking was average, perhaps I got lucky with street parking. Interior is pretty small but dishes are washed pretty clean. 

XLBs: Probably one of the better XLBs I've had in NorCal. Up there with DTF and perhaps even jucier. It came in a steamer with 6. I'm not really a fan of the foil cups that they use when steaming them, but it wasn't too much of a pain to take them out. Occasionally they would get stuck and the XLB would break apart. 

Pork Gyoza: Basically pot stickers. The filling was delicious, with meat and some veges, but my major problem was with the dough itself. It was very sticky and strange. IMO, the dough shouldn't be stick and should be more on the crispy side. Perhaps it's something they put in the dough. But flavor was good, not too salty. 

Steamed Dumplings: Very unimpressed. They added some sort of salad decoration on top. The dumplings were tiny and contained little to no meat. The bulk of the dumpling was the dough, which was also a similar consistency as the gyoza, sticky. Would not recommend. 

Beijing Noodles: Basically minced pork noodles. Zha Jiang Mian. So nothing really special there. They use flat noodles instead of round ones. Overall flavor was decent. Not too salty, which can often be the problem. 

Would come back if I were in the area. 
Probably would not recommend waiting if it's over 35 minutes. 
Get the XLBs for sure. Gyozas if you must.
author: Scott K.

description: Went here for date night since I have been wanting to go since it opened. We got there at 5:20 before it even opened and we were the 5th group there which the list quickly filled up behind us. The food was amazing so worth the hype, although the metal liners made it difficult to get the soup dumplings out without puncturing them. The king is fun for photos and still delicious but more of a one time thing for pictures. We will be going back again soon.
author: GIna K.

description:
GIANT XLB is what I came here for, but of course I got other stuff too. 

Shrimp Toast: was not what I thought it was going to be. It was a Chinese donut with shrimp on top, cilantro, and some sauce. Wish they put more sauce or had it on the side for dipping
Tom Yum Goong XLB: I thought they just tasted like regular Xiao Long Bao. Didn't really taste the tom yum flavors. 
KING-DUM: their giant XLB, i thought it was going to be bigger. so I was slightly disappointed in its size. BUT this was probably my favorite thing. SO JUICY!
Xi'An vegeterian dumpling: not a fan. presentation was nice, but the sauce was overpowering. I think i was eating a dumpling wrapped salad? 
XL Pork Bao: It was not XL. I was so sad. It was just a regular sized bao.. but considered XL compared to their regular sized baos. Tasted just ok to me. 
Trio of buns: not bad. flavors in the green tea and taro ones weren't too strong though. egg yolk bun was better than what iIve had at other places.
Beijing Noodles: pretty good and flavorful. 

I probably wouldn't come back again unless I want a giant xiao long bao.
author: Lina C.

description:
Food was awesome. Best dumplings in city, and great variety -- XLB, gyoza and  dim sum. Purist or not, you'll love it. 

And if you don't, less wait for me and all the other people who love this place.
author: Ryan C.

description: Gan ban noodles and pork dumplings. No words. The dumpling skin was delish but doughy, which I liked, but it may not up everyone's alley. All in all a very worthwhile visit. Did not wait long on a Monday evening at 6:45pm. But the dining room was full.
author: Alice W.

description: I came here for a friend's birthday for the first time. We ordered many items on the menu and each one tasted really good. My personal favorite was the Xiao Long Bao. The employees were accommodating. I would definitely come back here again.
author: Amy H.

description:
I was so excited to see a dumpling place open near work! Yahoo!

Tuesday lunch around 12:30-1, for 4, sat easily. No real wait. But also day after memorial day so maybe that's why a little slower? Or the hype died from when they first opened.

Anyways we ordered:
shrimp toast- yes, definitely a yes, crunchy, toasty, yummy shrimp!
shrimp and cilantro ha gow- nice chunks of shrimp, it came with a cilantro aioli too? tasted pesto-ish, but yummy.
seafood gyoza- pretty tasty, seared really nicely.
cha siu bun- we got it pan seared, I could skip this, it was average.
beijing noodles- pass, the noodles were on the softer side, and the grounded beef? was ok.
pork xlb- yummy, super juicy.
tom yum xlb- it was ok, like others say, you don't taste the tom yum.
trio dessert bao sampler- this was fun to share, nice sweet (but not overly sweet) finishing to our meal.

About $68 for 4, plus tip, around $20 a person. So not TOO bad, I was full, but the guys were saying how it was good but they'd be hungry in like an hour.

Area isn't too bad, can seem sketchy, half of the staff were really nice, the other half had the RBF or couldn't be bothered. I mighttt be back, with other coworkers! Oh and the wall decor art was really cool.
author: Christine M.

description:
Was very excited for dumplings and came to this place. First time  I siting this restaurant. Upon entering the manager walked to me, coughed all over me. Then proceeded to tell me they were all sold out of food? This is 8pm and they close at 11pm? I've literally never been to a restaurant that said they were sold out of food. I thought he was joking at first. I saw them seat multiple people right in front of me then told us we had to leave because they had no food. Like how as a restaurant are you completely out of everything. 

Literally the worst possible way to welcome any new customer.
author: Alex H.

description:
This place is poppin!

FOOD:
Garlicky green beans: kind of a smaller portion than I expected, and had a lot of garnish on it (not sure it needed it) and seems twice fried, but gotta get my greens :) this was aite, I'd order again just to eat veggies 

Pork gyoza: deslish! Perfectly crispy bottom and steamed top. This was done more traditionally than the other gyozas.

Seafood gyoza: think butter shrimp. Loved the flavor combo, definitely a fusion item. The sauce was a butter sauce 

Pork XLB: yummy!!! Extra soupy, which I loved. It comes in a tin foil bottom, which I carefully extracted from to eat in the perfect bite

Char-sua bao (BBQ pork): great! It is sweet, as expected but doesn't have that neon red glow that youre like where does this come from? 

Green tea and milk bun: green tea bun and milk cream filling. This came out with the main food, but we kept the lid on and it stayed warm till we were ready! It had a cute dumpling time stamp on it 

AMBIANCE:
It's got that "cool" vibe. Neon pink signage on the inside, back wall playing full screen K-pop mvs, and the crowd seemed like that sf foodie young profeah crowd (young-ish? 30's?) But there were families too

WAIT TIME: 30 mins yesterday on a Wednesday night. This place is new but everyone wants to try it!

SERVICE:
Seating hostess was great! And our waitress super sweet, they are doing a great job here!
author: Janet K.

description:
Delicious dumplings - loved the seafood gyoza, pork XLB and vegetarian dumplings, all excellent. 

Executing dumplings made to order is a respectable feat but it was very apparent in the wait time...both for a table and after ordering. While I truly enjoyed and appreciate watching the dumplings be made by hand, we waited for these items for over an hour and had to cancel the green beans which never came. All in all, if you're not in a rush and looking for some amazing dumplings, check this place out.
author: Morgan B.

description: Dumplings were very good! We had xiaolongbao, the king xiaolong bao, smaller shrimp dumplings, and the salad. Would recommend everything except the king, unless for novelty and snapchat purposes. The insides were clumped together and not very appetizing after the initial puncture. We got there right at 5pm and waited maybe 5 min to be seated. Would definitely return if I have time!
author: Dee Dee T.

description:
Worst dining experience I've had in years. 

Showed up at 7:30 on a Thursday with a party of 6. It took us an hour and a half to get seated. Meanwhile, 12 parties who arrived after us got seated. That's a minimum of 24 people. Basic math: 24 is a lot more than 6. At the very least they could have warned us and broken us up, but they didn't tell us they might need to break us up until after an hour wait, although they did ultimately seat us together. Absolutely garbage table/waitlist management.

In fairness to them, they gave us free small bites as a consolation. They were ok. I appreciate they recognize they done effed up.

By the time they sat us, I was legit ANGRY, but we'd already sank the time and it was late enough that most restaurants would have closed down already. We ordered x'ian dumpling, regular pork xiaolongbao (they'd sold out of the giant ones), and pork buns.

With that wait, I would have been placated if the food was great. And after all it was... ok. I liked X'ian Dumplings the best, something different. The XLB and bao... I've had better, I've had worse. Very middle of the road. I was crazy hungry at this point, and even with hunger bonus points, I wasn't particularly impressed. 3/5, maybe 3.5/5 if I wasn't so pissed.

I was really excited about this place because the food scene (and especially the Asian food scene) in Soma is terrible and the prices are great for SF. But it was a pretty terrible experience. MAYBE once they've been open a bit longer they'll get their crap together, but it'll be a while before I give them another shot.
author: David C.

description:
The boss and I treked here from the Omni, DAMNED GOOGLE MAPS! ;-) The 2 mile walk turned into 5, but it was worth it in the end!

Ambiance, zero. Service, 3, food,,,,,,,, 5! Tried the Cukes and the Lotus Root apps, both were really good! Chicken Bow Seared had great texture and taste. Seafood Gyozas also possessed a great texture and quality seafood flavor. Tom Yum Goong were the best XLB's either of us have had, juicer and tastier than any of the DTF's we have been too which is supposed to set the standard. Last but not least was the Shrimp Toast, wifeypie declared the order the best thing to hit the table.  I walked in with reservations as I am not big on fusion anything but this place blew us both away. 

Thanks Yelp for the great suggestion, Thanks wifeypie for finding it, and thanks Google Maps for making me get my walk on!

Humbly submitted,

Moi
author: Dave L.

description:
Dumpling Time is the newest gem in this design store wasteland, brought to you by the same folks at Omakase and Okane. 

If you're looking for a long, relaxed meal to chat with friends, this isn't it. The restaurant is a well oiled machine (despite being open for only 4 weeks), churning out dumplings and other goodies quickly. Multiple dishes came out at once, leaving us stuffing our mouths before we were too full. Both a good and a bad thing. 

Our waitress suggested our table get 3-4 dishes per person. Everything sounded quite delicious, so we asked her to pick 12 items for our party of 4 and surprise us. 

Notables of the meal:
- char siu bao, fluffy and falls apart right in your mouth 
- seafood gyoza
- shrimp toast
- pork xlb
- tom yum goong

We didn't go wrong with any of the picks. 

I would go as group so you can sample more dishes. First come, first served seating. You'll only be seated if your party is complete. Parties of 2 might be seated at the end of tables for a bit of communal style eating. 

Their credit card machines went down when we were about to pay so my group had to scramble to pool together enough cash (~$88 pre-tip).
author: Paulina D.

description:
Got there around 5:15pm and there was a line of about 4-5 ppl in front of us. We can tell the staff was still new and still figuring out the logistics which was fine since they've only been opened for a wk. 

XLB and Giant XLB  - Super 5 Stars! Delicious with perfect balance of soup and meat. Not too piping hot where you'll burn your mouth. You can taste and chew on big chunks of shrimp..big plus! However, were disappointed when we went to order more that there was a limited of 2 orders per table. Perhaps they were wanting to turn the tables faster? I find that hard to believe especially since we had to wait nearly 30 mins for our last dish, the Beijing noodles. Again, I attribute it the super green staff and would expect that to improve. 

Seafood Gyoza 4/5
Beijing noodles 3.5/5- a bit salty for my taste or maybe add more noodles
Shrimp Har Gow with cream cheese 3/5- I prefer the traditional dim sum one
Ck seared Bao 3/5
X'ian pork dumplings 3/5

Everything was beautiful plated and loved the attention to details. Can't wait to come back for more XLB and hopefully they won't limit us then!
author: Suzie J.

description:
We arrived at 12:25pm on a Sunday, and wait was only 5 mins for us.  When we came out at 1:20, there were lots of people waiting though.

Inside was clean, servers were friendly, and there were vegetarian dumplings and a noodle dish, which is great because my partner is vegetarian.

But unfortunately food itself was not good.  Yuba in an appetizer was still very hard -- it was not prepared right.  Skins of dumplings were too thick and felt heavy.  Noodles were too oily and too soft.  King XLB was the worst.  The top part was not cooked enough. It was too hard to cut with chopsticks.  The skin of the bao was very thick, actually it was too thick to eat, but there must have been a hole on the bottom of the bao because most of soup was spilled on the dish under the steamer.
author: Akiko O.

description: So delicious! I like the Gan Bang Noodle! Zucchini, eggs & mushroom make a good taste! Can't believe it's without meat!!
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
Me and my friend were getting a Thai massage nearby this place and saw a line of people waiting for this restaurant, so we decided to give this place a shot!
Turns out they just opened very recently, inside looks very new and clean, and you can see all the chefs making the dumplings from scratch.
Everything we tried was really good!! and bill was only about 60$ for 2person and we ate ALOT..great value.

Green beans - I wish they had rice, but this was my favorite side dish.
Lotus root salad - nice texture and this was also my memorable favorite.

Shrimp har gow - nice and soft, creamy feel to it, recommended with cilantro!
Tom yum goong - server recommended us this one and we loved it, I've had good XLB before but I found this one to be pretty distinct too.

Not to mention I'm a sucker for sweets and they have desert buns.. the green tea milk buns were out of this world and we ordered second rounds.. yep, 6pc of desert buns for us. We hope to come back next time and try the other ones like beet & taro too.
Overall experience was pretty good..we walked out happily with full of carbs in our belly, will def come back!
author: Mario K.

description:
A very busy place - went on a weeknight, so our wait was only 20 minutes.  the service from ordering to table is very quick.

Food selection is great!  I don't need to write anymore about what has already been said. 

Coming back next time for the KING DUM!
author: R M.

description: This is the only Chinese restaurant in the design district and SOMA area. This restaurant replaced a vegetarian place that went down. While the XLB's here have wrapping that's thicker than something like Ding Tai Fung, the flavor of every dish is quite good and authentic. The main dish I like here are the noodles which have a great chewy texture.
author: Thomas C.

description:
I wasn't expecting much until I found out it's by the same owners as Live Sushi down the street in Potrero and also run by the same awesome wonderfully hospitable manager Cindy. :) Even then I wasn't expecting much since their other restaurants aren't Chinese cuisine AND there isn't much Chinese food in this area of town period. 

Rating: DELICIOUS! 

Celery, yuba, peanut salad = 5/5
- fresh, crunchy, refreshing
Xi'an vegetarian dumpling = 6/5
- this might be the most creative California-ized Chinese dumpling ever
Pork XLB (xiao long bao) = 5/5
- this was a great tip thanks to another Yelper: ask to keep the basket lid to keep your precious xiao long bao hot! then you don't have to rush to gobble it down
Beijing noodles = 4.5/5
- not oily which is great!, seemed like homemade noodles
Trio of buns = 5/5
- warm, perfect, plump, delicious, dessert but not too sweet
author: Chris P.

description: This review is based off the service of this restaurant. Absolutely awful. They are obviously new and very disorganized in regulating traffic. They seated five guests who were obviously not there and when they were called they were not present so their names were scratched out. The hostess gave a poor excuse and said that their names were circled, so that's why they were seated even though their names were called thirty minutes ago and didn't show to their seats. Also the hostess was rude. What a waste of time and awful service!!
author: Blu M.

description:
Solid new spot for dumplings! I had the cucumber salad, Beijing noodles, seafood gyoza, pan fried char siu baos, both kinds of XLBs, the XL XLB, and the trio of dessert buns. The regular XLBs are delicious! Super soupy and the skin is slightly on the thicker side so they don't fall apart. I'd also highly recommend the pan fried baos and the seafood gyoza. The only item I thought was meh was the tom yum goong XLB - they didn't taste much different from the regular and were on the drier side.

Overall, great food (though slightly overpriced). Also, the service was a little slow but I think it's just new restaurant pains. I will definitely be back!
author: Brittany L.

description:
3.5 stars.

I went with four of my co-workers for a noontime Thursday lunch. We were greeted at the door by a smiling, pleasant hostess who deftly led us to the last available table. Our waitress came by within a few minutes and asked if we were ready to order. She was busy, as the restaurant was full, and it showed. She was all business, and made assertive recommendations based on what she thought we'd enjoy.

We were served our first order, along with the bill, so that the waitstaff could cross off delivered items. It was $118 for five of us. Welcome to the SOMA design district!

There were some very good dishes and a few that were poorly executed. And by executed, it looked like they received a death sentence. 

Overall this place has promise, but the chefs need to tighten up on some of the cooking times and food presentations. 

WERKIN'
+ Pleasant hostess and waitstaff
+ Food delivered quickly
+ Nice big tables for groups
+  Garlicky green bean flavor was great, but see below...
+ Char-Siu Bao was yummy with the peanut butter
+ Beijing noodles were tasty and fairly chewy (though could be a bit chewier)
+ Pork XLB was very good
+ Tom Yum Goong was incredibly delicious, and the reason I'd return. Soup was a great temperature, and had a nice spicy kick. Lots of flavor. 
+ Pork Gyoza was decent. Nothing to write home about.
+ Seafood Gyoza was really good. Lots of flavors and a great dipping sauce. 

NEEDS WORK
- Garlicky green beans were cooked a bit too long. I like them snappy. Great flavor though!
- Expensive, but yeah... SOMA
- The xiao long bao (soup dumplings) are served in a tin cup, and as other reviewers have pointed out, chances are that the tin cup will tear the skin when trying to extract the dumpling. This happened to 2/3 of my dumplings. PLEASE don't serve them in these tins.
- Egg yolk bun was overcooked resulting in a fully cooked yolk. I mentioned this to the server as I ordered a second serving. The second egg yolk bun was just as overcooked as the first.
author: Matt S.

description: XLB was just okay. But all other items on the menu is overpriced. 18% gratitude was add to the bill, which was fine. However, our table was joined by another party without them mentioning it.
author: Cal L.

description: Excellent dumplings! Love the shrimp and cilantro har gow and the seafood dumplings in particular. Will definitely be back!
author: Sheila E.

description: Overall meal was simple, good and hot! Great place for a tasty meal to warm the tummy. Snap peas were especially crispy & fresh.  Big dumpling over rated however. Broth inside was good, pork belly filling fine but the bun was undercooked & flavorless, sorry to have to say.  Service was stellar, everyone was helpful, friendly & efficient, a smooth team effort.  Reserving final judgement after a return trip to sample lobster sui mei & crispy tofu.
author: Judy B.

description:
Went here last Saturday and arrived 10 minutes before opening to secure a spot! I highly recommend coming right before they open, when we left the wait seemed pretty long. Space is minimal inside and they run out of dishes so why risk it? Come early and get guaranteed dishes and no wait. But before you start changing up your schedule to eat at Dumpling Time I have to say this place is a lot of hype. I'm not sure that I would go again but i'm glad I experienced it once to get my cravings out of the way.

For two people the boyfriend and I definitely over ordered (I have this problem of wanting to try everything on the menu). We ordered the snap peas, shrimp toast, pork gyoza, char-siu bao, pork xi'an dumpling, king-dum (giant xlb), and tom yum goong xlb.

Highlights
King-Dum (Giant XLB) - Highlight of my meal thought it had amazing flavor. 
Tom Yum Goong XLB - Tasty I was afraid of this one because Tom Yum soup in the form of a dumpling did not sound appealing to me. Luckily this wasn't that strong in Tom Yum flavor it was a subtle hint of Tom Yum.

Okay/Good
Pork Gyoza - While the gyoza didn't taste any different than your average gyoza the sauce they provided was worth mentioning. It came with a butter aioli of some sort and while really heavy it added a unique taste to the gyoza.
Snap Peas - With all the dumplings I recommend adding in a veggie dish and this one was good.

Pass
Pork Xi'An Dumpling - Pass on this, it's a steamed dumpling. Taste no different than other steam dumplings tbh it lacked flavor and I wouldn't be able to differentiate it from the frozen stuff.
Char-Siu Bao - I didn't find this extraordinary. Wasn't really a highlight so if you really want this just order it at dim sum next time.
Shrimp Toast - Greasy and pretty bland. I'm used to eating my chinese doughnuts with porridge or wrapped in rice paper and sauce.
author: Sarah C.

description: The name couldn't be more fitting! Seriously.... this place dumpling to very much on point. The staff is 100% on point with service. The dumpling, TDF. I don't say that much in any of my reviews. Actually I don't say it at all. Anyway the noodles are a must order as well. I usually get two of them. I share, only certain things in life, noodles is not one of them, especially from here. I recommend coming here early. Or beat the rush. If you're planning on coming here on a Sunday? Bring a newspaper or a fully charge cellphone. You'll be needing it.
author: Dang D.

description: We came on a Friday night at 8:00pm and there was still a wait list. We waited around half an hour to get seated. The waitress who helped us was super friendly and suggested that we should order at least 2-3 dishes per person. She was definitely right lol! The food turned out to be better quality and authentic than I thought. The king-dum was my favorite:D
author: Angela L.

description:
Tastes great. Service is slow. For the price, I'd expect better service. They keep your running tab at your table, taking up precious space. 
Food takes forever to come to your table, don't come here if you're in a rush. 
Yelp tells me to put mustard on this review. MUSTARD.
author: Andreas M.

description: One of the best Asian places I've ever been. Superb soup dumplings! Almost the entire menu is awesome. Pork xiao long bao is my favorite! Chicken and pork gyoza are delicious, perfectly pan fried. And I just can't get enough of the beijing noodles; its like a single noodle in the bowl that goes all the way (jk, basically long noodles). Everything is perfectly cooked. A happy way to enjoy meal here is to start with chicken/pork gyoza, then shrimp and cilantro har gow, followed by a beijing noodles  and finally a combination of any two xlbs. Lovely customer service and good ambience, place is usually crowded.
author: Ajinkya P.

description: Came here on a Thursday night at 7 and waited almost 2 hours to get seated with a party of 3. By the time we were seated, we were told that the Giant XLB and both noodle dishes were sold out and that there was a limit on how many Pork Xiaolong Bao each table could order (1 order for every 2 people, rounding down). So, we got Pork Gyoza, Pork Dumplings, Vegetable Dumplings, Snap Peas and the Trio of Buns for dessert. They were passable dumplings all around - not terrible, but not amazing, and definitely not worth the wait. The service was just okay, but I understand that they're still working out the kinks. If you're willing to wait for good dumplings, you might as well find another restaurant in another neighborhood or somewhere in South Bay.
author: Ada C.

description:
we had a party of 8 and we seated 20 minutes later on a Saturday night. the staff was super fast and friendly. the food came quickly and was really delicious! 

get the shrimp toast! i was worried the large xlb wouldn't be good, but there was so much soupy goodness. we basically ordered the entire menu and everything was good!
author: Monica W.

description: I have been waiting anxiously for Dumpling Time to open and after a long day of work I became ecstatic to see that as of today, it is open for business! First off, these dumplings are mini works of art. My favorite had to be the Xi'an dumplings with real flower garnish. What?!! Beautiful presentation as well as a light, fresh, flavor profile. To wrap things up (5 styles of dumplings later...) I parted ways with Dumpling Time for the night with the Green Tea and Milk dumpling dessert babies. For sure will be back, will definitely spread the word, may or may not share my to-go orders!
author: Alix T.

description: I've waited longer than i should be. I came alone. The waiter gave the table to 2 people who came after me again and again. Finally after 4 tables after me, I was served. But I was arranged in the middle of a group of table. The server never noticed me. I had to wait longer until the server finally came to my spot. And I came here for the king dum. But they said it was sold out just before my order. I mean if I could sit earlier, I would be able to have it. This is such a bad experience. Usually one person should get seated pretty easily. But this place made me keep waiting and waiting because they wanted to squeeze me in a 8 people long table so that one person could sit with another one person... my advice is that if you come alone, just write 2 people on the list so that you can get a table faster and you can be severed better
author: Danyang Danielle C.

description: Awesome dumplings.  If only the wait wasn't always so long, I'd be there with regularity!
author: Jack P.

description:
Another challenger in the fight for best XLBs in the bay. The XLB is so rich that they're in its own tax bracket. They are a must have and worth the wait. There are some unique ones in the Tom Yum and King XLB as well. Def get the Tom Yum but the King Dum is a little gimmicky. 

Other solid bites are the shrimp toasts, green beans, and the chive and shrimp dumplings. Finish off with the trio of sweet buns and your mouth will thank you. 

Wait can get gross later in the night so get early and service can get a little slow as well as it gets busy.  

Overall, will come back again and often! Maybe not the best XLB but still damn good.
author: Brian C.

description: Place filled up quick, I was surprised that so many people turned up right after they opened. We were the 3rd group to be seated. Friendly service and efficient. Speed of food was ok, although I see everyone else received their food before we did and they ordered after us. Had the shrimp toast, it was a fried Chinese doughnut with some shrimp on it. It was ok, nothing that would leave a lasting impression. The seafood gyoza was also ok, although it was just cooked and brought to us, the filling wasn't hot enough. The butter sauce with chili was not very spicy, it didn't do too much to elevate the seafood gyoza. We also had the pork xlb, they were nice and juicy. My favorite would be the xian dumplings, it was presented beautifully and the pork had the right seasoning to it. Another dish that we tried was the har how or shrimp dumping, the skin was nice and thin not thick, just the right consistency but I did not taste any cream cheese in it. It was fresh and hot and it really reminded me of eating dim sum.  As for the king- dum, I should've listen to my fellow yelpers and avoided that. The soup mostly drained to the plate under the steamer and I did not even used the straw that came with the dumpling. Novel idea but I'm still dreaming of the soup bao from Anthony Bourdain's travel segment. Mostly metered parking around the area.
author: Alicia A.

description: We stopped here on our way to the airport as a last SanFran meal and it was the perfect last meal. The dumplings were delicious and the noodles were so good. We tried some of everything and ate way too much- worth it!
author: Recii D.

description: It is not the traditional dumpling place. However the only food I like is Tom yum dumpling!! The "very big dumpling is interesting idea, but the taste is so so to me.
author: Timmy J.

description:
this had been on my to-try list for a while, and i finally got to go on thurs night.  my friend works nearby, so she got there about 5 min before me to put our names down.  the wait on thurs around 645 was not bad, so we sat around 7.

to eat we got the cucumber salad, string beans, chicken bao (steamed), tom yum goong xlb, pork gyoza, and the shrimp and cilantro har gow.  it sounded like a lot of food, but we ate everything except for one bao and half the string beans, which we took to-go.  my fave was the pork gyoza.  the tom yum xlb was interesting, but i wish the wrapper was a bit thinner/softer.  the food came so fast, so i felt rushed to eat everything while it was hot.  i wish they would pace out the courses a bit more.
author: Helen T.

description:
Ever since Din Tai Fung showed up to the Bay Area with its ridiculous lines, you knew someone was bound to make an attempt to go against the dumpling hype. Enter Dumpling Time. The restaurant is situated in the latest hip San Francisco area of the Design District, not too far from Soma and has your typical SF vibe. 

Now for the dumplings. We had the har gow, xi'an dumplings, char siu bow and of course, the XLBs. The har gow was very well made, but not a highlight and the xi'an dumplings were very delicious.  But we all know why you're reading this and getting ready to go to this restaurant. I've been the Din Tai Fung all over the world - from Sydney to Arcadia so I can understand where your head is at. I would rate the XLBs a solid 4/5. The skin is almost as thin as DTF and the flavor is definitely at the same level. If the skin were perhaps a bit smoother and more delicate, it would be close to the same level. Overall, the experience was great and the service was good for a Wednesday.  I would certainly consider coming here as much as I'd drive down an hour down to Santa Clara!
author: Ray W.

description: Yummy soup dumplings, shrimp toast and other dim sum favorites. The selection is edited and the prices are a higher than in Chinatown or the Richmond, but the service is friendly and it's awesome to have a dim sum restaurant in this burgeoning neighborhood!
author: Doug V.

description: such a cute place w rly yummy food!!! loved the chicken dumplings and seafood dumplings :) the service was nice and the food was fresh -- would recommend!
author: Maalvika B.

description:
The wait seems daunting but it moves quickly. Got there on a Sunday at around 6:30 and despite there being like 20 parties ahead of us our party of 4 was seated in less than 30 minutes. They have a lot of communal tables to get butts in seats so be ready to meet strangers!

The dumplings come out fast - we ordered pretty much 1 of every dumpling on the menu. The KingDum is fun- we split it 4 ways after taking turns drinking the soup out of a straw.

Favorites include the seafood gyoza with butter dipping sauce- highly recommended for seafood lovers! Packed with big chunks of lobster and shrimp, with a butter sauce I could drink.

The coconut milk/beet wrapped soup dumplings were also a star- really flavorful and different than your typical XLB. 

-1 star for being out of several beers. The menu isn't long so if they're out of some stuff there's not a ton of other options. They do tend to also run out of food around 9pm- staff said- but hopefully they'll beef up supply!

I left uncomfortably full but couldn't turn down another bite of dumplings. The tri-color dessert buns were bomb! Taro and egg custard being our fave. 

They have an outdoor patio which is just a waiting area right now but hopefully that'll become a dining area soon too! Get here- the hype is real.
author: Tiffany W.

description: I thought the food here was good but not as great as I was expecting being a die hard dumpling lover. 4 stars in that if a friend wanted to come back I'd say yes but I didn't think it was a unique or exceptional experience. The highlights were the pork soup dumpling, the seafood gyoza, and the excellent shrimp toast that was at once seafoody and donuty. I did not much care for the vegetarian dumplings as they were flavorless and bland. Everything else was in Btwn. Note: they still do not have liquor license despite having drinks listed in back of menu so don't be fooled.
author: Roxanne A.

description:
Probably would give around a 3.5 if I could give half ratings, but I'll give it a 4.

The food itself is good but a bit on the pricier side. I ordered the King-Dum which came decorated with flowers. It's visually aesthetic, but I don't really think it sufficed as a meal itself. It also comes with a cut boba straw so you can drink up the soup! 

The reason for a slightly lower rating is because of the restaurant itself. We were seated at a 6-person communal table (for a party of 3) which was slightly awkward. It's also extremely loud inside, so you basically have to shout to hear one another.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Update: 3/26/2018 7:15pm

Arrived at 7:13pm and immediately noticed they have a new patio area which added more seating to the place (a plus!!!!!) There was 2 groups of 2 infront and I wrote my name down on the waiting list. The hostess 2as already seating the first party and checked the list after. So the second party didn't wrote their name down but I let them get seated first. There was more tables open and it wouldn't of made a difference. We got seated at the patio but there was no settings ready so the hostess went to grab them and then she forgot the menus. We sat for about 5 mins before the server came with water then I asked for the menu and he quickly went to get it and apologized. (He was very aplogoectic even though it was not his fault) another 5mins passed and we were ready to order but the waitress asked if we could move to another table and so she can seat a party of 5. I didn't mind so we agreed. The first what! The party didn't want to sit in the patio! Then she and her group decided the patio was ok. So we moved and they sat... Haha and next! They moved the 2 tables that were set up for them to connect with another! OMG! (Super irritated at these 5). Then after they sat for about 5 minutes and drank their water, they requested to move inside instead! Holy cow! This has nothing to do with the restaurant but I just wanted to say that the hostess handled herself very well handling this group!

We ordered everything we wanted and they had everything plus added new items since they opened (or the last I was here.)

Seared chicken bao, pork xlb, 2 king dum, xi An Pork duMplings and clinatro har gow.

First was the XiAn Pork Dumpling: Plating is nicely done but the garnishes didn't help add flavor to the Dumpling. I tried it without sauces first and it did lack flavor. 

Second pork xlb : none of them broke! (Thank you !!!) The thickness of the skin was inconsistent. I had one that was super thick then 2 that were not. I wish there was more Juice in them (doesn't everyone ). The meat flavor was ok. One of them was super ginger-y.

Third clinatro Har Gow: I expected the skin to be thinner but I have seen thicker. The taste is ok but it does come with a clinatro sauce which I good BUT if your food is flavored right... Why would I need to use the clinatro sauce? Just my thoughts !

Forth was the seared chicken bao: I like the bao. A lot and I don't eat bao. The meat is not juicy and I think there a way too much mushroom inside . Also for a seared bao, they outside of the bun is overly moist. Which makes it stick to your fingers.

Fifth : king Dum (king xlb) literally ordered it for the gram. Takes the longest... We ate everything and it still wasn't here....And tun tun tun... After 40mins it's sold out! Wtf! Waiter said it was system miscount. Haha sold out right before we ordered ... I don't think so buddy!

Review stays the same 3 stars.


**********************************************************
came here when they first open about 8pm and they were basically sold out of most items already. The items we had were good but this review will be edited when i go back to try the other items i wanted to try. Parking is hard at time so please be prepared.
author: Jan H.

description:
I was going to give 3 stars, but because our waitress was so derogatory, it removed one star.

We were very disappointed with the dumplings and liked the other items. The XLB was placed in this tin foil, making it hard to eat. I've only seen it done in cheap dumpling places. When we told the waitress, she said "well, that's how it's done and that's how Koi Palace does this too" with an attitude. Unfortunately that's not how it's done and Koi Palace is definitely not the golden standard for XLB. 

For the big soup dumplings, they used this big boba straw which is weird because there wasn't a lot of soup. The other stuff we ordered such as dessert buns, noodles were ok. Not worth a long wait.
author: Loretta H.

description: Very delicious! But small portions and a little pricy. Nice for big group gathering. Not suitable for conversation.
author: Alison C.

description: Came here on a Thursday night two hours before closing. My favorites were the shrimp toast, crispy bao, and the siu mai. Waiter was great and fast, despite having to take care of a whole full section.
author: Jeselle O.

description: Omg so good. We went just when is opened on a Saturday night. No wait. All the gyozas and dumplings were so delicious. Some of the best in SF.
author: Z D.

description: First time eating dim sum. The service is incredible, and the food is amazing. Flavorful, good portions, and exciting. Highly recommend.
author: Bill K.

description:
Very tasty dumplings - both pork and dessert. Served was very helpful and the restaurant is very clean and modern. Would definitely recommend going with a group of friends or coworkers for lunch or dinner.

Still craving the green tea dessert dumpling.
author: Ben D.

description:
Pros:
- Cool concept
- Like the location

Cons:
- Taste was just ok
- Long line -- food not really worth the wait
- They put the dumplings on a tin, and they stick to the tin, so they rip when you pick them up and the soup spills out 

Overall, just ok.
author: Jim S.

description:
Food was great, though slightly on the expensive side. The service was superb! Our waiter gave us the top favorites, and very attentive with water or checking in on us and the food was delicious.

Shrimp har gow! The skin was thicker than most places and had a great chew to it. The shrimp itself was flavorful, cleaned well, and cooked to a good texture so that it wasn't too rubbery or overdone! Loved it, especially with the dipping sauce (not pictured). 

When you want a Kingdum all for yourself  but actually, the soup was hot! The pork had a clean taste! All in all, fun to get, but I would probably get the regular soup buns next time.

The chicken gyoza was amazing!! Crispy skin, flavorful chicken that was enhanced with the variety of mushroom! Would definitely recommend this 10/10!
author: Justina H.

description:
I came on Saturday at 11:30am (30 mins after it opened and the first wave of people just sat down. BAD IDEA!) Come 10 minutes before it opens or else you have to wait a long time!! (45 mins - 1 hour)

PSA - they ran out of the gigantic king XLBs when I was here :( I really wanted to try it! They only make 15-20 per day said the waitress and usually run out of it within 30-40 minutes.

WHAT TO ORDER: The shrimp toast and Beijing noodles were really good! The xlbs were good but didn't have enough juice in them. I would recommend trying the tom yum ones if you like tom yum soup :) it was yummy! The green tea and milk buns were also delish. Didn't really taste like green tea but I still liked them a lot! 

JUST OK: The hargow with cream cheese was weird. Also didn't love the seafood or pork gyoza - it could've been crispier. 

Overall, worth trying this place if the wait is 20-30 mins!! Not worth waiting 1 hour though.
author: Sophia L.

description: I went here with friends and got w buch of dumplings.  The shau long bau was just ok, but everything else was pretty good, especially the mom's special dumpling.  Expect long lines.
author: Michael E.

description:
Solid experience at Dumpling Time. We came a little before opening and thankfully made the first seating. My favorite things that we ordered, and that I will definitely come back for, are the shrimp toast, seafood gyoza, and the pork bao. 

I also want to note that I was really impressed with the service. Every single server was hustling, we never had to wait for water, and everyone was really nice and helpful. 

The only reason for the 4 out of 5 stars is there are definitely cheaper dumpling places in the Bay Area. All in all though, it was a good experience and I want to go back soon!
author: Caroline C.

description:
Seriously the best dumplings in SF. Great service, great food. 

The only two problems I had... 
1- Having to wait outside but it looks like ( based on the last time I went there ) they were building something outside. Either more seating or a waiting area. Either way, it was worth even standing outside for! Just bring a jacket if it is windy outside. Not worth docking a star for.  
2. The communal tables in the middle are a bit hard to talk across the table. I think its a bit too long. I found myself speaking super loud which might have bothered the people next to me. They ended up being super nice and talking to us about the basketball game going on so all was well ( GO WARRIORS!! ) Also not worth docking a star for bc honestly the food is that good. 

Let me put it this way.... we went on a Monday.... then went back again on Wednesday. Yep....that good.
author: Sheeva J.

description:
Always have a great time when I visit Dumpling Time. They have so many dumpling options for every kind of dumpling lover. My recommendations are:

Chicken bao steamed
- Good bun to meat ratio
- You can taste all the finely chopped ingredients rather than it being a mush like most other dim sum places

Seafood gyoza
- DELICIOUS!!!
- The shrimp combines really well with the chives and everything tastes fresh

Pork xiao long bao
- The juice is pipping hot (in a good way) and full of non-greasy, non-MSG flavor
- The meat itself tastes fresh

Main lobster siu mai
- YES PLEASE!!
- This dish is so good and a must order; so tasty

Shrimp and cilantro har gow
- I like the balance of the shrimp with the cilantro
- Tastes fresh

Pork xi'an dumpling
- Really good as well

Happy endings
- Delicious and not too sweet, a fantastic way to end the meal

Things I wasn't as impressed with:

Veggies/small dishes
- I wasn't as huge of a fan of the small dishes but I haven't tried them in a while so they may be better now
- I found them lacking in the complexity and taste that the dumplings have

Beijing noodles
- I wasn't overly impressed with this dish
- Found it to be on the heavier and oily side
- Has a heavy meat taste to it

Vegetarian xi'an dumplings
- Not very exciting but love the idea

Tom yum goong xiao long bao
- Not bad, but not my favorite combination
author: Emma L.

description:
This place was designed to cater to the bougie/hipster-y people who want to instagram their food. Food was pricey for the portion size, and flavor was just meh. Completely taking the Dim Sum experience out of dim sum food. They also make you sit at the same table with other strangers/couples, which I found to be quite an awkward dining experience. Came because the XLB were said to be great, but honestly I've had way better quality ones for cheaper price. Overall, would not be coming back again. 

TLDR; if you want authentic dim sum, do not come here.
author: Sherry Z.

description: We spontaneously came here on Chinese New Year when the idea of dumplings and noodles got in our heads. It was a Friday so we figured most places would be jammed. We decided to try Dumpling Time hoping its off the beaten path location at the intersection of SoMa and the Design District would help our case. And we're so glad we took the chance! The dishes were super tasty and had some modern touches that worked surprisingly well. For example, the boiled dumplings were hand crafted down to the wrappers, and they were topped with edible flowers and fennel shavings. The garnishes were unexpected but made the dish beautiful and tasty. We also loved the Beijing pork noodles - this was probably our favorite dish of the night. We also had the seafood gyozas, pork xiao long baos, and crispy fried tofu. Everything was tasty and made to order. The service was a bit uneven at times with a long wait in-between some dishes, but since it was busy and a Friday night that didn't bother us much. We would definitely go back.
author: Annie S.

description: I really enjoyed dumpling time. I know it's not authentic dumplings, but I thought the quality of the meat and dumplings here was fantastic. The har how had a ton of fresh shrimp, and the large king soup dumpling was very fun. I also would highly recommend the dessert dumplings to top off your meal -- delicious. This place gets very packed at all times, so be prepared to wait or come before peak hours.
author: Nikita K.

description: We tried pork XLB, shumai, beef noodles, gyozas, and pork bao. Everything was really good but the portions were a little small. It ended up paying $18ish per person for my group but we were all still pretty hungry when we left
author: Sally F.

description: Definitely yummy food. The dessert buns were amazing! Waited about 30-40 mins for dinner. Would definitely come back though despite the wait time.
author: Jasmine l.

description: My husband and I have been trying to get in to this place for months. It was always crazy busy... With people standing in long lines to get in. Which says: this place must be good!  We finally got in today and found out the long lines are justified. What a great place!! The food is so amazing-- get the shrimp toast for sure!  Our server, Kent, was amazing.. he went through the entire menu with us. He explained what everything was, his favorites and how you should eat them. You can even watch them making the dumplings!! Highly recommend. You will be waiting and they don't take reservations, but it's worth it!
author: Mindy Z.

description:
Hipster fusion done right. 
Delicious food, affordable prices, instagram-worthy yet still authentic (there's Chinese men making your XLB's when you walk in).
We didn't have reservations and got sat immediately on the patio on a Thursday at 5:30.

Chicken Bao (3/5) - Tasty but nothing phenomenal. Would opt for the pork bao next time.

Green Beans (4/5) - seasoned and cooked perfectly, crispy on the outside and still crunchy on the inside.

Pork XLB (5/5) - XLB's can be a hit or miss for me but it was cooked perfectly, soup still encapsulated inside and burst into a flavor explosion. Definitely ordering this again next time.

Shrimp Toast (5/5) - Didn't expect to enjoy this as much as I did. I could smell the shrimp as the waiter was bringing over the dish. The toast has a light crispy texture which complements the warm savory shrimp on top. The chili/soy sauce concoction I made made it even better.

Pleasantly surprised that I had an enjoyable dining experience, servers were attentive and chill vibes overall.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
These dumps are pretty legit

Classics were ok- satisfying 
Skip the pan fried bao- not crunchy enough and it's just a pork bun with crunchy bottom- not a true SJB. There's a chance we ordered the wrong thing!
Traditional XLB were hot and juicy, doughy top but not disturbingly so. 
Traditional boiled chive dumps were good too- maybe a little too thick skinned but also not bad.

New twists were the pleasant surprise:
Fusion flavors don't always work but the Tom Yum XLB were really delicious. Not for those who dislike coconut flavor. 
The seafood dumpling with the sauce is kinda mind blowing. 

Overall- decent classics and some interesting new stuff. Excellent veggies- snap peas and cucumbers were beautiful.

And the PRAWN TOAST IS ON A CHINESE DONUT. End review.
author: Hallie C.

description:
Nom nom nom nom! I've been here 4 times since it's opened already and I can't get enough! the Tom yum XLB (should really be Tom yummy) is so creative and unique but most importantly delicious! It was like a spicy & sour flavor bomb. 

The regular XLB was pretty tasty as well! I couldn't really differentiate between these ones (pork belly) vs. the regular pork ones from other restaurants. However, they did the king dum (giant dumpling) really well! I love soup and they had an abundance in it! I expected it to be dry but it was made really well. You can really tell the work they put into these. 

I also had the pork xi'an dumplings which were okay to me. The skin was a little thick for my liking but I did like that it had a spicy kick to it.

The ha gow & chicken bao were pretty standard, something you'd typically find at a dim sum restaurant. 


The servers were great and always helpful! 

The lines may also seem crazy long but the wait time isn't too bad. There's also a lot of parking in the area!
author: Marlene H.

description:
I would like to write a standard positive review but there is a character limit that is preventing me from being succinct.

A- GrubHub.
A+ Dumpling Time
author: Morellio B.

description: Oh wow wow. I wanted everything on the menu. As a compromise, we got something from every section. Everything was delicious! Stand outs include the garlicy green beans and seafood gyoza and BBQ pork bao (seared). Service is attentive and knowledgeable (they know the menu cuz they eatin' it) too!
author: Nicole O.

description:
Really a 3.5 but adding half a star for being the only decent Chinese place in the Mission Bay area.  Came here for lunch at around 11:30am on a weekend and probably waited in line for 15 minutes.  We had:
- Garlic seaweed salad (4/5) - Different from the seaweed salad you'd get at a Japanese restaurant, with thicker, crunchier strips of seaweed.  Pretty good.
- Beijing noodles (3.5/5) - The flavor was actually pretty good (and legitimately reminds me of the real thing), but there was probably half as much sauce as I would've liked.  With enough sauce and maybe some vinegar at the table, this would've been 4+ stars.
- Shrimp & cilantro har gow (3/5) - The flavor and texture was fine, but the dumpling skin was too thick.  Comes with a cilantro sauce that was interesting, although I personally wasn't a huge fan.
- Xi'an pork dumplings (3.5/5) - Pretty good, with a nice crunch from the cabbage.  One or two of the dumplings on our plate must have come from an entire batch that was way over-boiled, though, as they were mushy.
- Tom Yum Goong XLB (4/5) - Probably the best thing we had.  I'd never had Tom Yum in a XLB before, but it really worked - the soup and filling were both delicious.  The individual tin foil mini-pans that each XLB came in made it slightly more difficult to eat.  

I'm sure we'll be back a lot more, as this place will definitely satisfy some of our Chinese food craving without forcing us to trek all the way out to Richmond/Sunset or Chinatown.
author: Simon L.

description: I saw this place posted on Instagram and made my boyfriend take me immediately to get their giant soup dumpling. We waited on a Sunday night for like 45 minutes but it was 100% worth it. AMAZING.
author: Shannen B.

description: My sister found this place on Instagram and we planned ahead to scope out this cute dumpling place. (But she wasn't able to make it.) Henry and I went early because according to other yelpers it can be a long wait. We put our name down for two and we didn't wait long after they opened, maybe because we came 15 minutes before opening. There were about 7 parties ahead of us. It didn't take us long to order. We ordered almost from every section. Everything we had was delicious. We ate it all. We also order more before leaving because we enjoyed it so much. Service was quick. This will not be our last time at Dumpling Time!
author: Henry And Nalee B.

description:
We waited ~25 minutes for a table at 8.30 on a Friday night, not too bad for a restaurant in the city.

We ordered:

Cucumber Salad - Do not recommend.  Slices of raw cucumber with oil and chilis for like $6.  

Crispy Tofu Squares - This was our favorite dish of the night!  Really good flavor!

Seared Pork Bao - The bun itself was a bit dry and the meat was decent

Pork XLB - Din Tai Fung prices for Panda Express quality.  Also - the XLB stuck to the bottom of the aluminum tin which caused the skin to break and the soup to flow out.

Shrimp / Cilantro Har Gow - The sauce was actually really good.  Totally not asian but still tasty enough.

Pork/Shrimp Siu Mai - Tasted like any other dim sum restaurant's siu mai only twice the price

Veggie Dumplings - Definitely the least favorite at the table.  IMO - it was pretty looking but did not taste great.  All veggies were bland and the toppings didn't match the flavor of the dumpling

Beijing Noodles - Pork was seasoned really well.  Overall - a good dish.

Shrimp Toast - We ordered it but they ran out...but they didn't even tell us until we asked them where it was

Green Tea and Milk Bun - Definitely a must try.  I really enjoyed it.  It wasn't too sweet, which I liked.

Egg Yolk Bun - This is not a typical egg yolk bun like you get at a dim sum place, where the inside is runny.  This was more like an egg custard bun.

Service - Decent enough.  They made a mistake on our order but corrected it.  The maitre'd seemed rude though to folks (not to us but as you see her interacting with other guests)

Overall - I would not come back because the prices are too high to the quality of food you get.
author: Christopher L.

description: We came for the XLB and the King Dum, but I ended up loving the dessert dumplings the most! The dessert dumpling trio had an egg custard flavor, beet and taro, and green tea. It's a very hipster dumpling spot, with screens and decor to match, but at least it was a clean environment. The hubby enjoyed the shrimp toast and Beijing noodles as well. The green beans have us the needed veggie fix, and we downed everything with a bottle of sake. The har gow were just normal dim sum har gow, overpriced ($6.50 for 4), but the cilantro sauce was a different touch. The pork belly and peanut butter dumplings were also yummy!
author: Liz N.

description:
it was my first time here and we almost tried 60% of the food off the menu. may be a little pricy but we all thing well worth it.

definitely will return
author: Bo W.

description: First time here and was not disappointed. Great dim sum! Tasty dishes, traditional with a twist. Our favorite was the seafood gyoza. So tasty and fresh. The shrimp toast was also very good, as well as the chicken bao. Definitely will be back.
author: Kailee Q.

description: A bit pricey, but great food. The restaurant does get very busy, so plan ahead.
author: Joe F.

description:
Parking: Metered and street parking all around. Meters end at 6pm.
Pork XLB: lots of soup. Very soft center.
Seared chasu bao: a basic bbq pork bun was some sear. Id pass
Beijing noodles: this is a safe food. Id pass. Waste of stomach space.
Shrimp toast: a chinese donut (the one you get at porridge) with shrimp paste inside. Its good but literally a shrimp paste chinese donut.
Seafood gyoza: a very generous meaty shrimo dumpling. Amazing. Must get. Dip it in the white sauce. Dip it.
author: Kenny C.

description: Came here 5 min before opening on a Sunday morning. Put our names on the list and huddled together to wait in the patio as it was raining. So many people waiting in the patio, it was intimidating and seemed like it would be a long wait. There were about 15 parties ahead of my party of two. We were seated by 11:07a. Already knew what we wanted so we ordered and we're done eating by 12p. We ordered garlicky green beans (very similar to din tai fung and san Tung), king dum (skeptical cause some reviews said the small ones were better but I had to get it for the gram and I have no regrets because it was perfect for the raining weather), seared char siu bao (also very good and not too sweet with just the right amount of meat to bao ratio). I also really liked the chili oil on the side thatcam go with all the foods. It wasn't spicy but it had a little kick that made all the food better. Excellent food and excellent friendly service. The Chinese people in LA are always tired and rude. The Chinese people here were nice and friendly.
author: Nance_ E.

description: Be prepared to wait outside for 30-45 mins for dinner this place gets busy!! (Bring a jacket) Soup dumplings and the Beijing noodle dish were our favorite! Pork gyoza was great also! I would skip on the steamed pork buns and for SURE skip the dessert steam buns.
author: M N.
