description: Dumpling Time was delicious.  Its kind of a knock off of Din Tai Fung if anyone has been to one, and is not as good as DTF, however I really enjoyed my meal at Dumpling Time.  The Pork XLB was the star of the show.  They have them in little metal containers which is probably not needed but wasn't an issue.  I will be back next time I am in SF.
author: P T.

description: My friend told me about the place. So I went and try food and service make me come back again. I try almost everything in the menu cuz menu ain't that long like other dim sum place. very simple and service was great.
author: Lin H.

description: Basic Americanized dim sum. Sometimes you have an urge for dumplings and this place has a good array of options. The quality is fine, but overall bland without much subtlety or taste. Would advise not to order the shrimp toast. Looks like a sliced french baguet with a shrimp on top, pretty inauthentic even for an inauthentic dish like shrimp toast.
author: Liz S.

description:
The dumplings and bao's are pretty good here. The dumpling skin is chewy and the meat filling is moist and flavorful. However, the pork xlb was the biggest disappointment as it was the most bland of all the dumplings they have. I would definitely skip the xlb next time I'm back.

I was part of the early crowd but still ended up waiting about an hour before I got seated. They skipped around the waitlist and tend to sit smaller parties first. Beware of coming here with 4+ people!
author: Constance Y.

description:
Happy to find this new modern dumpling place! Very authentic and high quality food. Best served piping hot!

Pork XLB - high quality Xiao Long Bao soup dumplings. 5/5 stars

Pan-Seared Char Siu Bao - BBQ roast pork baos comfort food. 4.5/5 stars since it was not piping hot

Xian Veg Dumpling - meh since it was lukewarm and I'm not a fan of chives.

Shrimp Toast - can't go wrong with deep fried toasty goodness and shrimp. 5/5 stars

Garlicky Green Beans - delicious flashed fried green beans tossed in garlicky goodnesz. 5/5 stars

Trio of Buns - Egg custard, Green tea, Taro...hot out of the steamer...satisfies my sweet tooth! Absolutely love the egg custard bao!  5/5 stars
author: Lis A.

description:
Came here with a friend on Saturday, right at opening. There was already a line so we were a little shook but we were seated pretty quickly. The whole experience involves A LOT of waiting around for your food, so make sure you set aside at least 2 hours plus a little more if you have to wait in line. While we were ordering, the waitress kept pushing us to order more (and no shade, that's her job, get it gurl, ect) but honestly, don't do it. We, unfortunately, got pressured into doing so. 

We got:
1. Shrimp toast - I liked this, my friend didn't at all. It was super crunchy and oily. Wish they added a lil more shrimp to it. 
2. Char siu bao - This was alright. It wasn't bad or good. I honestly can't even remember what it tasted like. Forgettable. 
3. Pork XLB - I wish we didn't order this. I've had much better XLB at mom and pop shops in the east bay. It was so bland and lukewarm, don't even bother. 
4. King-dum - This is the only reason we came here so I was super excited to get it. It's huge and picture-worthy. Taste-wise, it was, like everything else, alright. The meat was mushy but it was fun to eat, I guess!

Overall, come here once if you must for the aesthetics. Food-wise, there are better, cheaper, more authentic spots out there. I really wanted to love this place but everything was so "meh."

PS: they ran out of the King-dum as we were wrapping up our meal. If that's what you're coming for, get there as early as you can.
author: Angela M.

description: This place ain't even all that. Usually a long wait. The decor inside is pretty but nahhhh. You could get XLB's for way cheaper in Clement or Chinatown and will probably taste better. The only thing I liked from this place is the shrimp toast but everything else (XLB's, veggie Xian dumplings, veggie spring rolls were just mediocre). Definitely over hyped in my opinion.
author: Jennifer S.

description: 3.5 We came here on a Saturday & didn't have to wait too long. My son loves xiao long bao so we had to try this place. A plus was to have good food w/ my puppy in their outside seating. Place was good but it was definitely a bit more pricey than most dim sum place. For example their regular xiao long bao you get 6 for $8.50 if you go to Koi Palace you'd get 10 of them for another $1. Shu mai for $6, which you can normally get for less than $5. Overall the food was good but catered to a very hipster crowd. So if you like the beard & man buns this is your place.
author: Mercy P.

description: This is probably my favorite dim sum restaurant. The seafood Gyozas were amazing and the service was great too. The dim sum had a different taste than other paces too.
author: Arya T.

description:
We love dumplings.
We search out good dumpling locations.
We are glad we found this place. 

You can read the negative reviews about price because they are a bit pricey.  But if you want a great experience and great Bao, great noodles and a must try Mothers Secret recipe, then you need to visit this place.  Just get there before 5:30pm.
author: Brian M.

description:
I love dim sum, and knew I had to try this place, but was hesitant for two reasons: I hate waiting, but it turned out the wait was short and so worth it.  Also, looks expensive at first, but the portions are very generous.

It turned out to be a great experience: fantastic server, yummy dishes, and good value for SF.
author: Ania B.

description: Really good dumplings...can get very busy, but the service is fast and efficient.  Love this place for a casual dinner or lunch.  Wish they did delivery and take out!
author: Dave R.

description: I highly recommend Dumpling Time.  The food is very tasty and the venue is fun - lots of young people and good music (I think when we went they were playing 2000s tracks).  Best of all, the experience is much more affordable than what it would be at comparable locations - 3 of us ordered 7 dishes (2 per person, then 2 of us split a 3rd), and the total was around $46 pre-tip.  Loved the seafood gyoza.  Overall, a fantastic spot for anyone who likes dumplings!
author: Curren I.

description: We stopped by for lunch one afternoon when we were starving. It was just what we wanted. Delicious dim sum at a trendy but unpretentious spot.
author: erich i.

description:
My boyfriend and I got FOOD POISONING from here! The night ended great praising how much we enjoyed their food and would like to come back since we live 2 hours away. I woke up the next morning at 7 am with non stop diarrhea and throwing up like there's no tomorrow. 

The service was great but as a waitress in the past, someone did not wash their hands or cooked our meals right. I'm very disappointed and don't think I'd consider coming back.
author: Abby L.

description: Was surprised by how good this place was. Growing up on dumplings, this place is definitely high on the list. lots of homeless people around the corner though.
author: Sam R.

description: Delicious dumplings! These veggie Xi'an dumplings with egg actually turned out to be one of our faves, even for my meat-loving boyfriend. Everything we've tried here is great! Though there's often a wait to be seated it goes pretty fast. And if you ever have to wait too long for one of your dishes to come out they might give you a free dish while you wait, great customer service.
author: Nick L.

description: Came here with a friend last month. It's located in an area that had good street parking so that was a plus. We ordered a couple different types of dumplings. While they tasted like they were made with fresh, good ingredients, they weren't the same as going to Din Tai Fong. It was just lacking something. I did appreciate that I didn't have MSG headache afterwards though. Service was good, tables are a little crammed together, vibe of place was casual and cool. If you're in the mood for dumplings, come here. But appreciate it for dumplings, not like Din Tai Fong though.
author: Vivian L.

description: We got here at 1pm and parking can be a hassle here. Lots of meter parking but really depends on your luck! There were 9 parties ahead of us when we got there. The wait went by fast because some people weren't there when the host called their names. We waited around 20mins and finally got seated. Menu was simple and easy to read. I knew exactly what I wanted so I ordered right away. I got the shrimp toast (since everyone raved on how good it is on yelp) pork gyoza, xlb, king dum (xl xlb), Beijing noodles, shiu mai, and trio buns. The food came out really fast. I love how the inside was very modern and they were playing Chinese music. One thing I really like was that you can see how the XLB or any dumplings were made right in front of you. They have the same concept as Din Tai Fung! Honestly I thought the food was okay. The food just looks pretty LOL. My favorite was the green tea bun I loved it!! Other than that nothing really stood out to me. Customer service was okay. We ordered 7 items and the bill total was $61 excluding tips. Overall I wouldn't return because it's more on the pricey side and I'll stick to my Koi Palace at Daly City or The Kitchen at millbrae!!
author: Tina C.

description: Super satisfactory dumpling adventure. Thank you for having quality food and supplying my savory tooth w all sorts of flavorful vibes!
author: Nina L.

description: I've been here a couple of times and I'm completely hooked on the Tom Yum soup dumplings! They are my favorite! Whenever I go, I order at least 3-4 orders of it. I also tried the regular pork soup dumplings and they are also really good but nothing beats the Tom Yum ones. It does get a bit crowded but I think it's worth the wait.
author: Lorni L.

description: Pretty good food environment was also pretty nice not the best ever but it is definitely very convenient for what it is. Might comeback sometime.
author: Khalid H.

description: I couldn't wait to go to Dumpling Time.  There are lines out the door, so you expect the food to be amazing.  The food was not amazing.  It was beautifully presented and utterly bland and uninspired.  I wanted it to be better.  It's not worth the hassle of the lines to have food that doesn't rise to the occasion.  It seems that they have chosen to focus on high volume QUANTITY over blow-you-away-tasty QUALITY.
author: Thomas M.

description: OMG! This place is delicious. I highly recommend the Tom Yum dumplings with the beet wrapper... but everything here is fantastic.
author: Eleanor Q.

description: Amazing dumplings! Average Price! Good Service!
author: Amrita G.

description: The food is good and offer different variety to the traditional dim sum. However, the wait is long especially out in the cold at night. There isn't anywhere for customers to sit and wait.
author: Michael Q.

description: The dumplings tasted very good,I liked them,there all very juicy and fresh.I ordered seven pans.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Came by last Sunday with the hubs after church around 1:30pm and we didn't have to wait long. We enjoyed the XLB, siumai and the dessert buns (matcha, egg custard and taro I believe) but the Xian dumplings were disappointing. The bbq pork buns were also pretty average - thought it would be different with the addition of peanut butter?? However, I will say that the actual buns (be it sweet or savory filling) were soft and fluffy. Overall, wouldn't mind coming back here as long as I don't have to wait for more than 20 minutes.
author: Viv C.

description: The XLB is the bomb.  Xi'an ones rival the ones I make.  The seafood gyoza is so tasty.  So the small plates are yummy too...like the celery and Yuba one.  I've been twice now and will go back...so happy there's a dumpling place on this side of the town that is worth going to.  And yeah they make them fresh.  Green tea buns are great desserts too.
author: Julia H.

description: Love this place!! Sometimes the flavor can feel a little watered down as they make huge batches so try to go during non-rush times. :)
author: Lucy C.

description: Honestly one of my favorite places to eat when I'm visiting SF for work. Quick service and delicious hand-made dumplings. What more can you ask for??
author: Rachel D.

description: This place is busy!  On a weekday, there was a line at the time of opening.  The place didn't fill up completely, but it was definitely busy.  Couple things to note, I guess since this place is starting out, they're still working on the kinks.  It would be nice to get the line seated instead of having them wait outside all that time.  They opened a bit later than their listed time for weekday dinner.  Also, the inside is very noisy, I'd probably site outside if you can get a table there.  For the food, I tried the pork buns, shrimp and cilantro har gow, and the giant XLB.  The pork buns and har gow were pretty good, not that memorable, but great if you're in the mood for it.  Might order the more adventurous versions of their dim sum next time.  As for the giant XLB, I enjoyed it!  It was exactly as I imagined it would be.  The soup was flavorful, and there was a good amount of meat packed inside.  Would definitely order it again, though I do want to try their other XLB as well.  I'll have to come back again soon!
author: Bryson L.

description: Small portions and overpriced. The soup dumplings are pretty authentic, but there are better restaurants where you can get your money's worth. It's popular because of the location and appeals to people working nearby.
author: Ivy L.

description: This place had good service and great tasting dumplings. Worth the wait of a long line and would come back again.
author: Rio L.

description: Dumplings I had here were delectable. I have yet to try the rest on their menu and I'm already wanting to have more. Will definitely be back here again soon. Also had recommended this spot to my friends and will also be tagging with them as well.
author: Patricia B.

description: So so so so good. We tried the small dumplings (forget the actual name but they're on the top right of the menu) which were great thanks to the little salad on top consisting of radishes, fennel, and jalapeño slices. The large soup dumplings were delicious. We tried the normal kind and also the beet ones. Both were great. We also got the trio of dessert dumplings. The "egg" one was my favorite.
author: John S.

description:
New spot in the soma area worth trying.  Really tasty and delicious . I came in with a few friends 
And we definitely enjoy the delicious food and the experience here . We order almost everything on the menu . So we can be sure what items are the best on our list and what is our least favorite .  Yummy 

Best on my list - green tea milky buns 
Tom yum goong 
Deep fried bread with shrimp 

What really brings me here is the chef make the dumpling in front of you and the noodles. How fresh can this get ? Must try place will be back often
author: Christina L.

description: My wife and I love this place. We came here before a show at Bottom of the Hill. What a great find! The queue was a little threatening but don't fear it, it moves quickly, a little patience will be rewarded. We're pescatarians - plenty of options for us. We tried all of the courses, right through to dessert. All very solid. This is a worthy place. We'll be back.
author: Phil L.

description: This cute dumpling place opened up recently in our neighborhood and was in the news for its giant dumpling. We went there on a Thursday night, were fortunate with the timing and got seated in under 5 minutes (a line did form later). The dumplings are very solid, with good variety. Dishes are creatively dressed and visually presented with attention to detail, including the soup dumplings in individual foil to keep every drop of the soup in. The famous king dumpling was a delight. We also had the dessert dumplings, which were great too. The wait staff were super friendly and attentive to us. The prices are actually fair and exactly where one would expect them to be, given the location and level of cleanliness and presentation. Highly recommended!
author: A K.

description: I love the whole look and feel of this place. It's so awesome and trendy in a good way. I love the wall with the projections and the neon signs. Even the copy on the menu is hilarious. The food is good, but not mind blowing. Still it's one of my favorite places because I totally connect with the vibe.
author: Dexter H.

description: Wow!! So pleasantly surprised by all the amazing flavors!  The service was also perfect! I think we tried everything on the menu and each item was delicious. Can't wait to come back!
author: Dina T.

description: Best. Dumplings. Ever. Go with a group so you can order a lot and try everything. I loved the pork Xao Long Bao and Beiijing Noodles.
author: J P.

description: Dumpling Time is one of my favorite Dim Sum places in the city. A very trendy restaurant with K-Pop music videos always playing on a large projector. I would recommend the large dumpling!
author: Hanna E.

description: My favorite place for dumplings. This place seams really clean and has good service. The food is fresh and tasty.
author: Serge P.

description:
+ THE FOOD
The food here is actually pretty decent but it's not the best dumplings or baos that I've ever had. After waiting for so long, my friends and I were excited to try their large XLB (the one that's so big you need a straw), but they were sold out!! We started with the shrimp toast, which is like a youtiao topped with a shrimp paste. I'm not sure if it was because we were starving, but we really enjoyed it. It was perfectly savory and the two different textures worked really well together. We also had their garlicky green beans which was very typical Chinese styled green beans, not all that special. Next came our pork bao that we requested to be pan fried. This was just a typical Chinese pork bun with lettuce and other vegetables. It wasn't all that special. We moved onto the two types of XLB- pork XLB and tom yum goong XLB. While both were filled with savory soups, we preferred the pork XLB over the tom yum goong XLB since it had less of a vinegry taste to it. The tom yum XLB wasn't spicy or sour like the soup usually is. Topped with meat and some ginger, the Beijing noodles were also pretty delicious, but it was definitely not enough to share for the 3 of us. We ended with the trio of happy ending buns- matcha and milk, egg yolk, and beet and taro bun. Of the 3 type of buns, the matcha and milk was our favorite, having a familiar custard-y, milky taste to it. 

- THE WAIT
DO NOT go on a weekend unless you know that are first in line. We arrived on a Saturday around 12:30 PM and we waited until 1:58 PM to be seated (it closes at 2:00 PM). Our food took a while to get out since there was still a lot of people waiting for their food.  We were starving and cranky, making us feel that this trip to Dumpling Time wasn't worth it. 

- THE PRICES
The prices here are pretty steep, considering typical Chinese food isn't very expensive. However, this is more of an Americanized Chinese place and every plate is nearly $10 for just a few pieces. Although the food is pretty good, I felt that the wait and the prices weren't all worth it.
author: Cindy C.

description: Great service from peter, good recommendations.  Food came out quick from kitchen everything fresh. Seafood toast mostly about the sauce still worth the order as long as you want comfort food, pork xlb was great, pork belly seared bao was good. Filling wasn't special to me but the bao was done perfect, I'd try another filling.
author: Jason A.

description:
Yes.

Hip vibe with both indoor and substantial outdoor (covered and heated) seating.  Some communal tables inside, but not cramped.

Service was great.  On-point server was attentive, smiley, and gave good suggestions when asked.  We ordered something they didn't have, and brought out 2 alternatives to choose.  Savvy.

Food was fresh.  Szechuan peppercorn is a nice touch for unique edamame.  Crispy spring rolls were a bit uninspired.  Chicken bao was seared nicely.  Shrimp har gow had plump, juicy prawns.  Mom would be proud of pork xi'an dumplings.  Egg yolk bun for dessert looks good and tastes better.

This is nice for a date or taking out-of-towners for a fun Asian experience.

Delicious.
author: T G.

description: Excuse me while I eat 1000 of these xiao long baos because they taste like cloud dumplings with the most incredible soup that bursts into your mouth like broth explosions. So yeah, they're pretty good. In addition to the xlb's we also ordered the BBQ pork buns which were also really really good because the dough was nice and light. We got them pan fried so it had a little crunch and a little lightness. The pork dumplings were pretty with the flowers and colors but were just ok in comparison to the xlb's. The surprise of the night were the pork gyozas which were absolutely amazing. Not too oily, lightly doughed, and lightly fried. The filling was flavorful and melted in the mouth instead of being chewy like a gelatinous mess...the way a lot of gyozas can be after being steamed and fried. The only disappointment was the giant King-Dum that is so beautiful and comes with a straw to sip the amazing soup. But it was difficult to sip, and the dough was tough and chewy and then messy to eat. Great novelty, but not great for eating or for $8. All in all, "souper" delicious. I
author: Tina P.

description: Went to Dumpling Time for lunch on a Tuesday with Carlos. We got there right when they opened at 11am and were seated fairly quickly. (It's a good thing we arrived early because by 11:30am the restaurant was full and there was a bunch of people waiting outside for tables.) The weather was nice so we opted to sit outside on the patio. Our server Maddie was extremely friendly. She suggested we order two to three items each and told us the dishes were best shared family-style. She then made a few recommendations from the menu and took our drink order. I got the the Holy Craft Harajuku Girl draft beer. Harajuku Girl is a rice ale brewed with yuzu, a Japanese citrus fruit. It was very refreshing. Carlos had a glass of chardonnay. For lunch we shared the shrimp toast, pan-seared chicken bao (steamed buns), Tom Yum Goong XLB (soup dumplings), seafood gyoza with chili butter sauce, and shrimp and cream cheese har gow (steamed dumplings) with cilantro dipping sauce. Everything was really delicious. Our favorites were the seafood gyoza, shrimp toast, and the shrimp and cream cheese har gow. For dessert (a.k.a. "Happy Endings") we shared the Trio of Buns (Egg Yolk, Green Tea & Milk, and Beet & Taro). Egg Yolk was my favorite. Overall I really enjoyed my lunch at Dumpling Time. The food was really good and the service was exceptional. I will definitely be back to try some of the other dishes on the menu.
author: Dustin F.

description: Good selection and delicious dumplings. A bit pricey compared to other dumpling places I've been to, but overall it's a good spot and I would go again.
author: g C.

description: So much better than other high profile dim sum places. Their service is top notch & each dish is freshly piping hot. I'm a fan of the seaweed garlic salad, seafood gyoza, shrimp cilantro har gow, beet soup dumplings, & trio of buns. Come w/ friends! :)
author: Caroline L.

description: Try their shrimp dumplings. They are pretty delicious. The service is a but lacking but very friendly none the less.
author: Jacob H.

description:
After reading the reviews, I've decided to write a long review haha. 

I went there on a weekday with my friends and I have to say I will definitely be back for the delicious food! Everything was fresh and handmade that satisfied my picky tongue :p! 
The wait wasn't very bad on a Monday night, definitely plan your visit time so you won't be "hangry" waiting in line :p
We got green beans, Beijing noodles, seafood gyoza, Tom yum goon XLB, shrimp har gao, and vegetarian dumpling, with a Trio of buns for my Happy Ending. Quite a lot of food cuz we wanted to try everything out! Food was absolutely tasty and on point and the seafood gyoza was my favorite! Thought the cream cheese in the har gao would be weird but it was alright. 
Service was attentive considering how busy they were. My waitress was so nice and informative, did a wonderful job checking on us, even with refilling the water :)
The price is on the higher end compare to other Dim Sum places in China town/Irving, but you definitely get what you pay. The place is underrated imo. As a Chinese myself, I know where to get cheap dumpling. However, there're always something in my concern: ingredients, sanitation and worker's right. I'm willing to pay a bit more to ensure I get what I want :pp
author: Ada L.

description: Really great food! Worth getting up early to get there at opening time on weekends. Lines get pretty long if you come later than 12pm :/
author: Jaimie P.

description:
postives:
modern, accessible, good location, parking 

negatives: food. service. 
no service for 10 minutes, no acknowledgement.
82 degrees inside the restaurant, goddamn that's warm.

all the dumplings were crap, except maybe the seafood dumpling which had big shrimp comparatively.

Skin needs major major work, with a chef from China you would expect a lot more, this is pretty terrible.

Xiao Long Bao needed to be cooked 5 minutes less, I will post pictures, you can see the skin is extremely extremely soggy.

Beijing noodle, soft noodle, meat topping not tasty at all.  Very one note, this is not authentic nor tasty.  It needs more skill to make the noodle, and you can't just stir from some bad ground meat and put it on top and call that beijing noodle.
author: J S.

description: This maybe the spot I will consider coming back even though the wait was a little bit ridiculous.   A better buns option compared to Din Tai Fung but differently lack the variety of noodles and side dishes.   But the chicken steam bun is my weakness to bypass all the differences!
author: Anna D.

description: If you've had dumplings at an actual dim sum place before, this place will be a total disappointment. A completely overpriced trap for people who don't have experience with good Chinese food. Portions are tiny for the prices.
author: Alex K.

description: Ooooh, this place is wonderful. I had the shrimp toast (like a yao tiu, Chinese donut, filled with shrimp paste), pork xiaolongbao, and seafood gyoza. The dumpings are so packed full of juiciness and tender meat. And every bao in the dessert trio is great. The wait wasn't too long, and definitely worthwhile. Plus, they have very entertaining K-Pop videos up on one of the walls, for when you've eaten too much delicious food to do anything but just sit and stare with a contented smile on your face. :)
author: Blake A.

description: Was visiting San Francisco for the first time and yelped a place for dinner. Decided to try this place. The food was fantastic. A great gem. Locals should be flocking here. Can't find a place to match down here in LA.
author: Claudine O.

description:
Came here today with my family and ordered a few dishes 
*kingdom dumpling 
*chicken gyoza 
*regular xiao long baos 
*pork dumplings
*trio buns 
*cucumber with chili 
The food was delicious and the customer service was pretty spot on! Definitely try the green tea and milk bun - the filling is super creamy and soft.
author: Mel J.

description:
Very hip dumpling spot with very friendly staff. I hear the line is out the door since they opened, but we lucked out and missed the rush when we got there around noon on a Monday. Everything was delicious and will def come back again! 

These are the items that we tried: 
-garlicky green beans: typical green bean dish from a Chinese restaurant. 
- shrimp gyoza: my fave dish! this comes with a butter chili sauce that is uniquely different than the usual gyoza sauce. But if u don't like it, it also comes with the basic sauce too. 
- shrimp toast: shrimp paste on top of a Chinese donut, fried to the perfect soft and crunchy combo. 
- Beijing noodle: the meat has plenty of flavors so be sure to mix it up well, otherwise the noodles will taste bland. Good with some chili hot sauce if u like the heat. 
- tum yum goong xlb: this dish intrigued me the most but I couldn't really taste the tum yum. Still really good but it'd be better if the broth is more robust with tum yum flavors
- "king-dum": took a while to come out. a large xlb that's as big as your fist, they actually give u a boba straw for the broth, but be careful, The broth is very hot. A bit hard to eat and the broth eventually seeps to the dish below, but overall the flavors are delicious. It's a really cool concept and def worth trying, but I personally prefer the regular sized xlb more 
- Tsing trio: the sweet baos - buns with filling inside. Too much bread for me for a dessert since I was already full,  but if u like sweet buns, be sure to try it!
author: Connie Y.

description: It was good, not a ton of selection. The large soup dumpling was fine, nothing special.
author: Amy L.

description: One of the best dumpling places in SF. We come here regularly and the food is consistently solid.
author: Marisol R.

description: Great food! Great staff! Very busy place, so plan ahead.
author: Chris D.

description:
Was so excited to give this place a shot while my friends and I were visiting from out of town. However, the way things are run around here is ridiculous. Walked in seeing a long line, with no greeting or welcome by a host or any of the workers. We didn't even know where to sign in. Why? Because the sign that says to sign in is taped to the door and the door was propped open so you couldn't see it. Checked in and signed in at 12:10 for a party of 4. 
There was already a ruckus inside due to a homeless woman walking in to the store and taking food. They kicked her out AFTER threatening to call the cops and cursing at her. However, she didn't leave the area and proceeded to the customer waiting area outside to get ready and do her hair. We sat there waiting uncomfortably while she proceeded to yell out, asking for food. Why didn't anyone call to have her removed from the property? I have no clue. 
By 12:45 several groups had already gone in before us, parties of 2's and 3's. We realized then that they were not going according to the list but by table availability. Which was rather frustrating since we already had to wait outside uncomfortably and starving because we were so excited to try their food. When we asked how much longer we had to wait, the host/waitress was extremely rude about it saying she didn't know and that it depended on the number of tables available. She didn't apologize for the long wait or anything. However it didn't seem that hard to just pull up another chair to seat a party of four. By then we decided to just leave and eat elsewhere since their customer service and wait time is complete shit.
author: Stephanie N.

description: Dude... this place is awesome. Listen to the wait staff and you'll be fine. Plus, skip breakfast and go at 11am. You'll thank me. Seriously.
author: Courtney C.

description: I will give Dumpling Time this - they are not your low-down, hispter, hyped-up Chinese food for the American palette. A few of their flavors might be muted, but they are making things here that remind you of home cooking. Get here quick, because wait times aren't immense right now, but there are only so many king-dum's (at $8) per day. Get one; you'll thank me later. It's a giant xiao long bao, and even though the thing is magnified by 5, it still carries the same thin skin and awesome pork filling and hot soup. That also means you have to get the xiao long bao. While you're at it, they're famous for their gyoza, and the pork ones don't disappoint. Ah heck, since you've had that much, start with the crispy, sauteed string beans and shrimp toast. It's exactly the same, if not better than the same dim sum places you grew up eating at. Want just a little bit more? The har gow are fantastic. Their wrapping skin is really what makes it, as it's perfectly translucent, springy, and thin. The same can be said for what's inside. Loads of real, springy shrimp. The price tag at the end is a little high, but it's a great concept, and once they get their liquor license, it's go time.
author: Danny C.

description: I was to Dumpling Time two weeks ago. Not gonna lie this was 'Dank & Authenticate'. I love the large Xiao Long Bao and the noodles, they were hella dank! Also, the total payment was worth it!
author: Ivan Y.

description: Really wanted to love this place but the dumplings weren't as tasty and juicy as other places like shanghai dumpling king etc. Will still come here tho since there are no Chinese places in Potrero!
author: Susan H.

description:
Our first time to restaurant.  Arrived early so got seated right away.  
 
* Servers were very friendly, helpful, and very attentive. "Tom" was very helpful in helping us 
   order
* Seafood Gyoza was so delicious that we re-ordered a second serving - shrimp was fresh! 
* Pan fried Char-Siu Bao was great with a little bit of sweetness from the peanut better
* Pork Xian XLB and Kingdum were very good
* Table next to us had the Bejing Noodles which looked fantastic, and they said it was 
   delicious.  We will definitely try it next time.

Place was crowded but lucky that we got there before it opened to get a seat as we saw some people standing outside for 30-35 minutes waiting to get in and we saw them still waiting when we left!  Will definitely go back again and bring out of towners here.
author: G G.

description:
Not worth a wait . 

Tried 3 times to give them a fair chance bc they're close . We've tried everything on the menu except their shrimp toast .

Mediocre dumplings - pass except a couple people liked their Xi'an dumplings ok. Their xiao long bao aren't bad. They use a lot of filler and not great meat/shrimp, just aren't that tasty. 

Noodles are mostly just grease and noodles  - definite pass .

Pretty good pan fried baos but they might be or miss regarding how panfried they are bc they got near soggy despite the fry our 2nd time round . I don't care bc I like baos :)

Dessert baos are solid - faves are the egg custard . 

Service is really slow. 

Also, when they got low on food, they just sold us subpar food . Eg:  sold us pork dumplings one late night - but we thought we were eating vegetarian dumplings with essence of pork until one of us found a tiny piece pork fat in one of them. 

I'd stop by if you're in the area, no wait, and want baos. Otherwise just stop by the Chinatown Stockton cheap dim sum place or head to sunset / richmond .
author: S C.

description: Overpriced dumpling with nothing special to it. I should just stick to Dragon Beaux where food is cheaper and there are way more options.
author: Jenny N.

description: Amazing take on dim sum. Had chicken dumpling which emphasized the use of mushroom. Delicious hao gaw, with shrimp and a hint of cream cheese which even though sounds questionable was a amazing fusion. Seaweed salad tasted fresh and was a refreshing take on the usual Japanese version. Highlight was the 3 bun dessert which was a beet/taro, egg tart flavor, and green tea. Highly recommend to my friends
author: Michelle T.

description: I loved this place! The dumplings were so fresh, nothing was overly fried or greasy. The presentation of every dish was beautiful, and you wanted to eat every corner of every plate. Service was great and the restaurant ambiance was modern/comfortable.
author: Brittany L.

description: It's always dumpling time at Dumpling Time! The service is great and the dumplings are even better. The seafood gyoza is the way to go!
author: Mimi N.

description: Seriously dabomb.com...and however else you want to describe it. Go here and order just about everything! Peanut butter and pork belly bao buns were outstanding! Veg dumplings were a bit flavorless, but light and refreshing. Cant wait to go back.
author: Kim M.

description: I love, love, love dumplings and this place did not disappoint. The pork XLB and tom yum goong were delicious and the broth was flavorful. Was hoping to get the giant king-dum soup dumpling but they were sold out. I'll definitely come back again earlier in the night to try it. You can watch them folding the dumplings behind a window at check in. There was a long wait between each dish coming to our table but the place was packed and they've only been open for a month so I'm sure that will get better with time.
author: Melissa B.

description: I just came here for lunch and got seated around 2 but keep in mind that they close at 3. I was ready to order right when I got seated and was told that half of the items on the menu was out! How is that possible when it's not even closing time yet and you are open for dinner at 5??!! 10 minutes later the waitress came back and told me that the pork soup dumplings are out too! At this point, I am furious! Why didn't you post that half of your menu is out when there are people still waiting in line to get seated??? This is a joke! I understand that you are a new establishment but out of food? I left the restaurant hungry and pissed!
author: winnie l.

description: Great dumplings! I never thought that you could find dumplings this good outside of China. The food is made with high-quality ingredients. Authenticity is difficult as families, communities and regions all have their own take on this traditional dish. The taste is outstanding - the quality and quantities of the ingredients really come through in flavor.
author: Adrian J.

description: My gf and I came here for the King Dum (big xiao long bao). The line looked long but it didn't take terribly long. Probably 30ish minutes. The way they seat people is super unorganized. The table we were at had 3 different couples seated at it (including ourselves). We were the 2nd pair to arrive. We ordered the King Dum, but later on the waitress told us it sold out. We ordered the regular xlb and the tom yum xlb. The lack of organization came up again when they basically forgot our order. Our waitress disappeared for a bit and we had to ask someone else about the status of our order. That person then went to someone else to ask and then that person finally tracked down our waitress. Who said it would be a few minutes with no reason why there was a delay. Not a good experience overall.
author: Alvin T.

description: Subtle flavors, well considered preparations, attractive plating, and reasonable prices make Dumpling Time a win for me. The service was friendly and knowledgable, especially for the first day open. I recommend the green tea dumplings for desert.
author: Matthew Z.

description:
My friend and I visited here on a Tuesday. We arrived at 6pm. There was availability to sit outside. When we left around 7:30 the wait was over an hour. Plan accordingly.

We got the Tom Yum soup dumplings, pork dumplings, and king pork dumplings. We loved every bite of each dish. 

Prices were fair. Service was wonderful. Couldn't ask for much more!
author: Anne K.

description: I can't say it was great, it was okay.  Maybe I am a dumpling snob, it just wasn't as great as I anticipated it to be. The king dumpling was dry and the skin was too thick.
author: Theresa W.

description:
The restaurant opens foe dinner at 5:30 and does not take reservations so get there early. 

The food is all very fresh and dumplings and noodles are handmade and piping hot when they arrive. We ordered the shrimp toast, seafood gyoza, xi loong pork dumplings, shrimp cilantro har gow, Beijing noodles, cucumber salad and the Trio for dessert.  Our favorites were the noodles, the har gow,  and seafood gyoza. 

Service was great, place is clean and the food came quickly.   Menu is limited but everything we tried were good. We will definitely come back again.
author: Sophie B.

description: Awesome xlb's and Beijing noodles! Their sauces are on-point and make all the food taste more delicious. Crazy long wait times though so I'd suggest getting there right when they open.. apparently they run out of menu items as well. If possible, put your name down and they'll call you when your table's ready. -1 for the mean woman who gave me attitude when I realized I ordered the wrong pork buns and wanted to add another order of Bbq pork buns onto my bill. She told me it would take 45 mins, then came up to me in 10 mins and asked me if I'd received them yet.. well they didn't take 45 mins, they took 20. I don't like liars. +1 for the nice man taking down names of people waiting for tables, and his diligence in keeping with the order in which people put their names down.
author: Holly M.

description:
They seemed to need to go through some more soft openings before opening it up to the public. 

We got there at 7 and put our names down. 2 hours later we were seated (which is fine). It took us about 20 minutes after we were seated to order.  At that time, they told us they were out of the shrimp toast and seafood gyoza. We then ordered a bunch of other things.  Thirty minutes later after we order, the waitress returns to let us know that they are out of 4 of the 5 non dessert things we ordered.  In the end, out of their entire menu, they only had some appetizers, the pork gyoza, noodles, har gow, giant pork buns and dessert left. 

I don't have an issue with being out of dishes since things are home made. My complaint is that they should have been able to predict this earlier and tell us this earlier.  They should have known when they were low on so many dishes. This wasn't just 1 or 2 dishes which is my main issue.  Clear communication here would have made the experience much better.

In any case,  the egg yolk bun and green tea bun are good. The extra large bbq bun is good too (but pretty expensive).  I'd pass on the beijing noodles, shrimp har gow, and shrimp won tons. 

I'd go back still in a few months to try the pan seared bao.
author: Howard C.

description: Love this place and try to visit the place every time I am in the city. This place is always crowded but inspite of having 10 parties ahead of us we got a table in 20 minutes. I was quite impressed with that. The garlic beans and cucumber salad in the appetizers is a must try. Other than that the steamed dumpling and pork dumplings are really good. The food all in all is value for money. I hope they add a few soups to their menu sometime.
author: Salonee R.

description: best dim-sum in the neighborhood. you'll never get tired of this food. really love it.
author: Anne G.

description: Happened upon this place tonight around 5:45. Such good timing  by 615 it was packed! Delicious!  The house veggie dumplings we're great. Best har gow w cilantro! Amazing dipping sauce. Don't skip the soup dumplings.  Soooo good!
author: Sue B.

description: Aesthetically pleasing small bites.  Staff was nice.  Large dumpling was kind of a gimmick, as suggested in other reviews good to try once.  Green tea custard bun was good, would order again.
author: Fanshu B.

description: Also came here to comment on the noodles coming with egg, not tofu. The menu says: GAN BAN NOODLES (Zucchini, carrot, shiitake, tofu, peanut). Please correct the menu or change the dish!
author: Lina L.

description: Pretty darn good dumplings. Good ambiance and kinda crowded. I tried a few things like the seafood gyoza it was all good. 5 stars
author: Dennis F.

description: Everything we had was delicious - xlb full of soup, dumplings were tasty, chicken and pork baos and the dessert trio were so good! Went back again in less than a week :)
author: jane c.

description: Mediocre food.  I am not sure what all the hype is about.  There are so many better dumpling places on Clement Street or in Chinatown.
author: Tanya B.

description: All the food was good but we particularly liked the Beijing Noodles and the Seafood Gyoza. Nice staff, good food, reasonable prices. Just a nice little spot!
author: B W.

description: Not worth the money. The presentation is nice but the dumplings are mediocre and don't taste authentic. Go to I'a Poke across the street instead. Way better
author: Damian M.

description:
A dumpling shop with a modern twist.

Each dumpling packed the right flavors. The bao and dumpling stuffings were great. The bao was delightfully soft but the seered version could be seered a bit more.

However I am not used to paying over a $1.50 per piece on my dumpling or xiao long bao.

This shop was delicious but the price tag leaves me questioning if I would want to return when other dumpling shops offer similar for far less
author: Francisco D.

description:
I'm not exactly impressed by anything. We ordered the following:
pork XLB: the pork was raw when we first got it. the second time around, we got 5 instead of 6, so we had to ask them to send in another order. when we finally got our order, the soup was good, but it was unclear whether the meat I was eating was really pork or just a lot of fat. it was definitely not high quality meat. on top of it, XLB in the foil just kind of ruins the experience for me. If you can make it well, you don't need the foil. 
har gao: the cream cheese is weird. this isn't ravioli and I don't understand why add the cream cheese. 
chicken bao: nothing wrong with it, but it's also just nothing to rave home about.
garlicy green beans: it's a bit dry, nothing more than what you get in any Cantonese cafe.
shrimp toast: my favorite. I could do without the sauce. 
pork xi'an dumpling: this one is very pretty with the micro green, but the taste is just ok.
overall, because this isn't your Cantonese cafe, I expected something better. I don't think they use high quality ingredients and it shows in the food. when you try to be better than the status quo and do creative things, you also have to step up in the ingredients you are using. I've had really great dumplings when I lived in China and I know this kind of food can be much much more than what this restaurant can give me. good concept, but it didn't deliver.
author: Cicie W.

description: It is delicious.  However, can Dumpling Time have live streaming of the line outside on their website???  I doubt it, but had to ask and even request.  The wait is pretty long.
author: Peyton P.

description: Unique dumplings....really love the Tom Yum Shao Long Bao! The only downside is long waits (they won't seat you until your ENTIRE party has arrived) and high prices. Definitely not your Chinese mother's fav joint, but I thoroughly enjoyed the different flavors and freshness of these dumplings! Give it a go!
author: Douglas S.

description: Very solid dumplings, on din tai fung's level. Short, easy menu. Good pricing. Come here 30 minutes before you plan to actually eat, given the wait time. Try to ignore the waiters, who seem to try and rush you out the door. Will be back!
author: Ryan A.

description: So good. The vegetarian dumplings, seafood gyoza, and the egg yolk buns are amazing. If you come at regular dinner hours the wait is pretty bad, but if you come around 8:30-9 then it's significantly faster (at least from my experience).
author: Elena N.

description: These dumplings didn't wow my taste buds like I expected them to. The food was decent, my party ordered the Ha Gaw- shrimp dumplings, and the skin fell apart before getting on my plate. We also tried the Beijing noodles which was very interesting, it tasted like spaghetti and meatballs! Sadly they were out of the giant straw dumpling, so we settled with the pork soup dumplings. They were great, super juicy which was a plus. The pork dumplings (regular not soup) got most of the flavor from the toppings but lacked flavor by itself. My biggest complaint were the chopsticks, the design of them would make my food fall everywhere except my mouth!
author: Houyee C.

description:
Solid dumplings - very expensive compared to the classic dim sum spots in other parts of the city. They're definitely looking for the 'gram with the giant xiao long bao but everything was tasty. 

Pro tip: this was the worst seaweed salad I've ever had. Avoid!
author: Brooke N.

description: So good! Worth the wait... and totally hits the spot! Loved everything...
author: Jennifer C.

description: Very tasty dumplings done correctly.  The soup dumplings, pan fried char shu bao, and seafood dumplings were quality.
author: Marcello G.

description:
So glad we can now get dumplings in SOMA.   The dumplings are great and the price is reasonable.   Got there at 11 and half the tables were already seated.  So it can get pretty crowded during lunch time.  

We ordered the following:
* Chicken Gyoza
* Pork Gyoza
* Pork XLB
* BBQ Pork Bao (pan seared)

My favorites were Pork XLB and BBQ Pork Bao.
Definitely come back!
author: Anonymous S.

description: I live in the neighborhood and I will definitely be coming back! Thanks for exceeding my expectations Dumpling Time!
author: Bryce M.

description: I found Dumpling Time on line as 1 of the top 10 Dim Sum spots in San Francisco & it did NOT disappoint! Absolutely delictable, the shrimp toast and soup dumplings to name a few are to die for.  The service is spot on. Yummy and just an overall great experience. Come to MIAMI. We NEED a great spot like this to come our way!
author: Janine D.

description: Pretty cool new place!!! plenty of parking around the area if you look, but its going to be mostly meter parking if the residential.  Got A LOT of food ordered and it was pretty damn good!!! got this very large XLB and it was pretty interesting because it was something that i've never seen before. definitely will be back tho.  the lines may be kind of line but they do go kind of fast.
author: Ben Z.

description:
Excellent food. The menu is limited, which I think is because of the size of the restaurant.
Ends up being on the pricier side. 
those tom yum dumplings are great
author: Ravi S.

description: I've been here twice, and both times I've been very satisfied but not too stuffed to the point where I feel like I'm going to pass out lol. This place is always crowded, so make sure to write your name down on the list and wait nearby. It's usually a 20-30 minute wait, but they call the names pretty quickly. The staff is friendly and attentive. One of the waiters even noticed I was trying to Shazam the song they were playing and offered to get the name of it for me haha that was a plus. My favorites are the pork xlb and tomyum xlb. For dessert, you can't go wrong with the trio (I think they recently renamed this to the threesom) so you can taste a bit of everything. The kingdom was fun to try at least once (and it makes for a great photo op). Although this place is always packed with people, it's one of the least hectic dimsum spots compared to other places in the city. I'll definitely be back again soon (drools).
author: Mel B.

description: Wicked good dumplings, highly recommend the bao dumplings that have peanut butter in them and the three buns for dessert! Usually pretty crowded even on a weekday so prepare to wait for a little but it moves fast.
author: Becca B.

description: Definitely try the pork bao! They were delicious. The atmosphere is pretty cool also.
author: Maegan P.

description: First place we ate when we got to San Fran and it was a hot.  It is going on or short list of places to revisit.  Shrimp today was awesome and the lobster shumai was excellent.  Look forward to our next trip.
author: Rob P.

description: The shrimp toast is pretty good. This place is good by SF Chinese standards but only ok as far as dumplings go. The Giant XLBs are meant for people who want to take cool Instagram pictures vs people who like XLB or want good dumplings.
author: Francis H.

description: Yessss! Very happy about this new addition to the neighborhood. Super fresh, fast attentive service, relatively cheap. Worth the wait!
author: Solomon S.

description: Har gow (cilantro) is my favorite. Char-siu baos are amazing. Wish there was some more shrimp in the shrimp toast. Our server, Kari, was very sweet. definitely coming back
author: Eing O.

description: Arrived right after opening, so there was no wait. The soup dumplings and pork gyoza were my favorite. Good, fast service!
author: Devon D.

description: Delicious,  good value and quick. We arrived and there was a waiting list of 14 tables ahead of us. We went for a walk around the block and then waited for about 15 mins to be seated. We got our menus, water and asked if we had any questions on the menu within 5 mins of sitting down. Very helpful staff. We got 4 different dumpling dishes to share, all we're great but the pork gyoza were our favourites. So 4 dishes plus 2 beers was $46. Really good value I thought and we had the added bonus of being able to see into the kitchen where we could see then dumplings being prepared. Looking forward to going again and trying the rest of the menu
author: Ger A.

description: The best soup dumplings and the best dumplings in San Francisco! I truly loooove this place! Amazing food but also amazing service! Despite the fact that you may have to wait outside a little bit (because it's so good) the staff members try to make you wait as little as possible by trying to accommodate everyone. The food is truly amazing and very fresh! Their tea selection is great and my experience over there has always been amazing everytime I went!
author: Looblue L.

description: Love this place! The ambiance is fantastic and the food is amazing. Because of the restaurants popularity there may be a wait but it is definitely worth it (have already been here a few times). I can't say enough about the staff. Everyone is extremely friendly and welcoming, their boss should to give them a raise!
author: Kenneth G.

description: One of the most interesting places to visit, if you're a fan of asian cuisine. The freshly cooked dumplings are absolutely astounding, full of flavor, and this place is still moderately cheap for this quality. Don't miss on this one, if you're in San Francisco.
author: Matic S.

description: Omg !! Just eat here food service and booze selection outstanding!! Shit I was in food heaven
author: Miranda H.

description: They don't have their license to sell alcohol so bring your own! The dumplings we ordered were all very good. The only negative was the vegetarian noodles. They had absolutely no flavor. We added soy sauce and scraped the remaining garlic bits from our garlic green beans to add flavor to them. Everything else was really good!
author: Julie H.

description: Some damn good BBQ pork bao, shrimp and cilantro har gow, and tom yum goong xiao long bao
author: John B.

description: This place is so good! I don't understand why the reviews are bad. I've eaten there twice now and had amazing food. Get the Beijing noodles and soup dumplings for sure!! I also liked the cucumber salad. I didn't love the shrimp dumplings but it was still good. People were super nice too.
author: Kristin S.

description: Finally found time to give this new restaurant a try. Love their small bites; we got Cucumber Salad and Garlic Seaweed Salad. Xiao Long Bao (XLB) aka soup dumplings weren't that extraordinary so meh. Shrimp toast was interesting as they put shrimp paste on top of Chinese fried doughnuts. The noodles were sold out so boooo. Also got the crispy/pan seared chicken bao which tasted great (unless you're like some weirdos I know who don't like mushrooms then you should probably skip these ) Fro Happy Endings/dessert, we got the Trio of Buns just so we could try them all. Loved the Beet & Taro Bun the best as it wasn't too sweet like the Green Tea & Milk Bun. I think they are in the preparation of having the outside dock area for outside seatings in the near future. But it's SUPER windy there and they'd have you waiting outside so be sure to dress in layers. There was at least half and hour to an hour wait so be prepared. Parking wasn't a nightmare so that was a plus.
author: Pearl T.

description: Ok - WOW. The line was a little long, but the dumplings were anything but short on flavor. These babies were D to the E to the L I C I O U S. The portions are small, of course, so order at least two dishes. You can watch the people making the magic in the kitchen through a window. And by magic, I mean dumplings of course. This isn't a place for dumpling purists, but it's definitely a good gateway into the Dumpling Dynasty.
author: Jenna J.

description: Very excellent dumplings and the xtra large XLB!  Highly recommend the Beijing noodles as well. Cindy the lead person was extremely helpful.
author: Vincent Kenman Y.

description: This was simply the best dumpling house I have ever been to. Make sure to get the shrimp toast!!  Best dish in the house.
author: Richard E.

description: Amazing dumplings!! Worth the 30 minute wait!!! Reasonable pricing as well. Sat on the patio great time. Will come back when I'm back in town again!!!!
author: Brian M.

description: The place was absolutely amazing! The food was a little expensive but you get QUALITY food so it was very well worth it! Definitely will come back in the future. The staff was very friendly as well!
author: Jia W.

description: Their colorful dishes snagged my attention. I believe I arrived around 11:30 am on a weekday; thirty minutes after they just opened. It started getting busy around 12-12:30. So I highly recommend going around the time they open.
author: Rabiya R.

description: Really nice place and really good food. The service was good and fast. The dumplings were amazing . We tried one from every kind and all of them met expectations. The noodle was okey-ish.
author: Hagop H.

description: I got a chunk of cork board in my chicken bao yesterday. This is disgusting and people would get choked on this... I'm surprised and highly disappointed.
author: Xiaohan W.

description: would put 0 stars. any restaurant that used tin foil to cook their xlb has gone out of business. using metal drastically heats up the temperature too much dries out the soup. the foil sticks to the skin and you rip it off when trying to take out of the foil.  plus metallic taste passes onto the food.  even Martin Yan tried it this way ay MY China, and theyre gone.
author: Wes H.

description: Everything was so good! The green tea milk buns were so delicious. Popular spot so you might be waiting, especially if you want to sit inside. But outside is not bad and they have heaters.
author: Zoe F.

description: Amazing food, amazing atmosphere, and amazing service from Cindy. Will most definitely be back.
author: Bill G.

description: Friendly service ... ( after you wait ) quick and the dumplings are great ... the large Soup dumpling is the only item I would not recommend for $9 its a soggy mess ... the rest of the menu is fresh and good... I think you can put you name on the waiting list via YELP .. avg wait from 11:30-1 is about 20 min .... outside of usual lunch there are usually seats.
author: F J.

description: The line was long, but it was worth it. Great food. Nothing I tried was bad, and most were exceptional. I'll probably show up earlier next time, but sill definitely be back.
author: Seth C.

description: Awesome dumplings. Particularly like the XL dumplings. The service was excellent as well with Pat being very communicative and on top of things.
author: Matthew T.

description: Very good xiao long bao, really enjoyed the Tom yum goong spin on the classic dish. Everything we ordered was very fresh and very good. A little on the pricey side.
author: Jordan C.

description:
We came on a Saturday and the wait wasn't too bad at approximately 20 minutes. We were seated at a communal table. I had this restaurant on my list for awhile as I, like everybody else, wanted the giant soup dumpling that you drink with a straw.  I only ever had this in Shanghai and was happy to see it here. Unfortunately when we ordered, we were curtly told they were sold out of these.  This is simply poor planning/management. It was 1PM on a Saturday, and yes there was crowd, but it wasn't so crowded that it would completely blow your estimation of what was needed for the day.  Especially given the known popularity of the dish. 

We ordered some noodles and a few other dumplings.  Like others noted, the dishes are on the smaller side, particularly the noodles. The dumplings were average - not bad, not good, though one dish was a bit mushy. 

I really wanted to try the King-Dum, but I don't know if I'd return or recommend it to others as I wouldn't want to come back only to be told it's unavailable again especially as the place is a bit out of the way.  I'm glad we only had to wait 20 minutes, I would have been much more annoyed if I waited hours as other reviews stated only to find out the one dish I wanted they didn't have. Honestly, the other dishes weren't stand outs from any other dim sum/ Chinese restaurants. If you want to try it, either go early or skip altogether.  There's not a lot else going on around it.
author: whatever I.

description: Their menu isn't that big so they get to concentrate on making good quality dumplings. The service was very friendly and it was great getting to see the dumplings made in house.
author: Ean H.

description: Solid new add to the Chinese food scene. Noodles were ok but the star of the show is the dumplings. We had the King-dum, the tom yoong XLB and veggie xi'an dumplings. All delicious.
author: Aman H.

description: Having just come back from Shanghai and Xi'an myself, I was excited to try Dumpling Time which just opened a week after I returned. However we arrived 15 minutes before they opened and 8 minutes after they opened we were informed that they ran out of food at 8pm the night before and it may be another hour before they opened. We decided not to wait. I would have removed 1 star due to this reason but when we returned on a Thursday at 2:30pm for a late lunch, there was no wait, service was attentive and the food was absolutely delicious. You will find your dumpling staples with a twist such as: har gow with cream cheese, XLB with beet juice wrappers, seafood gyozas, pan fried bbq pork buns, etc... These are what we have tried and everything was really good. The pan fried buns could be fried crispier and would definitely order the other items again and looking forward to try the other items on the menu. The XLB in my opinion is comparable to Shanghai's.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description: Very poor line management. Told it would be 30 mins ended up being closer to two hours. Food was ok for the price.
author: Alexander D.

description: Such a special place!!! AMAZING food, great service. We had a great experience. Highly recommended for very authentic San Francisco experience.
author: Smadar L.

description: The quality of this place's Har Gow is remarkable. And every single dish is legit. I'm very pleasantly surprised and impressed!
author: Julie I.

description: Not much vegan options. But love this place for the sautéed and gingered snap peas. Tofu was to die for. Never had such an amazing dish!!!
author: Surbhi J.

description: Is our first time at Dumpling Time and the food was great. Definitely will be our new hang our place
author: Bonnie L.

description: One of the best dumplings restaurants in the city.  Good aesthetics, better food!  The Beijing noodles is a must!   The service here is outstanding.  Our server, Cindy, had great entree suggestions and made sure to check on us throughout the entire night.  One of the best dining experiences I have ever had.  Will definitely come back again.  5 stars!
author: Brian K.

description: Everything tasted great! Nice to see a trendy and delicious place in this neighborhood. Be prepared to get there early, as there is usually a wait.
author: Ariadne R.

description:
Prologue: I rarely write reviews for restaurants on Yelp, but this establishment's food was so underwhelming and horrendous that I felt the need to vocalize my opinions and thoughts. I was not paid by another restaurant to write this review, but rather, so upset by the meal that I felt compelled to write this review

Pros
+ Prep is quick, food is served quickly and service is decent overall 
+ Ambiance is also positive, and also very convenient in terms of location being right next to my office

Cons
- Where to begin.. The food is hot trash. Period. This restaurant does not respect authentic Chinese recipes and I'm appalled that they'd even pass this place off as a dumpling house. -
- Cream cheese in a Har Gow? Peanut butter in a Char Siu Bao? Just stop.
- To be even more specific, the Xi'an dumplings tasted like mash potatoes or beans wrapped in a dumpling. Furthermore, it was completely shrouded in radish and tomatoes. WHAT? 
- The XLB was absolutely flavorless. The soup inside had no taste & the skin was stuck to the wrapping and I could not eat it the way I wanted to

Bottom line: You should avoid this restaurant if you have any knowledge of what an actual dumpling should taste like. People rating the food here as "great" or even "good" most likely don't have taste buds or have extremely low standards. I don't expect this place to last longer than 1 year.
author: ryan k.

description:
The best xaio long bao (soup dumplings) in the city. On par with some of the places I've been to in Vancouver.  Excellent, friendly, fast service.  Short menu, very focused on what they specialize in (dumplings & noodles) so it's easy to pick what to order.

If you like Chinese dumplings, you owe it to yourself to go to this place.  One downside: people are figuring this out.  Expect to wait at least 20 minutes to get seated.
author: Glyph L.

description: The selection was great, loved the variety from noodles to shu mai to gyoza to xiao long bao's. The customer service was not great and it took a while to flag down a waiter/waitress to place an additional to-go order.
author: Eileen K.

description: Amazing close to authentic Chinese food. My only complaint was the giant soup dumpling and Beijing noodles run out too often. The coconut soup dumplings in beat skin though are to die for ! Love it all :)
author: Natalia G.

description:
This was our 1st time there.  I was looking forward to a nice tasty lunch.  After we were done dining;  this is what we thought...

The pork over noodle was a bit dry n portion was small for the price. 

Xlb pork dumpling --excellent. 

Seafood gyoza--was good but took 30 mins plus to serve to us!!!   I think the chief forgot to make the gyoza.   We asked the 2 waiter n  1 waitress to check n nobody comeback to give us a status of our order,  they couldn't tell us the truth that they forgot the order!!!  They could of offer not to charge us since we had to waited over 30mins for the order to arrive.
author: Ms R.

description: Second time coming here just for the king dum. Definitely worth the wait. The shrimp toast, seafood gyoza and pork bao are to die for!!
author: Livia C.

description: Really, really, really great dumplings.  The atmosphere leaves something to be desired... as do the little foil cups the XLB are steamed in. The dumplings stick too hard to the cups and rip so easily! Other than that... superb. Love love love this place.
author: Lucy B.

description:
The dumplings are freshly made. That carries so much weight in this arena as the majority of non traditional Chinese restaurants will not serve fresh dumplings. 

Most of the dumplings were really good. My favorite had to be the shrimp Gayoza. The pork soup dumplings were ok. Goodish. I would order them again but the shrimp dumplings were awesome.

And all for something like 25 bucks a head. By SF standards, that's a huge bargain.
author: Ajit K.

description: New place on the corner of division and king st. Tried shrimp sauted toasted and seafood gyoza. Its yummy. Definately coming back.... loved the environement too. Inside sitting and patio.
author: Karma S.

description: Great service and food. It's busy but worth the wait. The dumplings are unique and the plating is colorful.
author: Ken N.

description: Amazing food with a unique authentic flavor. Great service! Would definitely recommend as a go-to restaurant!
author: Kristy A.

description:
Dumpling time is mediocre at best. What an anti climax- we had high hopes after spending 30 mins in the queue waiting for a table. Maybe if you have ever eaten dumplings before you would have been impressed but anyone was has eaten some great dumplings before will not be coming back. 

The dumplings were fresh, you can see them making them but completely lacked flavour. Bao buns were just ok- bread was tasty but filling was dry and pretty bland. You can always tell a good dumpling place by the sauce and the chilli sauce was not spicy and only came with soy sauce, no dumpling sauce. The xian pork dumplings were tasty they were the silver lining. 

Service was also unimpressive.

We won't be back and I wouldn't go out of your way to make it here.
author: Allie S.

description: I came in looking for some dumplings as I had visiting from back home.  We both stumbled upon this place and couldn't have been more pleased with it. The staff was very friendly and gave us suggestions on favorites and the food couldn't have been better.  Will definitely come back again.
author: Kim N.

description: Worth going a little out of your way! Get there right at opening like we did- it was completely full when we left with long waiting line. We tried a little bit of everything, and the Xiao Long Bao Tom Yum Goong really blew me away. Best little bit I've had in a long time. Service is friendly and prompt, but gets slow as the restaurant fills up so go early! And make sure your whole party is together before you try to sit
author: Betsy T.

description: Great place for dim sum.  Everything is fresh and priced very reasonably and the menu changes pretty often but you are able to order your favorites if not listed.  Great place and close to home.
author: Eric B.

description: We happened upon this place by accident and are thoroughly happy with our decision.  Walked right in and ate a delicious meal for two- under $40 with tip.  They don't have their liquor license yet but it's in the works. A nice cold beer will round out the perfect meal.
author: Caitlin E.

description: The shrimp toast is one of the best things I've ever eaten. Soup dumplings were great too, but I wasn't a fan of the fried or vegetarian dumplings.
author: Yoav G.

description:
Dumplin skins are overcooked, by a great deal.
Nice environment. Overpriced for what it offers.
author: Jaamaal r.

description:
im teetering between a 3-4 review on this one because the goods were great and the XLB was a fail.

1. didnt have alcohol yet though the website says coming in june- its june; but you can BYOB until they get their license

2. the good things: shrimp toast is AMAZING along with the shrimp & cilantro har gow. the cilantro sauce that comes with it is so tasty

3. the average: chicken bao and pork bao, we had them both pan fried, i prefered the pork over the chicken

4. the needs work. Xiao Long Bao is probably my favorite food. these didnt make the cut. we had both the king-dum and the pork xlb. the small ones are served in those little tins, which i really dont like. they all fell apart in the tin and you loose the soup-y goodness. the king-dum was awkward. also be careful when using the straw cause you can also get meat in there which is a little bit of a choking hazard. DTF is still #1 when it comes to XLB.

I hope they improve on their XLB and I would consider returning.
author: Kam L.

description:
We came by after seeing articles and pictures for this new spot.  It was pretty busy but the wait was not too bad.  The food itself is nothing to write home about, tastes very un-authentic.  I guess when its 95% white people @ an ethnic food restaurant, you can't expect very good quality.

The ambiance and feel of the restaurant is great, but I wouldn't come back for the food.
author: David M.

description: Great food and pleasant dining experience. Be advised, the word is out that this is a good place so the no-reservation policy can result in some long lines/wait time. There are a few places nearby like Saap Ver across the street and Skool, Starbucks and the Grove a block or so away to grab coffee or a drink and pass the time. It is worth the wait.
author: Brad M.

description: A victim of their own initial overwhelming success, we got to Dumpling Time at the tail end of lunch and they ran out of a third of the menu.   We were looking forward to the XLB and shrimp toast but they had already sold out.  However, we were pleased with what was available.  The seaweed salad and pickled lotus were delightful starters. The seafood gyoza with spinach skin was so plumb and tasty, we had to go for two more rounds. The vegetarian xian dumpling came pleasantly surprised with pickled vegetables.  The green tea and milk dessert bun was enjoyable.  The friendly general manager spearheaded the wait staff who did their best to serve the crowd with smiles.  On the way out, we talked to Jackson, one of the partners who was both appreciative that we came in but apologetic about menu item shortages.  He vows to improve the process to increase the volume of menu items.
author: Hugh Y.

description: so good and so fast! best dumplings in sf, hands down. we tried the chicken gyoza, the pork dumplings and the giant soup one.
author: Cherie V.

description: They wouldn't seat my group of 4, but sat other countless groups that came before me and my group. Which extremely pissed us off. She even said, they have to keep going on the list even if we don't get seats, which was bullshit because who is gonna spend more? A group of 2 or a group of 4? It's obvious. This review is based on customer service not their food
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I am not a food snob at all.  There are all kinds of good dumpling & dim sum restaurants out here on the west side of San Francisco.  Dumpling Time is something special and different.  

Took a friend to Dumpling Time this week to celebrate her recent graduation and the experience made both of us smile a lot and just feel very happy.

The food was delicious and plated beautifully and you could see and taste the level of care and attention to detail that went into each dish.  The wait staff was just so nice and friendly and responsive to questions and requests.  The food isn't cheap but thoroughly reasonable for the quality.  

Get the dessert trio!  It was a perfect finish to a great meal.  We were both smiling & almost giggling with each bite.  The custard one was just fantastic.
author: Jim H.

description: I personally love this place, but my Taiwanese friends thumb their nose at it ... I believe they referred to it as the PF Chang of dumplings. For anyone not looking for a fully authentic dumpling spot though, this place really hits the spot. Love it.
author: Neil X.

description:
Booze on the menu, but the liquor license is not yet in place... #bigfail

Get it together and then print it on your paper menus- seriously.
author: Dave D.

description: Went there once with coworkers. Took 2 tries to get seat. Dumpling taste good and I especially like the Tom Yum dumplings. Price is trying to be in MY.CHINA or Yank Sink range. Tried another time with friends on Saturdays and both times restaurant is closed for private events. Verdict: Overrated.
author: Richard W.

description: Good environment and amazing dumplings, The staff were all very friendly
author: Alex L.

description: These are some of the best dumplings I've had in my 40 years living in the city sampling Dim Sum.   Worth the wait.   I've been back 3 times, and each item I had was terrific.
author: charley N.

description: This place was bomb! Not traditional dim sum but a unique spin executed perfectly with quality ingredients and great prices. Get the Shrimp Har gow, seafood gyoza, and BBQ pork buns. Skip the Tom yum soup dumplings.
author: Jay H.

description: Awesome dumpling place! Love the veggie dumpling and the veggie nooodle! Oh don't get me started on the awesome threesome dessert baos ..oh so delicious!! I am craving for these baos as  I am writing this review!! Definitely recommend this place!
author: ST T.

description:
I was skeptical at first when I heard about the new dumpling restaurant opening up around my neighborhood, but I was not disappointed. Service was superb, very attentive to all my needs!! Also food was phenomenal! And what's even better was parking. Better than going all the way to Richmond or sunset and spend 30 mins looking for parking! 

XLB: packed with flavor and the skins also not too thick. It was just right. Their homemade sauces was very flavorful! I liked the middle one I forgot but it paired well with all the dumplings. 

HAR GOW: was very good! Shrimp was sweet and crunchy! 

MATCHA MILK BUN: perfect amount of sweetness! The matcha bun and the milky oozy milk custard. 

I would def. come back and try everything else. Might have just found my new spot. Thank you dumpling time!
author: Anna H.

description: This was an excellent find in the city.  We almost passed it by but decided to give it a try.  The smoked salmon eggs Benedict was delicious.  The pumpkin spice latte was most excellent.
author: Chuck K.

description:
I've had some shitty dining experiences before but this was by far the worst.  The hostess ripped the sign in sheet away from us just as we were reaching for the pen to sign in. She proceeded to ignore us completely while she walked outside to call out tables. We followed her outside and after she was done calling out tables we asked her to add our names to the list.  She responded by dashing back inside while saying that the sign in sheet and pen are over here, back at the original spot.  3 separate parties took this opportunity to jump ahead of us in line and sign in before us.  Just a ridiculously rude and unorganized way to handle your first interaction with customers. Once we were finally seated, it took a rather long time to be approached by a waitress.  We ordered a good amount of food, which then came out in a completely random order (appetizer, my main, her dumplings, her main, my dumplings, 2nd appetizer). This made a small table completely crowded. On top of that, we had to send back the veggie noodles because they had egg in it (vegan), even though the ingredients listed on the menu didn't mention egg, but did mention tofu, of which there was none.  They didn't apologize or offer any solution to that, so only one of us had a complete meal.

This dining experience left a bad taste in our mouths during our last night in San Francisco.
author: Mark T.

description: Hip, casual and lively dumpling spot. We ordered one item from every section and were not disappointed. The food comes out quickly and is piping hot. Even though its a dumpling place, the noodles were top notch. Good for big groups, and has communal seating and had parking which is a plus. My GF and I left for under $60 which is excellent for SF and the amount of food we ordered.
author: Aaron C.

description: Excellent dumplings, efficient and fast service.  Long lines.
author: L J.
